https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/trump-biden-protests-polling.html/How Trump and the Black Lives Matter Movement Changed White Voters’ Minds/"A majority of American voters support the demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice that have roiled the country over the past month
column2: embracing ideas about bias within the criminal justice system and the persistence of systemic racism that are central tenets of the Black Lives Matter movement
column3: according to a new national poll of registered voters by The New York Times and Siena College.

column1: Fifty-nine percent of voters
column2: including 52 percent of white voters
column3: believe the death of George Floyd at the hands of the police in Minneapolis was “part of a broader pattern of excessive police violence toward African Americans
column4: ” the poll found. The Black Lives Matter movement and the police had similar favorability ratings
column5: with 44 percent of registered voters viewing the movement as “very favorable
column6: ” almost identical to the 43 percent rating for the police.

column1: The numbers add to the mounting evidence that recent protests have significantly shifted public opinion on race
column2: creating potential political allies for a movement that was
column3: within the past decade
column4: dismissed as fringe and divisive. It also highlights how President Trump is increasingly out of touch with a country he is seeking to lead for a second term: While he has shown little sympathy for the protesters and their fight for racial justice
column5: and has continued to use racist language that many have denounced
column6: voters feel favorably toward the protests and their cause.

column1: A survey of battleground states critical to November’s election largely mirrored the national results. Fifty-four percent of voters in those states said the way the criminal justice system treats black Americans was a bigger problem than the incidents of rioting seen during some demonstrations. Just 37 percent said rioting was a bigger problem
column2: though Mr. Trump and his allies have tried to discredit the protests by focusing on some isolated incidents of violence."/['Astead W. Herndon'
column3: 'Dionne Searcey']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/politics/27UNREST-POLL1/27UNREST-POLL1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/us/politics/trump-coronavirus.html/New Numbers Showing Coronavirus Spread Intrude on a White House in Denial/"The return of the televised task force news conference — at which reporters were limited to only a handful of questions — revived the deep disconnect between Washington and the states where local officials spent Friday sounding the alarm and
column2: in some cases
column3: halting the reopening that Mr. Trump has so often encouraged.

column1: In Florida
column2: Gov. Ron DeSantis
column3: a Republican who has resisted rolling back the economic reopening
column4: banned drinking in bars after saying that patrons were not abiding by social distancing rules. In Texas
column5: Gov. Greg Abbott
column6: also a Republican
column7: went further
column8: ordering all bars closed in the state. And Judge Lina Hidalgo of Harris County
column11: calling the rise in cases there “a catastrophic and unsustainable situation.”

column1: Taken together
column2: it was grim news about a pandemic that is still a threat to the public’s health
column3: the nation’s economy and the president’s political future.

column1: At a time when his poll numbers now call into question whether he can win a second term in November
column2: Mr. Trump faces the prospect that his efforts to boost the economy by shrugging off the virus have backfired. Rather than head into the summer with a country on the mend
column3: the president will be forced to explain how his response to the coronavirus contributed to a resurgence of it that may force some Americans back into a painful shutdown.

column1: And yet Mr. Trump made no appearance at the task force briefing to demonstrate concern. Instead
column2: an hour after it was over
column3: the president addressed a panel of industry officials
column4: political allies and White House economic advisers for a self-congratulatory session about how successful the economic recovery has been.

column1: In taking his victory lap
column2: Mr. Trump made no mention of the increase in cases around the country
column3: underscoring a message that he posted on Twitter late Thursday night: “Our Economy is roaring back and will NOT be shut down. ‘Embers’ or flare ups will be put out
column4: as necessary!”"/['Michael D. Shear'
column5: 'Maggie Haberman']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/us/politics/26dc-virus-trump1/26dc-virus-trump1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/coronavirus-trump-mood-poll.html/How Americans Feel About the Country Right Now: Anxious. Hopeful./"Despite double digit unemployment
column2: majorities across demographic groups say the federal government’s priority should be to contain the spread of the virus
column3: even if it hurts the economy. Younger voters and black voters take the most stringent view of the social distancing rules
column4: with more than four in 10 saying the guidance is being lifted too quickly. Only backers of Mr. Trump overwhelmingly believe government should prioritize the economy.

column1: More than three-quarters of registered voters say they always or mostly wear a mask in public when they expect to be within six feet of another person
column2: including 60 percent who support Mr. Trump and 79 percent of those under 30.

column1: Men are more likely to go barefaced. Only 46 percent of men say they always wear a mask
column2: compared with 61 percent of women. The findings confirm academic research suggesting that men are more likely to opt out of wearing masks
column3: believing them to be “not cool” or “a sign of weakness
column4: ” even though men are at a higher risk of dying from Covid-19 than women.

column1: In the most heavily impacted states
column2: voters feel even more strongly about taking measures to stop the spread of the virus. A higher percentage of voters in Arizona and Florida
column3: where infections are spiking
column4: say restrictions don’t go far enough and that businesses are reopening too quickly.

column1: Scott Bertoglio
column3: of suburban Phoenix
column4: said he is considering not sending his three young children back to school in the fall because he was worried that the state government has failed to adequately implement rules protecting their health
column5: like mandating mask wearing.

column1: “We’ve essentially been holed up at home
column2: ” he said
column3: taking a break from watching a PowerPoint presentation in his home office. “But Arizona is not taking it seriously and the schools are saying we’re going to open.”

column1: Still
column2: the poll shows that voters overwhelmingly believe that any economic pain stemming from the virus will be temporary. Even among those living in a household with coronavirus-related job losses
column3: 81 percent say they expect to find work within the next few months or have already regained it."/['Lisa Lerer'
column4: 'Elaina Plott'
column5: 'Lazaro Gamio']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/us/politics/26mood-poll1/26mood-poll1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/black-trans-lives-matter.html/Black Trans Women Seek More Space in the Movement They Helped Start/"For decades
column2: the idea that “we were all minorities was enough for people to just say
column3: ‘OK
column4: that’s what we have in common
column5: so if I win
column6: that means you automatically are winning
column7: too
column8: ’” said Peppermint
column9: a black trans activist who co-hosted the Black Queer Town Hall
column10: a three-night series of virtual performances and discussions this month. “I think that the notion of intersectionality is becoming more readily available for people to understand that a win for one group or one identity doesn’t necessarily equal an automatic win for the other.”

column1: While L.G.B.T.Q. people have secured many legal rights and protections
column2: black transgender women are still killed so often that the American Medical Association has declared it an epidemic. Last year
column3: 91 percent of the transgender or gender-nonconforming people who were fatally shot were black women
column4: according to the Human Rights Campaign. This year
column5: at least 16 trans people have been killed — almost certainly an underestimate
column6: because many cases go unreported and many victims are misgendered.

column1: “So much money and resources and energy has been put into legislative fights or judicial fights
column2: which is important — those wins are important
column3: ” the activist Raquel Willis said. “But as a black trans woman
column4: I often have to grapple with the question of
column5: what do any of these protections mean if I am dead
column6: if I am still at risk of literally being killed?”

column1: Violence against transgender people increased after President Trump was inaugurated
column2: advocacy groups found in 2017
column3: and Mr. Trump has singled out trans people in his policies since the beginning of his presidency.

column1: His administration reversed Obama-era protections for transgender students
column2: reimposed a ban on trans people serving in the military and
column3: just this month
column4: erased rules protecting them from discrimination in health care. It also sought to define gender as an immutable trait assigned at birth — an effort that would
column5: essentially
column6: define trans people out of legal existence."/['Isabella Grullón Paz'
column7: 'Maggie Astor']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/us/politics/28trans-politics-p1/00trans-politics00-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/nyregion/princeton-university-woodrow-wilson.html/Princeton Will Remove Woodrow Wilson’s Name From School/"Princeton University will remove Woodrow Wilson’s name from its public policy school and one of its residential colleges
column2: the university’s president said on Saturday — a move that comes four years after it decided to keep the name over the objections of student protests.

column1: The university’s board of trustees found that Wilson’s “racist thinking and policies make him an inappropriate namesake for a school or college whose scholars
column2: students and alumni must stand firmly against racism in all its forms
column3: ” Princeton’s president
column4: Christopher L. Eisgruber
column5: said in a statement.

column1: “Wilson’s racism was significant and consequential even by the standards of his own time
column2: ” Mr. Eisgruber said. Wilson was the university’s president from 1902 to 1910 before becoming the U.S. president in 1913.

column1: Wilson had overseen the resegregation of federal government offices
column2: including the Treasury Department. In a meeting in the Oval Office with the civil rights leader Monroe Trotter
column3: Wilson said
column4: “Segregation is not humiliating
column5: but a benefit
column6: and ought to be so regarded by you gentlemen
column7: ” according to a transcript of the meeting."/['Bryan Pietsch']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/multimedia/27xp-unrest-princeton-wilson-pix1/27xp-unrest-princeton-wilson-pix1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/coronavirus-drug-pricing-legislation.html/As the Coronavirus Spreads
column2: Drug Pricing Legislation Remains Stalled/"Prescription medicine use has only intensified during the coronavirus crisis: Express Scripts
column3: a prescription benefit manager with over 100 million customers
column4: saw spikes in March for three-month refills and new prescriptions for conditions associated with higher coronavirus risk.

column1: “The problem has expanded
column2: ” said Representative Kim Schrier
column3: Democrat of Washington and a pediatrician.

column1: Because of border restrictions amid the pandemic
column2: Ms. Schrier said
column3: some in her state can no longer drive to Canada to purchase insulin at a fraction of what it costs in the United States. “There’s this fear that we’re going to run out of medications
column4: so people are trying to get more in hand
column5: ” she said.

column1: Mr. Mitchell said that his group had observed significant price increases on drugs needed for coronavirus patients
column2: including anticoagulants for blood clots.

column1: “There’s more of a sense of urgency
column2: ” said Representative Frank Pallone Jr.
column3: Democrat of New Jersey and the main sponsor of the House bill
column4: called H.R. 3
column5: which was given a low number to reflect its top ranking among Democratic priorities. “So many people have lost their jobs. So many people have lost income. They’re more conscious than ever of the price of health care.”

column1: Mr. Grassley’s bill would cap the growth of drug prices in Medicare at inflation level
column2: and impose a $3
column3: 100 limit on out-of-pocket costs for tens of millions of seniors and Americans with disabilities enrolled in its drug coverage program. The plan would provide nearly $100 billion in savings
column4: according to the Congressional Budget Office.

column1: The House bill goes further in seeking to control the growth of drug costs
column2: calling for the secretary of health and human services to negotiate prices with manufacturers
column3: a provision that is projected to save more than $500 billion over a decade
column4: according to the C.B.O. The House will vote on that provision again as part of a bill it plans to bring to the floor next week to bolster the Affordable Care Act."/['Noah Weiland']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/us/politics/00dc-prescriptiondrugs1/00dc-prescriptiondrugs1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/technology/pizzagate-justin-bieber-qanon-tiktok.html/‘PizzaGate’ Conspiracy Theory Thrives Anew in the TikTok Era/"WASHINGTON — Four minutes into a video that was posted on Instagram last month
column2: Justin Bieber leaned into the camera and adjusted the front of his black knit beanie. For some of his 130 million followers
column3: it was a signal.

column1: In the video
column2: someone had posted a comment asking Mr. Bieber to touch his hat if he had been a victim of a child-trafficking ring known as PizzaGate. Thousands of comments were flooding in
column3: and there was no evidence that Mr. Bieber had seen that message. But the pop star’s innocuous gesture set off a flurry of online activity
column4: which highlighted the resurgence of one of social media’s early conspiracy theories.

column1: Viewers quickly uploaded hundreds of videos online analyzing Mr. Bieber’s action. The videos were translated into Spanish
column2: Portuguese and other languages
column3: amassing millions of views. Fans then left thousands of comments on Mr. Bieber’s social media posts asking him if he was safe. Within days
column4: searches for “Justin and PizzaGate” soared on Google
column5: and the hashtag #savebieber started trending.

column1: Four years ago
column2: ahead of the 2016 presidential election
column3: the baseless notion that Hillary Clinton and Democratic elites were running a child sex-trafficking ring out of a Washington pizzeria spread across the internet
column4: illustrating how a crackpot idea with no truth to it could blossom on social media — and how dangerous it could be. In December 2016
column5: a vigilante gunman showed up at the restaurant with an assault rifle and opened fire into a closet."/['Cecilia Kang'
column6: 'Sheera Frenkel']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/business/28pizzagate-print10/28pizzagate-print10-facebookJumbo-v3.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/a-reckoning-with-race-to-ensure-diversity-for-americas-face-abroad.html/A Reckoning With Race to Ensure Diversity for America’s Face Abroad/"WASHINGTON — Tianna Spears dreamed for years of becoming an American diplomat. She quit in January after two
column2: and says she will never return to the State Department
column3: given what she has described as its failure to protect her from racial discrimination — from the United States government — while on the job.

column1: Ms. Spears is black. Her first foreign post
column3: was at the American Consulate in Ciudad Juárez
column4: just over the Mexican border from El Paso. Over six months
column5: she said
column6: U.S. border officials pulled her aside about 25 times for extensive questioning and inspections.

column1: She was asked if she was a drug dealer. At one point
column2: she said
column3: she was told to not look a male officer in the eye. The Customs and Border Protection officers questioned whether her diplomatic passport was counterfeit. At times she felt threatened. And her white colleagues
column4: Ms. Spears said
column5: appeared to cross the border easily and without delay.

column1: When she reported the episodes to her supervisors at the consulate
column2: Ms. Spears said she was advised against speaking out and was transferred to the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City."/['Lara Jakes']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/us/politics/28dc-unrest-state-race-print1/00dc-unrest-state1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/biden-guantanamo-prison.html/Biden Still Wants to Close Guantánamo Prison/"This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
President Barack Obama vowed to close it
column2: and failed. President Trump vowed to load it up with more “bad dudes
column3: ” and has not. Now Joseph R. Biden Jr. is saying that if elected president
column4: he would support shutting down the military prison at Guantánamo Bay
column5: Cuba — but has declined to specify how he would do it or what he would do with the 40 men held there as wartime prisoners
column6: including the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11
column8: attacks.

column1: In response to a question
column2: his campaign said in a statement that Mr. Biden “continues to support closing the detention center.” Echoing Mr. Obama
column3: the statement said the prison “undermines American national security by fueling terrorist recruitment and is at odds with our values as a country.”

column1: But Mr. Biden rarely
column2: if ever
column3: brings up the topic
column4: evidence of how politically toxic it remains after intense Republican efforts to cast Mr. Obama’s initiative as endangering Americans by transferring terrorists to U.S. soil or sending them without adequate safeguards to other countries.

column1: When asked about Guantánamo Bay in a primary debate in December
column2: Mr. Biden
column3: who was Mr. Obama’s vice president
column4: blamed Congress for thwarting closure
column5: but rather than suggest a path forward
column6: he pivoted to another issue."/['Carol Rosenberg']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/politics/27dc-gitmo/27dc-gitmo-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/us/politics/trump-monuments-executive-order.html/Trump Issues Executive Order Targeting Vandalism Against Monuments/"WASHINGTON — President Trump issued an executive order on Friday that instructed federal law enforcement authorities to prosecute people who damage federal monuments or statues and that threatened to withhold funding from local governments that fail to protect their own statues from vandals.
The order
column2: which Mr. Trump announced on Twitter
column3: comes as he seeks to seize on a cultural divide in the United States during his re-election campaign
column4: suggesting that Democrats are waging an assault on the nation’s history.

column1: “Anarchists and left-wing extremists have sought to advance a fringe ideology that paints the United States of America as fundamentally unjust
column2: ” Mr. Trump writes in the order
column3: which is titled
column4: “Protecting American Monuments
column5: Memorials and Statues and Combating Recent Criminal Violence.”

column1: The order adds: “Key targets in the violent extremists’ campaign against our country are public monuments
column2: memorials and statues.”"/['Michael D. Shear']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/us/politics/26dc-trump/merlin_173824434_c1acd490-2a10-4b1a-94cf-2b5fe7d372b7-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/video/us/politics/100000007212962/california-governor-coronavirus-counties.html/Newsom’s Call to Californians: ‘Wear These Masks’/We’ve been monitoring all 58 counties in the state of California for community spread. We’ve been looking at the positivity rates. We’ve been looking at I.C.U. volume. We’ve been looking at total number of hospitalizations
column2: not just deaths
column3: the most lagging of indicators as it relates to this pandemic. We’ve been doing so recognizing
column4: and I can’t again say this enough
column5: that California is the size of 21 states combined. The size and scope and scale of California require a disciplined understanding that there are parts of this state that are very distinct and unique from other parts of this state. So 15 counties
column6: overall
column7: that we’re monitoring very
column8: very closely
column10: that we have oversight and continue to monitor numbers — 4
column11: 890 positive tests
column12: a little bit better than yesterday
column13: a little bit better than that record number north of 7
column14: 000 a few days ago. But these trend lines of the last seven days
column16: are disturbing. And that’s why I cannot impress upon people more to wear these masks when they cannot practice physical distancing
column17: to continue to be vigilant about the spread of this virus./['The Associated Press']//"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/world/26virus-briefing-ca2/merlin_173940696_4696f283-f454-4c46-a934-93dbd9fe7be9-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/podcasts/the-daily/Gregg-Breinberg-PS22-chorus-education-virus.html/A Bit of Relief: The Long Distance Chorus/"Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:
Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher

Gregg Breinberg has been directing the chorus at Public School 22 on Staten Island for 20 years. He tells his fourth and fifth grade students that participation is not about whether they can sing on key or not. It’s about expressing the meaning of a song — and the music inside themselves. Today
column2: we listen to the voices of P.S. 22 as they harmonize through the pandemic."/[]/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/podcasts/26daily-newsletter-2/26daily-newsletter-2-facebookJumbo-v2.png"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/25/opinion/the-argument-biden-vice-president-supreme-court.html/Opinion | Place Your Bets on Biden’s V.P./"Background Reading:
Meet the Hosts
Frank Bruni
Image
I’ve been an Op-Ed columnist for The Times since 2011
column2: but my career with the newspaper stretches back to 1995 and includes many twists and turns that reflect my embarrassingly scattered interests. I covered Congress
column3: the White House and several political campaigns; I also spent five years in the role of chief restaurant critic. As the Rome bureau chief
column4: I reported on the Vatican; as a staff writer for The Times’s Sunday magazine
column5: I wrote many celebrity profiles. That jumble has informed my various books
column6: which focus on the Roman Catholic Church
column7: George W. Bush
column8: my strange eating life
column9: the college admissions process and meatloaf. Politically
column10: I’m grief-stricken over the way President Trump has governed and I’m left of center
column11: but I don’t think that the center is a bad place or “compromise” a dirty word. I’m Italian-American
column12: I’m gay and I write a weekly Times newsletter in which you’ll occasionally encounter my dog
column13: Regan
column14: who has the run of our Manhattan apartment.

column1: Ross Douthat
Image
I’ve been an Op-Ed columnist since 2009
column2: and I write about politics
column3: religion
column4: pop culture
column5: sociology and the places where they all intersect. I’m a Catholic and a conservative
column6: in that order
column7: which means that I’m against abortion and critical of the sexual revolution
column8: but I tend to agree with liberals that the Republican Party is too friendly to the rich. I was against Donald Trump in 2016 for reasons specific to Donald Trump
column9: but in general I think the populist movements in Europe and America have legitimate grievances and I often prefer the populists to the “reasonable” elites. I’ve written books about Harvard
column11: American Christianity and Pope Francis
column12: and decadence. Benedict XVI was my favorite pope. I review movies for National Review and have strong opinions about many prestige television shows. I have four small children
column13: three girls and a boy
column14: and I live in New Haven with my wife."/[]/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/25argument-eightyfour1/25argument-eightyfour1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/after-asking-americans-to-sacrifice-in-shutdown-leaders-failed-to-control-virus.html/After Asking Americans to Sacrifice in Shutdown
column2: Leaders Failed to Control Virus/"WASHINGTON — More than four months into fighting the coronavirus in the United States
column3: the shared sacrifice of millions of Americans suspending their lives — with jobs lost
column4: businesses shuttered
column5: daily routines upended — has not been enough to beat back a virus whose staying power around the world is only still being grasped.

column1: The number of new U.S. cases this last week surged dangerously high
column2: to levels not ever seen in the course of the pandemic
column3: especially in states that had rushed to reopen their economies. The result has been a realization for many Americans that however much they have yearned for a return to normalcy
column4: their leaders have failed to control the coronavirus pandemic. And there is little clarity on what comes next.

column1: “There has to be a clear coherent sustained communication
column2: and that has absolutely not happened
column3: ” said Dr. William Schaffner
column4: an infectious diseases specialist at Vanderbilt University in Nashville. “We’ve had just the opposite and now it’s hard to unring a whole series of bells.”

column1: There was “real hubris” on the part of public health officials at the very start
column2: Dr. Schaffner said
column3: that the United States could lock down and contain the virus as China had. That futile hope helped create an unrealistic expectation that the shutdown
column4: while intense
column5: would not be for long
column6: and that when it was lifted life would return to normal."/['Sabrina Tavernise'
column7: 'Frances Robles'
column8: 'Louis Keene']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/27virus-sacrifie-1/27virus-sacrifie-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/world/coronavirus-updates.html/Coronavirus Live Updates: Surge Threatens to Overwhelm Mississippi
column2: Houston/"Nationwide
column3: cases have risen 65 percent over the past two weeks. On Friday
column4: the country reported more than 45
column5: 000 new infections
column6: its third consecutive day of record new cases
column7: and a number of states have also been seeing record new levels. On Saturday
column8: Florida
column9: Nevada and South Carolina reported their highest one-day case totals. Before this week
column10: the country’s largest daily total had been 36
column11: 738 on April 24.

column1: Many business owners and workers who lost their jobs say they believe their leaders failed to prepare for the economic devastation that followed shutdowns that states had adopted
column2: to differing degrees
column3: since March. And they say that recent reopenings undercut their sacrifices.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: some conservatives said they had an additional concern: After weeks of being told that going to church
column3: attending funerals and participating in protests was a willful
column4: careless spurning of science
column5: political leaders and some public health officials condoned — and even joined — the crowds protesting the killing of George Floyd.

column1: “It’s just a real social whiplash
column2: ” said Philip Campbell
column3: vice president of a pest control company in Central Michigan
column4: who took part in the first protests against the lockdown in Lansing in April from the cab of his truck. “Two weeks ago you can’t go out because you are going to kill grandma. Now it’s ‘you have an obligation to go out.’ It leaves me feeling that the science and the public health authorities have been politicized.”

column1: A number of states are reconsidering their reopening plans. Florida and Texas reimposed limits on bars
column2: banning drinking inside or closing the premises entirely
column3: as they scrambled to control what appeared to be a brewing public health catastrophe. All this is leaving people with a strange sense of déjà vu and a bitterness at public officials for what felt like a fumbling of people’s sacrifices.

column1: “Are we doing a full circle? Yes
column2: ” said Judy Ray
column4: a cosmetologist and hairdresser in Florida who was laid off from her job at a barbershop at Walt Disney World Resort in March."/[]/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2020/04/09/corona-virus-social-images-by-section/assets/World_promo.jpg?u=1593293456133"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/world/europe/coronavirus-spread-asymptomatic.html/How the World Missed Covid-19’s Silent Spread/"When the health officials described the call
column2: Dr. Rothe and Dr. Hoelscher quickly finished and submitted their article. Dr. Rothe did not talk to the patient herself but said she relied on the health authority summary.

column1: Within hours
column2: it was online. It was a modest clinical observation at a key time. Just days earlier
column3: the World Health Organization had said it needed more information about this very topic.

column1: What the authors did not know
column2: however
column3: was that in a suburb 20 minutes away
column4: another group of doctors had also been rushing to publish a report. Neither knew what the other was working on
column5: a seemingly small academic rift that would have global implications.

column1: Academic Hairsplitting
The second group was made up of officials with the Bavarian health authority and Germany’s national health agency
column2: known as the Robert Koch Institute. Inside a suburban office
column3: doctors unfurled mural paper and traced infection routes using colored pens.

column1: Their team
column2: led by the Bavarian epidemiologist Dr. Merle Böhmer
column3: submitted an article to The Lancet
column4: another premier medical journal. But the Munich hospital group had scooped them by three hours. Dr. Böhmer said her team’s article
column5: which went unpublished as a result
column6: had reached similar conclusions but worded them slightly differently.

column1: Dr. Rothe had written that patients appeared to be contagious before the onset of any symptoms. The government team had written that patients appeared to be contagious before the onset of full symptoms — at a time when symptoms were so mild that people might not even recognize them.
The Chinese woman
column2: for example
column3: had woken up in the middle of the night feeling jet-lagged. Wanting to be sharp for her meetings
column4: she took a Chinese medicine called 999 — containing the equivalent of a Tylenol tablet — and went back to bed."/['David D. Kirkpatrick']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/22/world/xxasymptomatic/xxasymptomatic-facebookJumbo-v4.jpg"

column2: Dr. Rothe and Dr. Hoelscher quickly finished and submitted their article. Dr. Rothe did not talk to the patient herself but said she relied on the health authority summary.

column1: Within hours
column2: it was online. It was a modest clinical observation at a key time. Just days earlier
column3: the World Health Organization had said it needed more information about this very topic.

column1: What the authors did not know
column2: however
column3: was that in a suburb 20 minutes away
column4: another group of doctors had also been rushing to publish a report. Neither knew what the other was working on
column5: a seemingly small academic rift that would have global implications.

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/health/coronavirus-antibodies-asymptomatic.html/Actual Coronavirus Infections Vastly Undercounted
column2: C.D.C. Data Shows/"The number of coronavirus infections in many parts of the United States is more than 10 times higher than the reported rate
column3: according to data released on Friday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

column1: The analysis is part of a wide-ranging set of surveys started by the C.D.C. to estimate how widely the virus has spread. Similar studies
column2: sponsored by universities
column3: national governments and the World Health Organization
column4: are continuing all over the world.

column1: The C.D.C. study found
column2: for instance
column3: that in South Florida
column4: just under 2 percent of the population had been exposed to the virus as of April 10
column5: but the proportion is likely to be higher now given the surge of infections in the state. The prevalence was highest in New York City at nearly 7 percent as of April 1.

column1: “This study underscores that there are probably a lot of people infected without knowing it
column2: likely because they have mild or asymptomatic infection
column3: ” said Dr. Fiona Havers
column4: who led the C.D.C. study. “But those people could still spread it to others.”"/['Apoorva Mandavilli']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/27virus-briefing-cdc1/27virus-briefing-cdc1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/2020-primary-election-voting.html/From 47 Primaries
column2: 4 Warning Signs About Voting in a Pandemic/"No one appears to have studied whether printing capacity will be a bottleneck in November
column3: but election officials say they are deeply concerned. Mr. Burden
column4: of the Election Research Center
column5: said it was worth worrying about: “Printers have limited machines and employees
column6: so they can’t scale up” to meet massive demand
column7: he said. “There’s an ongoing concern that some jurisdictions are going to be left out.”

column1: The Russians are coming. So are Americans.
Among election experts
column2: the prospect that voters will be gulled by misinformation to dismiss November’s results as invalid or rigged is a top concern. Increasingly
column3: Americans
column4: not foreigners
column5: are seen as the greatest threat.

column1: President Trump and some Republicans have ratcheted up baseless charges that voting by mail is riddled with fraud
column2: and many on the left assume voter suppression is baked into every element of voting.

column1: Experts worry that delays in counting mail ballots will encourage some people to sow charges of fraud and suppression that are amplified by foreign adversaries. Experts are especially concerned that Americans accustomed to getting election results before bedtime will embrace conspiracy theories and disinformation if the November vote takes days to sort out
column2: as seems likely.

column1: “There is going to be stuff that goes wrong
column2: that isn’t perfect
column3: and our adversaries are looking to leverage that
column4: ” said David J. Becker
column5: the director of the Center for Election Innovation and Research. “Everyone expects there will be a fight against disinformation that is seeking to diminish confidence in the election results — no matter who wins.”

column1: Steve Connolly can speak to that. Mr. Connolly
column2: who bills himself as the longest-running Elvis impersonator in Las Vegas
column3: arrived at his polling place at 6:45 p.m. on June 9 and cast his vote at 3:09 a.m. on June 10
column4: the last voter in Nevada’s Clark County
column5: He was not happy
column6: but he thinks he may have a solution.

column1: “It made me want to run for mayor so I can fix the system
column2: ” he said. “I’ve been Elvis for 25 years. Maybe it’s time for another career.”"/['Michael Wines']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/27virus-voting-1/27virus-voting-1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/health/coronavirus-elevator-reopen.html/Going Up? Not So Fast: Strict New Rules to Govern Elevator Culture/"Kiss the elevator pitch goodbye — at least if it takes place in an elevator.
Change is coming to the daily vertical commute
column2: as workers begin to return to tall office buildings in New York and other cities. The elevator ride
column3: a previously unremarkable 90 or so seconds
column4: has become a daunting puzzler in the calculus of how to bring people back to work safely after the coronavirus pandemic kept them home for months.

column1: Employers and building managers are drafting strict rules for going up: severe limits on the number of riders (four seems to be the new magic number)
column2: designated standing spots to maximize social distance
column3: mandatory masks
column4: required forward-facing positions — and no talking.

column1: Some companies are hiring “elevator consultants” to figure how best to get thousands of people to their desks
column2: balancing risk of elevator density against a potential logjam as riders wait — at least six feet apart — for their turn.

column1: Reflecting the widespread interest and concern
column2: the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention plans to weigh in as early as next week with guidance for elevators and escalators. For escalators
column3: it will advise one rider every other step and hand sanitizer at the top. For elevators
column4: it will recommend limiting the number of riders but won’t specify a number; arrows showing different paths to get on and get off; masks; and signs urging people to “not talk unless you have to
column5: ” said Nancy Clark Burton
column6: a senior industrial hygienist at the C.D.C. who is part of the group developing the new guidance."/['Matt Richtel']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/23/science/00VIRUS-ELEVATORS1/00VIRUS-ELEVATORS1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column3: 000 cases
column4: according to a New York Times database. Cases there have doubled over the past month.

column1: The virus is also taking off in other parts of the world.
If the outbreak was defined early on by a series of shifting epicenters — including Wuhan
column2: China; Iran; northern Italy; Spain; and New York — it is now defined by its wide and expanding scope. And more risks lie ahead as nations begin to reopen their economies.

column1: In India
column2: which initially placed all 1.3 billion of its citizens under a lockdown — then moved to reopen even with its strained public health system near the breaking point — officials reported a record number of new cases Wednesday. And the virus is now spreading rapidly in nearby Pakistan and Bangladesh as well.

column1: It took Africa nearly 100 days to reach 100
column2: 000 cases
column3: the World Health Organization noted
column4: but only 19 days to double that tally. South Africa now averages a thousand more new cases each day than it did two weeks ago.

column1: And some countries where caseloads had appeared to taper — including Israel
column2: Sweden and Costa Rica — are now watching them rise again.

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/minneapolis-police-officer-kueng.html/The Black Officer Who Detained George Floyd Had Pledged to Fix the Police/"Growing up
column2: Mr. Kueng and his family made repeated trips to Haiti
column3: helping at an orphanage. Mr. Kueng and his siblings took a break from school to volunteer there after the earthquake in 2010.

column1: Joni Kueng
column3: likes to say that the Kuengs are a family of doers
column4: not talkers.

column1: “I had to stay out of the race conversations because I was the minority in the household
column2: ” Ms. Kueng said in her first interview since her son’s arrest. She said that race was not an issue with her
column3: but that she was conflicted. “It didn’t really matter
column4: but it does matter to them because they are African-American. And so they had to be able to have an outlet to tell their stories and their experience as well
column5: especially having a white mom.”

column1: Ms. Kueng taught math at the schools her children went to
column2: where the student body was often mostly Hmong
column3: African-American and Latino. Classmates described Alex Kueng as friends with everyone
column4: a master of juggling a soccer ball and a defender against bullies. Photos portray him with a sly smile.

column1: Darrow Jones said he first met Mr. Kueng on the playground when he was 6. Mr. Jones was trying to finish his multiplication homework. Mr. Kueng helped Mr. Jones and then invited him into a game of tag.
When Mr. Jones’s mother died in 2008
column2: Ms. Kueng took him in for as long as a month at a time.

column1: By high school
column2: Mr. Kueng had found soccer
column3: and soon that was all he wanted to do. He became captain of the soccer team; he wanted to turn pro. The quote next to his senior yearbook picture proclaimed
column4: “We ignore failures and strive for success.”

column1: Mr. Kueng went to Monroe College in New Rochelle
column2: N.Y.
column3: to play soccer and study business. But after surgery on both knees
column4: soccer proved impossible. Mr. Kueng quit. Back in Minneapolis
column5: he enrolled in technical college and supported himself catching shoplifters at Macy’s.

column1: About that time
column2: he started talking about joining the police
column3: Ms. Kueng recalled. She said she was nervous
column4: for his safety and also because of the troubled relationship between the Minneapolis police and residents."/['Kim Barker']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/12/us/unrest-kueng-promo/unrest-kueng-promo-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/mississippi-flag-confederate-legislature.html/Mississippi Lawmakers Push Ahead With Proposal to Take Down State Flag/"Some have framed the debate in moral terms
column2: arguing that the flag stands in the way of scabbing over the wounds left by the past. Yet the latest efforts for change have gained momentum in large part because of economic considerations
column3: with business and industry leaders saying that the flag discourages the investment needed to boost one of the poorest states.

column1: The financial threat had been underscored by recent announcements by the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Southeastern Conference that Mississippi would be precluded from hosting championship events until the flag is changed.
“Because of the N.C.A.A. and the SEC
column2: we can point to a quantifiable damage
column3: if you will
column4: that is occurring — a consequence
column5: a punishment
column6: ” Philip Gunn
column7: a Republican who is the State House speaker
column8: said in an interview on Friday afternoon.

column1: Still
column2: the growing calls to change the flag belie the extent of the division that still exists over the banner and how to interpret the legacy it symbolizes. Various polls show that
column3: even as the number of people supporting a change has increased
column4: nearly half of the state is resistant to the idea.

column1: Many remain attached to the flag because they see it as an enduring recognition of the blood shed by their ancestors who fought for Mississippi and their pride in the state’s history.
“We firmly believe that this political correctness
column2: this movement we are sensing out there right now to delegitimize our American institutions and our American history is a movement that’s incredibly dangerous and cannot be appeased
column3: ” said Chris McDaniel
column4: a Republican state senator."/['Rick Rojas']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/27unrest-mississippi-unrest-SWAP/27unrest-mississippi-unrest-SWAP-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/politics/coronavirus-trump-mood-poll.html#commentsContainer/How Americans Feel About the Country Right Now: Anxious. Hopeful./"Despite double digit unemployment
column2: majorities across demographic groups say the federal government’s priority should be to contain the spread of the virus
column3: even if it hurts the economy. Younger voters and black voters take the most stringent view of the social distancing rules
column4: with more than four in 10 saying the guidance is being lifted too quickly. Only backers of Mr. Trump overwhelmingly believe government should prioritize the economy.

column1: More than three-quarters of registered voters say they always or mostly wear a mask in public when they expect to be within six feet of another person
column2: including 60 percent who support Mr. Trump and 79 percent of those under 30.

column1: Men are more likely to go barefaced. Only 46 percent of men say they always wear a mask
column2: compared with 61 percent of women. The findings confirm academic research suggesting that men are more likely to opt out of wearing masks
column3: believing them to be “not cool” or “a sign of weakness
column4: ” even though men are at a higher risk of dying from Covid-19 than women.

column1: In the most heavily impacted states
column2: voters feel even more strongly about taking measures to stop the spread of the virus. A higher percentage of voters in Arizona and Florida
column3: where infections are spiking
column4: say restrictions don’t go far enough and that businesses are reopening too quickly.

column1: Scott Bertoglio
column3: of suburban Phoenix
column4: said he is considering not sending his three young children back to school in the fall because he was worried that the state government has failed to adequately implement rules protecting their health
column5: like mandating mask wearing.

column1: “We’ve essentially been holed up at home
column2: ” he said
column3: taking a break from watching a PowerPoint presentation in his home office. “But Arizona is not taking it seriously and the schools are saying we’re going to open.”

column1: Still
column2: the poll shows that voters overwhelmingly believe that any economic pain stemming from the virus will be temporary. Even among those living in a household with coronavirus-related job losses
column3: 81 percent say they expect to find work within the next few months or have already regained it."/['Lisa Lerer'
column4: 'Elaina Plott'
column5: 'Lazaro Gamio']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/us/politics/26mood-poll1/26mood-poll1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/hickenlooper-colorado-romanoff-gardner.html/Hickenlooper Stumbles in Colorado Race
column2: Complicating Democrats’ Senate Push/"KREMMLING
column3: Colo. — For months
column4: Democrats have figured that Colorado’s U.S. Senate race
column5: a linchpin of their strategy to take back the majority in November
column6: was essentially in the bag
column7: with the Republican incumbent Cory Gardner trailing by double digits behind their candidate John Hickenlooper
column8: the well-liked and well-known former two-term governor and Denver mayor.

column1: But Mr. Hickenlooper
column2: who was coaxed into the Senate contest after ending his brief presidential run
column3: has faltered in recent weeks ahead of the primary race on Tuesday. He now finds himself in a tougher-than-expected contest with Andrew Romanoff
column4: a former state House speaker and another longtime Colorado political presence
column5: in a fight with significant implications for the general election and control of the Senate.

column1: At a time when Democrats sense fresh momentum for flipping the Senate amid national crises that have tarnished President Trump and threaten to drag down Republican candidates
column2: Mr. Hickenlooper’s shaky primary performance has been a rare dark spot in an otherwise brightening landscape. Democrats would have a difficult time capturing the majority without a Centennial State victory.

column1: “He has had a bad June
column2: ” Kyle Saunders
column3: a political-science professor at Colorado State University
column4: said about Mr. Hickenlooper’s multiple travails and missteps. Chief among them was a contempt finding by the state’s independent ethics commission for defying a subpoena to appear at a hearing on a complaint against him — an event that prompted disastrous news coverage across the state."/['Carl Hulse']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/us/politics/28dc-hickenlooper-p1/27dc-hickenlooper1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/arts/11-of-our-best-weekend-reads.html/11 of Our Best Weekend Reads/[shouting] “We would call them bike hikes. We were just going out to go explore your world.” “There would be at least six
column2: seven
column3: eight of us. Our parents said as long as you were home before the streetlights came on
column4: you stayed as a group
column5: you’re fine.” “It was a beautiful day
column6: sunshine. The children in the neighborhood planned to go on a trip to McDonald’s just to have some fun
column7: something different to do.” “Rosedale we thought was a safe place. We all went down. We were riding our bikes.” “And then we saw down the block that there was this beautiful American flag flowing in the wind.” “We saw a group outside on the block. So we was like
column8: ‘Oh
column9: this is a block party.’” “The last thing that I remember was someone saying
column11: a parade.’ And so we went down to go see the parade
column12: and I laugh about it to this day because it was a parade to get the black people out of Rosedale.” Crowd: “White power — white resistance.” It’s the summer of 1975. White residents in Rosedale
column13: Queens
column14: are protesting black families moving into the neighborhood. [shouting] Crowd: “Equal rights for whites.” These are scenes from a documentary produced by journalist Bill Moyers. “Does he have a right to live here?” “No.” “Why not?” “Because he’s black.” “This was not the South. This was not Greenville
column19: Ga. This was right in the heart of the greatest metropolitan area in the country.” The documentary was found nearly 45 years later by a graduate student who posted a short clip on the internet. It went viral on Twitter and Facebook. And the question people kept asking
column22: this is Whitney Hurst calling from The New York Times. My name is Whitney Hurst. I’m a journalist —” To answer that question
column23: we called more than 90 people who had lived in Rosedale at that time. “I’m just trying to find anyone that might have known someone.” We couldn’t find any white residents who said they’d been there. “Came out because it got a little bit crazy.” But we spoke with several of the black children. We wanted to hear what happened to them that day to understand why their experience is resonating decades later. “We went down to see what was going on. Probably in the middle of the block
column24: that’s when we figured out it was something else
column25: and it was something that we definitely were not invited to.” “We noticed that they were running towards us. I was like
column29: ’ not thinking anything negative. And then we heard nigger.” [crowd shouting racial slurs] “Yeah
column30: nigger!” “And they surrounded my best friend at the time
column31: Lorena — one of the young men hit her
column32: and they started calling us names. They started throwing rocks.” “Hearing the word
column33: hearing it directed at me — ‘Why are you calling me that? That’s not me.’ You know
column34: I’ve always been told that’s not me. I didn’t understand. I was like
column35: ‘Who do you think you are to say we can’t come here?’ Like
column36: how dare you?” “What happened to you?” “This little boy
column37: he threw the rock. He tried to hit my sister
column38: but he almost hit me. It was about that much away from me. And I sure wish he had hit me with that rock. I would pick up the rock right next to me and hit him right dead in his face.” “I was just kind of amazed to see that people can act like that
column39: to tell you the truth. But that was like really the first when I was like
column41: people do not like black people.’” “They always do that. They always spit on us like we some dogs. They always —” “Spit back on them.” “Ain’t nothing going to change.” “I immediately was reminded of those programs my parents would have me watch with the dogs and the hoses
column42: and people trying to vote and being killed and lynched. It just
column43: it went right back to my history in this country. It just linked me immediately with that whole experience because I felt it.” “Do you forgive them?” “No. No. No. Can’t take back no hurt.” “And I didn’t know what to do with those feelings. I did not know what to do with those feelings.” For Moyers
column44: the video going viral shows how powerful images can be. “He just tried to hit my sister
column45: but —” “Because we were in their neighborhood.” “I mean
column46: I do believe that television has been a great teacher. This country didn’t really respond to what was going on in the South
column48: until the sheriff in Birmingham turned the water hoses and the dogs on those young people who were demonstrating there. We knew about it. We heard about it. We were aware of it
column49: but we didn’t see it. We couldn’t escape it once we saw it.” “As we filmed in Rosedale
column50: a group of blacks from South Jamaica was coming through the neighborhood in a demonstration of support.” “Every time a group of blacks get together
column51: they want to help Rosedale with their problems. We don’t need any outsiders helping us with our problems
column53: period.” Crowd: “Right on. Right on.” “All right
column55: this next scene is very disturbing
column56: all right? It’s the one I was telling you about yesterday. I started a sociology elective in 2004-2005 school year
column57: and my supervisor at the time said
column58: ‘Come up with something that’s close to home that maybe you can relate to today.’ I grew up in Rosedale.” “… and think that I have a right —” “And I said
column59: ‘I want to do a unit on race in America.’ And that Rosedale video
column60: we’ve been showing it for 15 years now
column61: giving it to the kids and say
column62: ‘What do you think?’” “I’ve never seen racism on camera. That was full-on racism and just bullying.” Crowd: “Equal rights for whites. Equal rights for whites.” “I’m glad that I saw it because it needs to be seen. I feel like everyone should see this.” “I think it’s come back up because of the fact that we’re going back kind of.” “Racism is still alive. It’s still poisoning other minds.” “This is how it was back then. Let’s not repeat it again.” “Emotionally
column63: I think it’s connecting with kids more today. This generation is that ‘I Generation.’ They can see it in a 10-second span
column64: make a connection to it.” “Can’t take back no hurt.” “The kids are never going to forget that. They can’t unsee it
column65: and it’s going to be with them forever.” “Rosedale
column67: so we’re welcomed there now. That day
column68: the American flag was the image
column69: the symbol that pulled us into that situation. We live in America. The American flag means good things. It means that we can go where we want to go. We can ride our bike down any street in America. But it really represented a symbol of do not enter. So they took that beautiful image and turned it into something ugly for me
column70: and I want the flag back.”/['Kaly Soto']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/multimedia/27weekendreads-promo/27weekendreads-promo-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: Joel Schumacher
column2: the director whose visually inventive movies included the coming-of-age drama “St. Elmo’s Fire” and the vampire action-comedy “The Lost Boys
column3: ” died on Monday at 80.

column1: He also directed a large budget film that was widely panned.
Which one?"/['Will Dudding'
column2: 'Jessica Anderson'
column3: 'Compiled Will Dudding']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/21/us/politics/26newsquiz-usattourney-p1sub/19xp-Clayton-2-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/23/opinion/objectivity-black-journalists-coronavirus.html/Opinion | A Reckoning Over Objectivity
column2: Led by Black Journalists/"It’s striking to read objectivity defined that way — not because it’s objectionable
column3: but rather because it barely resembles the way the concept is commonly discussed in newsrooms today. Conversations about objectivity
column4: rather than happening in a virtuous vacuum
column5: habitually focus on predicting whether a given sentence
column6: opening paragraph or entire article will appear objective to a theoretical reader
column7: who is invariably assumed to be white. This creates the very illusion of fairness that Mr. Jones
column8: and others

column1: Instead of telling hard truths in this polarized environment
column2: America’s newsrooms too often deprive their readers of plainly stated facts that could expose reporters to accusations of partiality or imbalance.

column1: For years
column2: I’ve been among a chorus of mainstream journalists who have called for our industry to abandon the appearance of objectivity as the aspirational journalistic standard
column3: and for reporters instead to focus on being fair and telling the truth
column4: as best as one can
column5: based on the given context and available facts.

column1: It’s not a novel argument. Scores of journalists across generations
column2: from gonzo reporters like Hunter S. Thompson to more traditional voices like Bill Kovach and Tom Rosenstiel
column3: have advocated this very approach. Mr. Kovach and Mr. Rosenstiel lay it out in detail in their classic text “The Elements of Journalism.”

column1: Those of us advancing this argument know that a fairness-and-truth focus will have different
column2: healthy interpretations. We also know that neutral “objective journalism” is constructed atop a pyramid of subjective decision-making: which stories to cover
column3: how intensely to cover those stories
column4: which sources to seek out and include
column5: which pieces of information are highlighted and which are downplayed. No journalistic process is objective. And no individual journalist is objective
column6: because no human being is.

column1: And so
column2: instead of promising our readers that we will never
column3: on any platform
column4: betray a single personal bias — submitting ourselves to a life sentence of public thoughtlessness — a better pledge would be an assurance that we will devote ourselves to accuracy
column5: that we will diligently seek out the perspectives of those with whom we personally may be inclined to disagree and that we will be just as sure to ask hard questions of those with whom we’re inclined to agree.

column1: The best of our profession already does this. But we need to be honest about the gulf that lies between the best and the bulk."/['Wesley Lowery']/2020-06-23 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/23loweryWeb/23loweryWeb-facebookJumbo.jpg"
