https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/opinion/sunday/tammy-duckworth-biden-2020.html/Tammy Duckworth is Biden's Best Running Mate Pick - The New York Times/"To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times
column2: download Audm for iPhone or Android.

column1: Whatever his wobbles
column2: Joe Biden has
column3: from the start of his presidential campaign
column4: got one thing exactly right: The 2020 election is a battle for the soul of America. That’s not just a pretty slogan. It’s the stomach-knotting truth — and it’s the frame he should use for choosing his running mate.

column1: It’s why he should pick Senator Tammy Duckworth of Illinois.
She’s a paragon of the values that Donald Trump
column2: for all his practice as a performer
column3: can’t even pantomime. She’s best described by words that are musty relics in his venal and vainglorious circle: “sacrifice
column4: ” “honor
column5: ” “humility.” More than any of the many extraordinary women on Biden’s list of potential vice-presidential nominees
column6: she’s the anti-Trump
column7: the antidote to the ugliness he revels in and the cynicism he stokes.

column1: Americans can feel good — no
column2: wonderful — about voting for a ticket with Duckworth on it. And we’re beyond hungry for that. We’re starving.

column1: That ache transcends all of the other variables that attend Biden’s deliberations as he appraises Elizabeth Warren
column2: Kamala Harris
column3: Val Demings and others: race
column4: age
column5: experience
column6: exact position on the spectrum from progressive to moderate."/['Frank Bruni']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/sunday/28Bruni/28Bruni-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/06/26/opinion/generational-inequality.html/Opinion | That Would Never Happen at My Parents’ Job/"I have been a nurse for four years. My grandmother
column2: father
column3: and mother all worked as nurses. I chose nursing because I knew you could always get a job. I never went to work with my parents
column4: but they talked about it at the dinner table every night. I knew they loved their jobs. So I decided to do the same thing they did.

column1: My benefits are horrible compared to my parents’ and they let me know it. When I first got my job I remember going to my parents’ house to help me sign up for benefits. And they just couldn’t believe how bad my health insurance was. I thought because I was in health care that I'd have really good insurance
column2: but I was wrong. I think the hospital does it to save money.

column1: Read More
My parents used to work 40 hours a week
column2: doing eight-hour shifts five days a week. But most nursing jobs now
column3: you work three 12-hour shifts
column4: which is just 36 hours a week. Even the pay difference from 36 to 40 hours is huge. And it’s harder to get overtime when you’re not working 40 hours. I think I get paid a pretty similar amount hourly to what my parents did
column5: but they always worked 40 hours a week and I work 36.

column1: It was super common to have a union when my parents were working; their benefits and wages were protected. I don’t think my parents would have taken a job that wasn’t union.
There's a lot of things that happen at my work that I feel wouldn't happen if we had a union. We have something called low-census days. If we have fewer than 16 patients on the unit
column2: they'll say that one of the nurses has to stay home. You have to use paid time off (PTO) to get paid
column3: or you won't get paid. It’s stressful because every year when you get new PTO you have to make sure you're saving some of it for low-census days. You never know when our unit might be low. That would never happen at my parents’ jobs. My parents have said they would not tolerate being treated like that
column4: but almost all nursing jobs now have low-census days.

column1: We have a 403(b) retirement savings plan
column2: but because of Covid-19
column3: the hospital is not contributing to that at all right now. When the pandemic started
column4: our hospital was losing money because we had to have every patient in their own room. They sent out an email saying that they're not contributing to our retirement until further notice. That's pretty stressful.

column1: In spite of all that
column2: I do really like being a nurse. It’s really active. All day I’m out on the unit playing games with patients or talking to them. I walk up and down the hallway with the medicine cart. It’s just interesting to talk to different people all the time. And the staff that I work with
column3: we’re always laughing. I feel like I have a strong community with the other nurses."/['Lora Kelley']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/25/opinion/generational-inequality-1593120145501/generational-inequality-1593120145501-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/25/opinion/black-lives-matter-corporations.html/If Black Lives Really Matter to the Rich
column2: Philanthropy Isn't Enough - The New York Times/"In recent weeks
column3: I have been invited to join dozens of conversations with many well-intentioned chief executives and generous philanthropists to talk about what they should be doing during an upheaval that feels like 1918
column4: 1932 and 1968 all at once. The irony is not lost on me: Many of those who are eagerly extending Zoom invitations are complicit in a system that desperately needs changing.

column1: I do see progress. I see business leaders like Marc Benioff
column2: Ursula Burns
column3: Ray Dalio
column4: Paul Polman and others acknowledge that we conduct our daily work in a system built on unfair incentives. This system puts the interests of capital over labor
column5: while it compounds privilege at the expense of opportunity.

column1: The boardroom elite are beginning to recognize that these unfairly structured incentives have grossly distorted our economy. I see an evolving understanding that our twisted economy is an existential threat that has pushed our republic to a breaking point.
This awareness is necessary. But it is not sufficient.

The old playbook — giving back through philanthropy as a way of ameliorating the effects of inequality — cannot heal what ails our nation. It cannot address the root causes of this inequality — what the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called “the circumstances of economic injustice which make philanthropy necessary.”
Instead
column2: those of us with power and privilege must grapple with a more profound question: What are we willing to give up?

column1: If we
column2: the beneficiaries of a system that perpetuates inequality
column3: are trying to reform this system that favors us
column4: we will have to give up something. Here are a few of the special privileges and benefits we should be willing to surrender: the intricate web of tax policies that bolster our wealth; the entrenched system in American colleges of legacy admissions
column5: which gives a leg up to our children; and above all
column6: the expectation that
column7: because of our money
column8: we are entitled to a place at the front of the line."/['Darren Walker'
column11: 'The Editorial Board']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/25/opinion/25walker1/25walker1-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/24/opinion/coronavirus-health-workers-nurses.html/Health Care Workers Are the Future. Protect Their Rights. - The New York Times/"These workers are essential not only in the present. They are essential in the future. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports the job projected to have the largest percentage increase in employment from 2018 to 2028 is the home health aide followed by the personal care aide
column2: a reflection of the growing older population in America.

column1: Despite the increasing need for these workers
column2: home health aides and personal care aides typically earn less than $12 per hour. And they are overwhelmingly women of color
column3: and disproportionately black women: 87 percent of paid adult care workers are women
column4: compared with 46 percent of nondomestic workers
column5: and about 25 percent of home care aides are black
column6: compared with 12 percent of nondomestic workers.

column1: The workers we need the most aren’t wearing boots and hard hats; they are wearing sneakers or scrubs.
We are at a critical juncture. The future of work will be decided by how we respond to this moment.
This is our moment to choose a future where we invest in the work that we now know is essential. Where care jobs become living-wage jobs with benefits
column2: protected by a strong federal safety net. Where essential workers can support their own families through their work
column3: even as they support ours.

column1: Or we can continue down the path we are on. As companies consider how they will use the economic recession as a moment to reset
column2: they will be making choices that determine the future of millions of jobs. More jobs could be outsourced
column3: subcontracted and offshored
column4: deconstructed into tasks or automated. Many jobs that were lost may never return. Increasing numbers of the jobs that do return could become gigs that are farmed out to disaggregated workforces managed by algorithms. Too many of us could end up working along a Walmart or Amazon supply chain
column5: while not earning enough to shop there. And more jobs might become inputs into an equation
column6: without recognition
column7: value or access to a safety net. Most economic choices we’ve made in recent decades make that possibility likely."/['Ai-Jen Poo'
column8: 'Palak Shah'
column11: 'Darren Walker'

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/26/opinion/statues-protests.html/Opinion | After the Statues Fall/"Likewise
column2: we should never honor public figures who
column3: by the standards of their own time as well as ours
column4: abused a public trust. Case in point: The more we learn about J. Edgar Hoover
column5: the more outrageous it is that the F.B.I. building in Washington is still named for him.

column1: These are the easy cases. Equally easy are the opposite cases.
Hans Christian Heg
column2: an ardent abolitionist whose statue in Madison
column3: Wis.
column4: was pulled down this week
column5: fell at the Battle of Chickamauga trying to make a more perfect union. Robert Gould Shaw
column6: who commanded one of the first black Union regiments and whose monument in Boston was defaced last month
column7: was killed at Fort Wagner trying to make a more perfect union. Ulysses Grant
column8: who did more than any other general to defeat the Confederacy and more than any other president to defeat the Klan
column9: and whose statue in San Francisco was pulled down last week
column10: devoted his life to trying to make a more perfect union.

column1: What about
column2: say
column3: Andrew Jackson
column4: Teddy Roosevelt
column5: Thomas Jefferson or George Washington?

column1: The central case against Washington and Jefferson is that they were slaveholders
column2: albeit ones who knew slavery was wrong. If their fault lay in being creatures of their time
column3: their greatness was in their ability to look past it. An unbroken moral thread connects the Declaration of Independence to the Gettysburg Address to Martin Luther King’s “I Have A Dream” speech. An unbroken political thread connects the first president to the 16th to the 44th. It’s impossible to imagine any union
column4: much less the possibility of a more perfect one
column5: without them.

column1: Jackson and Roosevelt? Both were avowed racists
column2: and the Indian Removal Act of 1830
column3: enacted during Jackson’s presidency
column4: stands with the Chinese Exclusion Act as one of the most shameful pieces of American legislation.

column1: But there’s historical irony in the fact that some of today’s progressives are eager to bring down statues to the two most progressive presidents of their times. Roosevelt busted trusts
column2: championed conservation
column3: and caused a scandal by inviting Booker T. Washington to dine with his family in the White House. Were those not acts in the service of a more perfect union?"/['Bret Stephens']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/26/opinion/26stephensWeb/26stephensWeb-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/opinion/sunday/trump-statues-2020-reelection.html/Opinion | Trump
column2: Not So Statuesque/"WASHINGTON — For a long time
column3: Republicans have brandished the same old narrative to try to scare their way into the White House.

column1: Their candidates were presented as the patriarchs
column2: protecting the house from invaders with dark skin.

column1: With Nixon
column2: it was the Southern Strategy
column3: raising alarms about the dismantling of Jim Crow laws.

column1: With Reagan
column2: it was launching his 1980 campaign on fairgrounds near where the Klan murdered three civil rights activists.

column1: With Bush senior
column2: it was Willie Horton coming to stab you and rape your girlfriend.

column1: With W. and Cheney
column2: it was Qaeda terrorists coming back to kill us."/['Maureen Dowd']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/28dowd1/28dowd1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/opinion/sunday/hispanic-americans.html/Opinion | Now Is a Time to Learn From Hispanic Americans/"A Brookings Institution study found that since the start of the pandemic
column2: one in six households in the United States has young children who aren’t getting enough food
column3: so I asked Francis about hunger. She acknowledged that there must be hungry children but added: “If people knew kids were hungry
column4: they would help. The community would step up.”

column1: On the other end of the United States
column2: Latinos in New York City display a similar resilience. Dr. Carmen Isasi
column3: an epidemiologist at Albert Einstein College of Medicine who has studied LatinX populations
column4: said that lately she has seen signs on Spanish-speaking churches offering food for the needy.

column1: Scholars have been debating the Hispanic Paradox at least since 1974
column2: when researchers found that the neonatal mortality rate in Texas was lower for people with Spanish surnames than with English surnames.

column1: Researchers have found another paradox within the paradox: First-generation Latino immigrants tend to live longest
column2: and their children — while better educated and earning more money — die earlier. Moreover
column3: Latinos embedded in ethnic enclaves seem to do better than those who live in heterogeneous neighborhoods.

column1: Part of the explanation may be that what many white Americans think of as “traditional American values” — an emphasis on faith
column2: family and community ties — are disproportionately found among Latino immigrants
column3: but then fade as their children assimilate.

column1: “If we find that someone needs help
column2: we help them
column3: ” Raúl González Hernández
column4: who works in a plant nursery and has just recovered from Covid-19
column5: told me. He said that others had helped him when he arrived from Michoacán State in Mexico
column6: so he wants to pay it forward — particularly if the person needing help is also from Michoacán.

column1: I’ve been long interested in the Hispanic Paradox because I grew up in a mostly white farm town in Oregon that has been devastated by lost jobs. As I’ve written
column2: a quarter of the kids on my old school bus are dead from drugs
column3: alcohol
column4: suicide and other “deaths of despair.”"/['Nicholas Kristof']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/28kristof1/28kristof1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/opinion/sunday/us-coronavirus-2030.html/Opinion | Waking Up in 2030/"There is something peculiar about time during the pandemic. On the one hand there’s a feeling that the normal calendar has simply stopped
column2: school schedules and sports seasons evaporating
column3: one homebound day passing much like another. It’s a feeling of hiatus
column4: intermission
column5: like the days between Christmas and the new year
column6: or some extra season invented by a Renaissance pope to fix a lagging calendar.

column1: Yet at the same time there’s a feeling of acceleration
column2: of changes that might have otherwise dragged out across a decade piling one atop the other. The George Floyd protests and their electoral consequences
column3: the transformation of liberal institutions by internal agitation
column4: the changes happening to cities and corporations and colleges and churches — in each case
column5: trends that were working slowly have seemingly speeded up.

column1: This means that when the coronavirus era finally ends
column2: there will be a Rip Van Winkle feeling — a sense of having been asleep and waking to normality
column3: except that we will have time-traveled and the normality will resemble the year 2030 as it might have been without the virus
column4: rather than just a simple turn to 2021 or 2022."/['Ross Douthat']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/opinion/28douthat1/28douthat1-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/opinion/laura-hillenbrand.html/Opinion | I Was in Love With a Tree That Swallowed the Sky/"I bought my house in Oregon without ever having set foot in it
column2: without ever having even been to the state. I bought it knowing I might never make it here
column3: that I’d have to risk my life to try. In my rowhouse in the clatter of Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: my only view was the back of another house
column6: about as far as I’d ever been able to see during years spent largely housebound with an illness that was finally beginning to let me go.

column1: One day five years ago
column2: I saw a photograph of this house and its gobsmacking view of a mountain
column3: of shining rivers
column4: of forests and hills that folded over one another into infinity. I hung my heart on that view
column5: bought the house and one morning six months later
column6: climbed into an RV and set off for Oregon in hopes of inventing my life out of nothing.

column1: On an autumn day
column2: I finally arrived. One of the first things to arrest me was the Norway maple in the backyard. It was an exuberant explosion of a tree
column3: its foliage so full that the branches kissed the ground. Each summer
column4: the tree bounded outward in all directions
column5: growing perhaps two feet; each fall
column6: its torrent of huge orange leaves whirled through the air like laughter. The tree was so in love with life that it swallowed the sky.

column1: This year
column2: in which everything has felt sundered
column3: the tree became my refuge. In the mornings
column4: I began carrying a pillow to it and ducking under the branches
column5: finding myself in a magical green cave. As the leaves sifted the breeze around me
column6: I’d sit on my pillow and meditate
column7: embraced in the dappled
column8: ebullient

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/24/opinion/what-woodrow-wilson-cost-my-grandfather.html/Opinion | What Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather/"Many black men and women suffered similar fates under Wilson. As the historian Eric S. Yellin of the University of Richmond documents in his powerful book “Racism in the Nation’s Service
column2: ” my grandfather’s demotion was part of a systematic purge of the federal government; with Wilson’s approval
column3: in a few short years virtually all blacks had been removed from management responsibilities
column4: moved to menial jobs or simply dismissed.

column1: My grandfather died before I was born
column2: but I have learned much about his struggle — and that of other black civil servants in the federal government — from his personnel file. What is most striking is his sense of humiliation; after all
column3: he had spent his career in a time and place where
column4: whatever was happening in the South
column5: African-Americans were able to get ahead. And then
column6: suddenly
column7: with Wilson’s election
column8: that all changed.

column1: Consider a letter he wrote on May 16
column3: barely a month after his demotion. “The reputation which I have been able to acquire and maintain at considerable sacrifice
column4: ” he wrote
column5: “is to me (foolish as it may appear to those in higher stations of life) a source of personal pride
column6: a possession of which I am very jealous and which is possessed at a value in my estimation ranking above the loss of salary — though the last
column7: to a man having a family of small children to rear
column8: is serious enough.”

column1: And the reply he received? His supervisor said
column2: simply
column3: that my grandfather was unable to “properly perform the duties required (he is too slow).” Yet there had never been any indication of this in his personnel file.

column1: Wilson was not just a racist. He believed in white supremacy as government policy
column2: so much so that he reversed decades of racial progress. But we would be wrong to see this as a mere policy change; in doing so
column3: he ruined the lives of countless talented African-Americans and their families.

column1: It is this legacy of injustice that the Princeton students demand the university
column2: and the country
column3: confront.

column1: We must listen to them."/['Gordon J. Davis']/2015-11-24 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/11/24/opinion/24davis1web/24davis1web-facebookJumbo.jpg"

https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/27/us/pride-parade-canceled-nyc-san-francisco.html/‘A True Disappointment’: When Your First Pride March Is Canceled/"Colin Beresford was looking forward to the summer of 2020
column2: and for the first time celebrating Pride among the crowds of people in Ann Arbor
column3: Mich.

column1: Mr. Beresford
column3: grew up in a conservative Michigan town and described a slow process of coming to understand that he was bisexual
column4: to acknowledge that within himself
column5: and finally to take pride in it.

column1: “For me
column2: it has been scary to accept myself
column3: ” he said. “I thought this year could be the year that I go and show myself
column4: and everyone else
column5: who I am. But
column6: just like countless other things
column7: that will have to wait.”

column1: Pride marches and events have been canceled or postponed throughout the country this year because of the coronavirus
column2: and many people like Mr. Beresford in the L.G.B.T.Q. community are missing out on an important moment of visibility and acceptance: their first Pride."/['Pierre-Antoine Louis']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/27/us/27virus-firstpride-01/27virus-firstpride-01-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/25/style/coroanvirus-america-summer.html/Summer’s Here
column2: and America Is Ready to Quarancheat/"But what if they’re lying?

column1: Rafael Agustin
column3: a TV writer in Los Angeles
column4: said he has broken his quarantine only twice. “Once to see the girl I thought I was dating
column5: and then once to see the girl I now hope to be dating
column6: ” he said. With both of them
column7: he had a rule: They must be mask wearers. There were a few ways to make sure that was the case. He could ask them directly and check their social media accounts. But there is no way to know exactly what they were doing behind his back and out of the spotlight. Still
column8: he’ll continue to insist.

column1: “Today
column2: face masks are the new condoms
column3: ” Mr. Agustin said. “If you’re not using them
column4: then you’re not getting any action. So please use protection because you don’t know if you might be a carrier.”

column1: ‘There Has Been Some Yelling’
Those who’ve been isolating in a group have been found a way to work around the strictures of quarantine from its beginning. But now
column2: with the patchwork of reopenings across the country
column3: disagreements are arising about which new pursuits may be permissible.

column1: Thomas Gunderson
column3: is an aviation student at Southern Utah University. By the end of March most students had left Cedar City
column4: Utah
column5: where he started living recently
column6: having transferred from a different school.

column1: Three people he knew were still in Cedar City including his brother
column3: who works for a network marketing business and is his roommate
column4: and two female students
column5: 19 and 30
column6: who live together. “The group got whittled down to the few of us
column7: ” he said. “We decided this was going to be our Covid group.”

column1: They are still socializing only together. At night they make food like tacos and watch television including “Money Heist” on Netflix. During the day they hike to Logan Canyon and the Great Salt Lake. They have decided not to go to restaurants
column2: which are reopening
column3: opting to wait to see whether the virus is halted or renews its spread."/['Alyson Krueger']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/fashion/24QUARANCHEATING/24QUARANCHEATING-facebookJumbo.jpg"

column1: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/25/magazine/angelo-bassi-quantum-mechanic.html/The Rebel Physicist on the Hunt for a Better Story Than Quantum Mechanics/"‘The thing that amazes me is that quantum mechanics is only 100 years old
column2: ” the physicist Angelo Bassi said. We were in conversation across a picnic table on a drab Soviet-era campus in Zagreb
column3: an early-autumn breeze swishing through the yellowing leaves of some nearby trees. “It’s a baby
column4: it’s nothing — 100 years in the history of science. How can you just stop there? It doesn’t make sense any way you look at it.” We sat in the shadow of a rust-stained beige building where Bassi was about to speak at a workshop for physicists who specialize in the century-old subject.

column1: Despite the theory’s advancing years
column2: even college-educated adults tend to have only a hazy sense of what quantum mechanics says. And for good reason. Although physicists use it to predict the behavior of the fundamental particles
column3: like electrons
column4: that make up atoms and the photons that make up light
column5: and in spite of its having been the basis of many of the 20th century’s signature technologies (including nuclear power
column6: lasers and computers)
column7: the theory has confounded even the cognoscenti from its beginnings in the 1920s. That’s because
column8: while it’s spectacular at making predictions
column9: it doesn’t describe what’s actually happening underneath nature’s hood to make those results come about. It would be one thing to concede that science may never be able to explain
column11: the subjective experiences of the human mind. But the standard take on quantum mechanics suggests something far more surprising: that a complete understanding of even the objective
column12: physical world is beyond science’s reach
column13: since it’s impossible to translate into words how the theory’s math relates to the world we live in.

column1: Bassi
column2: a 47-year-old theoretical physicist at the University of Trieste
column3: in northeastern Italy
column4: is prominent among a tiny minority of rebels in the discipline who reject this conclusion. “I strongly believe that physics is words
column5: in a sense
column6: ” he said across the picnic table. And whereas all the other talks at the workshop focused on the empirical implications of quantum mechanics
column7: Bassi’s would make a case for what a vast majority of his colleagues consider a highly implausible idea: that the theory upon which nearly all of modern physics rests must have something wrong with it — precisely because it can’t be put into words.

column1: Of course
column2: much about quantum mechanics can be said with words. Like the fact that a particle’s future whereabouts can’t be specified by the theory
column3: only predicted with probabilities. And that those probabilities derive from each particle’s “wave function
column4: ” a set of numbers that varies over time
column5: as per an equation devised by Erwin Schrödinger in 1925. But because the wave function’s numbers have no obvious meaning
column6: the theory only predicts what scientists may see at the instant of observation — when all the wave function’s latent possibilities appear to collapse to one definitive outcome — and provides no narrative at all for what particles actually do before or after that
column7: or even how much the word “particle” is apropos to the unobserved world. The theory
column8: in fact
column11: behave more like waves — a fact called “wave-particle duality” that’s related to how all those latent possibilities seem to indicate that an unobserved particle can exist in several places at once. The act of observation itself is then posited to somehow convert this nonsensical situation into the world we see
column12: of objects having definite locations and other properties. This makes human beings
column13: who are after all the ones making the observations
column14: in essence responsible for conjuring the reality we experience out of a murky netherworld that quantum mechanics implies is simply unknowable."/['Bob Henderson']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/06/28/magazine/28mag-bassi/28mag-bassi-facebookJumbo-v2.jpg"

https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/football/trent-alexander-arnold-liverpool-title-history-spt-intl/index.html/Liverpool star Alexander-Arnold bids to build new dynasty/"English Premier League winner. Check. Winning it all with your boyhood club. Check.
For players and fans around the world such an extraordinary feat would be far beyond their wildest imagination.
But for Liverpool's Trent Alexander-Arnold
column2: his fairytale dream has become a reality -- all at the age of just 21.

column1: It's hard to even comprehend what's actually happened -- I'm over the moon
column2: a beaming Alexander-Arnold told CNN Sport after the club secured its first league title in 30 years on Thursday.

column1: The right-back celebrated the achievement with his teammates and coaching staff at a golf resort in the city as they watched Chelsea beat Manchester City 2-1 -- thereby handing them the trophy with a record seven games to spare.
He admits
column2: though
column3: it wasn't quite the way he'd pictured such a historic moment playing out in his imagination.

column1: I always dreamt it as a last minute winner. It was a tight
column2: tight title race up until the last minute and we'd scored an equalizer to win the league
column3: he smiles.

column1: He likely pictured that moment with fans in the stadium
column2: too
column3: but the coronavirus pandemic means games are being played behind closed doors.

column1: Fans celebrated Liverpool winning the title outside Anfield stadium.
One icon inspires another
The England international joined the club as a six-year-old and immediately caught the eye of club legend Steven Gerrard
Gerrard
column2: who was part of the Liverpool side which narrowly missed out on the title in 2014 alongside Luis Suarez
column3: wrote in his 2016 autobiography: ""Trent has a terrific chance of making it as a top professional...he's got a lovely frame and seems to have all the attributes you need.""

column1: It's high praise
column2: which the defender has used as inspiration.

column1: [Gerrard's] a hero
column2: a legend
column3: an icon
column4: someone who I always looked up to
column5: someone that I try to become and want to emulate
column6: he said.

column1: I was just proud of him acknowledging my talents and singling me out individually as someone with a bright future. It was an honor for me...I always used him as an inspiration to become a better player.""
Former Liverpool star Steven Gerrard spotted Alexander-Arnold's talent from a young age
'We want to write our own chapter'
Since making his first-team debut in October 2016
column2: he has gone from strength to strength and is now widely acknowledged as one of the best full-backs in the world.

column1: Alexander-Arnold
column2: though
column3: doesn't want his or the club's relentless pursuit of success to stop here -- he wants to create a new legacy.

column1: When you're playing for one of the biggest clubs in the world and you're playing with world class players and you've got a world class manager the mentality has to be world class and that's relentless all the time.
To be able to do that you have to win trophies year after year
column2: and next year it's going to be about doing the same and recreating the feelings that we're feeling for the next few years and trying to become a legendary Liverpool team.

column1: We want to write our own chapter in this amazing history of the club -- we just want to be a special Liverpool team that fans can be proud of.""
The defender played an instrumental role in helping the club to win the UEFA Champions League in 2019
A voice for change and equality
His ambitions on the pitch are matched by those off it.
The defender has been inspired to speak out against racism by the impact of his England colleagues Marcus Rashford and Raheem Sterling.
During his side's recent Premier League clash with local rival Everton
column2: Alexander-Arnold wore boots which carried the message 'Black Lives Matter.' These were auctioned off after the game with the proceeds going to the Nelson Mandela Foundation.

column1: The movement has been so inspiring to me
column2: seeing so many people involved and so many people pick it up
column3: so many movements and institutions that are behind it.

column1: It's powerful to be a part of something and to know that you're an inspiration and a role model to a younger generation. It just inspires you more to put out the right messages.""
And Alexander-Arnold knows that for meaningful change to happen education is the key.
People shouldn't be treated differently because of the color of the skin or where they're from. So it's important to educate people.
For now
column2: it's about getting these types of stories and getting these types of messages out there as much as possible just to enforce that change and that education."""/['Aleks Klosok'
column3: 'Darren Lewis']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/200626214357-trent-alexander-arnold-liverpool-super-tease.jpg"

column1: https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/football/barcelona-celta-vigo-liga-football-spt-intl/index.html/Barcelona's title hopes dim after a draw at Celta Vigo/"(CNN) Real Madrid took a firm grip on the title race in Spain's La Liga without even playing after archrival Barcelona dropped two points at Celta Vigo despite Luis Suarez's double.
Iago Aspas' free kick in the 88th minute earned Celta a 2-2 draw after Suarez had twice given Barcelona the lead with assists from his pal Lionel Messi on both occasions.

The result means Barcelona moved ahead of Real Madrid by a point atop the standings but Los Blancos have played one fewer game and hold the advantage if the teams finish tied on points by virtue of having a better head-to-head record.
We've got little margin for error now and in theory
column2: we have to win all our games and hope our rival slips up
column3: Barcelona manager Quique Setien was quoted as saying by Marca. ""We'll try to keep picking up maximum points.""

column1: Barcelona's struggles at Vigo continued
column2: having won only once in the league there since 2015.

column1: Read More"/['Ravi Ubha']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/200627172025-vigo-barcelona-super-tease.jpg"

https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/motorsport/hamilton-ecclestone-comments-f1-gbr-spt-intl/index.html/Lewis Hamilton: 'Sad and disappointing' to read Ecclestone comments/"(CNN) Lewis Hamilton said it was ""sad"" and ""disappointing"" to see the former head of Formula 1
column2: Bernie Ecclestone
column3: claim that ""in lots of cases
column4: Black people are more racist than what White people are.""

column1: Hamilton -- the lone Black driver in Formula 1 -- took to Instagram to reply to the comments made by the 89-year-old billionaire to CNN Sport on Friday.
The six-time world champion began by writing
column2: ""Damn
column3: I just don't even know where to start with this one."" Hamilton later called Ecclestone's comments both ""ignorant"" and ""uneducated.""

column1: Ecclestone ran Formula 1 for roughly 40 years before being replaced as chief executive in 2017.

Bernie is out of the sport and a different generation but this is exactly what is wrong -- ignorant and uneducated comments which show us how far we as a society need to go before real equality can happen
column2: Hamilton wrote.

column1: Read More"/['Ravi Ubha'

column1: https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/27/tennis/novak-djokovic-adria-tour-backlash-spt-intl/index.html/Novak Djokovic: A week to forget for world No. 1 after exhibition tennis fiasco/"(CNN) Novak Djokovic should have been stepping out this Monday at Wimbledon
column2: opening the Championships as the defending champion.

column1: Instead
column2: the top-ranked Serb is involved in a damage limitation exercise after his exhibition tour in the Balkans
column3: intended to be an uplifting moment during the sport's hiatus because of the coronavirus pandemic
column4: was cancelled when Djokovic
column5: his wife Jelena
column6: three other players
column7: three coaches and one player's pregnant wife tested positive for the virus.

column1: Unlike other exhibition events during the pandemic
column2: there was limited social distancing on the Adria Tour
column3: which was played to crowded stadiums
column4: with players hugging and high-fiving each other
column5: playing basketball and dancing together.

column1: He hasn't had a good lockdown
column2: British sports marketing expert Tim Crow put it bluntly in a phone interview with CNN Sport.

column1: 'Extremely happy'
When Djokovic announced in May he would host the Adria Tour
column2: it seemed like tennis was slowly emerging from the shutdown
column3: which had led to the first cancellation of Wimbledon since World War II.

column1: The Adria Tour
column2: which was scheduled to be played in four cities from June 13 through July 5
column3: had attracted three-time grand slam finalist Dominic Thiem of Austria
column4: world No. 7 Alexander Zverev of Germany and three-time major semifinalist Grigor Dimitrov of Bulgaria
column5: among others. Djokovic's 24-year-old brother
column6: Djordje
column7: was named tournament director.

column1: Speaking at a launch press conference on May 27
column2: Djokovic said he was ""extremely happy"" to announce the series
column3: organized by him and his family. He stressed ""absolutely all income"" from it would be going to humanitarian organizations
column4: before proudly announcing that all the players would be playing for free.

column1: He also said the tour would ""follow to and adhere to"" the local regulations and rules.
Borna Coric
column2: Grigor Dimitrov
column3: Novak Djokovic and Alexander Zverev (left to right) pose for a group shot ahead of an exhibition basketball match in Zadar
column4: Croatia.

column1: Belgrade party
When Djokovic played his first match against fellow Serb Viktor Troicki on the afternoon of Saturday June 13 in Belgrade
column2: some 4
column3: 000 spectators had filled the stadium close to the Danube river to capacity
column4: with few fans wearing masks. The players
column5: good friends
column6: hugged after Djokovic won in straight sets.

column1: They also shook hands with the umpire
column2: while ball kids handed them their towels. They took selfies with fans afterwards
column3: and signed autographs.

column1: Serbia and Croatia
column2: neither of which experienced major virus outbreaks
column3: had recently lifted many lockdown measures. But the Serbian government was still asking people to remain one meter apart. The lack of social distancing left many stunned.

column1: It is as if Coronavirus has passed?"" wrote former British No. 1 Greg Rusedski on Twitter two days later. ""How was this managed and why no concern for public social distancing and face masks. I know the figures in Serbia but why are they able to do this?""
The seemingly carefree nature of the event
column2: which came a few days after a 20
column3: 000-strong crowd attended a soccer match in Belgrade
column4: also surprised Crow
column5: a former chief executive of London-based sports marketing agency Synergy.

column1: It was a screw-up
column2: he said. ""As soon as you turned the TV on
column3: you think
column4: 'Hang on a second
column5: what's going on here?' And unfortunately
column6: we all know what happened.""

column1: Also during that weekend
column2: players including Djokovic
column3: Thiem
column4: Zverev and Dimitrov were filmed dancing in a packed Belgrade nightclub.

column1: Behind closed doors
The limited social distancing at the Adria Tour was in sharp contrast to other exhibition events during the pandemic in the US
column2: Germany
column3: Britain and France
column4: which were all held behind closed doors.

column1: When Patrick Mouratoglou
column2: Serena Williams' long-time coach
column3: wanted to host an event at his academy in the south of France during the lockdown
column4: he reached out to the government. It sent him a long list of protocols
column5: which he has implemented in his Ultimate Tennis Showdown series.

column1: I wanted to make sure to do it in a way where no one is at risk
column2: Mouratoglou told CNN Sport in a phone interview on Friday.

column1: These include all players being tested the day before each weekend's matches
column2: no fans
column3: no handshakes or ball-sharing between players
column4: ball kids wearing gloves and masks and ample distance between every seat in the players' box.

column1: Speaking at the ceremonial opening of the Adria Tour the day before his match against Troicki
column2: Djokovic defended the limited social distancing of the crowd.

column1: He emphasized Serbia had ""better numbers"" compared with other countries. According to the Johns Hopkins Coronavirus Resource Center
column2: Serbia has had 13
column3: 372 confirmed cases
column4: including 264 deaths. Neighboring Croatia had registered 2
column5: 483 cases
column6: including 107 deaths.

column1: You can also criticize us and say this is maybe dangerous but it's not up to me to make calls about what is right and wrong for health
column2: Djokovic added. ""We are doing what the Serbian government is telling us.""

column1: Spectators watching matches at the Adria Tour in Zahar
column2: Croatia on Sunday June 21
column3: 2020. Later that day
column4: tennis player Grigor Dimitrov said he had tested positive for Covid-19
column5: leading to the cancellation of the entire Adria Tour.

column1: Dimitrov's bombshell
The next leg of the Adria Tour on June 20-21 once again attracted thousands of spectators
column2: including Croatia Prime Minister Andrej Plenković
column3: who briefly met Djokovic. Because Croatia had eased its lockdown measures before the event
column4: players and fans didn't have to stick to social distancing rules.

column1: Then came the bombshell announcement by Dimitrov on Sunday June 21 that he had tested positive for coronavirus.
The organizers swiftly canceled the entire series
column2: while most of the other players were tested the same night. Then
column3: on Monday
column4: Croatia's Borna Coric confirmed he too had tested positive
column5: while Zverev
column6: former US Open winner Marin Cilic of Croatia and Russia's Andrey Rublev all tested negative but promised to self-isolate for 14 days as a precaution.

column1: Spectators watch a tennis match during an exhibition tournament in Zadar
column2: Croatia
column3: Sunday
column4: June 21

column1: Troicki revealed he had tested positive soon after and then
column2: on Tuesday
column3: Djokovic confirmed that he
column4: too
column5: and his wife
column6: Jelena
column7: had done the same. Troicki's pregnant wife

column1: I was walking through the house and through the garage. And then
column2: for example

column1: We really
column2: really enjoyed it because we had a rhythm

Wibmer balances on the outside of a window of his house.

For a guy like me

column1: https://edition.cnn.com/2020/05/14/sport/jimmy-chin-free-solo-national-geographic-cmd-spt-intl/index.html/Free Solo: Oscar-winning director Jimmy Chin on risking it all for the perfect shot/"(CNN) Having survived an avalanche and been tested in some of the most remote places on earth
column2: Jimmy Chin knows what it's like to be at the mercy of mother nature.

column1: The renowned adventurer and filmmaker has spent the past 20 years traveling the world
column2: pushing himself to conquer one historic challenge after another
column3: and engaging in the sort of daring activities that would be beyond many people's imaginations.

column1: Whether it's climbing Everest or filming the Oscar-winning Free Solo
column2: the 46-year-old has captured the full extent of human endeavor.

column1: When you're pushing for cutting-edge expeditions
column2: you're often in close proximity to potential disaster
column3: he told CNN Sport. ""You're constantly managing risk and you're in fairly serious situations all the time
column4: so your senses are very sharpened.""

column1: But Chin's intrepid way of life has been put on hold as the world comes to grips with the coronavirus pandemic. To a certain degree
column2: his past expeditions have readied him for such uncertain times and
column3: he said
column4: he hoped others could learn from his experiences.

column1: This is a moment to pause
column2: reevaluate and think about what's important
column3: he added.

column1: Jimmy Chin has photographed all around the world.
Early years
As a film director and National Geographic photographer
column2: Chin has assembled a world-class portfolio of work. This year he returned from a trip to Antarctica
column3: where he and a team of adventurers skied two new routes down the tallest and second-tallest peaks on the continent.

column1: But such a life wasn't always the plan.
As a child growing up in rural Minnesota
column2: Chin was encouraged to pursue more traditional aspirations: excelling academically
column3: as well as in martial arts and as a competitive swimmer.

column1: But it was skiing on a small hill behind his house that he found freedom. ""If I did well in everything else
column2: I got to ski
column3: he said.

column1: Already with a taste for the world of outdoor sports
column2: Chin was introduced to climbing at college. At that point
column3: he said
column4: it was game over as the sport became a vehicle to see the world and explore places that made his ""heart sing.""

column1: He moved to Yosemite National Park where he worked odd jobs to fund his nomadic lifestyle
column2: eventually picking up a camera and starting to shoot.

column1: I have so many incredible photographer friends who had a really noble vision for being an artist with their photography
column2: he laughed.

column1: But my whole entry into it was just 'if I take these photos and I sell them I can make a little money so I can keep climbing.'""
His adventures have often involved very high stakes.
Chin climbing up the Pacific on El Capitain in Yosemite
column2: US.

column1: Capturing the impossible
Since he himself is a professional climber
column2: Chin's photography services have been that much more in demand over the years
column3: with the relationship between him and his subjects an important element of his success.

column1: If they're going to be doing this thing
column2: and you're the only one documenting
column3: they've got to trust that you're going to get it
column4: he said. ""Then I have to trust that the athlete isn't just doing it for the camera.""

column1: Such a collaboration was put to the ultimate test in perhaps his finest
column2: and most daring
column3: work to date.

column1: Alongside his wife Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi
column2: Chin documented Alex Honnold's astonishing free solo climb up El Capitan in 2017.

column1: Chin assembled a team of world-class climbers to help film Honnold ascend the 3
column2: 200-foot vertical rock face without a single safety rope.

column1: Working together
column2: they plotted where the cameras would be positioned on the wall so as to not distract Honnold on the day.

column1: The historic feat won the team an Academy Award for Best Documentary at a ceremony that will live long in Chin's memory.
My confidence in Alex [Honnold] and his capacity to execute was very
column2: very high
column3: said Chin
column4: who had known Honnold for around 10 years before his death-defying ascent.

column1: I had seen him in very difficult situations before
column2: completely unfazed
column3: and I also knew that he's the most calculated person I know. He's not going to go do it if he's not ready.""

column1: Dealing with fear
Despite his years of experience
column2: Chin said watching his friend train for and complete the climb was an ordeal.

column1: The fear was less acute than I think people might have perceived; it was more of a long-term dread
column2: he said
column3: now able to laugh at the thought.

column1: I felt like it was on my shoulders for almost three years
column2: from when we conceived of the project to filming it with him.

column1: Every day
column2: whether he was free-soloing or not
column3: there's a potential for somebody to get hurt or die because you're in these environments.""

column1: Dealing with uncertainty is an occupational hazard for Chin and although meticulous planning can help iron out some of the danger
column2: managing fear itself is essential to coping with the unexpected. Remaining calm
column3: avoiding emotional decisions
column4: can often be the difference between life and death.

column1: You have [to] step outside of yourself and be objective about a situation and make very objective decisions
column2: he said.

column1: Chin has embarked on climbing and skiing adventures.
Chin ascending a fixed line to the top of the Visor on Half Dome in Yosemite
column2: US.

column1: Lockdown lessons
Though still working at home on a number of projects
column2: it has taken a once-in-a-century event like the global pandemic to finally slow Chin down. He is now at least able to enjoy time with his young family.

column1: I'm just out in the yard playing with the kids
column2: usually a rarity for me
column3: he said
column4: acknowledging these were the most consecutive days he'd spent with his four-and six-year-old children.

column1: I don't get that much time to hang out with them so I've been running around the yard and having fun.""
Living in a rural area means Chin is able to leave his house while still abiding by social distancing guidelines
column2: a must for someone whose mental and physical well-being is ""tied"" to going into the wilderness.

column1: He is a man who
column2: in more ordinary times
column3: usually searches for solitude
column4: reveling in having time to think and ask existential questions. ""It's good to think about them
column5: he said.

column1: It is not the sort of life many would choose
column2: Chin admitted
column3: but he hoped people in lockdown could learn from his experiences.

column1: Those are the kinds of experiences that I go and seek and now there's an opportunity for people to do that. Take this moment."""/['Ben Church'

column1: https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/25/football/jurgen-klopp-liverpool-premier-league-title-spt-int/index.html/Jurgen Klopp: How the charismatic manager turned Liverpool into title winners/"(CNN) After 30 years of waiting
column2: Liverpool are once again England's dominant team . The champions of Europe are now English Premier League winners
column3: guided to the summit by their gregarious German manager
column4: the bespectacled man-hugger extraordinaire who has captivated the city and the club.

column1: Liverpool's transformation has been extraordinary. Few thought that the club which once ruled English football for such a prolonged period that it became dynastic would ever again wear the crown. Decades of disappointment and false hope had lowered expectations. Even optimists had become skeptics. By the time Jurgen Klopp took charge
column2: the empire had long since fallen

column1: When Klopp succeeded Brendan Rodgers as Liverpool boss in October 2015
column2: the team was 10th in the table and had been thumped 3-0 at home by West Ham that season. Twenty-five years had gone by since the club last won a league title and another championship felt as elusive as the unicorn.

column1: The scars of almost winning the title in 2014 had not healed and key members of that team were gone. Steven Gerrard had moved to Los Angeles
column2: Luis Suarez to Barcelona

column1: But the charismatic German with the extra-large personality promised change and raised the decibels. Though it has taken him five years to win English football's biggest prize
column2: Klopp's impact on Liverpool was immediate.

column1: We have to change from doubters to believers. Now
column2: were his striking words in his first interview as the club's new manager. Even before he had overseen his first match
column3: his charm and positivity gave weary fans hope.

column1: Klopp is unveiled as Liverpool's new manager during a press conference at Anfield on October 9
The man from the Black Forest was held in higher esteem than the Liverpool players he had inherited. Having taken over Borussia Dortmund when the club was mid-table and financially hampered
column2: he had twice guided the club to the Bundesliga title
column3: including a league and cup double in the 2011-12 season.

column1: His then new tactics of high
column2: concentrated pressing all over the pitch had not only turned Dortmund into winners
column3: but had gained admirers all over the world.

column1: When he signed
column2: all the fellas from work
column3: we couldn't believe it
column4: because he was bigger than the club at the time
column5: he was bigger and more well-known than any player we had
column6: Dan Fieldsend
column7: author of ""Local: a club and its city. Liverpool's social history
column8: tells CNN Sport.

column1: His words were perfect
column2: like poetry. This is a city of dreamers. So
column3: when he [Klopp] said my aim is to get Liverpool to the top of the table in five years and to win a trophy in three years
column4: that was just everything we'd longed to hear for a long time.

column1: Klopp was more far-sighted than even the fans at the time. The board as well
column2: they had a vision. That philosophy of never accepting second best
column3: we had kind of forgotten as a fanbase.""

column1: Klopp is tossed in the air by his players after winning the league title at the end of the Bundesliga match between Dortmund and FC Nuernberg on April 30
Despite his passion
column2: his words and his past successes
column3: the task before Klopp was Herculean. The opposition was extraordinarily wealthy
column4: and better than his team. There were also question marks over whether Klopp's high-octane tactics could succeed in a league where there was no winter break.

column1: Liverpool's was a squad which clearly needed to improve
column2: but In Klopp's first game in charge
column3: against Tottenham
column4: the team at least played with more energy -- running further than they had in any other match that season -- and there was one detail he could quickly affect
column5: regardless of the personnel at his disposal: the Anfield atmosphere.

column1: The man who can gesticulate as wildly on the sidelines as a broken windmill in a storm sought first to energize the supporters.
Sometimes
column2: he almost challenges the fans
column3: John Gibbons
column4: contributor to the podcast Anfield Wrap
column5: tells CNN. ""He's probably told us off more than any other Liverpool manager. He's headmastery in a way
column6: but he's a headmaster you want to please.""

column1: It was after a 2-1 home defeat to Crystal Palace
column2: his first loss as Liverpool boss
column3: that Klopp told the assembled media that he felt ""pretty alone"" at the sight of Liverpool fans leaving after Palace's 82nd-minute winner.

column1: A month later
column2: following an inauspicious 2-2 draw with West Brom
column3: Klopp and his players saluted the Anfield crowd
column4: which garnered some sneering from observers unable to fathom why scrambling a draw to lowly West Brom was worth celebrating. Klopp would reveal that he wanted to thank the fans for the ""best atmosphere since I came here.""

column1: He got stick for it
column2: says Gibbons of that West Brom celebration. ""But he was saying to the Kop 'this is what happens when we all stick to together
column3: the players will keep going if you do.'

column1: There's something about him that you trust. He's a leader and he'd be a leader in whatever he decided to do. He could run a bank and he'd be brilliant.""
Klopp (2L) leads his players in saluting the crowd after drawing against West Bromwich Albion at Anfield on December 13
It was Christian Heidel's gut instinct which launched a career which now not only consists of Bundesliga titles and a Champions League trophy
column2: but a historic Premier League title
column3: too.

column1: With Mainz desperate not to drop to the third tier of German football
column2: in February 2001 Heidel
column3: the club's then sporting director
column4: offered Klopp the chance to go from player to coach. Klopp was studying for a degree in sports business at Goethe University when he secured his first full-time contract as a player
column5: aged 23 at Mainz
column6: but had no managerial experience.

column1: Heidel has since said it was a decision ""made with the stomach and not the head."" Klopp was not the captain of the team but was
column2: said Heidel
column3: its ""emotional leader.""

column1: Eight weeks into the job
column2: Klopp had secured Mainz's safety and
column3: in the years that followed
column4: took the club and its fans on an unforgettable journey
column5: culminating in promotion to the Bundesliga for the first time in the club's history.

column1: Klopp celebrates promotion as Mainz manager.
Several influences shaped Klopp: his mentor Wolfgang Franks
column2: the late Mainz coach
column3: whose tactical path Klopp followed; his father Norbert
column4: a traveling salesman and former amateur goalkeeper
column5: who instilled in him a love of sport
column6: while his Mainz teammates are said to have upheld his belief that hard work and intelligence can compensate for a lack of skill.

column1: In Raphael Honigstein's book ""Klopp Bring The Noise
column2: Peter Krawietz
column3: Klopp's second assistant coach at Liverpool
column4: said Klopp learned an ""incredible amount about the thing that make a football team tick"" at Mainz.

column1: He's taken all these years in the dressing room
column2: reflected on them and found that many things can be sorted with a bit of common sense. He has a feel for the situation
column3: for saying the right thing at the right moment in the right manner
column4: said Krawietz.

column1: It was his captivating manner which made him a successful football analyst for German broadcaster ZDF during the 2006 World Cup in his home country. Still a second division coach and someone who had not won a significant trophy as either player or manager
column2: he nevertheless connected with the audience.

column1: Lutz Pfannenstiel
column2: analyst for ZDF for the 2010 World Cup
column3: has shared a television studio with Klopp and is not surprised his former colleague has become a success in England.

column1: He's extremely passionate
column2: extremely direct
column3: extremely funny
column4: Pfannenstiel
column5: sporting director at Fortuna Dusseldorf
column6: tells CNN Sport. ""He's obviously very emotional but when he talks about football he doesn't try to be a smart-arse. He always says it how it is
column7: what you see is what you get. He has that unbelievable skill to motivate people.

column1: He's the exact opposite of arrogant. He's like a general. In the film ""Gladiator
column2: whenever the guy put up his sword and said
column3: 'we're going to a war now
column4: ' they would just blindly follow him. That's somehow what he is without a sword.""

column1: There is a German word for people like Klopp: Menschenfanger
column2: someone who can talk people into doing things they themselves did not feel possible. It is why players take to heart his all-or-nothing approach and why fans would no longer countenance giving up on the team if they needed an improbable number of goals in the dying minutes of a match.

column1: Everyone likes being told they're important and Jurgen is really good at that. He tells the players how brilliant they are but also us
column2: so you turn up at Anfield feeling like you're a participant
column3: says Gibbons.

column1: Klopp celebrates with the Champions League trophy at Estadio Wanda Metropolitano on June 1
I give everything. I expect my players to give everything. Then we see what we get. That creates the mentality of the team
column2: said Klopp in a recent interview.

column1: Klopp has been given time and the funds to succeed at Anfield
column2: and the fans were patient because they had faith.

column1: Though Liverpool did not instantly challenge for the league under him -- in his first season the team finished eighth -- each year there was progress; in the players bought
column2: in the manner they played and in league positions: eighth
column3: fourth
column4: fourth
column5: second
column6: first.

column1: There has been some angst -- Klopp lost three finals with Liverpool before winning the Champions League last year
column2: his first silverware as Liverpool manager. And when Liverpool missed out on the title last season by a point there were those who wondered whether Klopp and his team could rebound from such agonizing failure.

column1: The team's response was emphatic and a 30-year wait has been ended by a commanding margin. The man who gives everything asked his players and fans to match his mentality and everyone has reaped the rewards."/['Aimee Lewis']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://cdn.cnn.com/cnnnext/dam/assets/200625115534-klopp-tease-super-tease.jpg"

https://edition.cnn.com/2020/06/23/tennis/bianca-andreescu-us-open-2020-spt-intl/index.html/US Open champion Bianca Andreescu wants to 'surpass Serena'/"(CNN) Tennis star Bianca Andreescu says she hopes to one day surpass the greatest players of all-time as she prepares to defend her title at this year's US Open.

The 20-year-old became Canada's first-ever grand slam singles champion when she defeated Serena Williams in straight sets at Flushing Meadows last year but the youngster is far from content with her achievements to date.
Her aim is simple: To be the best in the world and to break records in the process.
I want to surpass Serena [Williams] and her wins. Maybe even Chrissy Evert
column2: who knows? Margaret Court
column3: she told CNN Sport.

column1: I like to dream big; it gives me more motivation to actually step on the court and continue doing what I'm doing.""
Andreescu celebrates during the US Open in 2019.
On being the best
The youngster has quite some way to go before reaching the levels of Evert
column2: Williams and Court -- who have 18
column3: 23 and 24 titles respectively -- but her US Open win last year showed she's on the right track.

column1: The pressure that follows such a triumph sits comfortably on such young shoulders. After all
column2: as she says
column3: she delivers her best under pressure.

column1: Everything I do
column2: I always give 150% and I always want to be the best at it
column3: she said. ""For my tennis career I put in so much effort and sacrificed a lot
column4: so I want to be the best.

column1: Surpassing those players would make me the best but whatever God has in store for me.""
Andreescu reacts after beating Serena Williams in the US Open final.

column2: Andreescu has been out of action for a number of weeks with tennis postponed amid the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: However
column2: with restrictions beginning to ease across North America
column3: this year's US Open is scheduled to begin on August 31
column4: and the Canadian is desperate to defend her title.

column1: Many high-profile players have raised concerns about staging the event so soon but Andreescu is confident the tournament will be safe behind closed doors.
I actually didn't think tennis would come back so soon just because it's such an international sport but
column2: honestly
column3: I'm just super happy to go back there and hopefully defend my title
column4: she said.

column1: I know everyone involved is going to do their best to keep everyone as safe as possible. Just looking at all the other sports
column2: I think it's time for tennis to come back.""

US Open 2020
Although tennis will be back
column2: it promises to look very different.

column1: Perhaps the biggest change will be the lack of spectators in the stands
column2: something which Andreescu knows will take some getting used to.

column1: Fans played a huge part in her winning her maiden grand slam in 2019
column2: with the majority of the crowd supporting Williams on the night.

column1: As it turned out
column2: the partisan reception was all the motivation she needed.

column1: Playing in front of the crowd just brings the hype into everything. I would say I perform really good under pressure so I felt the crowd gave me a push
column2: she said
column3: adding that this year's tournament will feel very different.

column1: There will definitely be people watching at home so it would be good to keep that in the back of our minds.""
Andreescu is looking forward to defending her US Open title this year.
Last week
column2: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced that ""extraordinary precautions"" would be in place to ensure safety at the tournament
column3: including ""robust testing
column4: additional cleaning
column5: extra locker room space
column6: and dedicated housing and transportation.""

column1: However
column2: ensuring families were able to travel with players throughout the entirety of the tournament was a major factor in players agreeing to the plans
column3: according to WTA President Micky Lawler.

column1: Coming over would have been a big commitment because you're here for three to four weeks. So being here with just one person was a non-starter for people with families

column1: It was the last goal scored at that World Cup -- the fourth in a 4-1 hammering of Italy in the final -- and one that epitomized the Joga Bonito (Play Beautifully) mantra that Brazil had long been synonymous with.

We won the World Cup and I think in my life in sport

column1: It would be fair to say his prayers were answered.

column1: It was perhaps also a victory for those we would today refer to as 'football purists'; Brazil's Jogo Bonito against Italy's catenaccio

The tournament appeals by both providing live competition under current social distancing rules

column2: eight Soviet women climbers were pinned on top of a high mountain in the USSR in the worst storm in 25 years.

column1: It was June 1974. The Cold War was verging on détente

column1: Some 170 climbers from 10 Western countries occupied a huge mountaineering camp
column2: with another 60 Eastern European and Russian climbers and officials across a stream.

column1: This was the first major American expedition allowed in the Soviet Union
column2: which has some of the highest and most remote mountains in the world. The gathering was held to showcase the region and the skills of the host climbers and
column3: it seemed
column4: develop relationships with Cold War rivals. It was seen as a means to bring up young mountaineers and foster mountaineering relations between countries.

column1: Elvira Shatayeva and the Russian women made final preparations for Peak Lenin climb. July 30 - The Russian women’s team left Base Camp for Camp I. July 31 - The team took the Lipkin route and proceeded toward the summit without any problems. On August 3
column2: Shatayeva called a rest day. August 3 – An American team of climbers behind the Russian women reported: “Cloudy weather today and we have route-finding problems getting over to Camp III in whiteout conditions.” August 4 - A major storm was forecast
column3: and organizers recommended all climbers descend. The Russian women were seen walking in a line perhaps 400 feet below the summit. August 5 - The Russian women’s team radioed from the summit. August 6 - The women tried to descend but only managed a few hundred feet. Speaking to base then and August 7
column4: they reported their struggles. Their final transmission came through at 20:30. August 8 - The storm was over. From their final camp
column5: located about 400 meters below the summit
column6: the American team set out for the summit with no idea of the events that had occurred above.

column5: during the off season

column1: But a picture posted on Facebook last year of Harris playing for her team Carlton Blues elevated the then 21-year-old beyond the world of sport. She became one of the most talked-about sportswomen on the planet.
First came the vile messages
column2: and they came thick and fast -- sexist
column3: disturbing and damaging comments posted below a now iconic picture of Harris doing her job.

column4: to voice their support. She had stood up and spoken out. It changed her world.

column1: With one tweet Harris had made a lasting impression in the usually transitory world of social media

column1: If my example is going to help someone in any way
column2: I would be happy to go through it all again. I'd rather not

column1: To understand Harris' inner strength

column7: significantly

column1: Such spirit helped Harris -- who played Aussie Rules with boys until she was told to stop aged 14 -- rise to an elite athlete in two sports. She is unbeaten in seven professional fight and holds the Australian middleweight crown.
Yet like most women in sport

He said 'why do you care what someone who you've never met and will probably never meet and have never done anything for you in your life think' so

Even before that kick was immortalized in bronze in Melbourne's bustling Federation Square
