column1: https://edition.cnn.com/interactive/2019/06/sport/antisemitism-soccer-chelsea-spt-intl//‘My father buried his parents and sister with his bare hands... he had to dig the grave himself.’/"How one soccer club is helping educate fans on the horrors of the Holocaust
Anti-Semitism ‘My father buried his parents and sister with his bare hands... he had to dig the grave himself.’
(CNN) — Avram Grant remembers the screaming.
It came nearly 50 years ago when Grant
column2: then a teenager
column3: first fully began to grasp the horrors that his father
column4: Meir
column5: had been forced to endure during the Holocaust.

column1: “When I was 15 years old
column2: I was sitting on the balcony of my home with my friend and I heard screaming and shouting
column3: ” Grant
column4: the former Chelsea coach
column5: told CNN.

column1: Avram Grant visiting the Jewish Quarter in Krakow
column2: Poland. (Photo: Chelsea FC)

column1: “I had never heard anything like this
column2: not even in Hitchcock movies
column3: ” adds Grant
column4: referring to the legendary filmmaker.

column1: “It was a shock for me. My father was shouting
column2: I will never forget it. I said to my mum: ‘Mum
column3: what is happening?’ I saw she was very calm and she touched him and he went back to sleep.

column1: “I remember this day because I took a decision to realize how from this hell came such an optimistic and happy guy. I am telling you that I will never forget it.”

column2: Grant’s father fled Nazi-occupied Poland at the age of 13 along with the rest of his family before being exiled in northern Russia
column3: where temperatures plunged to minus 40 degrees Celsius. Only Meir and his brother survived.

column1: “My father buried his parents and sister with his bare hands … he had to dig the grave himself
column2: ” Grant said.

column1: “He was 13. This was all because of hatred. That’s why I am always here to speak about it. Always.”
Grant is not only committed to telling his father’s story
column2: but also to educating the next generation. That’s why he has embraced a campaign led by Chelsea
column3: the club he once managed
column4: aimed at eradicating anti-Semitism from soccer and society.

column1: “When you get to my age
column2: you realize there will be nobody left to tell the younger generation firsthand what happened. That’s why it is so important because we are coming to the end of the Holocaust survivor era.”

column1: Grant’s reservations appear well placed.
Lack of Holocaust knowledge
The results of CNN’s 2018 investigation into anti-Semitism in Europe unearthed a number of shocking statistics on the subject of Holocaust education
column2: with a third of Europeans in the poll saying they knew just a little or nothing at all about the Nazis systematic killing of six million Jews.

column1: The outlook was similarly bleak in the US.
Avram Grant talks to a group of youngsters about his family’s experiences during the Holocaust. (Photo: Chelsea)
A survey carried out on behalf of the Claims Conference in 2018 found that 11% of American adults were not sure they’d ever heard of the Holocaust
column2: rising to one in five millennials. Nearly half of the millennials surveyed could not name a single concentration camp
column3: and 45% of the American adults questioned failed to do so.

column1: In early May
column2: Grant led a delegation from Chelsea and MLS team New England Revolution to take part in “March of the Living
column3: ” in which participants were taken on a guided tour of Auschwitz and learned about the systematic mass murder of Europe’s Jewish communities.

column1: The visit was part of Chelsea’s highly respected “Say No to Anti-Semitism” campaign
column2: which was launched in January 2018 under the leadership of club owner Roman Abramovich.

column1: It was in November 2017 that Abramovich
column2: who is Jewish
column3: began discussions with the club’s board about a concerted campaign to fight anti-Semitism.

column1: He was perturbed by the number of anti-Semitic incidents that had taken place across Europe and was eager to take a stand.
It was also an opportunity to educate the club’s supporters on a subject that those who watched the team in the 1970s and 1980s would have been all too aware of
column2: given the anti-Semitic songs and chants that used to be heard at games.

column1: Auschwitz chants
Ivor Baddiel
column2: a Jewish Chelsea supporter
column3: said he stopped attending games temporarily in the 1970s after hearing chants of “Sieg Heil” from a section of fellow supporters and seeing anti-Semitic literature sold outside the stadium.

column1: Particularly vivid are his memories from games against Tottenham
column2: one of Chelsea’s London rivals
column3: that historically has a large following from the Jewish community.

column1: Baddiel says Tottenham fans were often targeted by anti-Semitic abuse with songs such as “Spurs are on their way to Auschwitz” and hissing noises mimicking the sound of the gas chambers used by the Nazis during the Holocaust.
Tottenham fans at the 2019 Champions League final in Madrid. (Photo: Clive Rose/Getty Images)
Baddiel also recalls the first time he heard the word “Yid
column2: ” a derogatory word for Jew
column3: at a game. At the time
column4: the word was also being used by Tottenham supporters
column5: who wanted to reclaim the word from the racists
column6: and instead
column7: in their view
column8: wear it as a badge of honor.

column1: Even today
column2: some Tottenham supporters refer to themselves as ‘“Yiddos” and the “Yid Army
column3: ” despite calls from Jewish groups to stop.

column1: Though shocked by the nature of the anti-Semitic abuse
column2: Baddiel
column3: later resumed attending games.

column1: He has made two videos on anti-Semitism
column2: one focusing specifically on the “Y-word” and the other for Chelsea’s current campaign
column3: both of which he hopes will help educate the public.

column1: “Absurd as it sounds
column2: those guys in the pub who are singing
column3: ‘Spurs are on their way to Auschwitz
column4: ’ I think you could even question whether they realize they are being anti-Semitic
column5: ” Baddiel said.

column1: “They think they’re being anti-Tottenham.
“I think a lot of people didn’t know it was a racist word for Jews and just thought it was about Tottenham fans.”
Fighting back
Today
column2: Chelsea is one of the most proactive sporting organizations in tackling anti-Semitism
column3: and its “Say No to Anti-Semitism” campaign has already won praise from both inside and outside football.

column1: A delegation from Chelsea visits Auschwitz-Birkenau. (Photo: Chelsea FC)
The club has taken supporters to Auschwitz-Birkenau to educate them about the horrors of the Holocaust
column2: has invited survivors to speak to players and staff about their experiences
column3: and is raising money to help fund a new Holocaust exhibition at London’s Imperial War Museum.

column1: Neil Beard
column2: a Chelsea supporter who attended his first game in 1970
column3: believes the club has helped fans become better equipped to fight against anti-Semitism by providing educational programs and taking them on trips to concentration camps.

column1: Beard
column2: who visited Auschwitz last year with his two teenage children
column3: and also attended a talk by a Holocaust survivor organized by the club in London
column4: says the work Chelsea is doing is having a hugely positive effect.

column1: “I feel we came back as advocates ready to tackle anti-Semitism
column2: particularly where it’s done casually and through ignorance and people think it’s funny
column3: ” Beard told CNN.

column1: “It’s not funny. We really need to take it seriously. It’s obviously a global issue with the rise of fascism but as Chelsea supporters and for the club I think we’ve come a long way because it’s now unacceptable and embarrassing among Chelsea supporters to sing some of the songs that were sung during the 1980s
column2: 1990s and even up to today.

column1: “Listening to a survivor had a huge impact on me
column2: trying to imagine yourself in that position and that was harrowing to think you could have found yourself there in that kind of hell. It was so powerful.”

column1: Chelsea’s David Luiz takes a selfie with students at Fuller Middle School in Framingham during the US trip. (Photo: Chelsea FC)

The Chelsea Foundation runs equality training workshops in 75 schools across the UK and ran sessions for hundreds of children in the lead-up to the team’s arrival in Boston for the club’s game against New England Revolution in a contest arranged to raise money for groups tackling anti-Semitism and discrimination.
Bruce Buck
column2: Chelsea’s chairman
column3: insists that while instances of anti-Semitism at the club’s games remain a “very small problem but an important problem” compared to 30 years ago
column4: there will be no letup in the fight against Jew hatred.

column1: He cites the training of stewards in identifying anti-Semitic behavior and the use of CCTV as key aides in tracking down those responsible.
“We’ve come a long way
column2: society has come a long way
column3: but there’s still a problem and I don’t underestimate the problem
column4: ” Buck told CNN.

column1: “We are only dealing with the overt incidents and not dealing with those behind the screen and that’s where the other aspect I think of our project
column2: the education part
column3: dealing with that
column4: trying to deal with what’s below the surface.”

column1: Chelsea has cracked down on instances of racism by its fans already this season. Four fans were suspended for appearing to racially abuse Manchester City’s Raheem Sterling last December
column2: while three supporters were barred from entering a Europa League game against Slavia Prague after a video on social media allegedly showed them abusing Liverpool’s Egyptian forward Mohamed Salah.

column1: “We all understand the power of football
column2: the reach of football
column3: it’s extraordinary
column4: ” Buck added. “As an American
column5: we think of ourselves as the biggest sports fans in the world and maybe we are
column6: but we don’t have the attachment to our club that you do in the UK which is cradle to grave
column7: whichever club your father supports
column8: you support
column9: and it’s unique. I think it’s true in continental Europe too. So that attachment gives them a loyalty and gives us an opportunity to education.”

column1: 'Could take an entire generation to correct properly'
Chelsea’s work has already been commended by sections of the local Jewish Community as well as UK Chief Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis.
Chelsea’s players visit the Holocaust memorial in the US city of Boston. (Photo: Chelsea FC)
Mirvis believes the role of education
column2: which Chelsea is keen to emphasize as part of its strategy
column3: is key to tackling anti-Semitism though he concedes there is no quick fix. “It could take an entire generation to correct properly
column4: ” he told CNN of the fight against anti-Semitism.

column1: “Chelsea is leading the field here and it’s huge congratulations to them. I think the most significant thing Chelsea has done is to acknowledge that there is a problem. That’s very much to their credit. They have taken some concrete and constructive steps.
“It’s an enormous challenge. I think education
column2: the concept
column3: needs to be repeated again and again
column4: together with genuine attempts. Our problem is that we are playing catch up when we are dealing with adults who are already in the stadium. They’ve been conditioned to some degree by their society to think in a certain way and find certain elements of conduct within their comfort zone.”

column1: “When you are talking about changing opinions you need thought leaders
column2: you need influencers.”

column1: Karen Pollock
column2: head of the Holocaust Educational Trust in London
column3: told CNN it had been “humbling” to see Chelsea committing itself to fighting anti-Semitism with direction coming from the very top of the club and being embraced by staff and players alike.

column1: “Footballers are role models for so many and their words and actions have such an impact
column2: ” Pollock said.

column1: “Their positive message of inclusion and tolerance is vital in tackling prejudice and hate.”
Pittsburgh
For Chelsea
column2: its arrival in the US could scarcely have been more timely.

column1: An annual report published in May by the Anti-Defamation League found that anti-Semitic incidents in the US remained near historic levels in 2018 after surging the previous year.
According to the latest figures from the ADL
column2: 2018 was the third-highest year on record for assault
column3: harassment and vandalism against Jews since it began tracking such incidents in 1979.

column1: There were a total of 1
column2: 879 attacks against Jews and Jewish institutions across the country
column3: according to the report. This includes the 11 people killed during the October 2018 mass shooting at the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh
column4: believed to be the deadliest attack on the Jewish community in the history of the US.

column1: These numbers are down slightly from the 1
column2: 986 anti-Semitic incidents in 2017
column3: the ADL said.

column1: Chelsea played New England Revolution in the US at Boston's Gillette Stadium. (Photo: Chelsea FC)

The decision to visit the US last month and hold a charity match against New England Revolution was made in the aftermath of the Pittsburgh attack. Both Abramovich and Revolution owner Robert Kraft had already expressed their desire to work with one another on tackling anti-Semitism
column2: but according to Buck
column3: Pittsburgh was the catalyst for the charity match.

column1: Both Abramovich and Kraft pledged to donate $1 million to the charity fund
column2: with a further $2 million being raised through gate receipts. The $4 million pot will be split between 15 different organizations tackling anti-Semitism and discrimination including the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh.

column1: 'Heroes'
Elan Carr
column2: the US special envoy for monitoring and combating anti-Semitism
column3: told CNN that while the attack in Pittsburgh and one at a synagogue in Poway
column4: California
column5: have recently left the Jewish community on edge
column6: programs such as the one deployed by Chelsea and New England Revolution could play a key part in educating future generations on the dangers of anti-Semitism.

column1: Chelsea’s David Luiz talks to students at Fuller middle school in Framingham in the US. (Photo: Chelsea FC)
“When you are talking about changing opinions you need thought leaders
column2: you need influencers – and athletes are influencers in a way no one else can be. These guys are heroes to kids from rural farmlands to cities
column3: they are adored and worshipped. To have athletes who are so influential stand up and fight for decency and justice
column4: and take positions and say ‘no’ to this scourge of anti-Semitism
column5: a human sickness
column6: and for athletes to say that is unacceptable
column7: that is a game changer
column8: ” Carr told CNN.

column1: “This example of what is happening and what Chelsea and New England are doing is a model that can truly change the world
column2: ” he added.

column1: 'Big power'
Such a responsibility is not lost on the players. Born in Brazil to parents who both worked as teachers
column2: defender David Luiz told CNN that the morals instilled in him during his childhood have helped him become more aware of discrimination within society.

column1: David Luiz on racism in football 2:22
“Football has big
column2: big power to do it and we have to use it in the right way
column3: ” Luiz told CNN of the sport’s role in bringing about positive social change.

column1: “I think we are examples for many people around the world and we have to use this power in the right way to make the real difference.
“If you go to the maternity unit you don’t see one baby with a bad vibe. The babies are good
column2: they are cute. It’s the pollution of the world and the system that makes people think in different ways.”

column1: Luiz was part of the squad that visited the New England Holocaust memorial in Boston and also took part in education workshops with local schoolchildren.
On the final day of the tour
column2: he played a part in Chelsea’s 3-0 win at Gillette Stadium with 25
column3: 000 fans lending their support to the game dubbed “Final Whistle on Hate.”

column1: Abramovich flew to Boston to watch the game alongside Kraft and visited the locker room afterward.
'I will keep speaking'
For Grant
column2: it was the final event of a trip that had brought the scourge of anti-Semitism to the forefront of the sporting agenda and gave hope to those working to tackle it each and every day.

column1: Avram Grant led Chelsea to the 2008 Champions League final. (Photo: Franck Fife/AFP/Getty Images)
But what would his father
column2: who passed away at the age of 82 in October 2009
column3: say?

column1: “You know
column2: if my father was alive now he would say: ‘Why are you living in the past?’

column1: “I would say to him that I’m not living in the past
column2: I want to know about the past so that it will not happen again."/['James Masters']//"https://cdn.cnn.com/cnn/interactive/2019/06/sport/antisemitism-soccer-chelsea-spt-intl/media/images/card.jpg"

column1: https://edition.cnn.com/2019/05/04/sport/hoop-dreams-25th-anniversary-spt-intl/index.html/"NBA: ""Hoop Dreams"" basketball documentary still relevant in 25th year"/"(CNN) When Dwyane Wade was a 12-year-old shooting jumpers on the playgrounds of Chicago
column2: a movie came out that would help navigate him through his future Hall of Fame career.

column1: Released in 1994
column2: ""Hoop Dreams"" shadowed the bumpy fortunes of Arthur Agee and William Gates
column3: two inner-city Chicago youths dreaming of NBA stardom.

column1: Wade's path to the Final Four with Marquette and championships with the Miami Heat would be lined with the same challenges faced by Agee and Gates

column1: https://cnn.com/interactive/2020/04/sport/liverpoolpremierleaguetitle//​​Liverpool: The agonizing wait for a first Premier League title/"1990 / 91 30 years of dreaming Liverpool's agonizing wait for English football’s biggest prize

Gary Gillespie doesn’t remember how he and his teammates celebrated Liverpool winning the English first division title in 1990. “We probably got together and had a few drinks and reminisced about the season
column2: ” the former Liverpool defender tells CNN
column3: chuckling at his hazy recollection.

column1: There was little reason to especially savor that year’s yield
column2: Liverpool’s 18th league title and Gillespie’s third in five seasons
column3: because winning was what the club did. Springtime in Liverpool was the season for picking up trophies.

column1: There was satisfaction and relief
column2: an uplift to the red half of the city after a heartbreaking decade
column3: but not the intoxicating hit on the senses that usually comes with the glory of being the best in the land.

column1: Liverpool
column2: it was assumed
column3: would do it all again in the seasons to follow
column4: or come close at least. No one knew the 1989/90 campaign was an ending
column5: a full stop on what had been an unforgettable sentence in English football history.

column1: “Everybody was used to winning and maybe took it for granted
column2: and
column3: anytime you take anything for granted in life
column4: sometimes it comes back and smacks you in the face
column5: ” says Gillespie
column6: “and that’s exactly what happened because we’re talking about this 30 years down the line
column7: and Liverpool haven’t managed to win a title since.”

column1: This year was supposed to be different. Jurgen Klopp’s men were 25 points ahead of nearest challengers Manchester City
column2: within two victories of winning English football’s biggest prize
column3: before the coronavirus pandemic caused the world to pause.

column1: As the 30th anniversary of the club’s last league title success is marked
column2: the wait continues. Agonizing
column3: uncertain
column4: with the story of the club’s revival missing its final page.

column1: ‘Managed decline’
1980s Britain. Margaret Thatcher’s decade. The city of Liverpool is fighting for survival.
The docks
column2: once the heartbeat of Liverpool's prosperity
column3: have been in decline since the 1970s. Manufacturing is shrinking
column4: economic stagnation is sharp
column5: the population is in decline
column6: inner-city homes are falling into decay and unemployment is high. The city is also the first in the UK to be hit by the heroin epidemic that will go on to wreck a generation.

column1: “Liverpool was being forced on its knees
column2: ” lifelong Liverpool supporter and retired academic Gordon Jenkins
column4: tells CNN. “I remember Chelsea fans used to wave £20 notes at us and say
column5: ‘we’ve got loads of money.’”

column1: On a red-hot July day in 1981
column2: thousands of well-wishers lined London's streets to cheerily wave Union flags in celebration of Charles and Diana's wedding in the English capital. Two-hundred miles away
column3: Liverpool was burning. Appalling economic conditions
column4: combined with tensions between the police and the African-Caribbean community
column5: had exploded into anger
column6: rapidly descending into nine days of disorder which resulted in hundreds of injuries
column7: arrests and one death.

column1: Widely referred to as the Toxteth Riots
column2: locally it is known as the ‘uprising.’

column1: “This was a city without leadership
column2: ” wrote Michael Heseltine
column3: the cabinet minister who would go on to construct a framework to revive Liverpool
column4: in his autobiography.

column1: “We must not expend all our limited resources in trying to make water flow uphill.” Geoffrey Howe
column2: UK finance minister

column1: In the aftermath of the unrest
column2: Thatcher’s closest ministers talked of a “managed decline” of the city
column3: National Archives files would reveal in 2011
column4: with Thatcher's finance minister
column5: Geoffrey Howe
column6: warning: ""We must not expend all our limited resources in trying to make water flow uphill.""

column1: It was during this decade Liverpudlians came to see themselves as outsiders
column2: separate from the rest of Britain. Thatcher had polarized and radicalized. A broken working-class city which
column3: historically
column4: had not always leaned to the political left turned red.

column1: But during these divisive times the people had football
column2: two of the country’s outstanding teams in Liverpool and Everton. The beautiful game gave Liverpudlians heroes and hope. Football
column3: says Jenkins
column4: was
column5: and still is
column6: “inexorably woven into the fabric of why we are who we are.”

column1: From 1981 to 1990
column2: the two Merseyside clubs between them won nine league titles
column3: two European Cups
column4: a Cup Winners' Cup
column5: three FA Cups and three League Cups.

column1: Liverpool Football Club had become the bastion of invincibility former manager Bill Shankly had envisaged when rebuilding the club in the 1960s. Shankly’s successors
column2: all appointed from within
column3: had carried the torch. Bob Paisley
column4: Joe Fagan and Kenny Dalglish. Seamless successions upon which a dynasty was built.

column1: The succession: Following in the footsteps of managerial greats
BILL
SHANKLY 783 GAMES / 1959-74 Lost 22.7% Drawn 25.3% Won 51.9% BOB
PAISLEY 535 GAMES / 1974-83 L 17.9% D 24.5% W 57.6% JOE
FAGAN 131 GAMES / 1983-85 L 18.3% D 27.5% W 54.2% KENNY
KLOPP 256 GAMES / 2015-PRESENT L 16.8% D 22.7% W 60.5%
“I was there eight years
column2: the worst we ever finished in the league was second
column3: ” Gillespie
column4: who left Liverpool for Celtic in 1991
column5: says. “If you finished second it was deemed a failure
column6: you’d had a poor season regardless of what else you’d won.""

column1: The league title was
column2: says Gillespie
column3: the ""be all and end all” and this was especially the case in the latter half of the decade when English clubs were indefinitely banned from European competition following the Heysel disaster in 1985.

column1: “We never got allowed to get carried away
column2: ” Gillespie says
column3: identifying the camaraderie formed on boozy nights out as one of the reasons for the club’s success.

column1: “The coaching staff were always calling us ‘big heads’ and any opportunity they had they would try to knock you down. There was never too much praise for us. I don’t think we needed it.
“When we came in after games
column2: we would have to tie our boots so it was easier for the coaching staff to put the boots away. When we took our kit off
column3: we just didn’t throw it on the floor; we had to put the shorts in a pile and the tops in a pile. It was little things like that that kept you grounded.”

column1: A city grieving
Though football saved the city during this decade
column2: it was also the source of unimaginable pain.

column1: On April 15
column3: Liverpool fans were crushed to death on the Leppings Lane terrace in Hillsborough
column4: Sheffield
column5: during an FA Cup semifinal. Ninety-six men
column6: women and children unlawfully killed
column7: an inquest would find 28 years later
column8: due to police failings and the criminal gross negligence of the officer in command.

column1: Players had watched the injured and dying being carried away on advertising hoardings used as emergency stretchers and
column2: in the weeks that followed
column3: provided solace for the grieving. At one stage
column4: the 38-year-old Dalglish
column5: by now Liverpool’s player-manager
column6: attended four funerals a day.

column1: Adding to the suffering were the false accusations
column2: published on the front page of the Rupert Murdoch-owned English newspaper ‘The Sun’ immediately after the disaster
column3: that Liverpool fans had urinated on police and pickpocketed dead victims.

column1: “It [the disaster] left its mark on a lot of people
column2: ” says Gillespie
column3: conceding that the players still do not like to talk about the tragedy.

column1: At the start of that year
column2: defending league champions Liverpool had been in an unfamiliar position: fifth in the league and nine points behind leaders Arsenal. And
column3: so
column4: the second half of the season was spent in relentless pursuit of the Londoners
column5: with Liverpool eventually bumping Arsenal from the summit with two games remaining thanks to 21 wins in 24 games. Yet the championship was not yet won. The end-of-season title-decider was still to come.

column1: Arsenal’s April visit to Anfield had been rescheduled to the final day of the season because of the Hillsborough disaster
column2: resulting in the jittery Londoners arriving on Merseyside needing to beat their rivals
column3: who six days earlier had won the FA Cup
column4: by two goals to become champions.

column1: No one expected Arsenal to win but this Friday night match under the lights was made legendary as soon as the final whistle blew. In a hallucinatory ending
column2: with seconds remaining and the visitors 1-0 ahead
column3: Arsenal's Michael Thomas burst from midfield and scored
column4: securing an extraordinary 2-0 win -- and the championship -- for the Gunners.

column1: At the final whistle
column2: television cameras capture Dalglish standing silently near the Liverpool dugout
column3: looking into the middle-distance.

column1: “When Arsenal score
column2: you can see a lot of them (Liverpool players) collapse to the floor. They were playing three games a week; they’d been going to all the funerals
column3: and there was a sense that a lot of them were exhausted
column4: ” says Gordon.

column1: Business as usual
For those who witnessed it
column2: the 1988/89 season finale lives strong in the memory. But when Liverpool's players returned to pre-season training four weeks later
column3: no one at the club mentioned the Arsenal defeat
column4: or even the previous campaign.

column1: “The coaching staff
column2: the manager
column3: the whole ethos of the club was to never look back
column4: to never linger
column5: regardless of whether you had won the title or lost it. It was just something that was ingrained in us
column6: ” Gillespie explains.

column1: “To win the championship after a heartbreaking decade ... it was a remarkable achievement.” Gordon Jenkins
column2: Liverpool fan

column1: Liverpool’s only major signing that summer was Swedish defender Glenn Hysen
column2: bought from Fiorentina for £600

column1: The new season started with an eight-match unbeaten run
column2: including a 9-0 thumping of Crystal Palace

column1: Liverpool's transformation has been extraordinary. And I think the way we've got to tackle this is by being more inclusive

column1: https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/21/football/football-merseyside-derby-liverpool-everton-spt-intl/index.html/Everton holds up Liverpool's title charge in goalless Merseyside derby/"(CNN) Liverpool took a stuttering step towards its first English league title in 30 years as the champion-elect was held to a goalless draw by Everton in the Merseyside derby at Goodison Park on Sunday.
It was not the result that Jurgen Klopp's men wanted on their return to action after a three-month hiatus
column2: but with a 23-point lead over Manchester City
column3: celebrations will not be long delayed.

column1: Everton
column2: improved under new manager Carlo Ancelotti
column3: came closest to securing victory with Tom Davies seeing his late effort roll against a post and Brazilian striker Richarlison forcing a smart save from Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson Becker.

column1: Tom Davies sees his late effort for Everton roll against the post with Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson Becker beaten in the closing stages of the goalless Merseyside derby at an empty Goodison Park.
Despite concerns over fans congregating near the stadium with Liverpool's Anfield less than a mile away
column2: permission was given for the match to go ahead at Goodison. But in an empty stadium
column3: the usually fevered atmosphere of the derby was lacking.

column1: Also lacking was clear-cut chances for either side
column2: with Liverpool
column3: leaving a not fully fit Mo Salah on the bench

https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/19/football/manchester-united-tottenham-rashford-premier-league-spt-intl/index.html/Marcus Rashford takes a knee and raises his fist as Manchester United draw/"(CNN) There was to be no perfect ending to a momentous week for Marcus Rashford as Manchester United was held to a 1-1 draw against Tottenham Friday.

It was only three days ago that the 22-year-old became a national hero with his free school meal campaign that forced the UK government into a U-turn but the forward was unable to inspire his side to victory in its first game since the Premier League restart.
Bruno Fernandes' late penalty saved a point for United after Steven Bergwijn had given the hosts the lead.
There were powerful images before a ball was kicked at the rainsoaked Tottenham Hotspur Stadium with players observing a minute's applause for those who have died during the coronavirus pandemic.
Added poignancy was provided by the personalized shirts draped over seats of Tottenham season-ticket holders who had lost their lives over the last few months.
Players also took a knee before play commenced in support of the Black Lives Matter movement which has grown in prominence since the death of Geroge Floyd.
As well as taking a knee
column2: Rashford raised his fist
column3: in recognition of the symbol of black protest and liberation. Notably
column4: Olympic medal winners John Carlos and Tommie Smith raised their fists on the podium at the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City during the US national anthem.

column1: The gesture has been adopted many times since
column2: and many have raised their fists during the Black Lives Matter protests in the aftermath of Floyd's death.

column1: Individual names on the back of players' jerseys were also again replaced with the words 'Black Lives Matter.'
Manchester United striker Marcus Rashford takes a knee.
Players applaud commemorating the victims of the Covid-19.
Tottenham's new stadium usually boasts a cacophonous atmosphere
column2: but with no fans allowed in Premier League games for the time being it seemed to take Jose Mourinho's side a while to get used to the empty stands.

column1: United started on top as man-of-the-moment Rashford was denied the opening goal by the feet of Hugo Lloris.
It was then left to Bergwijn to open the scoring for Tottenham after a wonderful run from the 22-year-old
column2: though United keeper David de Gea arguably was at fault for the goal.

column1: Chances were few and far between in the second half as players still looked to be kicking off the rust after a long period away from the action.

It was the introduction of Paul Pogba from the substitute bench that gave United the boost it needed and the Frenchman's clever play resulted in his side being rewarded a penalty after Eric Dier's clumsy challenge.
Fernandes made no mistake from the penalty spot as he continues his impressive start to his Old Trafford career.

The visitors almost had the chance to clinch all three points but VAR rightly overturned another penalty that was awarded to United in the closing stages after Fernandes went down. Those were nervy moments for Dier given he was initially adjudged to have fouled Fernandes.
Referee Jonathan Moss takes the ball from Marcus Rashford after wrongly awarding a penalty.
Eyes on Rashford
All eyes had been on Rashford before the game after quite a week for the talented forward.
Very few have used their platform with such success
column2: utilizing his extra spare time to focus on trying to help in his community.

column1: His campaign on school meals saw him dominate the news agenda and ensure some of the poorest families in England would get extra support over the summer holidays.
The Manchester-born star has also raised millions in donations alongside food charity FareShare
column2: launched a poetry competition for deaf children and learned sign language.

column1: It's work that's caught the eye of Rashford's club boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer
column2: who praised the talented youngster ahead of Friday's match.

column1: As his manager it's been fantastic to follow Marcus during the lockdown period
column2: he told a virtual news conference Thursday.

column1: It's not just that he got the prime minister to change his mind but also what he's done over the last few months.
He's changed the lives of so many kids this summer
column2: which is more important than any game of football he'll probably have ever played
column3: so hopefully he can keep both sides going as well as he's doing now.""

column1: However
column2: the forward failed to make a real impact in the match as United only really got going in the second half.

column1: There was a moment in the second half when Pogba's raking pass brilliantly picked out Rashford
column2: but the United forward was unable to capitalize on the chance.

column1: In Friday's early game
column2: Southampton brushed aside Norwich 3-0 at Carrow Road to leave the Canaries on the brink of relegation back into the second division.

column1: After a shaky start
column2: Saints dominated much of the action and took advantage of some lackluster defending from its hosts.

The Premier League returned Wednesday after a 100-day hiatus and fans have clearly enjoyed their fix of football with broadcaster Sky Sports reporting near-record viewership figures.
Manchester City's win over Arsenal attracted a peak audience of 3.4 million
column2: a 94% increase on the season's average.

column1: Meanwhile

column1: Spectators can now look forward to a weekend full of action with Liverpool's trip to local rivals Everton the highlight on Sunday.

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/26/coronavirus-live-updates-us//Live updates: Florida

column3: South Carolina and Nevada hit new highs in daily coronavirus cases/"LONDON — Holiday-loving Britons have reason to cheer: The British government said it would ease blanket travel restrictions early next month.

column1: Earlier in June
column2: Britain introduced new quarantine rules that meant almost anyone entering the country
column3: including British nationals
column4: would have to self-isolate for two weeks. For many Brits
column5: this made the idea of jet-setting to Spain or France for their annual summer holiday seem almost impossible. But the British government said that
column6: from July 6
column7: it will scrap the quarantine rules for several European countries.

column1: The news was splashed across the front pages of Saturday newspapers: “Fly out for sun
column2: sea and 70% off
column3: ” said the Daily Mail. “Holiday season back on
column4: ” ran a headline on the front of the Times of London.

column1: Brits love to holiday abroad: In normal times
column2: about 60 percent of Brits go on an overseas holiday. Of course
column3: these are not normal times
column4: and it remains to be seen how many people will book a vacation to sun-kissed destinations. But the hard-hit travel industry was clearly elated with the news.

column1: “It’s incredibly welcome
column2: ” said Jonathan Smith
column3: a spokesman for ABTA
column4: a trade association for travel agents and tour operators. He told the BBC that they expect a “surge of bookings … although some people may be slightly reticent to travel.”

column1: Under a “traffic light system
column2: ” countries will be given a green
column3: amber or red rating based on coronavirus levels and other measures. Passengers coming from countries with a “red” rating will have to continue to abide by the mandatory 14-day quarantine rules.

column1: The full list of countries will be published next week. Top tourist destinations like France
column2: Spain and Greece are expected to be on the approved list.

column1: There was no suggestion that the United States would be on the approved list
column2: although its exclusion could “potentially present a tricky diplomatic dynamic
column3: ” wrote the BBC’s Tom Burridge."/['Derek Hawkins'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/trump-border-wall-funding-illegal/2020/06/26/0d86a42c-b7cf-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html/Trump’s use of military funds for border wall construction is illegal
column2: 9th Circuit Court rules/"The president
column3: who ran for office in 2016 promising that Mexico would pay for the border wall
column4: has obtained more than $15 billion in U.S. federal funds for his signature project
column5: including $5 billion provided by Congress through conventional appropriations. The president has tapped into Pentagon accounts for the remaining $10 billion
column6: including the $2.5 billion transfer last year that the 9th Circuit said Friday was unlawful.

column1: Some of those funds already have been awarded as contracts to the private builders hired to construct the barrier. In its ruling
column2: the court said the White House “lacked independent constitutional authority to authorize the transfer of funds” from the military.

column1: AD
AD
“The panel noted that the Appropriations Clause of the U.S. Constitution exclusively grants the power of the purse to Congress
column2: ” the decision said. “The ­panel held that the transfer of funds violated the Appropriations Clause
column3: and
column4: therefore
column5: was unlawful.”

column1: In response to a request for comment
column2: the Department of Homeland Security sent a one-sentence statement from spokesman Alexei Woltornist. “We are sorely disappointed in this decision
column3: ” he said
column4: without responding to questions about potential effects on construction currently underway.

column1: The Trump administration is expected to appeal Friday’s ruling to the Supreme Court
column2: which last year sided with the White House and lifted a 9th Circuit injunction freezing transfers of funds from military accounts. The Sierra Club and a collection of border activists sued the administration again last year when Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper tapped new funding streams for a fresh $2.5 billion.

column1: Private contractors have completed about 220 miles of new fencing along the Mexico border
column2: and DHS officials say they remain on track to deliver on Trump’s pledge to finish 450 miles by the end of 2020.

column1: AD
AD
Construction has proceeded most swiftly on land already under government control
column2: including wildlife preserves
column3: national forests and other protected areas
column4: outraging environmental groups
column5: tribal authorities and others who view the 30-foot-tall steel structure as wasteful and destructive.

column1: Gloria Smith
column2: a Sierra Club attorney
column3: called the ruling Friday “monumental” and said the court had “put a stop to Trump’s unconstitutional wall construction.”

column1: “We should be protecting communities
column2: our democracy
column3: and the environment
column4: not tearing these things apart as Trump hoped to do
column5: ” Smith said in a statement.

column1: California Attorney General Xavier Becerra (D)
column2: who has filed multiple challenges to the administration’s construction plans
column3: also hailed the decision in a statement Friday. “While the Trump administration steals public funds to build an unauthorized wall at the southern border
column4: families across the country are struggling to pay their bills
column5: ” he said. “They deserve to know that their hard-earned dollars are going where Congress intended — to benefit them and their communities.”

column1: The Supreme Court last year lifted the lower-court injunction without ruling on the legality of the administration’s Pentagon transfers. But the administration has insisted the White House has the legal authority to pay for physical barriers as part of a wider effort to protect and defend the country’s borders. The Trump administration also has argued in recent months that security at the southern border is a crucial element of preventing further influx of the coronavirus
column2: though the outbreak within the United States is by far the worst in the world.

column1: AD
AD
The high court’s conservative majority ruled that the government had “made a sufficient showing at this stage” that private entities could not challenge the transfer of money by the executive branch.
But the 9th Circuit panel in San Francisco said “it is for the courts to enforce Congress’s priorities” and found that the Sierra Club “may invoke separation-of-
powers constraints
column2: like the Appropriations Clause
column3: to challenge agency spending in excess of its delegated authority.”

column1: The showdown between Trump and Democratic lawmakers over border wall funding led to a 35-day government shutdown
column2: the longest in U.S. history. It ended in January 2019 when the president dropped his funding demand for $5 billion
column3: reaching into military accounts instead.

column1: AD
A three-judge panel in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit also ruled this year in favor of the administration
column2: lifting a ­lower-court injunction blocking the use of military funds for barrier construction in the El Paso area.

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/26/fired-officer-charged-with-battery-after-video-shows-him-kneeling-black-womans-neck//Fired police officer charged with battery after video shows him kneeling on black woman’s neck/"The charges
column2: coming amid weeks-long protests against police violence against black people
column3: follow an incident with similarities to the May arrest of George Floyd
column4: a black man who died after a now-fired Minneapolis officer knelt on his neck for nearly nine minutes.

column1: AD
Miami Gardens Mayor Oliver Gilbert said in a Thursday news conference that he supported Martel’s firing and wants to alert the public that the law applies to everyone
column2: including those sworn to uphold it.

column1: AD
“The standards that our community require aren’t subject to interpretation
column2: ” he said. “If [police] violate those professional standards
column3: then we will terminate them. If their conduct rises to the level where it’s criminal
column4: [State Attorney Katherine Fernandez Rundle] is going to prosecute you.”

column1: An affidavit for Martel’s arrest states Satchell and her friend Raheam “Remy” Staats-Flemming left the nightspot after being dissatisfied with the service and were refunded money for food.
AD
Satchell threw tip money at a waitress on her way out
column2: prompting the club’s manager to notify security that he wanted uniformed Miami Gardens police officers who were working off-duty security to issue trespass warnings to Satchell and Staats-Flemming that would prevent them from returning for another visit
column3: according to court records.

column1: AD
As Satchell and her friend were about to leave the club’s parking lot
column2: a security person stood in front of their black Mercedes SUV and Martel walked up to the driver side to speak with Satchell through her rolled-down window
column3: according to the affidavit.

column1: The records state Martel told Satchell that he needed her information because she was being given a trespass warning
column2: despite her attempt to leave. He had no legal grounds to detain her
column3: court records state.

column1: AD
When Martel instructed Satchell to walk to his police car
column2: records state
column3: she requested to drive over because she wasn’t wearing shoes.

column1: Less than 30 seconds after his first command for Satchell to walk over to his patrol car
column2: Martel’s tone of voice grew agitated
column3: according to court documents.

column1: “Either you come out with me and do the trespass
column2: or you are getting arrested
column3: ” Martel said
column4: stating that Satchell would be cuffed for “resisting without violence
column5: ” according to the affidavit.

column1: AD
Records state that Satchell asked her friend to record what was happening and told Martel that her father was also a police officer
column2: to which he replied: “Okay. I don’t care about that.”

column1: AD
The two then engaged in a struggle that involved Martel reaching into the vehicle and trying to pull Satchell out while she tried to stop him from doing so
column2: court records show.

column1: Once he pulled her out of the vehicle
column2: Martel
column3: who is 5-foot-9 and 190 pounds
column4: used a leg sweep to force Satchell to the ground
column5: according to the affidavit.

column1: He knelt on the 5-3
column2: 117-pound woman’s neck and used a stun gun twice in her abdomen area even though he had control of her left arm and another officer had control of her right
column3: the affidavit states.

column1: Miami Gardens police officer arrested after video shows him with knee on woman’s neck
column2: stunning her with a Taser twice. Officer’s lawyer calls the arrest “politically motivated.” Here’s full video clip taken by the woman’s friend https://t.co/wDlUINtz4d pic.twitter.com/XPEMDYmJ0z — David Ovalle (@DavidOvalle305) June 26

column1: Satchell was transported to Miami’s Turner Guilford Knight Correctional Center that night.
AD

Investigators found that Martel’s retelling of the encounter in an arrest affidavit for Satchell and an incident report had inaccuracies about what happened. Body-camera footage and Staats-Flemming’s cellphone footage
column2: which captured a significant portion of the event
column3: contradicts claims he made in official documents
column4: according to court records.

column1: AD
After reviews of footage and audio
column2: Martel is accused of not mentioning arrest as often as he said he did in the reports
column3: being the aggressor in the interaction and lying about Satchell fighting him and the other officer
column4: according to the affidavit.

column1: Satchell incurred abrasions on her stomach from the stun gun and other bruising on her arms and legs as a result of the arrest
column2: resulting in Martel being accused of using “excessive force
column3: ” according to the affidavit.

column1: AD
The local police union told CBS Miami that Martel’s charges seem to be a reaction to nationwide events surrounding law enforcement. Martel’s attorney
column2: Douglas Hartman
column3: did not immediately respond to requests for comment but told the Miami Herald he thought the charges were a “political move.”

column1: AD
Jonathan Jordan
column2: Satchell’s attorney
column3: told the station in a statement that officers should be mindful of their actions.

column1: “If you’re an officer that has broken policy or acted under color of law with a belief that black lives don’t matter
column2: you ought to be looking over your shoulder
column3: because the chickens have finally come home to roost
column4: ” he said.

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/27/mississippi-flag-vote//Mississippi House takes first firm step to remove Confederate symbol from flag/"Ahead of the historic vote
column2: Speaker Pro Tem Jason White (R) argued forcefully against keeping the old flag
column3: saying that it had come to be viewed as a symbol of hate.

column1: “By changing our flag
column2: we don’t abandon our founding principles
column3: ” he said. “We embrace them more fully by doing what is right. We’re not moving further away from our founding fathers’ visions. We’re moving closer to them. We’re not destroying our heritage; we’re fulfilling it.”

column1: AD
AD
Earlier in the day
column2: Gov. Tate Reeves (R)
column3: who had long insisted voters alone should decide whether to abandon the state’s flag
column4: said for the first time Saturday that he would sign a bill on the issue if one is sent his way.

column1: “The legislature has been deadlocked for days as it considers a new state flag
column2: ” he wrote in a Facebook post. “The argument over the 1894 flag has become as divisive as the flag itself and it’s time to end it. If they send me a bill this weekend
column3: I will sign it.”

column1: A debate has raged this week over the state flag
column2: the last in the country to feature the Confederate battle flag in its design. The symbol
column3: with 13 white stars atop a blue X with a red background
column4: appears in the Mississippi flag’s upper-left corner.

column1: AD
Adopted more than 30 years after the end of the Civil War
column2: the banner has continued to fly despite years of criticism over its symbology
column3: including previous attempts to change it. In 2001
column4: Mississippians voted 2-to-1 to keep the 1894 design.

column1: AD
But amid a heightened focus on Confederate symbols across the nation
column2: Mississippi legislators and institutions have in recent days come out against the flag. Among those now opposing the flag are multiple legislators from both parties
column3: the Mississippi Historical Society
column4: Walmart and the Mississippi Baptist Convention.

column1: A state lawmaker told CNN Friday there now might be enough votes to remove it.

Reeves went from saying Wednesday that there was “an effort underway across the country to erase our nation’s history” and that a veto “would be pointless” to his Saturday statement that it was time “resolve that the page has been turned” and “find a way to come together.”
AD
“We should not be under any illusion that a vote in the Capitol is the end of what must be done — the job before us is to bring the state together
column2: ” Reeves said in his Saturday statement
column3: “and I intend to work night and day to do it.”"/['Brittany Shammas'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2020/06/27/emancipation-monument-in-washington-dc-targeted-by-protests//Frederick Douglass delivered a Lincoln reality check at Emancipation Memorial unveiling/"By all accounts
column2: Douglass
column3: the great orator and abolitionist
column4: was not pleased with the monument
column5: which depicted Lincoln holding a copy of the Emancipation Proclamation while towering over a kneeling black man who had broken his chains.

column1: Douglass
column2: who commanded audiences across the world with his dignified poise and intellect
column3: extended polite platitudes in the speech about the beauty of the monument
column4: which had been designed and sculpted by Thomas Ball and had been financed mostly by donations from formerly enslaved people.

column1: AD
AD
Then Douglass
column2: a tall man with a nearly white crown of hair
column3: launched into a 32-minute rapid-fire discourse on the conflicted legacy of Lincoln
column4: who issued the Emancipation Proclamation on Jan. 1
column6: as the country moved into the third year of the Civil War. Lincoln’s proclamation had declared “that all persons held as slaves” within the rebellious states “are
column7: and henceforward shall be free.”

column1: As great as the proclamation was
column2: Douglass explained
column3: Lincoln had issued the document of freedom reluctantly.

column1: Lincoln’s motivation was to save the union. According to the Library of Congress
column2: in response to a challenge in the New York Tribune by the journalist Horace Greeley that he take a clear stance on abolition
column3: Lincoln had provided a response stating
column4: “If I could save the union without freeing any slave
column5: I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves
column6: I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone
column7: I would also do that.”

column1: AD
AD
In his speech at the 1876 statue unveiling
column2: Douglass exposed Lincoln’s legacy. “Truth compels me to admit
column3: even here in the presence of the monument we have erected to his memory
column4: ” Douglass said
column5: “Abraham Lincoln was not
column6: in the fullest sense of the word
column7: either our man or our model. In his interests
column8: in his associations
column11: he was a white man.”

column1: Douglass
column2: who had met Lincoln on several occasions at the White House
column3: said that Lincoln was not a president for black people and that Lincoln’s motivation above all was to save the union
column4: even if it meant keeping black people in bondage.

column1: “He was preeminently the white man’s president
column2: entirely devoted to the welfare of white men
column3: ” Douglass said
column4: according to the speech stored at the Library of Congress. “He was ready and willing at any time during the first years of his administration to deny
column5: postpone
column6: and sacrifice the rights of humanity in the colored people to promote the welfare of the white people of this country.”

column1: More than 144 years later
column2: the controversy surrounding Lincoln’s legacy and the “Emancipation Monument” has erupted again. This week
column3: protesters demanded the removal of the monument
column4: which is also called the Freedmen’s Monument. Police built barriers around the monument to protect it after some protesters threatened to tear it down. On Thursday
column5: D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser (D) announced that the city should debate the removal of the statue
column6: and “not have a mob decide they want to pull it down.”

column1: Historians say the threats offer an opportunity to explain Lincoln’s complicated legacy to general audiences that know only the simplistic view of Lincoln as the president who freed the slaves.
AD
AD
C.R. Gibbs
column2: a historian and author of “Black
column3: Copper & Bright: The District of Columbia’s Black Civil War Regiment
column4: ” explained that the kneeling slave depicted in the Emancipation Monument was most likely inspired by an old abolitionist image used to fight for freedom for enslaved black people. “It was probable that the white sculptor was influenced by the poster with the words
column5: ‘Am I Not a Man and Brother’ over a kneeling slave
column6: ” Gibbs said.

column1: At the time of the monument’s commissioning
column2: Harriet Hosmer
column3: who was considered one of the first female professional sculptors
column4: designed an alternative sculpture that would have depicted several figures
column5: including a black Union soldier.

column1: “Some scholars and historians believe that would have been too revolutionary
column2: ” Gibbs said
column3: “and perhaps too expensive. But it was an opportunity missed.”

column1: AD
AD
Douglass used his speech at the unveiling
column2: Gibbs said
column3: ""to clean up and clarify exactly what Lincoln’s contributions were with respect to black people.”

column1: “For black people
column2: Lincoln was neither our man nor our model
column3: ” Gibbs said
column4: echoing Douglass. In his speech
column5: Gibbs said
column6: Douglass told the crowd that Lincoln “was important in the struggle and we honor that. But Douglass wanted Lincoln to emerge from the myth.”

column1: In August 1862
column2: Lincoln told a group of black leaders during a visit to the White House that they were to blame for the Civil War. “He said
column3: ‘But for your presence amongst us
column4: there would be no war.’ ”

column1: “Basically
column2: he was saying
column3: ‘you all are the cause of the war
column4: ’ ” Gibbs said. “Lincoln had said he was not an abolitionist. When we say Lincoln freed the slaves
column5: we leave out the agency and sacrifice of U.S. colored troops and those in the Navy who fought and died for this freedom.”

column1: According to the Library of Congress
column2: “Lincoln honored Douglass with three invitations to the White House
column3: including an invitation to Lincoln’s second inauguration. During his first visit
column4: Douglass petitioned Lincoln to pay African American Union soldiers as much as their white counterparts. Lincoln answered that African American soldiers would get their fair wages when the time was right
column5: which frustrated Douglass
column6: although he came to understand Lincoln’s reasoning.”

column1: In the speech at the unveiling of the monument
column2: Douglass gives the audience an idea of how complicated his relationship with Lincoln was.

column1: AD
AD
“The name of Abraham Lincoln was near and dear to our hearts in the darkest and most perilous hours of the republic
column2: ” Douglass said. “We were no more ashamed of him when shrouded in clouds of darkness
column3: of doubt
column4: and defeat than when we saw him crowned with victory
column5: honor
column6: and glory. Our faith in him was often taxed and strained to the uttermost
column7: but it never failed.”

column1: Douglass criticized Lincoln as not moving fast enough to free thousands of enslaved black people:

When he tarried long in the mountain; when he strangely told us that we were the cause of the war; when he still more strangely told us that we were to leave the land in which we were born; when he refused to employ our arms in defense of the Union; when
column2: after accepting our services as colored soldiers
column3: he refused to retaliate our murder and torture as colored prisoners; when he told us he would save the Union if he could with slavery; when he revoked the Proclamation of Emancipation of General Fremont; when he refused to remove the popular commander of the Army of the Potomac
column4: in the days of its inaction and defeat
column5: who was more zealous in his efforts to protect slavery than to suppress rebellion; when we saw all this
column6: and more
column7: we were at times grieved
column8: stunned
column9: and greatly bewildered; but our hearts believed while they ached and bled.

column1: Douglass also said that Lincoln’s slow pace was frustrating and bewildering. In short
column2: Douglass said
column3: Lincoln tried the patience of abolitionists who wanted a speedy end to slavery:

column1: “Despite the mist and haze that surrounded him; despite the tumult
column2: the hurry
column3: and confusion of the hour
column4: we were able to take a comprehensive view of Abraham Lincoln
column5: and to make reasonable allowance for the circumstances of his position
column6: ” Douglass said. “We saw him
column7: measured him
column8: and estimated him; not by stray utterances to injudicious and tedious delegations
column9: who often tried his patience; not by isolated facts torn from their connection; not by any partial and imperfect glimpses
column10: caught at inopportune moments; but by a broad survey
column11: in the light of the stern logic of great events
column12: and in view of that divinity which shapes our ends
column13: rough hew them how we will
column14: we came to the conclusion that the hour and the man of our redemption had somehow met in the person of Abraham Lincoln.”

column1: Douglass said abolitionists cared little about how Lincoln proclaimed emancipation.
AD
“It was enough for us that Abraham Lincoln was at the head of a great movement
column2: and was in living and earnest sympathy with that movement
column3: which
column4: in the nature of things
column5: must go on until slavery should be utterly and forever abolished in the United States.”

column1: AD
In the speech
column2: Douglass concluded that despite Lincoln’s failings
column3: he should be remembered for the great accomplishment of freeing thousands of enslaved people.

column1: “Though he loved Caesar less than Rome
column2: though the union was more to him than our freedom or our future
column3: ” Douglass said
column4: “under his wise and beneficent rule we saw ourselves gradually lifted from the depths of slavery to the heights of liberty and manhood.”

column1: AD
Then Douglass recalled the scenes of black people waiting for the emancipation to take effect.
“Can any colored man
column2: or any white man friendly to the freedom of all men
column3: ever forget the night which followed the first day of January
column5: when the world was to see if Abraham Lincoln would prove to be as good as his word?” Douglass asked. “I shall never forget that memorable night
column6: when in a distant city I waited and watched at a public meeting
column7: with three thousand others not less anxious than myself
column8: for the word of deliverance which we have heard read today. Nor shall I ever forget the outburst of joy and thanksgiving that rent the air when the lightning brought to us the emancipation proclamation.”

column1: AD

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/congo-declares-end-of-worlds-second-largest-ebola-outbreak/2020/06/25/88af8bc2-b4e2-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Congo declares end of world’s second-largest Ebola outbreak/"“It wasn’t easy
column2: ” said Matshidiso Moeti
column3: the World Health Organization’s Africa director. “At times
column4: it felt like mission impossible.”

column1: AD

Ebola is a hemorrhagic fever endemic in animal populations that reside in Africa’s tropical forests and is passed from person to person through contact with bodily fluids. Congo has had 11 outbreaks since the virus was first identified in humans in 1976. A new outbreak began on June 1 in the country’s northwest and has resulted in 15 deaths as of Thursday. The worst outbreak of the virus swept through Guinea
column2: Sierra Leone and Liberia between 2014 and 2016
column3: killing more than 11

column1: North Kivu and Ituri proved to be an exceptionally challenging theater for the contact tracing and community outreach required during an Ebola outbreak. Armed groups have killed hundreds of locals in numerous regional conflicts since the outbreak began
column2: and health workers often came under fire while doing their work.

column1: AD
Front-line nurses were routinely evacuated from particularly volatile areas
column2: leaving the response on pause and the virus more free to spread. One deadly stretch late last November saw four people involved in the response killed in attacks by unknown assailants. Overall 11 were killed and 86 injured
column3: according to the WHO.

column1: AD
The broader humanitarian situation has worsened as well. The number of people in need of aid in the two Ebola-affected provinces has grown more than 250 percent since the start of the outbreak
column2: from 1.2 to 4.3 million people
column3: according to the International Rescue Committee
column4: which has worked closely with the Ebola response. Eastern Congo has not seen a large number of coronavirus cases
column5: but Congo at large has not escaped the new pandemic.

column1: “Initial research indicates that covid-19
column2: which continues to spread with nearly 6
column3: 000 cases [across the country]
column4: could compound these devastating consequences for the most vulnerable populations
column5: ” said Borry Jatta
column6: the organization’s Ebola response director.

column1: Eteni Longondo
column2: Congo’s health minister
column3: said in a news conference on Thursday that tackling the coronavirus would require “the same strategy in the struggle
column4: the same methodology in the struggle” against Ebola.

column1: Despite the hurdles
column2: a well-financed global response was able to make use of several experimental vaccines and treatments
column3: which were credited with helping slow the virus’s spread while a cure remains elusive. Different strains of the virus exist
column4: and different outbreaks have had mortality rates ranging from 25 to 90 percent.

column1: AD
AD
More than 300
column2: 000 people were vaccinated with Ervebo
column3: a vaccine made by the American pharmaceutical giant Merck
column4: which became the world’s first fully licensed Ebola vaccine late last year.

column1: A second vaccine
column2: made by Johnson & Johnson
column3: also an American company
column4: was used as part of a clinical trial. Another clinical trial tested four experimental treatments
column5: and two were found to improve survival.

column1: While the response succeeded in containing the virus to two Congolese provinces
column2: it was regularly criticized by locals for being involved in the region’s rampant corruption as well as paying unpopular security forces for protection
column3: evidence of which was uncovered by journalists. The WHO
column4: which led the response
column5: has refused to comment on how much money it paid to the United Nations’ peacekeeping force
column6: the Congolese army or other local armed groups.

column1: AD
AD

Aid workers involved with the response regularly voiced frustration at the reliance on security forces and corrupt local business executives who they and locals say had vested interests in prolonging the outbreak for financial gain
column2: and who sometimes used their positions of power to commit violent crimes."/['Max Bearak'
column3: 'Nairobi Bureau Chief']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/VFUGEUVW4YI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/06/25/nascar-investigation-cant-determine-who-tied-noose-talladega-garage-stall//NASCAR releases noose photo and defends process but can’t determine who tied it/"NASCAR President Steve Phelps shared those findings Thursday in a conference call announcing that the sport had concluded its internal investigation of the incident that the FBI determined was not a hate crime but that nonetheless thrust stock-car racing into an ugly national spotlight and roiled its fan base.
AD
Moments before Phelps spoke to reporters about NASCAR’s findings and the steps it will take going forward
column2: NASCAR released a photograph of the noose taken by its security staff during the investigation.

column1: AD
“As you can see from the photo
column2: the noose was real
column3: as was our concern for Bubba
column4: ” Phelps said.

column1: Phelps vigorously defended the urgency of NASCAR’s response and said he would do the same again
column2: adding that in hindsight he should have used the word “alleged” in his initial statement condemning what he referred to as a “heinous act” hours after the discovery of the noose was reported by a member of Wallace’s race team Sunday afternoon.

column1: “Upon learning of and seeing the noose
column2: our initial reaction was to protect our driver
column3: ” Phelps said. “We’re living in a highly charged and emotional time. What we saw was a symbol of hate [that] was only present in one area of the garage: that of the 43 car of Bubba Wallace.

column1: AD
“… Based on the evidence we had
column2: we felt that one of our drivers had been threatened — a driver who had been extremely courageous in his recent words and deeds.”

column1: AD
Phelps’s remarks came two days after the FBI closed its investigation without bringing federal charges after determining that the noose had been in that particular stall since at least October
column2: when NASCAR last raced at Talladega. As a result
column3: the FBI concluded
column4: it could not have been intended as a symbol directed at Wallace because no one could have known Wallace would have been assigned that stall. In other words
column5: the FBI concluded it was an extreme coincidence.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: NASCAR continued with its own probe
column3: alarmed by why a noose was found in one of its garage stalls in the first place. Among the governing body’s questions: How did the noose get there? Was anyone an intended target? Was this a code-of-conduct violation? Are nooses present elsewhere in other garages where NASCAR races?

column1: AD

NASCAR’s investigation concluded the noose was “created at some point” during its October 2019 race weekend based on photographic and video evidence that showed it wasn’t dangling by the garage door at the weekend’s start but was at the end of the weekend.
AD

Wallace’s team ended up in that stall Sunday — one of 44 in Talladega’s garage — under a NASCAR policy that assigns stalls according to teams’ standings in the season-long points race. Under the sport’s novel coronavirus protocol
column2: that policy has been tweaked to place multicar race teams side by side
column3: which shuffled Wallace’s team
column4: then 20th in the standings
column5: further back in the garage than it normally would have been.

column1: At the October 2019 race
column2: the stall was assigned to Wood Brothers
column3: NASCAR’s oldest continuously operating Cup team
column4: founded in Stuart
column5: Va.
column6: in 1950. Members of the Wood Brothers team
column7: which fields the No. 21 Ford driven by Matt DiBenedetto
column8: were interviewed by the FBI
column10: along with race team personnel from multiple teams
column11: NASCAR officials
column12: track fire and safety personnel and track custodial staff.

column1: AD
“Given that timing and the garage access policies and procedures at the time [before coronavirus protocols limited garage access]
column2: we were unfortunately unable to determine with any certainty who tied this rope in this manner or why it was done
column3: ” Phelps said.

column1: NASCAR’s closure of the incident probably won’t quell the racial tensions that have ratcheted up daily since Phelps announced June 10 that the sport was banning displays of the Confederate flag at its racetracks to send a message that all fans are welcome at its events.
AD
On Thursday
column2: Phelps made clear that NASCAR would not retreat from that policy despite virulent pushback from a segment of its fan base that views the flag as the symbol of a fierce
column3: proud heritage.

column1: AD
“We are not going to back off of that policy
column2: ” Phelps said. “We have made the statement
column3: and we’re going to follow through to its fullest.”

column1: Much of the venom of irate fans has been directed at Wallace
column3: an Alabama native who had called on NASCAR to ban displays of the flag to send a message of inclusion. That advocacy had made him a target entering NASCAR’s June 21 race at Talladega
column4: the first event at which its flag ban would be enforced as the sport gradually emerges from quarantine
column5: admitting 5
column6: 000 spectators that day.

column1: From the moment NASCAR announced the discovery of the noose Sunday night
column2: a vocal group of conspiracists accused Wallace of staging the scene — even though neither he nor any of the 39 other Cup Series drivers had access to Talladega’s garage under the sport’s coronavirus protocols.

column1: AD
AD
Phelps acknowledged he was troubled and bewildered by the unfounded
column2: vitriol-laced allegations that erupted on social media. “I just find it incredibly disturbing that there are those that are out there that just feel the need to spread the hate or to spread false things
column3: ” he said. “I just — I don’t understand it. I really don’t.”

column1: Others slammed NASCAR
column2: the FBI and journalists for using the term “noose” to describe what they insisted
column3: sight unseen
column4: was an ordinary pull rope that is commonly used to shut garage doors or lower attic stairs.

column1: The photograph released by NASCAR makes clear
column2: however
column3: that the rope found in Talladega’s No. 4 stall was fashioned into a noose with deliberation.

column1: AD
Phelps would not speculate on the intent behind it.
“We have no idea what the intent was at all
column2: whether there was any malice in it or whether it was just fashioned as a noose for a pulley
column3: ” he said. “We don't know that.”

column1: AD
He also noted that many garage members must have passed by the noose
column2: whether this past fall or Sunday
column3: without noticing or commenting
column4: which has convinced him to mandate that all NASCAR members undergo sensitivity and unconscious-bias training.

column1: “Our ultimate conclusion for this investigation is to ensure that this never happens again
column2: that no one walks by a noose without recognizing the potential damage it can do
column3: ” Phelps said.

column1: AD
In closing
column2: he offered a final thought about Wallace.

column1: “Bubba has done nothing but represent this sport with courage
column2: class and dignity
column3: and he stood tall for what he believes in
column4: ” Phelps said. “And we all need to stand with him. I know I’m going to.”
