column2: 'Sports Reporter Focusing On Tennis']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/J4TY3BFXAEI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/06/26/nba-forges-ahead-plans-disney-restart/?itid=sf_sports/NBA forges ahead with plans for Disney restart: ‘No options are risk-free’/"NBA Commissioner Adam Silver said the league and the players’ union share the belief that their “deliberate
column2: intentional and collaborative” plan will provide a safe environment even though Florida reported nearly 9
column3: 000 new cases Friday.

column1: AD
AD
“We are left with no choice but to learn to live with this virus
column2: ” Silver said on a conference call with reporters
column3: his first since April. “No options are risk-free right now. And if we can’t sit on the sidelines indefinitely
column4: we must adapt. My ultimate conclusion is that we can’t outrun the virus. While [the bubble] is not impermeable
column5: we are in essence protected from cases around us. For those reasons
column6: we’re still very comfortable being in Orlando.”

column1: More than 300 players reported to teams in their home markets this week for testing as the league entered Phase 2 of its return plan. Sixteen players tested positive and will be subject to self-quarantine in the coming days
column2: although Silver noted that none of the players “were seriously ill in any way” and that the number was “roughly where we expected
column3: ” given age and demographic trends.

column1: Players who tested positive will undergo subsequent tests and a cardiac screening before they will be cleared to travel to Florida. A few players
column2: including Washington Wizards forward Davis Bertans and Los Angeles Lakers guard Avery Bradley
column3: have announced they will not play.

column1: AD
AD
“I’m somewhat relieved that the number [of positive tests] wasn’t higher
column2: ” said NBPA Executive Director Michele Roberts
column3: who joined Silver on the conference call. “I was also relieved that we had the foresight to identify the players that would be testing positive now. The great majority of our players have been doing exactly what they should be doing. One [positive test] is too many
column4: but 150 would have been devastating.”

column1: The NBA’s bubble plan
column2: laid out in a 113-page health and safety protocol
column3: drew praise from public health experts
column4: including Anthony S. Fauci
column5: the nation’s top infectious-disease expert and a member of the White House’s coronavirus task force
column6: because it reflected many best practices in mitigating the spread of the virus. Games will be held on a single-site campus without fans. Players must undergo daily testing
column7: and wear masks and maintain social distancing when they are not playing. A positive test within the bubble will be met with a strict quarantine procedure and contact tracing efforts; play will continue without the affected player
column8: who will be treated as if he was injured.

column1: Even so
column2: as Florida’s coronavirus cases skyrocketed this week
column3: doubts about the plan mounted in part because some Disney employees will be allowed to leave the bubble to return home after work and in part because numerous other teams in Florida have had to suspend training camps and practices after positive tests. After keeping its daily new caseload under 2
column4: 000 throughout April and May
column5: Florida surpassed 3
column6: 000 new cases June 18
column7: exceeded 5
column8: 000 on Wednesday and nearly hit 9
column11: also has had its case numbers and positivity rate dramatically increase.

column1: “I probably wouldn’t have played because the unknown going into that situation looks crazy right now
column2: seeing so many new cases
column3: ” Brooklyn Nets forward Kevin Durant told the DawgTalk podcast this week. “It’s just so unpredictable. It’s easy for me to say right now because I’m injured [so I can’t play anyway]. I probably would have chilled [at home].”

column1: AD
AD
Silver acknowledged the league’s internal concern “has increased” this week and said the league and players are “closely monitoring” developments
column2: but he expressed confidence in the bubble concept. A “subset” of Disney employees could be subjected to additional testing
column3: he added
column4: as a method to ensure the health of personnel inside the bubble.

column1: “We ultimately believe it will be safer on our campus than outside it
column2: ” Silver said
column3: leaving open the possibility that a “significant spread” of the coronavirus inside the bubble “might lead us to stop” the resumed season. “We’re not saying full steam ahead no matter what happens.”

column1: The NBA has not set a threshold for when to pull the plug if faced with a widespread outbreak. The players
column2: cognizant of the bubble’s inherent uncertainties
column3: opted to proceed anyway. Roberts said she can “sleep at night” knowing the level of detail that was put into the health and safety plan
column4: which includes extensive security to maintain the perimeter of the bubble and efforts to manage players’ mental health.

column1: Still
column2: the idea of living and working within the bubble for up to three months without the ability to freely come and go is daunting.

column1: “We never pictured ourselves playing like this
column2: ” said Oklahoma City Thunder guard Chris Paul
column3: the NBPA’s president. “When people hear health and safety
column4: a lot of times people think about injury or they just think about covid-19. While both are important
column5: I think mental health is the biggest thing that a lot of us players think of first.”

column1: AD
AD
The finalized restart agreement followed ongoing conversations about social justice protests that included Silver
column2: Deputy Commissioner Mark Tatum
column3: Roberts
column4: Paul and other members of the NBPA.

column1: Numerous players
column2: including Nets guard Kyrie Irving
column3: have argued that resuming basketball could take attention away from efforts to reform police departments or expand voting rights. In a joint statement
column4: the NBA and NBPA said Wednesday that “the goal of the season restart in Orlando will be to take collective action to combat systemic racism and promote social justice.”

column1: The players have engaged the league on increasing the number of black executives and coaches
column2: adding partnerships between the league and black-owned businesses and launching a foundation to support efforts in the black community. While Paul didn’t disclose specific plans for player demonstrations during time spent in the bubble
column3: he added that they have no intention of participating in “a shut-up-and-dribble situation.”

column1: AD
AD
“We have a great group of players who are well-informed … about covid-19 and social injustices
column2: ” said Andre Iguodala
column3: a Miami Heat forward and the NBPA’s vice president. “Everyone is making some type of sacrifice. A lot of people in America don’t have jobs right now. [By playing
column4: ] we have the opportunity to be a beacon of light and show our sympathies.”

column1: Before the NBA proceeds to its standard 16-team postseason format
column2: each team will play eight regular season games in a “seeding” round that will set the playoff bracket and allow players to shake off rust. The results and statistics for these games will count toward regular season totals
column3: and the matchups were determined by the remaining opponents on each team’s schedule before the shutdown
column4: with a balancing process used to finalize pairings.

column1: Games begin July 30 with a TNT doubleheader that features the New Orleans Pelicans versus the Utah Jazz and a crosstown battle between the Los Angeles Lakers and Clippers. July 31 will see five games
column2: highlighted by an ESPN doubleheader featuring the Boston Celtics versus the Milwaukee Bucks and the Houston Rockets versus the Dallas Mavericks. This TV-friendly launch ensures that the league’s brightest stars set to compete in Orlando — LeBron James
column3: Kawhi Leonard
column4: Giannis Antetokounmpo
column5: Luka Doncic and James Harden — all appear on the first two nights.

column1: AD
AD
Teams will then play between four and seven games per night through Aug. 14
column2: with at least three of those games nationally televised on TNT
column3: ESPN or NBA TV. From there
column4: the schedule will proceed to a possible play-in round for the eighth seeds in each conference before the first round of the playoffs starts on Aug. 17.

column2: 'Nba Reporter']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/HHHMLEFX2AI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2020/06/25/saturday-night-live-blackface//SNL is proof that blackface has long been an issue in comedy/"“What if the blackface was just part of your costume of a black person?” one lawmaker asked. “Does it count if you did it all the way back in the ’80s?” another wondered. Blackface “was never funny or cool
column2: ” chided Thompson’s character
column3: who ultimately concluded that his colleagues were beyond help.

column1: The sketch would have been just as timely a few months before when Megyn Kelly parted ways with NBC after questioning why it would be considered racist to wear blackface as part of a Halloween costume. Or a few months later when Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologized for resurfaced photos and videos of him in blackface. And that
column2: of course
column3: was part of the point. But as the New York Daily News and other outlets later pointed out
column4: “Saturday Night Live” has its own history with blackface — a history that spans most of the show’s 45-year existence.

column1: AD
AD

SNL’s not-so-distant history with blackface garnered renewed attention earlier this month after social media users called out “Tonight Show” host and SNL alum Jimmy Fallon for wearing blackface during a 2000 sketch. SNL
column2: of course
column3: isn’t the only TV comedy to use blackface: Fallon’s ABC counterpart Jimmy Kimmel apologized this week for doing the same while impersonating NBA player Karl Malone on Comedy Central’s “The Man Show” in the early aughts
column4: and several years-old episodes from shows including “30 Rock” and “W/ Bob & David” were pulled from streaming services because they feature blackface. But as a long-standing institution of American comedy
column5: SNL provides a window into a culture that has continued to passively embrace an inherently racist tradition meant to demean and mock black people.

column1: Blackface as entertainment emerged from 19th-century minstrel shows that featured white actors in dark makeup
column2: playing characters who embodied stereotypical depictions of African Americans. It continued well into the 20th century with white performers
column3: including legendary child star Shirley Temple
column4: donning blackface in highly visible roles. Some actors
column5: such as Al Jolson
column6: rose to fame in blackface
column7: which also seeped into children’s cartoons before largely — but not completely — falling out of public favor after the civil rights movement.

column1: SNL
column2: which debuted in 1975
column3: featured white performers in blackface long after that. Billy Crystal wore blackface while impersonating Sammy Davis Jr. in the 1980s
column4: even while acting opposite civil rights leader Jesse Jackson
column5: who hosted the show in 1984. National moments of reckoning — such as Ted Danson’s widely ridiculed appearance in blackface at the 1993 roast for his then-girlfriend
column6: Whoopi Goldberg — also did little to deter the show. More than a decade after Jackson’s hosting gig
column7: Darrell Hammond
column8: who was on SNL from 1995 to 2009
column9: darkened his skin to play Jackson on a recurring basis.

column1: AD
AD

Fallon came under fire in late May after clips from the sketch show in which he is wearing blackface while impersonating former SNL cast member Chris Rock recirculated online. “I am very sorry for making this unquestionably offensive decision and thank all of you for holding me accountable
column2: ” Fallon tweeted. He later apologized on his late-night show
column3: where he discussed the incident with CNN’s Don Lemon
column4: anti-racism educator Jane Elliott and NAACP President Derrick Johnson
column5: who praised Fallon’s “powerful” monologue.

column1: Rock famously left SNL after an early-’90s stint
column2: during a portion of which he was the show’s only black comedian. He landed at “In Living Color
column3: ” the far more diverse sketch comedy series created by Keenen Ivory Wayans. “I wanted to be in an environment where I didn’t have to really translate the comedy that I wanted to do
column4: ” Rock told Marc Maron in a 2011 interview.

column1: Even when SNL has employed racial stereotypes in an attempt to offer subversive commentary
column2: past efforts often fell flat because of the show’s lack of diversity on- and off-screen. When Oprah Winfrey hosted in 1986
column3: the cold open centered on her pointed refusal to dress up as Aunt Jemima. But the same sketch featured Danitra Vance
column4: then the only black comedian on the show
column5: serving coffee to executive producer Lorne Michaels
column6: whom she called “Mr. Lorne
column7: ” while dressed like Celie
column8: Goldberg’s character from “The Color Purple.” Michaels asks Vance what he should do to get Winfrey to play Aunt Jemima. “Beat her
column10: it’s Winfrey who doles out a faux beating.)

column1: AD
AD
In an ironic twist nearly 30 years later
column2: SNL was urged to hire a black female comedian after Thompson told TV Guide in a 2013 interview that he would no longer dress up as a woman to play prominent black women
column3: including Winfrey. A few weeks later
column4: the show — which hadn’t featured a black woman in its cast since Maya Rudolph’s departure in 2007 — controversially featured host Kerry Washington as Michelle Obama
column5: with cast members poking fun at how they hadn’t seen the first lady in “years.”

column1: But even after a concerted effort — following an onslaught of criticism — to add black cast members and writers among its ranks in recent years
column2: the show has yet to publicly grapple with its long history of blackface. The result is an uneven legacy that juxtaposes the show’s occasionally sharp racial humor (ranging from the groundbreaking “Racist Word Association Interview” sketch starring Richard Pryor to last year’s masterful “Mid-Day News”) with recurring missteps around representation and sketches that perpetuate racial stereotypes instead of subverting them. At worst
column3: the show undermines the brilliance of sketches such as “Black Jeopardy
column4: ” which is elevated by the insight of SNL’s black staffers
column5: including Thompson
column6: now the show’s longest-running cast member
column7: and Michael Che
column8: the first black comedian to be named a head writer on the show.

column1: Michaels
column2: who also produced “30 Rock
column3: ” defended his show’s use of blackface as recently as 2008
column4: when Fred Armisen
column5: who is not black
column6: donned conspicuously darker makeup to impersonate President Barack Obama. Michaels told The Washington Post’s Paul Farhi that the show had auditioned several black comedians — including Thompson
column7: then the show’s lone black cast member — to play Obama but that Armisen had the “best take” on the nation’s first black president.

column1: AD
AD
“It’s not about race
column2: ” Michaels said. “It’s about getting a take on Obama
column3: where it serves the comedy and the writing.” Armisen
column4: who is of Venezuelan
column5: Korean and German descent
column6: dismissed the criticism
column7: telling New York magazine
column8: “There’s shading on my eyebrows and plastic behind my ears.” He added that he wore the same “honey color” he wore to portray another black entertainer: Prince.

column1: Eventually
column2: Jay Pharoah
column3: who is black
column4: took on the role of Obama after joining the show in 2010. But critiques endured when it came to how SNL used black cast members in sketches. After leaving the show in 2016
column5: Pharoah recalled nearly losing his job after saying
column6: in an interview with theGrio
column7: that SNL needed to pay more attention to black female comedians. In the end
column8: he told “Ebro in the Morning
column9: ” he felt underutilized and too often reduced to doing impersonations of famous black men.

column1: “You go where you’re appreciated. You know what I mean?” said Pharoah
column2: whose SNL contract wasn’t renewed for a seventh season. “And if you have multiple people on the cast saying things like ‘You’re so talented
column3: and you’re able; they don’t use you
column4: and it’s unfair and it’s making us feel bad because they don’t use you and you’re a talent …’ ”

column1: AD
AD
The comedian also noted that the show had yet to name his successor in impersonating Obama in the final months of his presidency
column2: a position it never ended up filling. “Honest to God
column3: no disrespect to them
column4: but I kind of feel like they gave up
column5: ” he said."/['Bethonie Butler'
column6: 'Reporter Covering Television'
column7: 'Pop Culture']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/AELUIVDOTNC6NI6BEHTUDZ5TMY.JPG&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2020/06/25/dixie-chicks-change-name-chicks//Dixie Chicks drop Dixie
column2: change name to The Chicks: ‘We want to meet this moment’/"The name change comes two weeks after Lady Antebellum
column3: another country trio
column4: announced that they would just be known as “Lady A
column5: ” and expressed regret and embarrassment at their previous name’s association with the pre-Civil War slavery era. Afterward
column6: others wondered on social media whether the Dixie Chicks would take the same step
column7: given the Dixie association with the Confederate South.

column1: AD
AD
In a statement
column2: the Chicks also noted that they checked with a New Zealand duo also called the Chicks — a likely preemptive measure after Lady A saw backlash when they didn’t realize their new moniker was already used by a blues singer in Seattle. “A sincere and heartfelt thank you goes out to ‘The Chicks’ of NZ for their gracious gesture in allowing us to share their name
column3: ” the band said. “We are honored to co-exist together in the world with these exceptionally talented sisters. Chicks Rock!”

column1: The Chicks also dropped a new music video for “March March
column2: ” which features people through history marching for civil rights as well as many recent videos from Black Lives Matter protests. (Including an image of “Black Lives Matter” painted in front of the White House.) The first scene shows a quote on screen: “If your voice held no power
column3: they wouldn’t try to silence you.” That sentiment should come as no surprise
column4: as the Chicks are known for speaking up: The band was essentially blacklisted from the country music industry after Maines criticized George W. Bush on the eve of the Iraq War in front of a London concert crowd.

column1: However
column2: the trio never backed down: Their first single after the incident was titled “Not Ready to Make Nice
column3: ” and called out the people who just told them to shut up and sing. (It wound up winning three Grammy Awards.) Earlier this year
column4: the band confirmed plans for their first new album in 14 years titled “Gaslighter
column5: ” which shares a name with the fiery title track about an unrepentant liar. It was originally scheduled to drop in May
column6: but amid the coronavirus pandemic
column7: the release date was postponed until July 17.

column1: AD
AD"/['Emily Yahr'
column2: 'Style Reporter Covering Pop Culture']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/O5DVHLFXAII6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/workers-removed-thousands-of-social-distancing-stickers-before-trumps-tulsa-rally-according-to-video-and-a-person-familiar-with-the-set-up/2020/06/27/f429c3be-b801-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html/Workers removed thousands of social distancing stickers before Trump’s Tulsa rally
column2: according to video and a person familiar with the set-up/"The removal contradicted instructions from the management of the BOK Center
column3: the 19
column4: 000-seat arena in downtown Tulsa where Trump held his rally on June 20. At the time
column5: coronavirus cases were rising sharply in Tulsa County
column6: and Trump faced intense criticism for convening a large crowd for an indoor political rally
column7: his first such event since the start of the pandemic.

column1: As part of its safety plan
column2: arena management had purchased 12
column3: 000 do-not-sit stickers for Trump’s rally
column4: intended to keep people apart by leaving open seats between attendees. On the day of the rally
column5: event staff had already affixed them on nearly every other seat in the arena when Trump’s campaign told event management to stop and then began removing the stickers
column6: hours before the president’s arrival
column7: according to a person familiar with the event who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal matters.

column1: AD
AD
In a video clip obtained by The Washington Post
column2: two men — one in a suit and one wearing a badge and a face mask — can be seen pulling stickers off seats in a section of the arena. It is unclear who those two men are. When Trump took the stage on Saturday evening
column3: the crowd was clustered together and attendees were not leaving empty seats between themselves.

column1: The actions by Trump’s campaign were first reported Friday by Billboard Magazine. As rally preparations were underway
column2: Trump’s campaign staff intervened with the venue manager
column3: ASM Global
column4: and told them to stop labeling seats in this way
column5: Doug Thornton
column6: executive vice president of ASM Global
column7: told the magazine.

column1: “They also told us that they didn’t want any signs posted saying we should social distance in the venue
column2: ” Thornton said. “The campaign went through and removed the stickers.”

column1: AD
AD
A spokesman for ASM Global declined to comment.
Trump campaign spokesman Tim Murtaugh did not directly respond to questions about the sticker removal.
“The rally was in full compliance with local requirements. In addition
column2: every rally attendee received a temperature check prior to admission
column3: was given a face mask
column4: and provided ample access to hand sanitizer
column5: ” Murtaugh said in an emailed statement.

column1: In a separate statement
column2: the campaign said: “There were signs posted and we are not aware of any campaign staff asking that they be removed.”

column1: Trump held his Tulsa rally despite opposition by Oklahoma health authorities and residents who feared that convening a large crowd indoors could accelerate the spread of the coronavirus. The number of coronavirus cases in Tulsa County was spiking in the days leading up to the rally and has continued to increase since.
AD
AD
The director of the Tulsa Health Department
column2: Bruce Dart
column3: had recommended that the event be postponed until it was safer. A number of city residents and business owners brought a lawsuit against the venue manager
column4: ASM Global
column5: seeking to require all attendees wear masks and adhere to social distancing guidelines from health authorities.

column1: The Oklahoma Supreme Court rejected that suit.
On June 13
column2: a week before the rally
column3: Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt (R) wrote to the venue management saying he understood that Trump’s campaign “has presented plans to ASM Global in order to accommodate capacity crowds during a political rally.”

column1: Stitt noted that Oklahoma was in “Phase 3” of its reopening plan and Trump’s rally “proceeding as planned is consistent with the guidance” of that plan. Stitt’s letter added that “we have also encouraged event licensees to refer to the general CDC guidelines for more information about COVID-19.”
AD
AD
Two days before the rally
column2: the managers of the BOK Center had asked the Trump campaign to provide a detailed written plan outlining the “health and safety” measures it intended to use to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

column1: Before the rally
column2: Murtaugh said in an emailed statement: “We take safety seriously
column3: which is why we're doing temperature checks for everyone attending
column4: and providing masks and hand sanitizer. This will be a Trump rally
column5: which means a big
column6: boisterous
column7: excited crowd. We don’t recall the media shaming demonstrators about social distancing — in fact the media were cheering them on.”

column1: As the crowd entered the day of the rally
column2: the Trump campaign handed out masks and small bottles of “Make America Great Again 2020” branded hand sanitizer.

column1: AD
The BOK Center also put down floor decals in front of concession areas and put up plexiglass to protect vendors.
AD
At 1:47 p.m. that day
column2: Fox 23 News posted on its Facebook page a photo from inside the BOK Center showing two members of the event staff putting stickers on seats. “Stickers are going on every other seat in the BOK Center saying ‘Do Not Sit Here’ to try to spread the crowd out for President Trump’s rally tonight
column3: ” the post read.

column1: After the majority of the stickers were in place
column2: a member of Trump’s campaign radioed staff in the event war room where arena management was monitoring preparations and told them to stop
column3: according to the person familiar with the event. Event staff was told to continue applying the stickers. Later
column4: the campaign began pulling them off
column5: the person said.

column1: AD
In video footage of Trump’s rally
column2: there appeared to be no effort to keep an empty seat between attendees.

column1: Attendance turned out to be less than Trump expected — he had said some 1 million people wanted tickets — and the arena was not full
column2: particularly in the upper level.

column1: AD
Trump had wanted every seat packed
column2: and he told advisers coming in on Air Force One and at the arena he was displeased that the crowd was not larger
column3: said two Trump advisers
column4: who like others spoke on the condition of anonymity to relay private conversations.

column1: “He was quite angry
column2: ” said one person who interacted with him.

column1: Trump had told North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper (D) during a May 29 phone call that he would not hold a socially distanced convention in Charlotte because he had never had an empty seat since he came down the escalator at the start of his presidential campaign in 2015.
AD
Neither Trump nor the White House asked that the stickers be removed
column2: said a senior White House official. While campaign staff and some attendees wore masks during the rally
column3: many rallygoers did not.

column1: At least six members of the Trump campaign advance staff have tested positive for the coronavirus
column2: including two Secret Service employees. Dozens of Secret Service officers and agents who attended the Tulsa rally were ordered to self-quarantine.

column1: AD
Since the rally
column2: coronavirus cases in Tulsa County hit a new high of 259 new confirmed cases on June 23."/['Joshua Partlow'

column5: 'The Middle East.'
column6: 'Josh Dawsey'
column7: 'Reporter Covering The White House']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/J372APVYCUI6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/with-the-novel-coronavirus-suddenly-at-60-were-now-old/2020/06/26/16b1406c-afea-11ea-8f56-63f38c990077_story.html/Coronavirus makes age 60 feel old/"Suddenly 60 is the new 65. At 62
column2: I believe I speak for many other late-stage boomers when I say: Wait
column3: what?

column1: “I turn 60 later this year so I noticed that acutely
column2: ” said Chip Conley
column3: founder of the Modern Elder Academy
column4: which he calls the world’s first midlife wisdom school. “It was all of a sudden: I’m in a high-risk group? I’m perceived as elderly?”

column1: AD

I don’t mean to reject any help that might keep me and my graying cohort alive. Bring on those peaceful senior shopping hours. Nor would I ever argue that policing these linguistic limits should be a top priority when thousands of Americans have died
column2: tens of millions are out of work and our democracy is floundering.

column1: AD
All the same
column2: this sudden downward pressure on the boundary of old age strikes me as un-American. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Census for years have used 65 to define older Americans. (It was only last Thursday that the CDC tried to calm the confusion with a news release stating: “It’s not just those over the age of 65 who are at increased risk for severe illness.”) You still can’t get Medicare until 65 or full Social Security benefits until age 66. So maybe this is something else we can blame on China and the World Health Organization
column3: given that both use “over 60” to define old age
column4: and both have been the source of a lot of coronavirus news.

column1: More important
column2: for those of us in the early-60s gray zone
column3: the slipping standard harms more than our vanity
column4: stealing our last shred of deniability even as the shutdown deprives us of tools we’ve relied on to pass ourselves off as younger
column5: such as Botox
column6: hair salons and gyms.

column1: AD
Denial plays a vital role in human survival
column2: which helps explain why most prefer to bask in it as long as possible.

column1: “From age 40 onwards
column2: people report feeling about 20 percent younger than their chronological age
column3: an amount that obviously gets bigger over time
column4: ” Sarah Barber
column5: an expert on cognitive aging at Georgia State University
column6: told me. As we age
column7: we also tend to imagine “old age” as beginning later and later
column8: she said
column9: further boosting our illusion that we’re still young.

column1: AD
We’re only as old as we feel
column2: as they say. The hitch is we can be made to feel older — and frailer and less competent — when reminded of our age and the inevitable downsides. This has been established by studies of the “stereotype threat
column3: ” meaning that when old people
column4: or mothers
column5: or other groups
column6: for example
column7: are reminded of the stereotypes about their group
column8: they unwittingly tend to validate them.

column1: AD
In one seminal study
column2: older adults — in this case ages 62 to 84 — were split into three groups. One group read articles linking age to cognitive decline. Another read articles describing older people who stayed sharp as they aged. The third group did no reading. All three groups then took a test that challenged them to remember several words. Guess which group forgot most of them? The first one
column3: of course.

column1: Focusing on gloomy images of aging can make you less coordinated and even less healthy. Researchers have found that people who feel more negative about aging in midlife may later be less competent drivers and have a harder time recovering from a heart attack. People who accept the most depressing cultural images of aging may also take worse care of themselves
column2: even shortening their own lives by an average of 7.5 years.

column1: AD
Pandemic culture floods us with constant reminders about aging and death
column2: not least with its nasty Twitter hashtags like BoomerDoomer and BoomerRemover. Stories about “seniors” are frequently illustrated with images of stooped postures and canes
column3: or photos of lonely
column4: white-haired grandmothers peering out of locked windows.

column1: AD
No wonder my knees ache and I’ve recently switched to stronger reading glasses. More than once
column2: I’ve asked my husband what day it is
column3: which is unsettling for both of us
column4: as much as I’ve heard other age groups are having the same trouble.

column1: Seeking to stop stereotypes from becoming self-fulfilling prophecies
column2: groups like Conley’s Modern Elder Academy and AARP have been trying to “reframe” aging
column3: emphasizing the many purported benefits
column4: such as wisdom and contentment. They’re casting a wide net
column5: given that the average age of Conley’s “elders” is 52
column6: and AARP starts mailing you membership cards when you turn 50.

column1: AD
Ageism has long been one of America’s favorite prejudices
column2: even though — if we’re lucky — we’ll all become its target. “We disparage elderly people without fear of censure
column3: ” wrote the psychologist authors of a study on aging stereotypes
column4: “Doddering but dear.” Among other discouraging news
column5: they cite research demonstrating that on top of discrimination in hiring and medical decisions
column6: older adults are more likely than any other age group to appear on TV and in movies “as conduits for comic relief
column7: exploiting stereotypes of physical
column8: cognitive

column1: AD
No wonder even many in the over-65 set don’t feel ready for the new considerations and limitations based on being officially over the hill.
“I feel grounded like a wayward adolescent punished for underage smoking or drinking
column2: ” complained Politico editor Paul Taylor
column4: referring to his cohort of “fit
column5: never-been-busier
column6: un-retirees” as “the twelderly
column7: ” inspired by the word “tween
column8: ” for a pre-adolescent.

column1: AD
Before the pandemic
column2: I too imagined myself as
column3: at worst
column4: pre-elderly
column5: while assuming there was widespread agreement about the endpoint of plausible youth. I’ll even confess to a shimmer of schadenfreude on reading Texas Lt. Gov. Daniel Patrick’s controversial call for old people to consider sacrificing their lives for the economy
column6: given that Patrick’s standard was “70 plus.”

column1: AD
But then I realized just how much the coronavirus may be infecting all of us with the most dreadful view of aging
column2: in which “old” is synonymous with useless and expendable. And who’s ever ready for that?

column1: Read more"/['Katherine Ellison']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/JNAKV5FXEII6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"
https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/27/coronavirus-live-updates-us//Live updates: Florida
column2: Georgia
column3: South Carolina and Nevada hit new highs in daily coronavirus cases/"LONDON — Holiday-loving Britons have reason to cheer: The British government said it would ease blanket travel restrictions early next month.

column1: Earlier in June
column2: Britain introduced new quarantine rules that meant almost anyone entering the country
column3: including British nationals
column4: would have to self-isolate for two weeks. For many Brits
column5: this made the idea of jet-setting to Spain or France for their annual summer holiday seem almost impossible. But the British government said that
column6: from July 6
column7: it will scrap the quarantine rules for several European countries.

column1: The news was splashed across the front pages of Saturday newspapers: “Fly out for sun
column2: sea and 70% off
column3: ” said the Daily Mail. “Holiday season back on
column4: ” ran a headline on the front of the Times of London.

column1: Brits love to holiday abroad: In normal times
column2: about 60 percent of Brits go on an overseas holiday. Of course
column3: these are not normal times
column4: and it remains to be seen how many people will book a vacation to sun-kissed destinations. But the hard-hit travel industry was clearly elated with the news.

column1: “It’s incredibly welcome
column2: ” said Jonathan Smith
column3: a spokesman for ABTA
column4: a trade association for travel agents and tour operators. He told the BBC that they expect a “surge of bookings … although some people may be slightly reticent to travel.”

column1: Under a “traffic light system
column2: ” countries will be given a green
column3: amber or red rating based on coronavirus levels and other measures. Passengers coming from countries with a “red” rating will have to continue to abide by the mandatory 14-day quarantine rules.

column1: The full list of countries will be published next week. Top tourist destinations like France
column2: Spain and Greece are expected to be on the approved list.

column1: There was no suggestion that the United States would be on the approved list
column2: although its exclusion could “potentially present a tricky diplomatic dynamic
column3: ” wrote the BBC’s Tom Burridge."/['Derek Hawkins'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/young-people-are-driving-a-spike-in-coronavirus-infections-officials-say/2020/06/27/3654638c-b7b4-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/Young people urged to take virus more seriously as pandemic worsens in U.S./"“Younger Americans have a particular responsibility to make sure that they’re not carrying the coronavirus into settings where they would expose the most vulnerable
column2: ” Pence said.

column1: AD
Robert R. Redfield
column2: the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column3: said younger people are often asymptomatic or have mild symptoms but can easily spread the virus to older or immune-compromised patients.

column1: AD
While the virus is most dangerous to the elderly
column2: it can be devastating to younger victims as well
column3: health professionals said. Younger coronavirus patients are a widening percentage of total coronavirus hospitalizations
column4: with those in the 18 to 49 age group growing from about 27 percent of hospitalizations the week ending March 7 to 35 percent this past week
column5: CDC figures show.

column1: Officials across the country — from Ohio to Arizona — said coronavirus cases among young people were spiking as many red states that were slow to shut down in the early days of the pandemic threw their doors open again.
AD
In Texas
column2: Gov. Greg Abbott
column3: a Republican
column4: on Friday closed bars except for delivery and take out
column5: limited restaurant capacity to 50 percent and closed popular rafting and tubing businesses that drove hundreds of young people to gather on spots near New Braunfels and the Comal River. More than half of new cases in the counties that encompass Austin
column6: Dallas
column7: Houston and San Antonio came among the young
column8: authorities said.

column1: AD
Mark Escott
column2: Austin’s medical director
column3: said case investigation and contact tracing are challenging because people have been interacting with more people in recent weeks. His team recently learned about a large party in the city’s western suburbs that attracted 300 to 400 high schoolers to a single location. The students were together for hours.

column1: “There is concern about substantial transmission
column2: and there’s an effort now to identify those individuals
column3: ” said Escott
column4: who did contact tracing for another cluster of young people who went to Cabo San Lucas for spring break and brought the virus home.

column1: AD

Escott said increasing numbers of young people are ending up in the ICU and on ventilators because so many are infected with the virus. Escott said some young people will be forever changed by the virus
column2: unable to return to a normal life or work.

column1: AD
“This is a devastating disease
column2: and this is not something you want to take chances with because the impact is just so variable that it’s very hard to predict who’s going to do well and who is not
column3: ” he said.

column1: In Oklahoma
column2: Gov. Kevin Stitt
column3: a Republican
column4: said nearly half of all coronavirus cases diagnosed after the state reopened in late April have been among people under 35. The vast majority — 70 percent — of cases since reopening have been diagnosed in people under 50. Stitt said the state will not order any businesses to close. More than 12
column5: 000 Oklahomans have been diagnosed with the coronavirus.

column1: AD

Tulsa health director Bruce Dart said new cases and hospitalizations are at record highs; 40 percent of the cases and a quarter of hospitalizations from the virus are among people ages 18 to 35. Last weekend 6
column2: 200 people attended an indoor rally with President Trump.

column1: AD
“They’re conducting themselves like it’s pre-covid
column2: and that’s not going to work anymore
column3: ” Dart said. The younger cohort is “not social distancing
column4: not wearing masks or paying attention to hand-washing. These are the only tools we have to break the chain of transmission now.”

column1: Dart said it was too soon to tell if any new cases would stem from Trump’s rally
column2: where several of his Secret Service and staff tested positive for the virus
column3: and that any impact would not show until later next week.

column1: AD
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis
column2: a Republican
column3: said earlier this week that the state had a “real explosion” of cases among the young — including a drop in the median age of new cases that plummeted from age 65 to 35. DeSantis’s decision to close bars is an attempt to quell risky socializing; in recent days officials yanked liquor licenses from bars that were not adhering to social distancing and capacity guidelines.

column1: AD
Geoff Beere
column2: a student at the University of Miami and a club promoter
column3: said that when bars in Florida reopened in June
column4: they were quickly packed — even those that tried to enforce social distancing. He said students were tired of being cooped up during the statewide stay-at-home order.

column1: “College kids are gonna be a little bit more stupid about things than older people
column2: maybe a little more reckless
column3: ” he said.

column1: AD
Now that bars and clubs have been effectively shut again as the state prohibits businesses from selling alcohol indoors
column2: he predicts parties and pool parties that flourished at the beginning of the pandemic will do so again.

column1: Beere said he is cognizant of the spread of the coronavirus among his age group
column2: but he is not overly concerned.

column1: “I don’t feel invincible
column2: and the virus is obviously serious
column3: ” he said. “But in the same sense
column4: I’m young
column5: I’m healthy
column6: and it’s not likely to kill someone like me. But I know it can affect somebody else.”

column1: AD
Beere wears a mask during his daily life when he goes to the gym or grocery shopping
column2: but not when he is at a club or a party.

column1: AD
“I’m not anti-mask
column2: ” Beere said. “But you really can’t drink with it on.”

column1: In Oklahoma
column2: several large-scale events have been canceled as the state’s cases have spiked
column3: including a popular Oktoberfest in Tulsa and the state fair. But in-person high school graduations have gone on
column4: and several communities are having Fourth of July celebrations. The party has not stopped at Dripping Springs
column5: the party cove at Grand Lake O’ the Cherokees in northeastern Oklahoma
column6: where revelers on boats tie up
column7: drink
column8: mingle in the water and turn up the country music.

column1: “You’re taking a chance going down there
column2: but it’s slimmer than going to a night club or bar surrounded by people you don’t know
column3: ” said Kaden Clites
column4: a Butler Community College student from Wichita who spent a day on a boat in the party cove with some friends earlier this month.

column1: AD
AD
Restaurants and bars in Oklahoma are operating without restrictions
column2: and Stitt said in a news conference Thursday that would continue.

column1: “Closing down the economy is not part of the discussions at this point
column2: ” Stitt said.

column1: Matthew Broberg-Moffitt
column3: an immunocompromised writer who lives in Oklahoma City
column4: said few of the young people in his town embraced mask-wearing.

column1: Shortly after the state eased its restrictions on reopening
column2: he passed an upscale pizza place in the town’s Plaza District and saw dozens of young people milling about outside
column3: not socially distanced.

column1: “It’s very distressing
column2: ” Broberg-Moffitt said. “It’s definitely causing me to lose sleep — and I feel a lot of anger. I’m not an angry person. I was a Buddhist monk for a while. But I’m having a lot of pent-up anger and moments that are almost like rage at how poorly this is being handled.”

column1: AD"/['Annie Gowen'
column2: 'National Correspondent'
column3: 'Arelis R. Hernández'
column4: 'Reporter Covering The U.S. Southern Border'
column5: 'Immigration'
column6: 'Texas'
column7: 'Lori Rozsa']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/EAI5BTFYQ4I6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/27/some-states-families-can-start-visiting-nursing-homes-again//In some states
column2: families can start visiting nursing homes again/"Barred since March
column3: many have worried that no one has sufficiently taken up the slack.

column1: Now
column2: after tens of thousands of residents died as the coronavirus swept through one nursing home after another
column3: more than a dozen states are cautiously setting rules for the return of a limited number of family visitors. They range from New Jersey
column4: where officials believe the peak of the pandemic has passed
column5: to New Hampshire
column6: which has seen very few cases all spring
column7: to Oklahoma
column8: where even as cases are spiking
column9: criteria have been drawn up to allow family access. But the distancing rules in effect will prevent visitors from carrying out much of their earlier hygiene care.

column1: AD
AD
Limited access raises difficult questions about equity and bias. Not every resident
column2: or every family
column3: will qualify for a visit. Nursing homes vary considerably in their capacity to control infection. The pandemic is still raging
column4: and some states — including New York
column5: Pennsylvania
column6: Ohio and Florida — have not budged.

column1: June Cox had gone to see her mother
column2: Dorothy Cox
column3: three times a day at her nursing home in San Diego. “I tried to take care of her physically
column4: emotionally
column5: musically
column6: spiritually
column7: every way I could think of
column8: ” she said.

column1: After March 13 she called as often as she could on FaceTime. “ ‘I’ll be there as soon as I can be
column2: as soon as I’m allowed
column3: Mama
column4: ’ ” she told her mother. “She’s not a prisoner. She hasn’t committed a crime. She’s not supposed to be living in solitary confinement.”

column1: AD
Dorothy began declining shortly after the lockdown began and died alone April 7 after a seizure. “My mother would still be alive
column2: I’m pretty sure
column3: ” said June
column4: if she had been able to keep looking after her.

column1: AD
On March 11
column2: Leonard Beatty of Ashland
column3: Mo.
column4: seemed as robust as he had been in months. His appetite was back. His wife
column5: Myrna
column6: and daughter
column7: Cindy Harper
column8: had made plans to bring him home from The Bluffs nursing home in nearby Columbia by early April. The staffers “worked their butts off
column10: but they felt they could care for her father
column11: who had dementia
column12: better at home. He was unnerved
column13: she said
column14: by the “hollering” and crying of other residents.

column1: “Then covid hit
column2: ” she said
column3: referencing the disease caused by the coronavirus. “The door slammed. What do you do?”

column1: AD
They visited with him through a window March 31
column2: his 84th birthday
column3: and he still seemed strong. But when they sang “Happy Birthday
column4: ” he started sobbing.

column1: The next time they saw him was a week later. “We were shocked
column2: ” Harper said. “He was just a shell of himself. We didn’t know what was going on.”

column1: AD
No one from the nursing home had told them he was failing.
Two days after that
column2: a staff member called them and said he should be put in hospice care. He had bronchitis
column3: they were told. He was not tested for the coronavirus. Instead
column4: with considerable difficulty
column5: they arranged to bring him home
column6: where he died 29 hours later.

column1: Myrna Beatty believes that by being there she had enabled him to survive a bout of pneumonia in October. She and Harper think their absence this spring was fatal to him
column2: that he would still be alive if they had been able to bring him home April 1 as they had planned.

column1: AD
“I have to accept this is the way it went down
column2: ” Harper said. “We have to tell ourselves we did our best. It was out of our hands that we weren’t there to help him. And that hurts. Covid? It did us in. We’ll feel forever guilty.

column1: AD
“He may not have died from covid-19
column2: but he definitely died because of it.”

column1: The tension with renewed visits is between safety and compassion
column2: said Susan Frampton
column3: president of an advocacy group called Planetree International. Staffers and residents alike shouldn’t be needlessly exposed to the virus. But neither should someone be cut off from all family contact. Frampton points out that family members can spot troubling signs in residents more quickly than can staff members
column4: who may be rotating through shifts and not well acquainted with certain residents.

column1: AD
“Isolation has serious impacts on the health and well-being of the residents of these facilities
column2: ” said Daniel Rusyniak
column3: chief medical officer of the Indiana Family and Social Services Administration. As with most of the other states relaxing visitation rules
column4: Indiana now permits families to meet outdoors only
column5: socially distanced
column6: masked
column7: supervised and tested for the coronavirus.

column1: AD
New Jersey’s rules are similar
column2: with special attention given to infection control measures as residents move through the nursing home to meet their relatives outdoors. Visits are allowed only at nursing homes that have “attested” to the state their ability to meet the requirements. As of this week
column3: more than 300 had done so
column4: according to Dawn Thomas
column5: a spokeswoman for the Department of Health.

column1: In Oklahoma
column2: the rules are not so strict. “We encourage families as they reunite with their loved ones to consider getting tested in advance and to wear masks for visitations and closely follow heightened protocols at the facilities
column3: ” Commissioner of Health Lance Frye said in a news release.

column1: AD
On June 18
column2: Texas Gov. Gregg Abbott (R) said that guidance for visits would be coming within a week. But since then
column3: cases have spiked and he has announced a pause on further reopening in the state.

column1: AD
Elaine Ryan
column2: vice president of state advocacy and government affairs for AARP
column3: said she is concerned that the states are moving too fast and too haphazardly.

column1: “No state has the infection and death count under control in nursing homes and assisted living
column2: ” she said. “Nursing homes are struggling with just the basics. We have a long way to go to have the assurances that these kinds of visits can be done safely.”

column1: But the coronavirus already has a foothold in many if not most nursing homes
column2: brought in through the “back door” by staff
column3: said Mike Dark
column4: an attorney with California Advocates for Nursing Home Reform.

column1: AD
And since March
column2: those nursing homes have been operating without the vigilant oversight that visitors provide.

column1: “Facilities have spiraled into apocalyptic conditions without that outside eye
column2: ” he said. “And we’re looking for this crisis to play out over years
column3: not months.” There’s no way that residents can be kept isolated from their families that long
column4: he said.

column1: AD
A California woman who spoke on the condition of anonymity out of fear of reprisals said of her 38-year-old son
column2: paralyzed four years ago when he was hit by a truck: “I don’t want him to feel like he’s been put in a closet and forgotten.” He can’t speak because of a tracheotomy
column3: and she fears that has contributed to less-than-attentive care.

column1: AD
“It’s very easy to ignore people who don’t have voices themselves
column2: ” she said. That’s why she wants to get back in to be his constant advocate.

column1: Marcia Reimer’s 93-year-old mother
column2: Joyce
column3: was in a nursing home in Orchard Lake
column4: Mich. Marcia visited at least four days a week. “I had made up my mind to be a presence there so they knew I was watching
column5: ” she said. She believes it paid off; she has no qualms about the care her mother received.

column1: Joyce had always been strong and independent
column2: Marcia said
column3: but went into the nursing home after falling and breaking her hip. One day after the lockdown began
column4: a trusted aide told Marcia over the phone: “You know
column5: I’ve never seen her mad. But today she was as mad as could be. She was mad at that virus.”

column1: AD
She died May 30. The doctor said it was congestive heart failure.
“She slipped away
column2: ” Marcia said. “That was her wish and my wish. She would have hated the drama
column3: that bedside vigil thing.”"/['Will Englund'

In the months since an outbreak of the novel coronavirus first surfaced in China late last year
column2: millions of people have been infected
column3: with cases reported in almost every country in the world.

column1: Hundreds of thousands of people are confirmed to have died of covid-19
column2: the disease the virus causes
column3: according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. In many places
column4: testing remains limited
column5: and the true case and death counts are probably far higher than the confirmed tally.

[Tracking the U.S. coronavirus outbreak
column2: state by state]

column1: “It took more than two months for the first 100
column2: 000 cases to be reported
column3: ” Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus
column4: secretary-general of the World Health Organization
column5: said in June. “For the past two weeks
column6: more than 100
column7: 000 new cases have been reported almost every single day.”

column1: At least reported deaths At least reported cases
[A more detailed look at the virus’s spread through U.S. counties and states]
Many countries turned to drastic containment measures to try to curb the spread of the virus. While some countries saw success in flattening the curve
column2: or in the case of New Zealand
column3: driving confirmed infections down to zero for a time
column4: others faced rising case numbers as global hot spots shifted.

column1: The Chinese city of Wuhan
column2: where the virus was first reported last year
column3: and parts of Europe once overwhelmed by the virus have largely begun to reopen and report far fewer cases and deaths.

column1: In the United States
column2: where testing efforts faltered early in the outbreak
column3: cases and deaths are slowing in some states but rising in others. The total number of U.S. reported cases remains by far the highest in the world. Brazil
column4: where cases surged as government leaders disagreed over the severity of the crisis and resisted lockdown measures
column5: now ranks second for the largest number of cases and deaths. Russia
column6: which ranks third for the highest number of confirmed cases
column7: is also struggling to contain a massive outbreak although its official death toll remains far lower than those of other hot spots.

column1: In May
column2: the World Health Organization declared South America the new epicenter of the global pandemic.

column1: [What you need to know about coronavirus]
In the early months of the outbreak
column2: China reported more cases than any other country. Its tally of new infections peaked in mid-February and approached zero by mid-March
column3: although questions surround the accuracy of its data.

column1: As the disease waned in China
column2: it began to surge in Italy and Spain. By May
column3: more than 150
column4: 000 people had died throughout Europe. This month
column5: a cluster of cases in Beijing linked to a large market has raised alarm over another major outbreak in the country.

column1: Deaths Cases Adjusted Adj. for population Raw numbers Per 100K Total Deaths Cases
While the virus appears to have plateaued or declined in much of Europe
column2: countries in South America
column3: South Asia and the Middle East have reported increases in case numbers.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: many countries — including China
column3: given the new cases in Beijing — fear the onslaught of a looming second wave of infections.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2020/03/13/if-you-feel-sick-are-worried-about-coronavirus-call-your-doctor-dont-rush-er//Q&A: Keeping yourself and others safe as states reopen/"You likely know the basics of keeping yourself and others safe: Keep at least six feet from other people
column2: avoid crowds
column3: wash your hands frequently and thoroughly and limit nonessential trips. And when around others in public
column4: wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth.

column1: AD
As Avi Selk wrote in The Post’s Coronavirus Updates newsletter: “Virtually anyone can have the virus at any time. You might feel very ill
column2: or mildly under the weather
column3: or perfectly fine and still pass it on to your loved ones. Act accordingly
column4: and be safe.”

column1: AD
Here’s the latest of what The Post knows about common questions as businesses and states reopen.
Is it safe for me to go outside?
For most people
column2: absolutely
column3: experts say. The outdoors may preserve your sanity — and save social distancing.

column1: Experts say that if you maintain a six-foot distance from other people
column2: you should be even safer outside than in a closed area.

column1: When outdoors
column2: “you don’t have to stay six feet away from your spouse or child
column3: ” said Maria Raven
column4: chief of emergency medicine at the University of California at San Francisco. “But if you are meeting a friend for a hike or going to the grocery store
column5: keep your distance.”

column1: AD

Dog walking is a good activity — as long as you don’t let your pet get too close to other dogs or other people. While the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says there is no indication pets play a significant role in transmitting the virus
column2: it recommends you treat them like family members
column3: keeping them away from animals and people not in your household. The Agriculture Department has confirmed the country’s first canine case of the virus in a German shepherd in New York
column4: as well as a few cases in cats.

column1: AD
Recommended reading:
If I’m older
column2: do I have to stay inside all the time?

column1: It’s hard to generalize
column2: because “some 70-year-olds run marathons
column3: so you can’t make a blanket statement about people’s risks
column4: ” said Jeanne Marrazzo
column5: director of the division of infectious diseases at the University of Alabama at Birmingham. But conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
column6: heart disease and diabetes raise people’s risks of becoming severely ill or dying of covid-19
column7: the disease caused by the coronavirus. Patients with such conditions die at 12 times the rate of those with none
column8: according to a recent CDC report. And even healthy seniors
column10: “don’t get a complete pass” on increased risk. The bottom line: All seniors should take extra care.

column1: AD
If you are a senior citizen or someone who is chronically ill or has a suppressed immune system
column2: see if you can get prescriptions and groceries delivered
column3: or send a younger relative to pick them up.

column1: AD
Recommended reading:
What about masks? Should I wear one?
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends wearing face coverings in public to slow spread of the coronavirus.

That guidance reversed earlier recommendations following evidence that infected people without symptoms can spread the virus. Experts and health officials stress a “collective responsibility”: your cloth mask may help protect others — not necessarily yourself. That means you are most protected when others around you wear them.
AD
Masks don’t remove the need for hand washing
column2: social distancing or other measures
column3: the CDC says. But the agency does recommend masks for “public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (e.g. grocery stores and pharmacies) especially in areas of significant community-based transmission.”

column1: AD
The science is still emerging. But a round of recent research
column2: including one review of 172 observational studies
column3: supports wearing masks to slow the spread of the virus. Officials in Springfield
column4: Mo.
column5: now credit face coverings with preventing an outbreak among at least 140 people exposed to two masked
column6: infected hair stylists.

column1: That evidence has convinced Carlos del Rio
column2: a professor of medicine and global health at Emory University. “We can stop transmission today
column3: ” he said
column4: referring to research on population-based masking when combined with other public-health measures. “We don’t need to wait until we have a vaccine.""

column1: AD
Health officials made clear that the public should avoid using the kind of gear — N95 respirators or surgical masks — that is in short supply and desperately needed by health workers.
AD
Recommended reading:
What do I do if my significant other gets sick?
It depends. If you have been with the person day and night for several days
column2: you may already be exposed. Still
column3: you can’t know for sure
column4: and doctors say it’s wise to err on the side of caution and distance yourself as much as possible.

column1: Most cases of covid-19 have mild or moderate symptoms
column2: and a spouse probably will be able to take care of himself or herself. If possible
column3: the ill spouse should move into an extra bedroom
column4: use a different bathroom and wear a mask to protect others in the household.

column1: AD
If you are living with someone who needs help
column2: you should wear a mask and gloves while providing care. If you are removing a dinner plate
column3: for example
column4: grab it with a dishrag or wear gloves
column5: doctors say.

column1: Even at a distance
column2: however
column3: it’s important to monitor a person with covid-19. Doctors are finding that covid-19 can appear with blood clots
column4: strokes and other serious conditions that require immediate medical care.

column1: AD
Recommended reading:
What are the symptoms of covid-19?
Months into the crisis
column2: we now know the disease has a far wider range of symptoms than initially thought. In addition to fever
column3: coughing
column4: shortness of breath and other flu-like symptoms
column5: doctors are seeing gastrointestinal problems — nausea and vomiting
column6: for example — chest pain and a loss of taste or smell.

column1: AD
In rare cases
column2: children and young adults are falling ill with a Kawasaki-like inflammatory illness that doctors call MIS-C. Some doctors report brain inflammation and pinkeye in patients. It’s not clear
column3: physicians say
column4: whether some of the varied symptoms are caused by covid-19 or just occurring at the same time.

column1: The CDC has added several new symptoms to its list for covid-19
column2: including chills
column3: repeated shaking with chills
column4: muscle pain
column5: headache
column6: sore throat and loss of taste and smell. The symptoms could appear two to 14 days after infection.

column1: AD
Recommended reading:
What do I do if I think I’m infected?
Consult your primary care doctor
column2: if you have one. Don’t go to the physician’s office or the emergency room without calling ahead. The coronavirus is highly contagious
column3: and doctors want to protect themselves and other patients from infection. You’ll probably be advised to self-quarantine and
column4: because there is no effective treatment for the disease
column5: take over-the-counter pain medicines such as Tylenol.

column1: AD
If symptoms worsen
column2: and you have trouble breathing
column3: persistent chest pain or pressure
column4: confusion or have underlying medical conditions
column5: seek immediate medical care.

column1: Recommended reading:
What if I have other health issues or emergencies?
Norman “Ned” Sharpless
column2: director of the National Cancer Institute
column3: has warned that delayed screenings and treatments could lead to an estimated 10
column4: 000 excess deaths from breast and colorectal cancer over the next decade. He urged doctors to make patients comfortable with coming in for screenings and treatment.

column1: AD
As with other appointments
column2: talk with your doctor’s office about their procedures
column3: and the possibility of a telemedicine visit
column4: before showing up in person. When you visit
column5: wear a mask
column6: keep yourself apart from other people and wash your hands or use hand sanitizer between points of contact.

column1: If you think you are having a health emergency
column2: call 911. Medical groups urged patients to do so after hospitals saw fewer patients coming in with heart attacks and other emergencies earlier this year.

column1: Recommended reading:
Will I be tested for the virus?
It depends on where you live and even what hospital or health system you use. After a sluggish start
column2: diagnostic testing is ramping up in many parts of the country
column3: helped by the entry of commercial labs and the approval of rapid tests by the Food and Drug Administration.

column1: Home testing
column2: an early point of interest
column3: is rarer. Since April
column4: the FDA has given emergency authorization for a few tests that allow patients to collect saliva or nasal samples at home and send them off for diagnosis.

column1: Some localities
column2: including in the DMV
column3: say they’re approaching the testing and tracing capability that experts say is critical to resuming parts of public life. And they’re encouraging people turned away by earlier testing issues to seek tests
column4: in some places even if they don’t have symptoms. The CDC recommends checking with your doctor
column5: or with your state or local health department for guidelines
column6: wait times and availability.

column1: Recommended reading:
What about antibody tests?

Antibody or serology tests are designed to detect whether you have been exposed to the virus and have antibodies that may help show whether you have immunity to the illness. They are not designed to detect active infections.
Dozens of antibody tests are on the market
column2: but the FDA has given emergency authorization to only a few. The agency has tightened its initial hands-off approach
column3: removing several dozen test makers from its list of authorized distributors.

column1: Even authorized tests have come in for scrutiny. Some government and business officials tout them as a way to reopen the economy by identifying people who can safely return to work. But many scientists
column2: as well as the World Health Organization
column3: say evidence is lacking that even high-quality antibody tests can prove someone who was infected has immunity from the novel coronavirus and is not at risk of being reinfected.

column1: For now
column2: experts say the tests are more useful as part of research than individual decision-making. “There’s no reason to get an antibody test other than curiosity
column3: ” del Rio said.

column1: Recommended reading:
Should I go shopping? To the dentist? To church?
Any enclosed space with other people will carry some risk. The standard guidelines for lowering that risk help keep yourself and others safe: The common use of masks indoors
column2: social distancing and hand-washing.

column1: The CDC released more detailed guidance for different activities as states eased restrictions. Some of the agency’s guidelines for reopening have come with delays and extended disputes from the White House.
Recommended reading:
What about going back to work?
The CDC has released stricter guidelines for office work
column2: including recommendations for cloth face coverings everywhere
column3: physical barriers and distancing and cutting back on communal items. Companies vary in how they’re handling reopening — one executive told The Post the guidelines were “kind of just a nice way of saying you can’t go back to the office.”

column1: Some federal and state policies may change your workplace rights during the pandemic
column2: and whether you may return or stay home.

column1: Recommended reading:
When will this end?
No one knows. Experts say the social distancing practiced by many Americans has prevented the pandemic from being worse. But the country hit a new single-day high for cases in June
column2: after many states eased restrictions and showed new highs in cases or hospitalizations.

column1: In June
column2: Anthony S. Fauci
column3: the top U.S. infectious-disease expert
column4: told the British Telegraph newspaper that it could be about a year before life in the U.S. returns to “some degree of real normality.”

column1: Public health officials have warned state leaders to proceed carefully and to be prepared to reinstate tough regulations if the number of virus cases surges. Experts say any successful reopening strategy must be accompanied by additional testing and contact tracing to quickly find and isolate people who contract the virus.
Chances are good we will have to maintain some measures — isolating the infected
column2: wearing face coverings
column3: regular hand-washing
column4: some degree of social distancing — until viable treatments and vaccines are developed
column5: which could take months or years.

column2: but if your interests skew toward baking
column3: you may have noticed a few common themes making the rounds: Sourdough. Elaborately decorated focaccia. Banana bread.

column1: Why so much banana bread? Hard to say. Maybe it’s because it is a comforting
column2: cozy and easy project
column3: especially for entry-level bakers. Maybe it’s ideal for when your grocery order goes completely rogue — like that time I asked for 17 bananas and got 17 BUNCHES. (True story
column4: thankfully I managed to donate most of them.)

column1: [One no-knead dough will give you focaccia

column1: There’s also a lot more variation in the genre than you might realize. Here are a few options from our archives to help you mix — and mash — things up.
Coffee-Spiked Banana Bread
column2: above. After I made this recipe for the photo you see here
column3: my family may have a new favorite. This supremely moist loaf from the popular “Moosewood Cookbook” has a gentle undercurrent of coffee that you might not even recognize. It will also make you appreciate how great milk chocolate chips can be in an otherwise semisweet or bittersweet world.

Naturally Sweet Banana Bread. There’s no added sugar in here thanks to dates pureed with yogurt
column2: both of which give the crumb of this cake (that’s what banana “bread” really is
column3: right?) an outstanding texture.

column3: homemade naan is the no-fuss bread for the no-fuss baker]

Banana Bread With Chocolate Drizzle. Using all whole-wheat flour and less sugar makes this recipe from Ellie Krieger not as over-the-top as some others.
[How to make a little yeast go a long way when baking bread]
(T. Susan Chang)
Gluten-Free Hazelnut Banana Bread. In addition to a nutty
column2: tender loaf
column3: you’ll have leftovers of the grain-free flour blend you can use for another batch or a different recipe.

column1: (Deb Lindsey for The Washington Post)
Sticky Banana Bread With Fresh Mango and Muscovado Cream. Mango and macadamias add some tropical flair to this recipe. The mango is served on the side
