column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2020/06/26/dc-museum-reopenings-coronavirus//Museums and gardens are reopening across the region. Here’s what you can visit now./"But other attractions have swung open the doors to their buildings and sculpture gardens. Safety is obviously a concern
column2: with stringent social distancing precautions: “Thou shalt wear a face mask” is one of the Museum of the Bible’s “Covid Commandments
column3: ” while the Spy Museum provides a “spy gadget
column4: ” or stylus
column5: for use with touch screens
column6: elevator buttons and any other surface that might spread germs. The National Gallery of Art’s Sculpture Garden has designated entrance and exit gates to control crowd flow.

column1: If you're looking to get the kids out of the house for a few hours
column2: or just spend an afternoon enjoying art in the open air
column3: one of these museums or historic homes could be the answer.

column1: AD
AD
This list will be updated as more institutions announce their plans.
Fully reopened
Hillwood Estate and Gardens: Marjorie Merriweather Post’s Northwest D.C. estate reopens to the public on June 27. Capacity will be limited to help with social distancing
column2: so visitors are required to make separate timed-entry reservations for the 25-acre gardens
column3: the mansion and exhibitions. (There’s no additional fee for admission to the mansion and exhibition.) Open Tuesday through Sunday. $5-$18. Ages 5 and younger free.

column1: International Spy Museum: The museum
column2: which moved to an expansive new building in L’Enfant Plaza last year
column3: has reopened with a limited capacity and extra distancing. (The museum now recommends a minimum of two hours to explore.) Many of the interactive elements have been modified to reduce contact
column4: but some elements are temporarily closed — including the sections in which visitors crawl through an air duct
column5: and attempt to escape East Berlin by hiding in a Trabant. “An interactive like the Air Duct is exceptionally difficult to transition to an appropriate touchless form
column6: so we will not make it available at this time
column7: ” Spy Museum media relations manager Aliza Bran explained in an email. However
column8: staff members have created alternatives in the space: The Trabant on display has a mannequin demonstrating the contortions needed to fit into a hidden space in the car. Open daily. $16.95-$24.95. Ages 6 and younger free.

column1: AD
AD
Museum of the Bible: Even beyond the coronavirus
column2: it’s been a rough year for the Museum of the Bible
column3: which forfeited a rare cuneiform tablet in May because federal authorities believe it entered the country illegally. In March
column4: it was revealed that 16 texts displayed as fragments of the Dead Sea Scrolls were actually modern fakes. But the museum is moving ahead. Most of its interactive exhibits are open
column5: as is the Milk and Honey Cafe. (The Virtual Reality Tour of the Lands of the Bible and the hands-on children’s area are closed.) Procedures to limit contact are in effect: Visitors will receive styluses to use with touch screens
column6: and are asked to download museum maps to their phones instead of picking up paper copies. Advance tickets are recommended. Open daily. $9.99-$19.99. Ages 6 and younger free.

column1: Partially reopened
Mount Vernon: George Washington’s historic estate became one of the first major attractions to reopen in the Washington area on June 21
column2: though
column3: for now at least
column4: social-distancing rules mean visitors can’t enter the mansion — it’s just too tight a squeeze for groups on the mandatory guided tours — or the distillery. Still
column5: the family-friendly museum is open
column6: minus the theaters and hands-on history area
column7: and all 160 acres of the grounds are open
column8: including the gardens
column10: farming demonstrations and the first president’s tomb. Capacity will be limited
column11: so advance ticket purchase is recommended. Open daily. $10-$18. Ages 5 and younger free.

column1: Outdoor areas only
Please note that access to facilities
column2: such as restrooms and cafes
column3: is limited. Check before going.

column1: AD
AD
Baltimore Museum of Art: The museum’s two sculpture gardens
column2: spread over three terraced acres
column3: include pieces by Alexander Calder
column4: Auguste Rodin and Elsworth Kelly. A cellphone tour with commentary is available. Open Tuesday through Sunday. Free.

column1: Glenstone: The much-buzzed-about Potomac art museum reopened as “an outdoor experience” in early June
column2: with visitors allowed to stroll the 300 acres of grounds and admire sculptures by Richard Serra
column3: Michael Heizer and Jeff Koons. Open Thursday through Sunday. Free
column4: reservations required. Tickets are released at 10 a.m. every Monday.

column1: National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden: The National Gallery’s beloved sculpture garden on the Mall reopened on June 20 as the first phase of the museum’s reopening. There are shorter hours (11 a.m. to 4 p.m.
column2: daily)
column3: limited capacity (a maximum of 271 visitors) and a new traffic flow
column4: but those are minor inconveniences when you just want to enjoy the enormous central fountain and art by Tony Smith
column5: Barry Flanagan and Louise Bourgeois. Open daily. Free.

column1: AD
AD"/"['Fritz Hahn'
column2: 'Reporter Covering Bars'
column3: 'Drinks'
column4: ""Nightlife For The Washington Post'S Weekend Section""]"/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/MG74KVXI2YI6HJYO5IMGGIUTS4.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2020/06/27/nascars-top-series-has-had-two-black-drivers-ever-can-bubba-wallace-change-that//NASCAR’s top series has had just two black full-time drivers. Can Bubba Wallace change that?/"Nearly 57 years later
column2: another African American stock-car racer
column3: Bubba Wallace
column4: is leading NASCAR’s break from the lingering remnants of a past tinged with racism. And he has the full-throated support of NASCAR’s president and fellow drivers
column5: who stood beside him in response to what appeared a hate crime in the wake of the sport’s June 10 ban on displays of the Confederate flag
column6: which Wallace had advocated.

column1: While investigators quickly determined no federal crime had been committed
column2: the controversy that ensued after a noose was found tied to a door inside Wallace’s garage stall at Talladega (Ala.) Superspeedway last weekend landed NASCAR in national headlines at a time of heightened tension
column3: unrest and polarization over systemic racism and the police-involved killings of unarmed African Americans.

column1: AD
AD
And it highlighted an almost unbelievable narrative in stock-car racing: Scott
column2: who financed his own team until a 1973 wreck at Talladega forced his retirement
column3: and Wallace aren’t simply the most notable African American drivers to compete in NASCAR’s top ranks. They are the only ones to have competed full-time in NASCAR’s Cup series in the sport’s 73-year history.

column1: Worlds apart
Several factors account for the dearth of black drivers in NASCAR
column2: which remains the country’s most popular form of auto racing despite sharp declines in TV ratings and race-day attendance since its popularity peaked in 2005.

column1: Retired racer Bill Lester
column3: may not be a household name among sports fans. But he’s an accomplished
column4: respected figure in motorsports
column5: a former sportscar racer and NASCAR Truck Series regular
column6: with 142 starts from 2000 to 2007. As part of stock-car racing’s connective tissue between the careers of Scott
column7: who died in 1990
column8: and Wallace
column9: Lester well understands the barriers that have made it difficult for African Americans such as himself to make headway in NASCAR.

column1: AD
AD
In a recent telephone interview
column2: Lester distilled it to three:

column1: A general lack of exposure to motorsports among minority youth.
The high cost of getting launched as a youngster
column2: which typically requires significant family investment.

column1: And
column2: most significantly
column3: the challenge of landing corporate sponsors once launched to fund front-running equipment.

column1: In his eight seasons in NASCAR
column2: which included one start in its Xfinity Series (1999) and two in its elite Cup Series (2006)
column3: Lester learned to navigate what at times was a hostile workplace as deftly as he navigated the right and left turns of sportscar circuits
column4: where he established himself after giving up a 15-year career at Hewlett-Packard to race full-time.

column1: As a black Californian competing in NASCAR’s Truck Series
column2: Lester found that when he could drive his rental car directly to the competitors’ parking lot on race day
column3: avoiding fans
column4: it was a good day.

column1: While other Truck racers didn’t exactly embrace him
column2: he said he never felt overt hostility.

column1: AD
“They referred to me as ‘Yankee!’” Lester recalled with a laugh. “Yankee? Obviously it was because of the way I carried myself
column2: the way I sounded
column3: the way I talked. I didn’t have any southern drawl or accent.”

column1: AD
The fact was
column2: he said
column3: he was as foreign to them as they were to him.

column1: “I did everything I could to try to immerse myself in their culture
column2: ” Lester said. “I went to lunch with these guys at Cracker Barrel
column3: which I had never even heard of before I came to the South. And they told me about Krystal [burgers].”

column1: On the track
column2: Lester said
column3: NASCAR’s Truck veterans raced him hard and aggressive
column4: and he raced them in kind — the only way a driver earns respect. He deepened that respect by winning poles and leading laps.

column1: AD
Lester found the reception less comfortable outside the confines of NASCAR garages — particularly at the small
column2: rural bullrings such as Martinsville (Va.) Speedway
column3: where drivers had to park outside the track and walk through the grounds teeming with fans to reach the garage.

column1: “I saw conversations stop. Fingers point
column2: ” he recalled. “I heard the n-word murmured under people’s breath. It was very disconcerting and very uncomfortable for me
column3: needless to say. And it was bad enough that I had to look at those Confederate flags.”

column1: AD

Lester soon learned that his biggest hurdle as a black NASCAR driver — the one that stymied his career far more than the boos he heard during prerace driver introductions for no reason other than his skin color — was convincing a corporate sponsor to underwrite an opportunity to race full-time in NASCAR’s Xfinity Series or Cup ranks
column2: which was his goal.

column1: AD
“People don’t understand how expensive it is to race in NASCAR’s top series
column2: its Cup series
column3: ” Lester noted. “It’s about an $18 [million] to $20 million proposition a year
column4: per team
column5: per car. One of the biggest disappointments of my career was a lack of support from corporate America.”

column1: That’s not a dealbreaker in stick-and-ball sports.
At the NFL Combine
column2: a great running back can dazzle with nothing but sneakers
column3: shorts and a scout’s stopwatch. In motorsports
column4: money buys speed
column5: and not even the most gifted driver can consistently win in second-class equipment.

column1: AD
That’s assuming a driver is fortunate enough to get a chance at second- or third-rate equipment.
Launching a youngster in racing these days is extremely costly. Even a 10-year-old’s campaign on a national karting or scaled-down stock-car circuit can cost six figures annually
column2: Lester said. Few families have access to that sort of capital; fewer still among African Americans.

column1: Money matters
Those are some of the barriers NASCAR has tried to address through its Drive for Diversity initiative
column2: launched in 2004 to increase the pool of minority and female competitors.

column1: AD
Its early efforts were criticized as window-dressing by some and well-intentioned but ineffective by others.

column2: NASCAR hired former entertainment lawyer Max Siegel
column3: who had worked two years as president of global operations at Dale Earnhardt Inc.
column4: to remake the program with the goal of broadening NASCAR’s fan base.

column1: AD
Siegel
column2: who is also CEO of USA Track & Field
column3: said he believed NASCAR’s leadership then and now is fully committed to diversity and inclusion. It became his job to help the sport get there.

column1: “If you want to increase your fan base
column2: fans connect to the athletes
column3: so we needed to increase those numbers so they could connect with a driver
column4: ” Siegel said. “We had no [minority or female] pit crew; nor [minority] drivers in the national series. We needed a pipeline.”

column1: AD
Blending his entertainment background with corporate stock-car racing expertise
column2: Siegel launched academies to develop that pipeline. Then he developed a 2010 reality series called “Changing Lanes” in conjunction with BET
column3: which chronicled 10 young female and minority racers in the Drive for Diversity program as they competed for four spots on an existing NASCAR team.

column1: Among those who shined during tryouts was 16-year-old Bubba Wallace
column2: who then went by his full name
column3: Darrell Wallace Jr. His parents had funded his entry into racing at 9
column4: but family assets couldn’t keep up with their son’s need for better equipment as he climbed the sport’s ranks.

column1: AD
“He was so hungry and so focused
column2: and he was going to put in the work to do whatever he could to succeed
column3: ” Siegel recalled of Wallace
column4: at 16
column5: in a telephone interview. “He tried to win every race he could
column6: and he’d seek out the advice of some of the Cup drivers and crew chiefs. He wasn’t trying to skip a step. He always tried to get every bit of experience
column7: every bit of learning that he could.”

column1: AD
Wallace
column2: in a recent telephone interview
column3: credited his confidence and comfort in advocating for social change to his experience in the 2010 Changing Lanes cast.

column1: “A lot of positives came out of that
column2: on track and off track
column3: ” said Wallace
column4: who went on to claim his first of six NASCAR Truck series victories at Martinsville in October 2013 and started 85 Xfinity Series races before landing his full-time Cup ride two years ago in Petty Motorsports’ famed No. 43. “I think ‘Changing Lanes’ is where I started to learn what pressure was and what stress was
column5: just going from emotion to emotion with a camera in your face 24-7 and not wanting to mess up on television.”

column1: As Lester looks on from his home in Florida
column2: he applauds NASCAR’s Confederate flag ban — something he never thought he’d see — and Wallace’s role in it.

column1: AD
“Bubba has been fortunate enough to be on a platform where he has been able to get the ears and eyes of people across the spectrum
column2: ” Lester said. “That’s something I wouldn’t have been able to do
column3: that [fellow African American racer] Willy [T. Ribbs] wasn’t able to do
column4: that Wendell Scott wasn’t able to do.

column1: “ … Corporate America always talks about
column2: ‘Is this person a good brand ambassador? Can they speak well? Do they present themselves well?’ Bubba has done a terrific job of doing that
column3: yet his car continues to be effectively un-sponsored
column4: ” Lester said
column5: alluding to the No. 43 Chevrolet’s lack of major corporate signage."/['Liz Clarke'
column6: 'Sports Reporter Focusing On Tennis']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/MKOLRTFX4EI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/violence-rises-in-minneapolis-as-debate-over-role-of-police-rages/2020/06/26/12fd6020-b7c6-11ea-aca5-ebb63d27e1ff_story.html/Violence rises in Minneapolis
column2: as debate over role of police rages/"“I thought somebody was going to die
column3: ” Trueblood said.

column1: As gunfire rang out early Monday evening here on the city’s north side
column2: Trueblood and six other coaches threw their bodies atop as many children as they could. Frantic parents took cover behind cars
column3: desperate to crawl to their kids but caught in the middle of a gun battle between a nearby group and a car that circled the park
column4: spraying bullets across the field where the Jays were playing.

column1: AD
AD
Minneapolis officials have described an unprecedented burst of violence following George Floyd’s Memorial Day death
column2: after an officer held him down with a knee to his neck
column3: sparking worldwide fury and massive protests. At least 113 people have been shot since May 25
column4: eight fatally
column5: according to Minneapolis police
column6: with hundreds of reports of gunfire across the city
column7: including several shootings in broad daylight.

column1: The spike in violence has come amid a raging debate over the role the Minneapolis Police Department should play in addressing crime in this city. Public confidence has so deteriorated that a majority of the City Council has pledged to dismantle the agency. Some residents have accused officers of purposefully curbing response to crime
column2: which police deny. Others have decided to stop using the agency’s services altogether.

column1: At the Jays’ practice on Monday
column2: several parents frantically called 911
column3: according to Trueblood. Officers
column4: he said
column5: still hadn’t arrived by the time they gathered up the children and fled.

column1: AD
AD
“We needed the police
column2: ” Trueblood said.

column1: On Monday
column2: nine people were shot in a four-hour span across the city
column3: starting around 2:30 p.m. That came a day after gunfire struck 11 people during an early-morning gun battle along a busy stretch of bars and restaurants in Uptown Minneapolis
column4: in what officials called one of the worst mass shootings in the city’s history.

column1: Three other people have been killed
column2: according to police
column3: including one in a fatal stabbing Monday afternoon in downtown Minneapolis
column4: just blocks from city hall. The police scanner has been jammed with reports of robberies
column5: carjackings and other violent incidents across the city.

column1: Mayor Jacob Frey has asked for additional law enforcement assistance from several regional and federal agencies
column2: including the Hennepin County Sheriff’s Office
column3: the Bureau of Alcohol
column4: Tobacco
column5: Firearms and Explosives
column6: the FBI and the Secret Service
column7: to help investigate and stem the bloodshed. A more robust law enforcement operation featuring the additional agencies was to begin Friday.

column1: “The violence and lawlessness that we’ve seen the last few days is not acceptable in any form
column2: ” Frey told reporters this week. “We’re going to restore order. We’re going to make sure that people throughout our city feel safe.”

column1: Law enforcement and other city officials have been publicly reluctant to link the uptick of violence to Floyd’s death
column2: but the incident stirred deep tensions between residents and the police department
column3: which has long been accused of racism and use of excessive force against people of color.

column1: AD
AD
After Floyd’s death in South Minneapolis
column2: scores of residents in the surrounding neighborhood
column3: a deeply progressive area known for its diverse population
column4: said they would no longer call the police out of fear they might put more African Americans at risk. The declaration was echoed in other parts of the city
column5: where the plywood put up to protect windows of businesses during the recent demonstrations has been decorated with messages including “Stop Calling the Police.”

column1: A majority of the Minneapolis City Council announced earlier this month that they would work to defund and dismantle the police department
column2: insisting past reform efforts had done little to change the culture and behavior of the long-troubled agency.

column1: The council voted Friday to advance a measure that would ask voters in November to approve a change to the city charter allowing Minneapolis to replace its police department with a new agency focused on safety and violence prevention. The proposed agency would employ some officers
column2: though it’s unclear how many and how they would operate.

column1: AD
AD

Adding to the tensions are claims from some in the community that police officers have stepped back from the job amid the anti-police sentiment — a claim strongly denied by Minneapolis police officials
column2: who say officers are working as hard as ever to protect the city amid sometimes “hostile” conditions.

column1: Both Frey and John Elder
column2: a police spokesperson
column3: have described incidents in recent days in which police officers were pelted with bottles and rocks while responding to scenes
column4: including a shooting last Friday near 38th Street and Chicago Avenue
column5: the site where Floyd was killed.

column1: On Monday
column2: Minneapolis Police Chief Medaria Arradondo pointedly praised community members and bar and restaurant employees working near the site of Sunday’s shooting for “protecting officers and shielding them” as they responded to the scene. Officers have been working in “unbelievable conditions
column3: ” Arradondo said
column4: but they “continue to show up and continue to serve.”

column1: AD
AD
But many residents have said in recent days that they have noticed a less robust presence from the police department
column2: including in South Minneapolis
column3: where they have seen fewer patrol cars in the past four weeks
column4: even as there have been more sounds of gunshots and reports of crime.

column1: One South Minneapolis resident
column2: who declined to be named out of fear of retribution
column3: said after past police killings in the region
column4: officers often tried to ease tensions within the community
column5: by driving around with their windows down to encourage more interaction. “But all you see now is them with their windows up
column6: ” the person said.

column1: Jamar B. Nelson
column2: a longtime Minneapolis activist who co-founded the anti-violence group A Mother’s Love
column3: said he knows several people who have chosen to stop reporting crimes because they did not want to be labeled “snitches” by neighbors or others.

column1: AD
AD
He accused City Council members who have pushed to dismantle police of further eroding the “lack of respect” toward Minneapolis officers
column2: which he said has in turn encouraged “lawless behavior” to spread across the city in recent weeks.

column1: Nelson was caught up in the early Sunday shooting while engaged in community outreach with members of the anti-violence group. He had seen just one visible officer patrol the area
column2: even as the street grew busy with patrons visiting bars that had been closed for months because of the coronavirus.

column1: One of the gunmen had been just feet away from him
column2: and Nelson estimated he fired dozens of rounds toward another gunman
column3: who fired back. He saw bodies falling and was surrounded by people he thought were dead.

column1: “There was no fear
column2: ” Nelson said. “You get what’s happening from people not fearing police being called.”

column1: Lisa Bender
column2: the president of the City Council
column3: who has led efforts to dismantle the police department
column4: did not respond to a request for comment. But in an interview with the Star Tribune
column5: she linked recent shootings to the usual uptick in crime during the summer and ongoing stress in the community after Floyd’s death. And she pointedly said the police department was still in place.

column1: AD
AD
“We still have a police department today
column2: ” Bender told the Star Tribune. “Its funding has not changed from three weeks ago.”

column1: The fear of a potentially violent summer has scared Minneapolis residents still traumatized by Floyd’s death and the chaos that followed
column2: including the fiery protests that burned and destroyed several hundred buildings across the city.

column1: In North Minneapolis
column2: Monday’s close call has forced Trueblood and his Minnesota Jays to scramble to find a new place to practice and play. Benched for weeks because of the coronavirus
column3: the Jays had only recently returned to the park
column4: which has hosted summer youth football teams like theirs for decades.

column1: AD
Minneapolis police officers usually came to watch
column2: parking their squad cars and cheering on the kids
column3: but “in the last week or so
column4: we haven’t seen them
column5: ” Trueblood said.

column1: AD
Like many of his young players
column2: Trueblood is black. In recent weeks
column3: the team
column4: which also includes several white players
column5: has grappled with the aftermath of Floyd’s death. They had talked about the images some had seen of the 46-year-old black man gasping for breath
column6: a white police officer’s knee at his throat
column7: and then the violent protests that had erupted afterward
column8: leaving blocks of the city burned.

column1: They are raising money to help pay for the costs of renting a new practice field and transportation for kids who live near Jordan Park to travel there. At a team meetup at a park miles away on Wednesday night
column2: the kids hugged and went back to practice
column3: even as some were still jittery at the sound of fireworks popping in the distance.

column1: As a black man
column2: Trueblood admitted he was “torn” over the debate about the police. But right now
column3: he was more worried about what to say to his players. They were like his own kids. All he could do was promise to keep them safe. But what did that mean in Minneapolis at a moment like this?"/['Holly Bailey'
column4: 'National Political Reporter']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/R2HCHQVX2YI6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/in-south-carolinas-economy-of-shame-the-good-guys-wear-masks/2020/06/26/9fd5a250-b7da-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/Opinion | In South Carolina’s economy of shame
column2: the good guys wear masks/"Secession
column3: in certain quarters
column4: wasn’t just a passing fancy but is an attitude that persists
column5: no matter the century. Federal dictates or even recommendations for your own good are viewed with suspicion. And then there are the strict constitutionalists
column6: such as Republican Gov. Henry McMaster (for whom my son works)
column7: who believe government shouldn’t dictate people’s behavior but rather should encourage their better angels.

column1: AD
AD
The governor reluctantly ordered nonessential businesses and beaches closed for a couple of weeks starting at the end of March
column2: but has never imposed a strict stay-at-home order
column3: as other states have. In part
column4: this was because South Carolina didn’t have as many cases relative to its population as other states and a surge wasn’t expected to hit until late May or early June. With the predictability of hurricane season
column5: the surge came and most sensible people have begun to get nervous. Yet
column6: with few exceptions
column7: businesses and restaurants remain open
column8: if with self-imposed restrictions and to fewer customers.

column1: Wearing a mask
column2: says McMaster
column3: is a matter of “personal responsibility.” Which should and may be true in some places
column4: but not in our little insane asylum. Speaking of the devil
column5: South Carolina is also home to a not-small number of religious charismatics who believe that the wearing of masks is Satan’s handiwork
column6: designed to block the breath of God. Why
column7: there’s talk that even the Episcopalians are passing around snakes these days.

column1: AD
AD
But
column2: seriously
column3: how can officials fight a highly contagious and sometimes deadly disease against such stubborn resistance? Fortunately
column4: the Bible’s authors thought of that
column5: too: shame.

column1: Though largely banished from the public square decades ago
column2: shame is making a comeback not just here but also in the broader culture. The death of George Floyd while in police custody was finally enough to shame enough white Americans into acknowledging that Black Lives Matter and that the burden of setting things right is the majority population’s to bear. Week after week
column3: we see the remnants of slavery
column4: Jim Crow and the Confederacy being toppled
column5: removed or abandoned
column6: right down to the “Dixie” in the now-renamed “The Chicks.”

column1: Wearing a mask may seem a minor issue compared to systemic racism or police brutality — unless
column2: that is
column3: you happen to be one of the more than 123
column4: 000 Americans already felled by the disease. But it’s all part of the same zeitgeist of community
column5: with an emphasis on shared sacrifice and unity. Besides
column6: businesses are getting on board
column7: which can change everything. In the capitalist commune
column8: virtue becomes an incentive and only the morally fit businesses survive.

column1: AD
AD
If shaming the smokers conquered Big Tobacco
column2: could shaming the mask-deniers tame the pandemic?

column1: Greenville
column2: a vibrant city in the western half of the state
column3: decided to find out. Together with the Greenville County government
column4: the Greenville Chamber of Commerce and other business entities
column5: the city recently launched the Greater Greenville Pledge
column6: by which retailers
column7: restaurants and other businesses declare their adherence to state and federal guidelines for social distancing
column8: sanitizing
column9: capacity and employee health monitoring. Once a pledge is made
column10: businesses can download a marketing package that includes signs for windows and counters. Customers who don’t see a pledge sign may well go elsewhere
column11: the thinking goes.

column1: McMaster liked the idea so much
column2: he decided to duplicate the effort statewide
column3: but only for restaurants. Called “Palmetto Priority
column4: ” the state program encourages restaurants to complete a (lengthy) checklist of reopening guidelines and to participate in both a required online education program and health department food-safety inspections. Upon completing the checklist and signing a commitment to employees and customers
column5: restaurants would receive a program endorsement and a sticker for their window. The program also includes an online form for patrons to evaluate restaurants’ standards.

column1: AD
AD
Sound good? Absolutely not. Did I mention this is South Carolina? Already some restaurant owners are upset that
column2: under the program
column3: they’d essentially be regulated twice over and subject to the whims of angry customers.

column1: But aren’t restaurants always subject to critical reviews of Yelp and Trip Advisor? The only difference now is diners would prefer sanitizer in their finger bowls. Besides
column2: it’s all voluntary
column3: which should please advocates of “personal responsibility
column4: ” as well as restaurateurs committed to surviving the pandemic.

column1: In the new economy of shame
column2: the good guys wear masks.

column1: AD
Read more:
AD
AD
AD"/['Kathleen Parker'
column2: 'Columnist Covering Politics']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/CIRAYAFX4QI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/06/27/white-house-is-right-about-one-thing-covid-19-we-need-young-peoples-help//Opinion | The White House is right about one thing on covid-19: We need young people’s help/"The current surge of coronavirus infections has shifted
column2: strikingly
column3: to younger adults. In Florida
column4: the median age of those infected has dropped from 65 to 35. People between 20 and 44 make up almost half of new covid-19 cases in Arizona. In parts of Texas
column5: the majority of new infections are in people under the age of 30.

column1: This is not surprising — it’s the young who are taking most advantage of loosening stay-at-home rules. They’ve got quarantine fatigue. They know they’re not likely to get terribly sick if they get the virus; many may never even know they have it (which of course makes them more dangerous
column2: because they unknowingly infect others).

column1: They are also getting some blame for a situation that’s not their fault. The United States is in this mess largely because of a failure of political leadership. We should have contained covid-19 much more aggressively from the beginning. Public officials have sent mixed messages
column2: politicizing something as basic as wearing masks. The president himself hosted an indoor rally that is sure to lead to new infections.

column1: AD
AD
Yet nothing changes the fact that America needs the help of young people to contain covid-19. And it’s in their best interests to go along.
So I’m talking to young people here: You’ve upended your lives for the past 3½ months of pandemic. You and your loved ones have made enormous sacrifices. Now
column2: we need your help to ensure these sacrifices were not made in vain.

column1: Please enjoy life — just do it safely. Let’s talk about seeing friends: Whenever possible
column2: do it outdoors. Numerous outbreaks have been linked to what some health officials dub the “serious seven”: bars
column3: gyms
column4: weddings
column5: funerals
column6: faith-based activities
column7: house gatherings
column8: and other small events. There’s a case in Florida of 16 friends who went to a bar; within days
column11: suggests indoor gatherings may carry a transmission risk nearly 19 times greater than those outdoors.

column1: AD
AD
So take advantage of the summer. Safer gatherings will be tougher in a few months
column2: when cold
column3: rainy weather will drive people indoors. But what we fail to do now will make it even harder for all of us later.

column1: You’ve been invited to a bar? If it’s crowded and people aren’t wearing masks
column2: suggest to your friends that you all go somewhere else
column3: perhaps a park or someone’s backyard. Similarly
column4: if you want to get out of town with friends
column5: try a camping or hiking trip instead of a resort holiday.

column1: Need to work out? Go running. Take an outdoor fitness class. If you go to an indoor gym
column2: go during off-hours
column3: keep a six-foot distance
column4: and wipe down the equipment before and after you use it.

column1: Dating and sex are more difficult questions
column2: but for many already used to the world of online dating
column3: covid-19 means you need to take it one step further. Substitute a Zoom or FaceTime chat for that first meeting
column4: then get together for a date where you go for a walk — six feet apart. As things progress
column5: have a conversation about how each of you has been considering your coronavirus risk. As for sex
column6: there are safer ways to do this that prevent covid-19 transmission (and protect against STIs
column7: too).

column1: AD
AD
And
column2: of course
column3: wear a mask. Be a public health role model — you know it’s the young who set trends
column4: so set this one.

column1: What if your friends don’t want to go along? Remind them that the more precautions we take now
column2: the sooner we can resume the things we really want to do. Colleges are more likely to open
column3: sporting events are more likely to resume
column4: and we all have a better chance of getting back to normal if we can get the virus under control. And for those who are passionate about fighting racial injustice
column5: point out that everything we do helps to reduce rampant disparities
column6: as it is black Americans and people of color who are bearing the brunt of covid-19.

column1: And let’s not forget that
column2: though people over 65 are more threatened by the virus
column3: young people also do get seriously ill. In Tulsa County
column4: one-quarter of hospitalizations for covid-19 are among those 18 to 35. A 28-year-old woman in Chicago just received a double lung transplant in an attempt to save her life. Previously healthy people in their 30s have suffered strokes due to covid-19; some may never regain their ability to speak or to walk.

column1: If young people are now the drivers of the pandemic in the United States
column2: it is they who also hold the key to reducing infections and saving lives. As a physician
column3: I care about you; I have faith in you; and I thank you. Please stay safe for yourself
column4: for each other
column5: and for all of us.

column1: AD
AD"/['Leana S. Wen'
column2: 'Contributing Columnist Focusing On Public Health'
column3: 'Health Policy'
column4: 'Contributing Columnist']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/7QTNOMVPSYI6VGFVE6NGI6NB4Q.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/theres-a-war-raging-against-health-officials-we-cant-afford-to-lose-their-expertise/2020/06/26/8d8f4580-b7d8-11ea-aca5-ebb63d27e1ff_story.html/Opinion | Trump’s perverse pandemic response has thrown health officials into a vortex of fury/"Opponents of a mask order recently came to the house of Chris Farnitano
column2: a public health officer in Contra Costa County
column3: across the bay from San Francisco. On the sidewalk
column4: they drew an arrow pointing to his residence
column5: according to the Los Angeles Times. “Tyranny is not the answer
column6: ” someone wrote in chalk. In Orange County
column7: in Southern California
column8: late last month
column9: an angry group spoke out at a county supervisors meeting against an order requiring face coverings. “One person suggested that the order might make it necessary to invoke Second Amendment rights to bear arms
column10: while another read aloud the home address of the order’s author — the county’s chief health officer
column11: Dr. Nichole Quick
column12: ” according to a report by Kaiser Health News. She was later given personal protection from the sheriff
column13: and then
column14: after another meeting that included criticism from the board of supervisors
column15: resigned. Seven senior public health officials in California have quit since the pandemic began.

column1: Amy Acton
column2: the Ohio health director
column3: drew widespread praise for her calm demeanor and her participation in Republican Gov. Mike DeWine’s decisive and rapid response to the pandemic. But as the lockdown stretched on
column4: protesters demonstrated in front of her house. Outside the statehouse
column5: a protester held up a sign saying
column6: “Dr. Amy is Killing Ohio!” Ms. Acton resigned on June 11 but remains an adviser to Mr. DeWine.

column1: AD
AD
Ms. Acton’s experience is being repeated over and over across the country
column2: even as the virus surges out of control in some places. Responsibility for public health falls predominantly on states and counties
column3: and they have borne the brunt of frustration and confusion over the pandemic. At least 27 state and local health leaders have resigned
column4: retired or been fired since April across 13 states
column5: a review by Kaiser Health News and the Associated Press showed. Others have faced ugly death threats and been forced to ask for security protection.

column1: It is difficult to maintain public trust in the teeth of widespread anxiety
column2: harder when circumstances call for unpopular measures. But these inevitable challenges have been compounded by Mr. Trump’s instinct to politicize the pandemic response and drag it into the culture wars. The president eggs on anti-lockdown demonstrators with calls to “liberate” their states; he refuses to wear a mask; he spouts nonsense about the virus fading away; he endorses therapies that are useless or worse. The resulting hostility and disrespect for science and medicine is corrosive and counterproductive. The nation can ill afford to lose public health expertise. It needs the best advice that public health professionals can muster at this moment of extreme duress.

Tap through this roundup of editorial cartoons from June 21 to June 26./['Tom Toles']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/resizer/zlsHhyfzbSG7KqwCrkYTQLTdB9I=/arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost/public/AU6ESRGJ7ZG3ZNKRNWL34A6LMY.jpg"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/06/25/science-is-better-when-we-open-our-doors-immigrants//Opinion | Science is better when we open our doors to immigrants/"As the nation grapples with a new recession
column2: deals with a resurgence of covid-19 and reckons with systemic racism
column3: the war on immigration continues. The Trump administration is now ending visa programs — including ones for skilled immigrants — under the pretext of staving off the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic and saving jobs for the American worker. This move will be catastrophic to the U.S. scientific enterprise at a time when we should be strengthening it with investments of funding and talent
column4: all while likely having no substantial effect on U.S. unemployment.

column1: AD
AD
In April
column2: while the government scrambled to address PPE and testing shortages
column3: President Trump issued a presidential proclamation suspending entry of new immigrants
column4: with the stated intention of mitigating the impact on job availability and economic recovery. Since then
column5: several groups of lawmakers have pushed for further restrictions on immigration such as suspending all skilled-worker visas for at least a year and halting all Chinese nationals receiving visas to do scientific research at the graduate or postgraduate level.

column1: This week
column2: Trump signed an executive order extending previous immigration restrictions and barring issuance of several work visas
column3: including the H-1B
column4: H-2B and J-1 programs. But immigrant scholars on some of these visas are crucial drivers of scientific research. An end to these programs
column5: or even a long pause
column6: won’t help job-seeking Americans for two main reasons: STEM jobs have long experienced labor shortages even at times of major unemployment
column7: and welcoming immigrant scientists and engineers creates thousands of new jobs for U.S. workers.

column1: Most foreign-born scientists are on H-1B or J-1 visas. While researchers on J-1s appear to be exempt at this time
column2: researchers on H-1Bs are not. There is little to no evidence that ending such programs would create jobs for native-born workers
column3: especially in the short run. Yet there is plenty of data showing that it would slow economic growth and job creation in the long run. A decision to curb highly skilled immigration programs would be shortsighted and likely harmful to the economic
column4: intellectual
column5: moral and public health of this country.

column1: AD
AD

A nationwide study by the American Enterprise Institute and New American Economy shows that for every 100 immigrants who come to the United States to earn their advanced STEM degree and stay to work here
column2: 262 new jobs are created and filled by native-born workers. The benefits to U.S. workers don’t come just from immigrants who are educated at U.S. institutions: The report also shows that adding 100 immigrants with advanced STEM degrees from foreign universities create an additional 86 jobs for native-born workers. When you look at data strictly from H-1B visa recipients
column3: adding 100 H-1B skilled temporary foreign workers adds an additional 183 jobs for the native-born. Adding 100 H-2B less-skilled nonagricultural workers produces 464 jobs for native-born workers. Another study from the National Foundation for American Policy reports that increasing H-1B visa holders by just 1 percent in an occupation reduces that field’s unemployment rate by about 0.2 percent and increases wages in the profession.

column1: Whichever way you slice it
column2: immigrant scholars (including those on H-1B visas) create and do not “steal"" U.S. jobs. And senior administration officials know this. Ending these visa programs will stunt the United States’ long-term economic growth and set us on the path of abandoning our place as a leader in education
column3: science and innovation on the world stage. There is little reason for implementing an immigration policy with such long-term impacts based on short-term economic problems related to a pandemic.

column1: But that’s just the economic argument. Immigrants are valuable as people
column2: regardless of their impact on U.S. science
column3: and we should welcome the opportunity to enrich our communities with them. Perhaps one of the most troubling things about these policies is that they use the coronavirus pandemic as pretext for implementing anti-immigrant policies that the Trump administration has been seeking since Day One.

column1: AD
AD

The way to emerge from a major economic and public health crisis shouldn’t include rejecting scholars who are ready and willing to help. Science is better when we open our doors to curious minds from all over the world and harness their creativity
column2: potential and ambition. The success of our scientific endeavor rests
column3: in no small measure
column4: on the dedication of exceptional immigrant researchers. This includes
column5: by the way
column6: discovering treatments for covid-19.

column1: We scholars tackle tough and complicated questions in our labs. Rather than adding more clouds of fear and uncertainty to the lives of immigrant scientists working hard to answer those questions
column2: the United States should be supporting their work and embracing them with open arms.

AD"/['Ubadah Sabbagh']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/AT2ZLMVWMYI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/george-and-martha-washington-enslaved-300-people-lets-start-with-their-names/2020/06/26/d3f7c362-b7e7-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/Opinion | George and Martha Washington enslaved 300 people. Let’s start with their names./"Austin
Moll
Giles
Ona Judge
Paris
Hercules
Joe
Richmond
Christopher Sheels
William Lee
That’s just 10 names of the more than 300 people enslaved by George and Martha Washington. They worked and traveled most closely with our nation’s first First Family as chamber maids
column2: postilions
column3: cooks
column4: waiters
column5: laborers
column6: seamstresses and valets.

column1: AD
Did you know that George Washington had only one tooth in his mouth when he became president in 1789
column2: thanks to bad health and 18th-century dentistry? But his false teeth were not made of wood
column3: as is often described in folk songs and lore. His dentures were made from the pulled teeth of slaves.

column1: AD
Roll that around in your head for a minute.
Did you know that the president was often unwell
column2: having survived two wars and a nasty bout with a cutaneous form of anthrax? He was tended to by Richmond and William Lee during long stretches when he was unable to sit or stand.

column1: Did you know that some of the names belong to people who were “dower slaves
column2: ” legally controlled by Martha? She had the money in the family as a widow who was left with thousands of acres and hundreds of people when her first husband
column3: Daniel Parke Custis
column4: died.

column1: AD
Did you know that when Ona Judge escaped
column2: Martha insisted that George do everything in his power to track her down so she could gift her to a granddaughter as an attendant (thus avoiding the need to reimburse her first husband’s estate for loss of property)? And yes
column3: the correct word is “property
column4: ” because next to acreage (as in real estate)
column5: the enslaved composed the greatest source of wealth for families such as the Washingtons.

column1: AD
And let’s not forget that one of the reasons that our nation’s capital was moved to Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: was it was closer to Virginia
column4: where slavery was practiced and protected under law. When Washington traveled to New York — or
column5: later
column6: to Philadelphia — to preside over a newly formed government
column7: he left all but a few of his slaves behind at Mount Vernon. Once Washington moved north
column8: he was legally at risk of losing his slaves in the City of Brotherly Love.

column1: Did you know that Pennsylvania’s Gradual Abolition Act of 1780 held that if you lived in that state for more than six months with enslaved people
column2: they could successfully petition for their freedom?

column1: AD
Correspondence shows that Washington thought he was exempt from that law because his work required that he reside in the state for an extended period. His attorney general
column2: Edmund Jennings Randolph
column3: cleared up that false impression when he knocked on Washington’s High Street door in Philadelphia one day to say that Randolph’s own slaves had familiarized themselves with that law and were packing up to leave.

column1: So the Washingtons came up with an elaborate shuffling plan to cycle in and out of Pennsylvania so their slaves would never hit the legal threshold for freedom. Sometimes they would take a trip back to Virginia. Sometimes they would just make an excuse to go across the river to New Jersey. The schedule was complicated and burdensome
column2: but Washington kept it up because he and Martha were determined to keep the people they owned in bondage.

column1: AD
Washington explained in a letter to his secretary Tobias Lear that the scheme was meant to deceive the enslaved and the public
column2: said Erica Armstrong Dunbar
column3: a professor of history at Rutgers and author of the book “Never Caught: The Washingtons’ Relentless Pursuit of Their Runaway Slave Ona Judge.”

column1: AD
The man who supposedly never told a lie figured out how to stretch the truth.
Did you know that Washington’s cook
column2: Hercules
column3: also escaped? He did so on Washington’s birthday
column4: a departure with an unmistakable message.

column1: These are just some of the stories. (Many others are in Dunbar’s book
column2: which ought to be on Americans’ reading list about our real history.) The Washingtons had hundreds of people on their official slave census. Mostly
column3: we don’t know their names or their stories. There are no buildings named for them. No statues. Yet their toil and their torture helped to build a new nation.

column1: AD
Many say Washington deserves some measure of grace because he arranged to free some of his slaves upon his death. So
column2: he did in death what he would not do in life? We must own up to the fact that he owned people
column3: that those people were separated from their loved ones
column4: made to work without pay
column5: made to live without dignity
column6: made to suffer whippings
column7: made to disappear. Because of that their names are monuments unto themselves.

column1: AD
Names we should remember.
Austin
Moll
Giles
Ona Judge
Paris
Hercules
Joe
Richmond
Christopher Sheels
William Lee
. . . And so many more.

Correction An earlier version of this column said that Tobias Lear knocked on Washington’s door in Philadelphia to alert him that his own slaves were planning to leave in accordance with Pennsylvania’s Gradual Abolition Act of 1780. It was Edmund Jennings Randolph. This version has been updated.

column2: 'Opinions Contributor']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/SCM3USFX6II6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/06/26/i-thought-id-be-safe-waiting-out-coronavirus-texas-i-was-wrong//Opinion | I thought I’d be safe waiting out the coronavirus in Texas. I was wrong./"AD
Then came a series of dangerous policy decisions — and a face-smacking encounter with Texas culture — that proved me wrong.
AD
Abbott
column2: a Republican
column3: was one of the last governors to issue a stay-at-home order
column4: waiting until the very end of March and even then balking at that terminology. He was an early champion of rushing to reopen the state
column5: despite saying that he knew doing so would put lives at risk. He barred mayors in Texas from fining people who failed to wear masks. In late April
column6: when a Dallas salon owner was jailed for violating Abbott’s own executive order to shut down nonessential businesses
column7: he called for her release. Several days later
column8: he eased restrictions on restaurants

column1: Meanwhile
column2: many Texans convinced themselves that the coronavirus threat was overblown
column3: that masks were for wimps
column4: and that contact tracing at open businesses would be an assault on our God-given freedom to shop until we drop.

column1: AD
I haven’t ventured out much
column2: but when I have
column3: the level of irresponsible behavior has been alarming. On one outing to another Dallas suburb
column4: Cedar Hill
column5: a woman without a mask insisted at a Dillard’s makeup counter that she be allowed to test liquid foundation on her face. The masked attendant informed her that it was against policy at this time
column6: and that not being able to test foundation was better than falling ill with coronavirus. The maskless woman exclaimed
column7: standing close to the attendant and to me
column8: “Oh
column9: I don’t care! I’ve got insurance!” She just wanted her makeup — distancing and masking be damned. I hurried and left the scene.

column1: The combination of bad governance and stubborn ignorance has been predictably deadly. On Wednesday
column2: the state reported a record-high 6
column3: 584 new cases. Positive test rates are climbing
column4: as are hospitalizations; intensive care beds are filling up. The number of known cases has grown steeply
column5: from fewer than 30
column6: 000 when the state began to reopen May 1 to more than 130
column7: 000 now. Overall
column8: nearly 2

column1: AD
So Abbott has been backpedaling. On June 3
column2: as he announced the third phase of the state’s reopening
column3: he crowed that “the people of Texas continue to prove that we can safely and responsibly open our state for business.” By Tuesday
column4: he sounded far different: “The safest place for you is at your home
column5: ” he urged residents. And on Friday
column6: Abbott put the reopening on hold
column7: ordering that bars close
column8: river-rafting operations shut down and that restaurants scale back to operating by 50 percent capacity ahead of the July 4th holiday.

column1: AD
You have to ask whether things would have become anywhere near this bad if Abbott hadn’t been so gung-ho about reopening.
You have to work hard not to see the racial divide at work. One foray to West Village commercial district in downtown Dallas featured largely maskless
column2: non-socially-distancing white patrons enjoying their meals and drinks on restaurant patios
column3: while servers
column4: mostly workers of color
column5: wore masks and gloves to protect themselves and the customers.

column1: And you have to wonder: Is it something about Texas culture
column2: particularly white Texans
column3: to believe that our lives don’t matter
column4: but bowling alleys
column5: gyms and MAC stores do? Is it something in our water that makes people say out loud that grandparents should be willing to sacrifice themselves for the economy
column6: as Republican Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick did?

column1: AD
AD
Abbott also announced Friday that federal funding for testing sites would continue past the original June 30 end date
column2: but Texas is about to become a case study in whether it is possible to put the genie back in the bottle once it has been freed from lockdown. It will be difficult to convince businesses to shut down again and people to stay inside once more. It all sounds so painfully familiar; after all
column3: it was the Trump administration that ignored early warning signs and has failed to come up with a national strategy
column4: instead leaving each state to deal with the worst public health crisis of our lifetimes.

column1: Texans
column2: like
column3: Americans
column4: pride themselves on being exceptional. We joke that we deserve to be our own country. But as the number of Texans falling ill and dying of the coronavirus continues to increase
column5: I can’t help but feel like I have come back to live in a failing state.

column1: Read more:
AD"/['Karen Attiah'
column2: 'Global Opinions Editor'
column3: 'Writing On International Affairs'
column4: 'Social Issues']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/UTS3JOVQDYI6VGFVE6NGI6NB4Q.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/forgive-trump-for-the-first-three-months-of-covid-19-everything-else-is-his-responsibility/2020/06/26/08464174-b7b7-11ea-aca5-ebb63d27e1ff_story.html/Opinion | Trump will richly deserve his fate. But he won’t pay the heaviest cost./"In fact
column2: the U.S. death rate was in the middle of the pack for a big
column3: rich country. The United States did better than Italy
column4: France
column5: Spain and Britain
column6: worse than Germany or Canada. Outside of Asia
column7: however
column8: no country fared particularly well

column1: Humans assess risks in two key ways: by reference to their own experience and by looking at what others like them are doing. This works extremely well most of the time
column2: which is how humankind has managed to stay alive for so long. But when dealing with a truly new kind of danger — such as
column3: say
column4: a once-in-a-century pandemic — the system breaks down
column5: utterly. Your own experience tells you that modern medicine has brought plagues under control
column6: so there’s no need to worry. Everyone else’s experience says the same thing
column7: so when you look at your neighbors to see whether they sense danger
column8: you’ll get the impression that everything is fine. This is why the history of crisis and catastrophe suggests that most people
column9: institutions and nations perform badly under the initial onslaught of a novel threat.

column1: Countries in China’s vicinity
column2: however
column3: had a firsthand brush with a nasty
column4: new infectious disease: the SARS epidemic of 2003. That experience helped them develop playbooks for future outbreaks. So when the novel coronavirus emerged
column5: Asian populations masked up and stayed home. In Western countries
column6: meanwhile
column7: the virus spread silently for months. Our government and others acted only after thousands of deaths were inevitable and the only way to avoid even more was to send the citizenry into lockdown. At that late date
column8: how badly a country did seems to have mostly been a matter of dumb luck: how early was the population seeded with disease
column9: and did those index cases propagate quickly through crowded super-spreading events
column10: or mosey along through the moderately infectious and the modestly social?

column1: AD
AD
The United States was middling lucky. Note the past tense.
The quality of our leadership might not matter much in the initial “headless chicken” phase of a crisis when no one knows what they are doing
column2: and many of the efforts will turn out to be useless or counterproductive. But
column3: over time
column4: luck matters less and management matters more. We expect leadership to get better
column5: to learn what works and what does not
column6: to understand the risks and progressively fine-tune their response. That is what European nations have done
column7: and it is precisely what Trump has not. Months in
column8: the president is still playing down the threat
column9: still encouraging people to go out and gather in large groups
column10: still hostile toward the wearing of masks.

column1: The effects are evident in the stark divergence between the number of new U.S. and European Union cases. Graphs tracking the outbreak show the E.U. leading the United States until April
column2: then the E.U. curve falls off sharply — from more than 30
column3: 000 cases a day to 4
column4: 000. The United States hits roughly the same peak a little later
column5: but our curve enters a shallow glide
column6: almost brushes 20
column7: 000 cases
column8: then turns northward again. As of this writing
column10: 000 new cases a day are emerging.

column1: AD
AD

Not all of that can be laid at Trump’s feet. American federalism means local officials have considerable discretion over public health efforts. And the worst U.S. outbreak occurred under two Democrats — New York Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio — who initially rivaled Trump in their “see no evil” approach to covid-19. But the outbreak has shifted its locus to many states with Republican governors. When a president from your party convenes mass gatherings in viral hot spots
column2: tells people they needn’t bother wearing masks and disparages expanded testing
column3: that makes it very hard to say “No
column4: don’t do those things” to voters for whom ignoring the health nannies has become a point of partisan pride.

column1: So perhaps forgive Trump the first three months as the natural course of calamity. The outcomes in the months after that
column2: however
column3: will be his responsibility. And
column4: unfortunately
column5: the heaviest cost for his failures will be paid not by Trump
column6: but in American lives.

column1: AD

AD"/['Megan Mcardle']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/TGCK5CFX2QI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/06/26/are-you-logger-or-does-tom-cotton-think-you-shouldnt-vote//Opinion | Are you a logger
column2: or does Tom Cotton think you shouldn’t vote?/"Well
column3: this is much clearer! Here I was thinking that all the rationales for voter suppression and denying representation (Is voting by mail good or to be forbidden at all costs? Is two senators for 700
column4: 000 people perfectly just or a terrible slight not to be borne?) were starting to be confusing and transparently racist
column5: but once again Tom Cotton has proved me incorrect. It all has to do with your proximity to key industries. You must log trees
column6: not keystrokes; you must mine ore
column7: not data. You must — well
column8: he said it better than I possibly could
column9: perhaps even as well as our Founders.

column1: AD
AD
As the Declaration of Independence said
column2: “All men are created equal
column3: but those even tangentially involved in the production of seafood are more equal than others.” This matter of industries was actually the very thing Jefferson and Hamilton were always fighting about; Jefferson was saying that yeoman farmers should get 100 percent of the votes
column4: and Hamilton was saying that they should save some votes for workers in manufacturing. Both
column5: it turns out
column6: were correct. (Hamilton
column7: alas
column8: perished before he could cast his first vote; he was trying to catch a fish on Weehawken
column10: knowing how powerful his franchise would be if he ever got to exercise it
column11: was determined to stop him. The fish survived.)

column1: You start to wonder how a great many states managed to enter the Union in the first place. Massachusetts has always been rich in fish
column2: but it must have vexed John Adams not to be able to participate in the democratic process at all
column3: given that his connection to that vital business was tenuous at best.

column1: “Dear Abigail
column2: ” John Adams wrote to his wife
column3: “alas for this country! I sought all day to Catch a Mammoth Cod but my effort was futile. My Net was cast in vain
column4: but my Vote shall not be cast at All. I would that Providence had made me a logger or a worker in mining
column5: logging and construction. I understand well why we specified that only Such ought to be Represented in this land
column6: but it galls me.”

column1: AD
AD
The popular slogan
column2: “Taxation without representation is tyranny
column3: unless you are not involved in the crucial industries of logging
column4: mining and construction!” rang out across the land in those heady days
column5: and people cheered wholeheartedly
column6: understanding immediately that this was a logical basis on which to assign votes and not some sort of wafer-thin rationale that would be used for denying representation to the many hundreds of thousands of residents of a historically black city.

column1: Before attempting to vote
column2: as Cotton illustrates
column3: you need only ask yourself a very simple set of questions: Are you a logger? Could you appear on the side of a set of paper towels? Are you a majestic redwood tree? Are you a big rock shaped like a human being? Are you several rocks? Are you an ear of corn waving in the wind? Are you somehow affiliated with the fishing industry? Are you a flag at half-staff on the top of a barn? Are you now or have you ever been a worker in mining and construction? Are you an enormous wheel of cheese? Are you a piece of map colored bright red? Do you represent what Tom Cotton would identify as a rich
column4: robust
column5: American industry? (This also includes things to do with horses or involving marveling at the land
column6: staring off majestically over a large field your ancestors violently seized.)

column1: The Founders’ rationale for this has yet to be discovered. The early days of deciding who counted as a state must have been difficult ones indeed. There were plenty of workers engaged in construction in the South
column2: but the Constitution did not technically consider them to be people
column3: so I am not sure how this issue was resolved. My guess is that Arkansas is still not a state
column4: but I could be mistaken.

column1: AD
AD
My point is
column2: what Cotton has to say makes sense and I have no further questions. It is certainly not that he is harking back to a tradition as old and robust as American democracy
column3: that if there are people you do not consider to be fully people in a certain place
column4: you do not have to let them vote at all.
