Read more from Alexandra Petri:"/['Alexandra Petri'
column2: 'Columnist Offering A Lighter Take On The News'
column3: 'Opinions Of The Day']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/NPSYEEVJBQI6VJB3X2PWJFFIPU.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://washingtonpost.com/politics/mary-trump-once-stood-up-to-her-uncle-donald-now-her-book-describes-a-nightmare-of-family-dysfunction/2020/06/25/be52d7f2-b4ba-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html?tid=pm_pop&itid=pm_pop/Mary Trump once stood up to her uncle Donald. Now her book describes a ‘nightmare’ of family dysfunction./"Over time
column2: she deepened her studies of the disorder
column3: contributed to a book on treating schizophrenia
column4: wrote a dissertation on stalkers
column5: and became a clinical psychologist. But not since she became part of the lawsuit in 2000 against her uncle has she spoken in detail about what she sees as the disorders of Donald Trump.

column1: AD
AD

Now her silence could be coming to an end. Her book about her uncle — “Too Much and Never Enough: How My Family Created the World’s Most Dangerous Man” — is slated to be published next month. The book is so potentially explosive that the Trump family is seeking to block publication
column2: citing a confidentiality agreement that Mary Trump signed as part of a settlement about her inheritance. Mary Trump’s lawyer
column3: Theodore Boutrous Jr.
column4: said the president is trying to “suppress a book that will discuss matters of utmost public importance.”

column1: The publisher has not revealed specifics
column2: and Mary Trump
column4: declined an interview request. But clues to her dark view of her uncle can be seen in lawsuits
column5: and interviews with former colleagues and teachers
column6: academic papers and a series of now-deleted tweets
column7: including one that said her uncle’s election was the “worst night of my life.”

column1: A description of the book from publisher Simon & Schuster suggests it will draw heavily on her studies of family dysfunction
column2: with Mary using her clinical background to dissect “a nightmare of traumas
column3: destructive relationships and a tragic combination of neglect and abuse
column4: ” including “the strange and harmful relationship between” her late father and Donald Trump.

column1: AD
AD

The tragedy to which the book description alludes probably is informed by an event that infused both her life and that of her uncle: the death of her father — President Trump’s older brother Fred Jr. — of alcoholism when she was 16 years old.
Friends of her father’s told The Washington Post last year that they blame his death in part on the way he was treated by Donald Trump
column2: and the president said in an interview last year with The Post that he regrets how he dealt with his brother.

column1: President Trump told Axios that he didn’t think his niece was allowed to write the book because she signed the confidentiality agreement. The White House declined further comment.
AD
Donald Trump’s brother Robert
column2: who filed the petition to stop the book
column3: said in the filing that Mary had agreed after accepting an unspecified financial settlement from the inheritance fight that she “would not publish any account” of her relationship with Donald Trump or his siblings. In a statement
column4: Robert Trump said Mary’s decision to “mischaracterize our family relationship after all these years for her own financial gain is a travesty and injustice” to her late father
column5: Fred Jr.
column6: and grandfather
column7: Fred Sr.
column8: saying the family feels that “Mary’s actions are truly a disgrace.”

column1: AD
A Queens County Surrogate’s Court on Thursday denied the petition on grounds of lack of jurisdiction
column2: but Robert Trump on Friday refiled the case with the New York State Supreme Court.

column1: Gilded life
From birth
column2: Mary Trump was supposed to be set for a gilded life
column3: a grandchild of Fred Sr. and Mary. Her father
column4: Fred Jr.
column5: was the eldest of Fred Trump Sr.’s children
column6: and he was expected to follow his father as the leader of the family business.

column1: AD
Mary was featured in society columns as a fashionably dressed young girl
column2: and she spent time at her grandparents’ palatial home in Queens
column3: watching her father feud with Donald and Fred Sr.
column4: who ran a New York City real estate company.

column1: Much to the family’s consternation
column2: Fred Jr. was interested in becoming a pilot for TWA
column3: not in renting New York City apartments. After graduating from Lehigh University in 1960
column4: he married a flight attendant named Linda Lee Clapp in 1962. He went to flight school and the couple had two children
column5: including Mary
column6: who was born in 1965.

column1: Fred Jr. was already drinking heavily by the time Mary was born
column2: and his troubles with alcohol may have caused him to give up his dream of becoming a commercial airline pilot
column3: according to three former TWA employees who trained with him. Meanwhile
column4: Donald Trump and Fred Sr. continued to pressure him to join the family business.

column1: By the time Mary was 6 years old
column2: her mother divorced Fred Jr. A family friend
column3: David Miller
column4: said in an interview that while Fred Jr.’s drinking played a role in the divorce
column5: there was also a lot of pressure from Fred Sr.
column6: who Miller said disliked Linda. “She wasn’t welcomed into the family
column7: ” Miller said of Linda. Linda could not be reached for comment.

column1: AD
AD
Fred Trump Sr. agreed at the time of the divorce to support Linda and his grandchildren
column2: providing rent and $100 per week for expenses
column3: plus $25 per week for Mary and her brother
column4: Fred III
column5: according to court records. Fred Sr. agreed to pay for Mary to attend a private school during her early years as well as her college and medical expenses.

column1: On Sept. 26
column3: Fred Trump Jr. died at 42 years old of a heart attack
column4: which the family has said stemmed from alcoholism. Mary was 16 years old.

column1: Carried a burden
Mary eventually attended Tufts University
column2: where she studied the Southern novelist William Faulkner. In a seminar with English professor Alan Lebowitz
column3: Mary and her 15 or so fellow students analyzed the Compson family portrayed in novels such as “The Sound and the Fury.”

column1: AD
The Compsons bore some similarities to her own family: Like Donald Trump’s mother
column2: the Compsons immigrated to the United States from Scotland
column3: and the family was riven by dysfunction. At the time
column4: Donald Trump was running his Atlantic City casinos
column5: which went into bankruptcy
column6: and preparing to divorce his first wife
column7: Ivana
column8: and marry Marla Maples.

column1: AD
Lebowitz said in a telephone interview that he has rarely had a student as exceptional as Mary Trump
column2: who was featured in the Tufts commencement program as having won the award for top English student.

column1: “She was just as smart and accomplished as any I’ve taught in 40 years
column2: ” Lebowitz said. “She took a seminar on William Faulkner with me and she wrote two absolutely stunning papers
column3: long
column4: deep and elegant. We studied an enormously complex
column5: interesting writer and she got deeply into it because she is a deep thinker.”

column1: AD
Lebowitz
column2: who is retired
column3: recalled that when she entered his classroom more than 30 years ago
column4: he learned of the weight she carried.

column1: “I knew that her father had been a very sad story and that she was carrying the burden of that story
column2: ” he said.

column1: Mary and Fred III had received some financial support over the years from the Trump family
column2: and they expected to receive a significant inheritance from their grandfather
column3: Fred Sr.
column4: who died in 1999. Mary and her brother had hoped they would get an amount close to what would have gone to their father
column5: if he had lived
column6: but they learned they were due to receive a lesser amount
column7: and a probate fight ensued
column8: court records show.

column1: AD
AD
Mary and Fred III alleged that an unnamed person associated with the Trump family improperly engineered a change in the will of their grandfather
column2: who had Alzheimer’s disease during his last years. Mary and her brother said the changes in the will were “procured by fraud and undue influence.”

column1: Donald said at the time that he supported a cutoff of medical coverage that had been provided by a family company for Fred III’s son
column2: William
column3: who had cerebral palsy. Donald Trump told the New York Daily News that when he and his siblings were sued by Fred III and Mary
column4: he felt
column5: “Why should we give [William] medical coverage?”

column1: Donald’s brother Robert said in a deposition that the family had given Mary annual gifts of $20
column3: in addition to income from family ventures
column4: estimating that Mary and Fred III annually received “close to $200
column5: 000 without either one lifting a finger at any time.”

column1: AD
Mary was livid about the family’s decision to cut off medical coverage for her nephew William. She told the Daily News at the time
column2: “Given this family
column3: it would be utterly naive to say it has nothing to do with money. But for both me and my brother
column4: it has much more to do with that our father be recognized. He existed
column5: he lived
column6: he was their oldest son. And William is my father’s grandson. He is as much a part of that family as anybody else. He desperately needs extra care.”

column1: In the 2000 lawsuit
column2: Mary did not directly address her uncle Robert’s assertion that she was “not gainfully employed.” But it was around this time
column3: after working on a master’s degree in English at Columbia University
column4: that she served in a voluntary role in the study of schizophrenia patients
column5: assisting senior social worker Rachel Miller at Zucker Hillside Hospital in Glen Oaks
column6: N.Y.

column1: Miller said Mary Trump showed an intense interest in understanding what drove people into psychological dysfunction. “She went into a situation that is hard to see. Many doctors and social workers couldn’t go there
column2: it was so frightening to see somebody losing their mind
column3: ” Miller said.

column1: AD
Mary Trump accompanied her in visits with patients who were typically 16 to 25 years old and experiencing their first episodes of schizophrenia. “She had her life set on doing what she wanted to do
column2: which was to be a psychologist
column3: ” Miller said.

column1: Later
column2: when Miller needed help on a book she co-wrote
column3: “Diagnosis: Schizophrenia
column4: ” about the study
column5: she said Mary worked long hours to help her research and write the manual
column6: which became popular in the field and with families of people with the disease.

column1: 'Worst night of my life'
Mary Trump continued her studies at Adelphi University
column2: where she earned a master’s degree in psychology in 2001
column3: a master’s in clinical psychology in 2003
column4: and a doctoral degree in clinical psychology in 2010
column5: a school official said.

column1: In her 205-page dissertation
column2: “A Characterological Evaluation of the Victims of Stalking
column3: ” she examined whether there were certain personality characteristics that made some people “more vulnerable to being victims of stalking by an intimate partner.”

column1: A few years later
column2: Mary founded a company called Trump Coaching Group
column3: which provided wellness and fitness services on Long Island.

column1: An archived version of the now-deleted company website said the company focused on nurturing relationships. It said Mary’s interest stemmed “from her own struggles as an athlete with asthma which have given her a true appreciation for the extent to which physical well-being is vital to psychological and emotional well-being.”
One of the coaches listed as a team member said the company didn’t develop much beyond the creation of the website. Paige Crosby
column2: who said she participated in a year-long training program with Mary Trump to become a life coach
column3: recalled her talking about her “hurt feelings” from her “sour relationship” with Donald.

column1: As Donald Trump announced his candidacy in 2015
column2: Mary Trump does not appear to have said anything publicly about him.

column1: But when it became clear that her uncle had won the presidency
column2: she took to Twitter. “Worst night of my life
column3: ” she wrote at least 12 times in tweets that have been deleted recently. She wrote that “We should be judged harshly. . . . I grieve for our country.”

column1: Mary Trump’s publicist
column2: asked to verify that Mary wrote the tweets
column3: declined to comment.

column1: Last year
column2: according to corporate filings
column3: Mary created a company that echoed the name of the tragic family in Faulkner’s novels: Compson Enterprises. In an initial listing for her book
column4: designed to keep the project a secret
column5: her name was given as Mary Compson.

column1: Now Mary Trump appears to hope that
column2: with an assist from the publication of her book
column3: the next presidential election will turn out differently from the last. She foreshadowed it at 4:07 a.m. on Nov. 9
column5: shortly after her uncle was declared the president-elect
column6: when she tweeted simply: “2020.”"/['Michael Kranish'
column7: 'National Political Investigative Reporter']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/LLUMSJHCUQI6NJCTDHWEWPIJXI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://washingtonpost.com/politics/workers-removed-thousands-of-social-distancing-stickers-before-trumps-tulsa-rally-according-to-video-and-a-person-familiar-with-the-set-up/2020/06/27/f429c3be-b801-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html?tid=pm_pop&itid=pm_pop/Workers removed thousands of social distancing stickers before Trump’s Tulsa rally
column2: according to video and a person familiar with the set-up/"The removal contradicted instructions from the management of the BOK Center
column3: the 19
column4: 000-seat arena in downtown Tulsa where Trump held his rally on June 20. At the time
column5: coronavirus cases were rising sharply in Tulsa County
column6: and Trump faced intense criticism for convening a large crowd for an indoor political rally
column7: his first such event since the start of the pandemic.

column1: As part of its safety plan
column2: arena management had purchased 12
column3: 000 do-not-sit stickers for Trump’s rally
column4: intended to keep people apart by leaving open seats between attendees. On the day of the rally
column5: event staff had already affixed them on nearly every other seat in the arena when Trump’s campaign told event management to stop and then began removing the stickers
column6: hours before the president’s arrival
column7: according to a person familiar with the event who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss internal matters.

column1: AD
AD
In a video clip obtained by The Washington Post
column2: two men — one in a suit and one wearing a badge and a face mask — can be seen pulling stickers off seats in a section of the arena. It is unclear who those two men are. When Trump took the stage on Saturday evening
column3: the crowd was clustered together and attendees were not leaving empty seats between themselves.

column1: The actions by Trump’s campaign were first reported Friday by Billboard Magazine. As rally preparations were underway
column2: Trump’s campaign staff intervened with the venue manager
column3: ASM Global
column4: and told them to stop labeling seats in this way
column5: Doug Thornton
column6: executive vice president of ASM Global
column7: told the magazine.

column1: “They also told us that they didn’t want any signs posted saying we should social distance in the venue
column2: ” Thornton said. “The campaign went through and removed the stickers.”

column1: AD
AD
A spokesman for ASM Global declined to comment.
Trump campaign spokesman Tim Murtaugh did not directly respond to questions about the sticker removal.
“The rally was in full compliance with local requirements. In addition
column2: every rally attendee received a temperature check prior to admission
column3: was given a face mask
column4: and provided ample access to hand sanitizer
column5: ” Murtaugh said in an emailed statement.

column1: In a separate statement
column2: the campaign said: “There were signs posted and we are not aware of any campaign staff asking that they be removed.”

column1: Trump held his Tulsa rally despite opposition by Oklahoma health authorities and residents who feared that convening a large crowd indoors could accelerate the spread of the coronavirus. The number of coronavirus cases in Tulsa County was spiking in the days leading up to the rally and has continued to increase since.
AD
AD
The director of the Tulsa Health Department
column2: Bruce Dart
column3: had recommended that the event be postponed until it was safer. A number of city residents and business owners brought a lawsuit against the venue manager
column4: ASM Global
column5: seeking to require all attendees wear masks and adhere to social distancing guidelines from health authorities.

column1: The Oklahoma Supreme Court rejected that suit.
On June 13
column2: a week before the rally
column3: Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt (R) wrote to the venue management saying he understood that Trump’s campaign “has presented plans to ASM Global in order to accommodate capacity crowds during a political rally.”

column1: Stitt noted that Oklahoma was in “Phase 3” of its reopening plan and Trump’s rally “proceeding as planned is consistent with the guidance” of that plan. Stitt’s letter added that “we have also encouraged event licensees to refer to the general CDC guidelines for more information about COVID-19.”
AD
AD
Two days before the rally
column2: the managers of the BOK Center had asked the Trump campaign to provide a detailed written plan outlining the “health and safety” measures it intended to use to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

column1: Before the rally
column2: Murtaugh said in an emailed statement: “We take safety seriously
column3: which is why we're doing temperature checks for everyone attending
column4: and providing masks and hand sanitizer. This will be a Trump rally
column5: which means a big
column6: boisterous
column7: excited crowd. We don’t recall the media shaming demonstrators about social distancing — in fact the media were cheering them on.”

column1: As the crowd entered the day of the rally
column2: the Trump campaign handed out masks and small bottles of “Make America Great Again 2020” branded hand sanitizer.

column1: AD
The BOK Center also put down floor decals in front of concession areas and put up plexiglass to protect vendors.
AD
At 1:47 p.m. that day
column2: Fox 23 News posted on its Facebook page a photo from inside the BOK Center showing two members of the event staff putting stickers on seats. “Stickers are going on every other seat in the BOK Center saying ‘Do Not Sit Here’ to try to spread the crowd out for President Trump’s rally tonight
column3: ” the post read.

column1: After the majority of the stickers were in place
column2: a member of Trump’s campaign radioed staff in the event war room where arena management was monitoring preparations and told them to stop
column3: according to the person familiar with the event. Event staff was told to continue applying the stickers. Later
column4: the campaign began pulling them off
column5: the person said.

column1: AD
In video footage of Trump’s rally
column2: there appeared to be no effort to keep an empty seat between attendees.

column1: Attendance turned out to be less than Trump expected — he had said some 1 million people wanted tickets — and the arena was not full
column2: particularly in the upper level.

column1: AD
Trump had wanted every seat packed
column2: and he told advisers coming in on Air Force One and at the arena he was displeased that the crowd was not larger
column3: said two Trump advisers
column4: who like others spoke on the condition of anonymity to relay private conversations.

column1: “He was quite angry
column2: ” said one person who interacted with him.

column1: Trump had told North Carolina Gov. Roy Cooper (D) during a May 29 phone call that he would not hold a socially distanced convention in Charlotte because he had never had an empty seat since he came down the escalator at the start of his presidential campaign in 2015.
AD
Neither Trump nor the White House asked that the stickers be removed
column2: said a senior White House official. While campaign staff and some attendees wore masks during the rally
column3: many rallygoers did not.

column1: At least six members of the Trump campaign advance staff have tested positive for the coronavirus
column2: including two Secret Service employees. Dozens of Secret Service officers and agents who attended the Tulsa rally were ordered to self-quarantine.

column1: AD
Since the rally
column2: coronavirus cases in Tulsa County hit a new high of 259 new confirmed cases on June 23."/['Joshua Partlow'
column3: 'National'
column4: 'Foreign Affairs. Former Correspondent Focusing On Latin America'
column5: 'The Middle East.'
column6: 'Josh Dawsey'
column7: 'Reporter Covering The White House']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/J372APVYCUI6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/27/coronavirus-live-updates-us/?tid=pm_pop&itid=pm_pop/Live updates: Florida
column2: Georgia
column3: South Carolina and Nevada hit new highs in daily coronavirus cases/"LONDON — Holiday-loving Britons have reason to cheer: The British government said it would ease blanket travel restrictions early next month.

column1: Earlier in June
column2: Britain introduced new quarantine rules that meant almost anyone entering the country
column3: including British nationals
column4: would have to self-isolate for two weeks. For many Brits
column5: this made the idea of jet-setting to Spain or France for their annual summer holiday seem almost impossible. But the British government said that
column6: from July 6
column7: it will scrap the quarantine rules for several European countries.

column1: The news was splashed across the front pages of Saturday newspapers: “Fly out for sun
column2: sea and 70% off
column3: ” said the Daily Mail. “Holiday season back on
column4: ” ran a headline on the front of the Times of London.

column1: Brits love to holiday abroad: In normal times
column2: about 60 percent of Brits go on an overseas holiday. Of course
column3: these are not normal times
column4: and it remains to be seen how many people will book a vacation to sun-kissed destinations. But the hard-hit travel industry was clearly elated with the news.

column1: “It’s incredibly welcome
column2: ” said Jonathan Smith
column3: a spokesman for ABTA
column4: a trade association for travel agents and tour operators. He told the BBC that they expect a “surge of bookings … although some people may be slightly reticent to travel.”

column1: Under a “traffic light system
column2: ” countries will be given a green
column3: amber or red rating based on coronavirus levels and other measures. Passengers coming from countries with a “red” rating will have to continue to abide by the mandatory 14-day quarantine rules.

column1: The full list of countries will be published next week. Top tourist destinations like France
column2: Spain and Greece are expected to be on the approved list.

column1: There was no suggestion that the United States would be on the approved list
column2: although its exclusion could “potentially present a tricky diplomatic dynamic
column3: ” wrote the BBC’s Tom Burridge."/['Derek Hawkins'
column4: 'National'
column5: 'Breaking News Reporter'
column6: 'Karla Adam'
column7: 'London Correspondent Covering The United Kingdom'
column8: 'Meryl Kornfield'
column11: 'Foreign Affairs'

column1: https://washingtonpost.com/health/medical-mysteries/his-anemia-was-followed-by-searing-foot-pain-seventeen-years-later-in-precarious-shape-a-stellar-athlete-learned-what-was-wrong/2020/06/26/1acfdebe-95ec-11ea-82b4-c8db161ff6e5_story.html?tid=pm_pop&itid=pm_pop/His anemia was followed by searing foot pain. Seventeen years later
column2: in precarious shape
column3: a stellar athlete learned what was wrong./"But in May 2001
column4: his energy was flagging. Sipos
column5: who lived in Riverside
column6: consulted his longtime general practitioner
column7: who ordered blood tests that revealed an abnormally low iron level.

column1: Several years later when he developed foot pain
column2: Sipos saw a podiatrist who told him he had osteoarthritis
column3: typically caused by wear and tear on joints. A few years later
column4: a specialist diagnosed his painful wrists and ankles as rheumatoid arthritis
column5: a serious autoimmune disease. That was followed by the diagnosis of a rare blood condition that a hematologist monitored
column6: but did not treat.

column1: AD
AD
It wasn’t until 2018 — nearly 17 years to the day after he first saw a doctor for fatigue — that Sipos learned he had none of those illnesses.
The news was delivered by a specialist whose gentle
column2: measured tone belied the shocking message that galvanized Sipos: Without treatment
column3: which was long overdue
column4: he could die.

column1: “We both started crying
column2: ” Sipos recalled of his reaction and that of his wife
column3: Tami. “It felt like the oxygen had been sucked out of the room.”

column1: He credits his survival to the expertise and compassion of that specialist
column2: who continues to oversee his treatment.

column1: Energy boost
Sipos trusted the family physician
column2: who had delivered his sons. The doctor told Sipos his fatigue was the result of anemia and could be easily treated with an over-the-counter iron supplement that he should take when he felt unusually tired.

column1: AD
AD
The pills seemed to work. “For the next 10 years I would pop iron pills every so often and notice a bump” in energy
column2: Sipos said.

column1: In 2007 a new problem arose: The soles of his feet ached and burned. He consulted a podiatrist who told Sipos he had “fallen arches” — flat feet that develop in adulthood. The doctor prescribed orthotics. For a while
column2: they quelled the pain.
the foot pain was considerably worse and had engulfed his ankles
column3: putting an end to his participation in extreme sports. Sipos’s hands felt tingly and numb and he was referred to a neurologist and a rheumatologist.

column1: The neurologist told Sipos he was suffering from carpal tunnel syndrome — numbness or tingling in the hands caused by a compressed nerve — as well as peripheral neuropathy
column2: damage to the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.

column1: AD
AD
“He said I should have it looked at because someone 46 years old should not have neuropathy
column2: ” Sipos remembers being told. Peripheral neuropathy can be caused by a variety of ailments
column3: among them diabetes
column4: liver disease and bone marrow disorders.

column1: The rheumatologist ordered blood tests and diagnosed “seronegative” rheumatoid arthritis. Although testing did not show antibodies to the disease
column2: his joint pain
column3: the doctor said
column4: strongly suggested it.

column1: The rheumatologist prescribed two drugs: methotrexate
column2: a chemotherapy drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis
column3: and when that didn’t help
column4: hydroxychloraquine
column5: an anti-malaria drug used to treat autoimmune disorders. Neither worked.

column1: AD
At that point
column2: Sipos recalled
column3: the pain was so intense “the weight of the [bed] sheets would feel like my feet were being crushed.” He wore braces on his wrists and ankles in a mostly failed attempt to deaden the pain
column4: and took the opioid pain killer hydrocodone to make it through the day.

column1: AD

column2: Sipos consulted a second rheumatologist. She agreed it was odd that neither drug had been effective and prescribed other medications. When they failed
column3: she ordered a test for immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies
column4: which can assess immune function. The test showed an “m spike
column5: ” an indication that Sipos might have a precancerous condition or possibly multiple myeloma
column6: an uncommon cancer.

column1: In early 2017 she referred Sipos
column2: who by then was suffering from frequent night sweats
column3: to a specialist who treats blood disorders.

column1: A precursor?
The hematologist immediately ordered urine and blood tests. On the basis of those
column2: Sipos said
column3: she assured him he did not have cancer
column4: but rather a precancerous condition called MGUS
column5: short for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance.

column1: AD
MGUS is often found incidentally
column2: when doctors are looking for other things. It frequently causes no symptoms but must be watched closely because in about 1 percent of patients annually it can progress to multiple myeloma
column3: a cancer of plasma cells
column4: or another malignancy. If there is no progression
column5: treatment is usually not required.

column1: AD
“She said the standard of care was watch and wait
column2: ” Sipos recalled. That meant appointments every three months to check his blood and urine.

column1: Sipos said the doctor also performed several bone marrow biopsies but the results were inconclusive.
When he asked the doctor about the unrelenting burning pain in his hands and feet
column2: she offered no explanation.

column1: AD
In early 2018
column2: he said
column3: he confronted her. “I’m getting worse
column4: ” he remembered saying. Her reply was stark. “She said
column5: ‘Yes
column6: you may be in a wheelchair
column7: but we would never treat this.’ ” His IgM level
column8: she told him
column9: was not sufficiently elevated to warrant the risks of treatment
column10: which would involve chemotherapy. Watchful waiting was the safest course.

column1: The hematologist told Sipos he was free to seek a second opinion. He was initially hesitant. Even though she was routinely an hour or two late for scheduled appointments
column2: the doctor “seemed so knowledgeable and wise and would speak with such authority
column3: ” he said. But at his wife’s urging
column4: Sipos decided it was time for another expert to weigh in.

column1: AD
What he didn’t know was that getting a second opinion would possibly save his life.
A dramatic reversal
Sipos and his wife waited six weeks for the consultation with Muhammad Omair Kamal
column2: an assistant professor of medical oncology at Loma Linda University Cancer Center.

column1: AD
Transferring his records to Kamal in preparation for the appointment was a struggle
column2: Sipos said
column3: requiring multiple phone calls by him as well as Kamal’s staff.

column1: Both Jeff and Tami Sipos say that details of the May 14
column3: meeting are seared into their memories.

column1: “I remember Dr. Kamal leaned forward and in his soft
column2: sweet voice full of concern said
column3: ‘Mr. Sipos
column4: has anyone told you you have cancer? How come you’re not getting treated for this?’ ” Sipos recalled.

column1: The stunned couple repeated what the hematologist had been saying for more than a year: that Sipos did not have cancer and that monitoring was the best course of action.
AD
Kamal strenuously disagreed. “You have cancer
column2: ” Sipos remembers him saying. “If you were my patient
column3: you’d be started on chemotherapy tomorrow.” Then he handed the couple treatment guidelines from the National Cancer Institute.

column1: AD
Although he still didn’t have all of Sipos’s records
column2: Kamal said he strongly suspected the principal had a rare
column3: slow-growing form of B cell lymphoma called Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
column4: also known as Waldenstrom’s or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Kamal had seen four other cases in his career. MGUS can be a precursor of multiple myeloma or Waldenstrom’s. Sipos later learned that a January 2017 pathology report mentioned it as a possible cause of his symptoms.

column1: About 1
column2: 500 cases are diagnosed annually in the United States
column3: compared to about 32
column4: 000 cases of multiple myeloma.

column1: AD
Waldenstrom’s occurs mostly in men over 60 when lymphoma cells in bone marrow proliferate
column2: crowding out normal red and white blood cells. Anemia is common and symptoms include fatigue
column3: neuropathy and night sweats. There is no cure. Treatment typically consists of chemotherapy and targeted treatments that kill only cancer cells. The disease is diagnosed through blood tests and a bone marrow biopsy and can be confirmed by a test for a genetic mutation.

column1: Kamal said he cannot fathom why Sipos went undiagnosed for so long. “He was seeing the right doctor
column2: ” Kamal noted
column3: referring to the proper specialty.

column1: When he received Sipos’s complete records
column2: Kamal said
column3: “lab after lab after lab” showed results that warranted treatment. “There are not many diseases [other than Waldenstrom’s] where you see high IgM and neuropathy. Most patients are diagnosed within a year or two.”

column1: Sipos said that when he told the first hematologist what Kamal had recommended
column2: she balked and insisted that her diagnosis was correct. Switching doctors was problematic; Kamal was outside his insurance network.

column1: So another month elapsed while Sipos
column2: unsure about what to do
column3: obtained another opinion. The third cancer specialist strongly sided with Kamal. “If you don’t have chemo
column4: you’re going to expire
column5: ” Sipos remembers her saying.

column1: Sipos called his insurance company and requested a transfer to Kamal; it was quickly approved.
He then underwent another bone marrow biopsy and testing to rule out amyloidosis
column2: a rare disease caused by the accumulation of a protein that can result in organ failure. A positive test for the MYD88 L265P mutation linked to Waldenstrom’s clinched the diagnosis. (The mutation is not passed on to offspring.)

column1: In mid-August 2018
column2: Sipos began a grueling chemotherapy regimen to treat Waldenstrom’s. He wore a Superman T-shirt that one of his kindergarten students had given him to every session as a sort of talisman. By January 2019
column3: his cancer was in remission.

column1: But the agonizing nerve damage to his hands and feet continues to plague him. Kamal said the damage is probably irreversible and may have occurred because his cancer went untreated for so long.
Sipos
column2: who sees a pain specialist
column3: said he has been prescribed methadone
column4: which “takes the zing out of it.”

column1: He said he has learned through bitter experience to ask questions.
“No healthy adult male should be anemic
column2: ” he said. “I wish I’d had the foresight to ask
column3: ‘What would cause this?’ ”

column1: Sipos also wishes he had sought a second opinion sooner. “I was afraid I was going to offend her
column2: ” he said
column3: referring to the first hematologist.

column1: To Kamal
column2: Sipos’s case illustrates the necessity for doctors to keep looking and not brush off what patients tell them. “Don’t just ignore neuropathy
column3: or any symptoms
column4: in young patients. Even if they’re young
column5: they can have cancer.”"/['Sandra G. Boodman'
column6: 'Medical Reporter'
column7: 'Creator Of The Monthly Medical Mysteries Column']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/3N5SFLVXAII6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://washingtonpost.com/opinions/george-and-martha-washington-enslaved-300-people-lets-start-with-their-names/2020/06/26/d3f7c362-b7e7-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html?tid=pm_pop&itid=pm_pop/Opinion | George and Martha Washington enslaved 300 people. Let’s start with their names./"Austin
Moll
Giles
Ona Judge
Paris
Hercules
Joe
Richmond
Christopher Sheels
William Lee
That’s just 10 names of the more than 300 people enslaved by George and Martha Washington. They worked and traveled most closely with our nation’s first First Family as chamber maids
column2: postilions
column3: cooks
column4: waiters
column5: laborers
column6: seamstresses and valets.

column1: AD
Did you know that George Washington had only one tooth in his mouth when he became president in 1789
column2: thanks to bad health and 18th-century dentistry? But his false teeth were not made of wood
column3: as is often described in folk songs and lore. His dentures were made from the pulled teeth of slaves.

column1: AD
Roll that around in your head for a minute.
Did you know that the president was often unwell
column2: having survived two wars and a nasty bout with a cutaneous form of anthrax? He was tended to by Richmond and William Lee during long stretches when he was unable to sit or stand.

column1: Did you know that some of the names belong to people who were “dower slaves
column2: ” legally controlled by Martha? She had the money in the family as a widow who was left with thousands of acres and hundreds of people when her first husband
column3: Daniel Parke Custis
column4: died.

column1: AD
Did you know that when Ona Judge escaped
column2: Martha insisted that George do everything in his power to track her down so she could gift her to a granddaughter as an attendant (thus avoiding the need to reimburse her first husband’s estate for loss of property)? And yes
column3: the correct word is “property
column4: ” because next to acreage (as in real estate)
column5: the enslaved composed the greatest source of wealth for families such as the Washingtons.

column1: AD
And let’s not forget that one of the reasons that our nation’s capital was moved to Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: was it was closer to Virginia
column4: where slavery was practiced and protected under law. When Washington traveled to New York — or
column5: later
column6: to Philadelphia — to preside over a newly formed government
column7: he left all but a few of his slaves behind at Mount Vernon. Once Washington moved north
column8: he was legally at risk of losing his slaves in the City of Brotherly Love.

column1: Did you know that Pennsylvania’s Gradual Abolition Act of 1780 held that if you lived in that state for more than six months with enslaved people
column2: they could successfully petition for their freedom?

column1: AD
Correspondence shows that Washington thought he was exempt from that law because his work required that he reside in the state for an extended period. His attorney general
column2: Edmund Jennings Randolph
column3: cleared up that false impression when he knocked on Washington’s High Street door in Philadelphia one day to say that Randolph’s own slaves had familiarized themselves with that law and were packing up to leave.

column1: So the Washingtons came up with an elaborate shuffling plan to cycle in and out of Pennsylvania so their slaves would never hit the legal threshold for freedom. Sometimes they would take a trip back to Virginia. Sometimes they would just make an excuse to go across the river to New Jersey. The schedule was complicated and burdensome
column2: but Washington kept it up because he and Martha were determined to keep the people they owned in bondage.

column1: AD
Washington explained in a letter to his secretary Tobias Lear that the scheme was meant to deceive the enslaved and the public
column2: said Erica Armstrong Dunbar
column3: a professor of history at Rutgers and author of the book “Never Caught: The Washingtons’ Relentless Pursuit of Their Runaway Slave Ona Judge.”

column1: AD
The man who supposedly never told a lie figured out how to stretch the truth.
Did you know that Washington’s cook
column2: Hercules
column3: also escaped? He did so on Washington’s birthday
column4: a departure with an unmistakable message.

column1: These are just some of the stories. (Many others are in Dunbar’s book
column2: which ought to be on Americans’ reading list about our real history.) The Washingtons had hundreds of people on their official slave census. Mostly
column3: we don’t know their names or their stories. There are no buildings named for them. No statues. Yet their toil and their torture helped to build a new nation.

column1: AD
Many say Washington deserves some measure of grace because he arranged to free some of his slaves upon his death. So
column2: he did in death what he would not do in life? We must own up to the fact that he owned people
column3: that those people were separated from their loved ones
column4: made to work without pay
column5: made to live without dignity
column6: made to suffer whippings
column7: made to disappear. Because of that their names are monuments unto themselves.

column1: AD
Names we should remember.
Austin
Moll
Giles
Ona Judge
Paris
Hercules
Joe
Richmond
Christopher Sheels
William Lee
. . . And so many more.

Correction An earlier version of this column said that Tobias Lear knocked on Washington’s door in Philadelphia to alert him that his own slaves were planning to leave in accordance with Pennsylvania’s Gradual Abolition Act of 1780. It was Edmund Jennings Randolph. This version has been updated.

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/russian-operation-targeted-coalition-troops-in-afghanistan-intelligence-finds/2020/06/26/ac710092-b80f-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html/Russian operation targeted coalition troops in Afghanistan
column2: intelligence finds/"The officials said administration leaders learned of reported bounties in recent months from U.S. intelligence agencies
column3: prompting a series of internal discussions including a large interagency meeting that was held in late March. According to one person familiar with the matter
column4: the responses discussed at that meeting included sending a diplomatic communication to relay disapproval and authorizing new sanctions.

column1: AD
AD
Spokesmen for the National Security Council
column2: the Pentagon
column3: and the CIA declined to comment.

column1: The Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that the story
column2: “illustrates the low intellectual abilities of propagandists from American intelligence
column3: who instead of inventing something more reliable have to come up with such nonsense... However
column4: what else can be expected from intelligence
column5: which miserably failed the twenty-year war in Afghanistan”

column1: The Taliban denied any involvement.
“We categorically reject the notion of ever planning or carrying out targeted attacks against U.S. or foreign forces at the behest of foreign intelligence or for the sake of collecting bounty
column2: ” said Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid in a statement
column3: “and we also reject receiving material support from foreign intelligence because such undertakings are harmful for the sovereign decision-making of any country and movement.”

column1: AD
AD
The reports of Russian involvement in operations targeting Americans
column2: if confirmed
column3: sparked anger on Capitol Hill and questions about why the administration has not responded to it.

column1: Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.)
column2: a combat veteran who sits on the Senate Armed Services Committee
column3: criticized Trump for supporting Russia’s return to the G-7 group of nations at a time when Moscow was
column4: according to U.S. intelligence
column5: seeking to harm American troops.

column1: “Donald ‘America First’ Trump is literally placing Russian interests ahead of American lives
column2: and Republicans do nothing
column3: ” she said on Twitter. “Putting party before country doesn't just empower Trump to continue serving his own interests
column4: it can cost American lives too.”

column1: AD
Rep. Michael McCaul (R-Tex.)
column2: the top Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee
column3: said he had requested additional information from the Trump administration
column4: saying that such an operation would deepen his concerns about Moscow’s actions beyond Russian borders. “If accurate
column5: the administration must take swift and serious action to hold the Putin regime accountable
column6: ” he said on Twitter.

column1: AD

It was not immediately clear whether the militants approached by Russia as part of the operation had succeeded in killing Americans or allied forces. News of the murky initiative comes as American diplomats attempt to kindle political talks that could put an end to America’s longest war
column2: now in its 19th year.

column1: Earlier this year
column2: the administration struck an initial peace deal with the Taliban. The agreement
column3: which outlined the full withdrawal of the U.S. military within 14 months
column4: was supposed to lead to a prompt start to talks between militant representatives and the Afghan government.

column1: AD
But the Afghan parties have failed to complete interim steps
column2: and with the coronavirus crisis taking hold in Afghanistan
column3: those talks have yet to materialize. Hanging over the process is Trump’s oft-stated desire to remove U.S. forces from the country
column4: where local forces have been unable to secure an edge over the Taliban despite two decades of foreign funding and advising.

column1: AD
The attempt to stoke violence against Americans
column2: if confirmed
column3: would also represent a significant departure from Moscow’s earlier position toward Islamist militants in Afghanistan. Previously
column4: U.S. officials had cited what they characterized as sporadic
column5: low-level Russian support for the Taliban
column6: including the supply of small arms via Afghanistan’s northern neighbors.

column1: After the Soviet Union’s own punishing insurgent war in Afghanistan in the 1980s
column2: Moscow remained largely in the background in the years after U.S. and NATO forces entered the country in the wake of the Sept. 11
column4: attacks. But as the U.S. intent to withdraw fueled uncertainty
column5: Russia has attempted to wield greater influence.

column1: AD
While Moscow’s motives for offering alleged bounties were not immediately clear
column2: officials said they might include retaliation for the U.S. military’s 2018 killing of Russian mercenary troops working for Yevgeniy Prigozhin
column3: an oligarch with links to Russian President Vladimir Putin
column4: in Syria
column5: or simply
column6: as one official put it
column7: an attempt to “muddy the negotiations on Afghanistan by throwing a stick in that.”

column1: AD
During the Soviet war in Afghanistan
column2: which ended in 1989
column3: the U.S. government provided weaponry and funds to Afghan mujahideen rebels fighting against Soviet forces.

column1: The unit that officials identified as responsible for offering the bounties has also been linked to the poisoning and attempted murder of former Russian military spy Sergei Skripal in Britain in 2018.
AD
While that attack — along with Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and its role in the war in Syria — has generated strong criticism in Europe and from many of Trump’s most senior advisers
column2: the president himself has frequently appeared to have a chummy relationship with Putin
column3: downplaying the Kremlin’s interference in the 2016 U.S. election and other Russian transgressions.

column1: The United States has imposed sanctions on Russia over various issues
column2: including Moscow’s annexation of Crimea
column3: cyberattacks
column4: and election interference. Military officials this month spoke out in unusually harsh terms over what they said was Russia’s decision to move fourth-generation fighter jets into Libya
column5: adding to a spiraling proxy conflict there.

column1: AD
News of the cloaked operation comes as speculation mounts about the future of U.S. forces in Afghanistan. While the Pentagon has completed its initial drawdown to about 8
column2: 600 servicemembers
column3: a first step toward a full withdrawal that under the Feb. 2020 peace deal is supposed to occur by the spring of 2021
column4: officials describe the exit plans as “conditions-based” and say those terms have not yet been met.

column1: AD
Even as Taliban forces halt attacks against U.S. forces as part of that deal
column2: the militants have continued to assault Afghan troops
column3: making for what one senior Afghan official described this week as the deadliest situation in 19 years.

column1: CNN reported on Saturday that the administration was “close to finalizing” a decision to remove an additional 4
column2: 000 troops by the fall. Officials say that no final decisions have been made but that
column3: conditions allowing
column4: several thousand more will likely be withdrawn by fall.

column1: AD"/['Ellen Nakashima'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/foul-play-suspected-in-case-of-missing-fort-hood-soldier-vanessa-guillen/2020/06/26/e2fc4e9e-b659-11ea-a8da-693df3d7674a_story.html/Foul play suspected in case of missing Fort Hood soldier Vanessa Guillén/"“If they find my daughter dead
column2: I will shut down this base
column3: ” said her mother
column4: Gloria Guillén
column5: during a news conference at Fort Hood this week. Her remarks came after a meeting with command staff. Gloria Guillén fell ill after watching searchers comb a river near the base for her daughter. “I want my daughter alive
column6: ” she said. “That girl is my life.”

column1: AD
AD

The private’s family reported her missing hours after they last communicated with her and friends could not find her on the base. The family has pressed the U.S. Army and federal lawmakers to pay attention to the case
column2: enlisting the help of Rep. Sylvia Garcia (D-Tex.)
column3: a Latino civil rights organization
column4: Hispanic celebrities and Spanish speakers on social media to amplify the story.

column1: Guillén’s family has been critical of military command
column2: accusing it of indifference and failing to shut down Fort Hood in the hours after she disappeared. Vanessa Guillén complained to friends and family about being sexually harassed by a sergeant
column3: according to her family and their attorney
column4: but there is no record of any formal complaint. Army investigators said the harassment allegations “did not produce any viable leads” related to the soldier’s disappearance. They have also said they investigated an alleged incident of verbal harassment against Guillén that they have been unable to corroborate.

column1: Army Col. Ralph Overland
column2: commander of Guillén’s 3rd Cavalry Regiment
column3: said in a statement that the Army takes “allegations of sexual harassment very seriously
column4: ” and a separate administrative review of the harassment allegations will take place independent of the criminal investigation into Guillén’s disappearance.

column1: AD
AD
The Criminal Investigation Command (CID) — the military’s equivalent of the FBI — said its investigators have interviewed more than 300 people and have not ruled out anything
column2: according to spokesman Christopher Grey. They began searching for Guillén with the help of several agencies
column3: including the FBI
column4: he said.

column1: “We will not stop until we find Vanessa
column2: ” Grey said in response to emailed questions. “Our agents are working around-the-clock and have conducted a tremendous amount of investigative work.”

column1: More than 500 soldiers have searched for Guillén on the ground and in water
column2: using drones and helicopters in and around Fort Hood
column3: but have found nothing
column4: said Fort Hoodspokesman Chris Haug. Guillén is as important to the Army as she is to her family
column5: he added.

column1: AD
The military also posted a $25
column2: 000 reward for information about Guillén’s whereabouts. Grey
column3: however
column4: said it is not uncommon for the CID to open cases for soldiers who disappear under suspicious circumstances.

column1: AD
“It says the Army criminal investigators are serious about finding [Guillén]
column2: they are serious about looking
column3: and serious about taking this case seriously
column4: ” said Maggie Haswell
column5: a former Air Force security specialist who has tracked more than 100 missing service members since 2013. She has been in touch with Guillén’s family.

column1: “They do not believe she left of her own free will.”
The family and congressional lawmakers met with Fort Hood command staff and investigators on Tuesday to discuss the case. Natalie Khawam
column2: an attorney for Guillén’s family
column3: said she was pleased to have more answers after weeks of hearing nothing but was angered by discrepancies in the statements Army investigators made to the family.

column1: AD
Khawam said the Army initially said Guillén had reported for a 3 p.m. check-in with her supervisor
column2: but
column3: when pressed
column4: admitted the report was erroneous. The Army did not say why the report was wrong.

column1: AD
Khawam said she emailed questions to investigators before the meeting and was promised a timeline and records. But when they arrived
column2: the attorney said she could not obtain specific details
column3: such as who called Guillén into work that day and the location of her cellphone. Khawam said she will file FOIA requests and subpoena phone records herself.

column1: “Their answers were not justified. It was bogus. How dare you not be more transparent with the family?” said Khawam
column2: who has worked on previous military sexual assault cases and is advocating for tougher legislation in Congress. “I think a lot of people dropped the ball. They were being disingenuous about their efforts to find her.”

column1: AD
The meeting
column2: Khawam said
column3: felt staged and devolved into a tense exchange because investigators declined to provide more details
column4: fearing it could jeopardize the case.

column1: AD
“I think the most important part is that they are using the words now: ‘foul play
column2: ’ ” Garcia said at a news conference following the meeting. They “are looking at potential criminal activity to have occurred. The question is: who
column3: what and when?”

column1: In a statement
column2: base command said it appreciated the opportunity to show Guillén’s family
column3: attorney and lawmakers her work area and the lot where she was last seen.

column1: Guillén’s disappearance is the latest in a series of missing persons cases in recent years at Fort Hood
column2: one of the Army’s largest military installations. Gregory Wedel Morales went missing in August 2019
column3: days before his expected discharge. His remains were found earlier this week
column4: buried in a field in Killeen.

column1: AD
“Maybe if they had just been searching from the beginning
column2: we’d have some answers
column3: ” his mother
column4: Kim Wedel
column5: told Tulsa’s ABC affiliate. “You know
column6: he didn’t bury himself in a field on his own.”

column1: AD
The Army declares absent service members as having gone absent without leave
column2: or AWOL
column3: after 24 hours of failing to report for duty. Commanders are required to look into individual cases
column4: but critics say the search is not exhaustive because of the stigma the label carries. Families are often frustrated by what they perceive as delays and a lack of interest by the military. After 30 days
column5: the Army drops the missing soldier from its roster or classifies them as a deserter
column6: and the vacant position is quickly filled.

column1: “They don’t look for them like they should
column2: ” Haswell said.

column1: AD
Patrice Wise-Franklin hired a private investigator and felt dismissed by Army commanders when she pressured them to keep searching for her son
column2: Dakota Stump
column3: after he went missing from Fort Hood in October 2016. Investigators followed false leads before finding his body three weeks later beneath his car in a wooded area on the base. He died in a single-vehicle car accident.

column1: AD
“It felt like it was a joke to them
column2: ” Wise-Franklin said. “Until Fort Hood makes the hard decision on changing the protocol on how they handle missing soldiers
column3: they are going to keep having this happen with the same outcome.”

column1: Haug
column2: the Fort Hood spokesman
column3: said the Army searches for missing soldiers the moment they disappear. Haug said there is a process by which supervisors are tasked with searching the soldier’s belongings
column4: residence and work to find the missing soldier as the case goes up the chain of command. Grey said the CID routinely opens missing soldier cases.

column1: AD
In Guillén’s case
column2: her older sister
column3: Mayra
column4: was the first to notice something was wrong. Her sister was scheduled to go hiking with friends on April 22 but was unexpectedly called into work on her day off at the armory
column5: family said
column6: where she works with small arms and artillery. The CID said most soldiers have been in their barracks during the pandemic and are routinely called in “if something had to be accomplished.”

column1: AD
The sisters are close and communicate often. When Vanessa Guillén stopped replying between 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m.
column2: her sister was alarmed. Others tried to text the soldier but the messages were not delivered and calls went straight to voice mail. Mayra Guillén said she reported her sister missing to command and drove three hours from Houston to Killeen to start searching
column3: but she could not get on the base until the next morning.

column1: The League of United Latin American Citizens
column2: the oldest Latino civil rights organization in the country
column3: has backed the family and denounced what it calls the “total and reckless mishandling” of the investigation by the Army CID. It is urging Latino families across the country to stop their children from enlisting in the military until Guillén is found."/['Arelis R. Hernández'
