column6: 'Texas']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/LFGVR2VX7YI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/religion/2020/06/26/scandals-compensation-programs-lead-catholic-clergy-sex-abuse-complaints-quadruple-2019//Scandals
column2: compensation programs lead Catholic clergy sex abuse complaints to quadruple in 2019/"The annual audit of nearly 200 dioceses and church entities across the country has been done since 2002
column3: when reports of clergy abuse and coverups exploded and U.S. bishops approved reforms
column4: including a yearly review of complaints and compliance. The reform package is often called the “Charter.""

column1: The report released Thursday by the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops said the 2019 report — which covered July 2018 through June 2019 — counted 4
column2: 434 allegations of clergy sex abuse against minors. That number was 1

column1: Of the 4
column2: 434 allegations covered in the report
column3: about half — 2
column4: 237 — were deemed credible by the church.

column1: AD
AD
Thirty-seven of the 4
column2: 434 allegations came from people who were minors during the time period the report covered — eight of which the church-run bodies deemed substantiated
column3: according to the report. In recent years
column4: that’s about average for substantiated
column5: past-year claims. There are about 37
column6: 000 diocesan and religious order priests in the country.

column1: The complaints the church deemed credible were analyzed further by the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate
column2: a church-affiliated research center on the Catholic Church. CARA found that of those whose time frame could be determined
column3: 57 percent of credible allegations that came in 2019 happened before 1975
column4: 41 percent between 1975 and 1999
column5: and 2 percent since 2000
column6: the report said.

column1: Church officials said the fact that there remains such a small number of claims of recent abuse shows that their reforms are working and that the jump in reporting of older claims reflects confidence complaints will be taken seriously.
AD
AD
“It reflects the same pattern we’ve been seeing — there hasn’t been a real uptick in cases since the Charter
column2: ” said Francesco C. Cesareo
column3: the chairman of the National Review Board
column4: a committee created by the Catholic Church in 2002 to oversee the implementation of the Charter. “I think the data is out there to show that the Church has been the one institution that has really taken an institutional approach to this and put in place policies and protocols that have resulted in a much safer environment within the Church.""

column1: Some survivor advocates saw other things in the report. SNAP
column2: a clergy-abuse survivors’ organization
column3: emphasized the report’s finding that the status of 863 allegations is “unknown” and another 956 are ongoing.

column1: “Church officials pretend they’re reporting on a past problem when in fact thousands of proven
column2: admitted and credibly accused clerics who have committed or concealed child sex crimes remain ‘under the radar
column3: ’ living and working among unsuspecting neighbors
column4: friends
column5: co-workers and even relatives
column6: ” SNAP wrote. The Church
column7: it said
column8: should be focusing on locating all still-living child abusers to protect from future abuse and “punishing the still-living ‘enabling’ clerics who are ignoring or hiding those criminals.”

column1: Cesareo wrote in a letter attached to the report that the Church needs to allow a more in-depth and truly independent audit. While the report uses the word “independent” six times
column2: the nature and scope of the audit is determined by the bishops
column3: as are the questions. The audit is done by StoneBridge Business Partners
column4: using information given to it by dioceses. The dioceses also determine which allegations are credible.

column1: AD
AD
A more independent process is needed “if the bishops hope to regain the credibility that has been lost among the laity
column2: ” Cesareo wrote.

column1: The report says the spike in numbers is in part due to the fact that multiple dioceses around the country created compensation funds for victims whose cases had passed the statute of limitations in their states to sue
column2: as well as lawsuits and diocesan bankruptcies. The report says such cases account for 37 percent of allegations.

column1: Catholic provinces and dioceses that responded to the CARA survey said they had paid out a total of $282 million related to allegations the came in between July 2018 and June 2019.
Chieko Noguchi
column2: a spokeswoman for the USCCB
column3: said researchers believe there are many additional factors
column4: including “the news of high-profile revelations that also prompted people to step forward.”

column1: AD
AD"/['Michelle Boorstein'
column2: 'Religion Reporter']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/5LP2IUFYCUI6TDUDJZTIP2MYCQ.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/realmenwearmasks-may-be-helpful-but-the-fact-that-we-need-it-is-a-shame/2020/06/27/8f372340-b7eb-11ea-aca5-ebb63d27e1ff_story.html/Masks have nothing to do with masculinity. It's too bad we have to pretend they do./"This came on the heels of dire coronavirus news. Florida set an ignominious record
column2: with 9
column3: 000 new cases reported in a single day. The governor of Texas re-implemented restrictions on public spaces after 6
column4: 000 new cases were reported in his state. Drs. Anthony Fauci and Deborah Birx were back on television for their first coronavirus task force briefing in two months. And shortly after
column5: Cheney was on his daughter’s Twitter account. He wore a navy fleece vest
column6: a tan cowboy hat and
column7: covering everything from his chin to the bridge of his nose
column8: a standard pale blue surgical mask. Typed Liz Cheney
column9: who is also a Wyoming congresswoman: “Dick Cheney says WEAR A MASK.”

column1: Have we gathered here today to mock Dick Cheney
column2: the accidentally-shot-a-friend-in-the-face former Vice President of the United States? We have not. Cheney showed up this week demonstrating that he respected public health. He understood that masks are both the best way to protect other people from your germs
column3: and also one of the few reliable means of slowing the spread of the virus. He was humble enough to do what doctors and epidemiologists recommend.

column1: AD
AD
Thank you
column2: Dick Cheney. Thank you
column3: Mitch McConnell
column4: who lofted a mask at a news conference Friday and declared
column5: “These are really important.”

column1: The maddening aspect of #RealMenWearMasks isn’t the message but what’s behind it: We’ve reached the point of this polarized pandemic where our current plan for salvation is convincing certain recalcitrant men that wearing masks is the testosteroney thing to do.
“People need face coverings that make them feel stylish
column2: cool
column3: and — yes — even manly
column4: ” a Harvard epidemiologist wrote in the Atlantic.

column1: Men
column2: otherwise
column3: are less inclined to wear masks. A recent study
column4: co-authored by professors at Berkeley and the U.K.’s Middlesex University
column5: found that men resisted for several reasons: They were less likely to believe they’d get sick with the coronavirus (they are actually more likely to get sick)
column6: and “Men more than women agree that wearing a face covering is shameful
column7: not cool
column8: a sign of weakness

column1: AD
AD
As a result of this toxic mask-ulinity
column2: we have a whole campaign dedicated to slipping men’s faces into some sexy
column3: sexy N95s.

column1: “Mask shaming men won’t work. Here’s what will
column2: ” read the headline of a Los Angeles Times article suggesting ways to “make masks and masculinity a better fit.”

column1: Do you have an unmasked man in your life? You could
column2: the article suggests
column3: make sure he had some “tough” looking masks
column4: perhaps with “camouflage” or “shark teeth.” Or
column5: you could pull him in with a little “benevolent sexism
column6: ” i.e. encouraging him to think of mask-wearing as a “paternalistic” and “chivalrous” act — a way for the mask-wearer to think
column7: “I’m being a hero.”

column1: AD
Three things:
First
column2: [screams out window for 12 whole seconds].

column1: It’s slightly worrisome that
column2: in order for us to survive as a species
column3: spouses and daughters or sons must scour Etsy for Venom-themed masks so that their 52-year-old packaging-engineer husbands and fathers can feel gender-secure when they pop out to Safeway for some milk.

column1: AD
Second
column2: who knows if this will work? At the Alabama shore last month
column3: a CNN reporter asked a sun-baked man at the beach whether he would consider wearing a mask. “I don’t
column4: my wife and kids do
column5: ” he said
column6: adding that he just didn’t think he’d get sick. The reporter pointed out that the purpose of a mask wouldn’t be to protect him
column7: but to protect his wife and kids — benevolent sexism in the wild — and the guy shrugged. It just seemed like most people survived covid-19
column8: he said
column9: so he wasn’t going to bother.

column1: AD
Third — look
column2: we should do whatever works. If more recalcitrant men will wear masks if we convince them that doing so makes them look like Jason Momoa or one of the brothers Hemsworth
column3: let’s do that. Whatever. Sounds good. More than 123
column4: 000 Americans have died.

column1: #RealMenWearMasks. Let’s spray paint it on every sidewalk in the country
column2: hire skywriters to scribble it up and down the Gulf coastline. Get Lee Greenwood to write a song. Let’s hope other politicians get behind it
column3: too. (Ahem
column4: President Trump and Vice President Pence?)

column1: AD
But the messaging behind all of this is crap. It presents mask-wearing as something cool that men can individually do in order to be rugged heroes
column2: deserving of accolades for their brave
column3: manly choices.

column1: What masks really are is a pain in the neck. Chafing
column2: uncomfortable
column3: uncool in every imaginable way. You don’t wear them because Dick Cheney decided he can pull it off in a cowboy hat. You do it because nobody can make a mask look cool
column4: but we’re going to do it anyway: be chafed and dorky together
column5: all of us
column6: because doing that saves lives. You can call that being a hero
column7: but you can also call it being a responsible adult.

column1: AD"/['Monica Hesse'
column2: 'Style Reporter']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/743G43VYEUI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/medical-mysteries/his-anemia-was-followed-by-searing-foot-pain-seventeen-years-later-in-precarious-shape-a-stellar-athlete-learned-what-was-wrong/2020/06/26/1acfdebe-95ec-11ea-82b4-c8db161ff6e5_story.html/His anemia was followed by searing foot pain. Seventeen years later
column2: in precarious shape
column3: a stellar athlete learned what was wrong./"But in May 2001
column4: his energy was flagging. Sipos
column5: who lived in Riverside
column6: consulted his longtime general practitioner
column7: who ordered blood tests that revealed an abnormally low iron level.

column1: Several years later when he developed foot pain
column2: Sipos saw a podiatrist who told him he had osteoarthritis
column3: typically caused by wear and tear on joints. A few years later
column4: a specialist diagnosed his painful wrists and ankles as rheumatoid arthritis
column5: a serious autoimmune disease. That was followed by the diagnosis of a rare blood condition that a hematologist monitored
column6: but did not treat.

column1: AD
AD
It wasn’t until 2018 — nearly 17 years to the day after he first saw a doctor for fatigue — that Sipos learned he had none of those illnesses.
The news was delivered by a specialist whose gentle
column2: measured tone belied the shocking message that galvanized Sipos: Without treatment
column3: which was long overdue
column4: he could die.

column1: “We both started crying
column2: ” Sipos recalled of his reaction and that of his wife
column3: Tami. “It felt like the oxygen had been sucked out of the room.”

column1: He credits his survival to the expertise and compassion of that specialist
column2: who continues to oversee his treatment.

column1: Energy boost
Sipos trusted the family physician
column2: who had delivered his sons. The doctor told Sipos his fatigue was the result of anemia and could be easily treated with an over-the-counter iron supplement that he should take when he felt unusually tired.

column1: AD
AD
The pills seemed to work. “For the next 10 years I would pop iron pills every so often and notice a bump” in energy
column2: Sipos said.

column1: In 2007 a new problem arose: The soles of his feet ached and burned. He consulted a podiatrist who told Sipos he had “fallen arches” — flat feet that develop in adulthood. The doctor prescribed orthotics. For a while
column2: they quelled the pain.
the foot pain was considerably worse and had engulfed his ankles
column3: putting an end to his participation in extreme sports. Sipos’s hands felt tingly and numb and he was referred to a neurologist and a rheumatologist.

column1: The neurologist told Sipos he was suffering from carpal tunnel syndrome — numbness or tingling in the hands caused by a compressed nerve — as well as peripheral neuropathy
column2: damage to the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.

column1: AD
AD
“He said I should have it looked at because someone 46 years old should not have neuropathy
column2: ” Sipos remembers being told. Peripheral neuropathy can be caused by a variety of ailments
column3: among them diabetes
column4: liver disease and bone marrow disorders.

column1: The rheumatologist ordered blood tests and diagnosed “seronegative” rheumatoid arthritis. Although testing did not show antibodies to the disease
column2: his joint pain
column3: the doctor said
column4: strongly suggested it.

column1: The rheumatologist prescribed two drugs: methotrexate
column2: a chemotherapy drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis
column3: and when that didn’t help
column4: hydroxychloraquine
column5: an anti-malaria drug used to treat autoimmune disorders. Neither worked.

column1: AD
At that point
column2: Sipos recalled
column3: the pain was so intense “the weight of the [bed] sheets would feel like my feet were being crushed.” He wore braces on his wrists and ankles in a mostly failed attempt to deaden the pain
column4: and took the opioid pain killer hydrocodone to make it through the day.

column1: AD

column2: Sipos consulted a second rheumatologist. She agreed it was odd that neither drug had been effective and prescribed other medications. When they failed
column3: she ordered a test for immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies
column4: which can assess immune function. The test showed an “m spike
column5: ” an indication that Sipos might have a precancerous condition or possibly multiple myeloma
column6: an uncommon cancer.

column1: In early 2017 she referred Sipos
column2: who by then was suffering from frequent night sweats
column3: to a specialist who treats blood disorders.

column1: A precursor?
The hematologist immediately ordered urine and blood tests. On the basis of those
column2: Sipos said
column3: she assured him he did not have cancer
column4: but rather a precancerous condition called MGUS
column5: short for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance.

column1: AD
MGUS is often found incidentally
column2: when doctors are looking for other things. It frequently causes no symptoms but must be watched closely because in about 1 percent of patients annually it can progress to multiple myeloma
column3: a cancer of plasma cells
column4: or another malignancy. If there is no progression
column5: treatment is usually not required.

column1: AD
“She said the standard of care was watch and wait
column2: ” Sipos recalled. That meant appointments every three months to check his blood and urine.

column1: Sipos said the doctor also performed several bone marrow biopsies but the results were inconclusive.
When he asked the doctor about the unrelenting burning pain in his hands and feet
column2: she offered no explanation.

column1: AD
In early 2018
column2: he said
column3: he confronted her. “I’m getting worse
column4: ” he remembered saying. Her reply was stark. “She said
column5: ‘Yes
column6: you may be in a wheelchair
column7: but we would never treat this.’ ” His IgM level
column8: she told him
column9: was not sufficiently elevated to warrant the risks of treatment
column10: which would involve chemotherapy. Watchful waiting was the safest course.

column1: The hematologist told Sipos he was free to seek a second opinion. He was initially hesitant. Even though she was routinely an hour or two late for scheduled appointments
column2: the doctor “seemed so knowledgeable and wise and would speak with such authority
column3: ” he said. But at his wife’s urging
column4: Sipos decided it was time for another expert to weigh in.

column1: AD
What he didn’t know was that getting a second opinion would possibly save his life.
A dramatic reversal
Sipos and his wife waited six weeks for the consultation with Muhammad Omair Kamal
column2: an assistant professor of medical oncology at Loma Linda University Cancer Center.

column1: AD
Transferring his records to Kamal in preparation for the appointment was a struggle
column2: Sipos said
column3: requiring multiple phone calls by him as well as Kamal’s staff.

column1: Both Jeff and Tami Sipos say that details of the May 14
column3: meeting are seared into their memories.

column1: “I remember Dr. Kamal leaned forward and in his soft
column2: sweet voice full of concern said
column3: ‘Mr. Sipos
column4: has anyone told you you have cancer? How come you’re not getting treated for this?’ ” Sipos recalled.

column1: The stunned couple repeated what the hematologist had been saying for more than a year: that Sipos did not have cancer and that monitoring was the best course of action.
AD
Kamal strenuously disagreed. “You have cancer
column2: ” Sipos remembers him saying. “If you were my patient
column3: you’d be started on chemotherapy tomorrow.” Then he handed the couple treatment guidelines from the National Cancer Institute.

column1: AD
Although he still didn’t have all of Sipos’s records
column2: Kamal said he strongly suspected the principal had a rare
column3: slow-growing form of B cell lymphoma called Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
column4: also known as Waldenstrom’s or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. Kamal had seen four other cases in his career. MGUS can be a precursor of multiple myeloma or Waldenstrom’s. Sipos later learned that a January 2017 pathology report mentioned it as a possible cause of his symptoms.

column1: About 1
column2: 500 cases are diagnosed annually in the United States
column3: compared to about 32
column4: 000 cases of multiple myeloma.

column1: AD
Waldenstrom’s occurs mostly in men over 60 when lymphoma cells in bone marrow proliferate
column2: crowding out normal red and white blood cells. Anemia is common and symptoms include fatigue
column3: neuropathy and night sweats. There is no cure. Treatment typically consists of chemotherapy and targeted treatments that kill only cancer cells. The disease is diagnosed through blood tests and a bone marrow biopsy and can be confirmed by a test for a genetic mutation.

column1: Kamal said he cannot fathom why Sipos went undiagnosed for so long. “He was seeing the right doctor
column2: ” Kamal noted
column3: referring to the proper specialty.

column1: When he received Sipos’s complete records
column2: Kamal said
column3: “lab after lab after lab” showed results that warranted treatment. “There are not many diseases [other than Waldenstrom’s] where you see high IgM and neuropathy. Most patients are diagnosed within a year or two.”

column1: Sipos said that when he told the first hematologist what Kamal had recommended
column2: she balked and insisted that her diagnosis was correct. Switching doctors was problematic; Kamal was outside his insurance network.

column1: So another month elapsed while Sipos
column2: unsure about what to do
column3: obtained another opinion. The third cancer specialist strongly sided with Kamal. “If you don’t have chemo
column4: you’re going to expire
column5: ” Sipos remembers her saying.

column1: Sipos called his insurance company and requested a transfer to Kamal; it was quickly approved.
He then underwent another bone marrow biopsy and testing to rule out amyloidosis
column2: a rare disease caused by the accumulation of a protein that can result in organ failure. A positive test for the MYD88 L265P mutation linked to Waldenstrom’s clinched the diagnosis. (The mutation is not passed on to offspring.)

column1: In mid-August 2018
column2: Sipos began a grueling chemotherapy regimen to treat Waldenstrom’s. He wore a Superman T-shirt that one of his kindergarten students had given him to every session as a sort of talisman. By January 2019
column3: his cancer was in remission.

column1: But the agonizing nerve damage to his hands and feet continues to plague him. Kamal said the damage is probably irreversible and may have occurred because his cancer went untreated for so long.
Sipos
column2: who sees a pain specialist
column3: said he has been prescribed methadone
column4: which “takes the zing out of it.”

column1: He said he has learned through bitter experience to ask questions.
“No healthy adult male should be anemic
column2: ” he said. “I wish I’d had the foresight to ask
column3: ‘What would cause this?’ ”

column1: Sipos also wishes he had sought a second opinion sooner. “I was afraid I was going to offend her
column2: ” he said
column3: referring to the first hematologist.

column1: To Kamal
column2: Sipos’s case illustrates the necessity for doctors to keep looking and not brush off what patients tell them. “Don’t just ignore neuropathy
column3: or any symptoms
column4: in young patients. Even if they’re young
column5: they can have cancer.”"/['Sandra G. Boodman'
column6: 'Medical Reporter'
column7: 'Creator Of The Monthly Medical Mysteries Column']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/3N5SFLVXAII6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/22/racist-culturally-offensive-images-pulled-hugely-popular-trading-card-game//‘Racist’ and ‘culturally offensive’ images pulled from hugely popular trading card game/"This month
column2: the company behind “Magic: The Gathering” permanently banned that card and six others carrying labels like “Jihad” and “Pradesh Gypsies.” Wizards of the Coast
column3: a subsidiary of toy giant Hasbro
column4: acknowledged the images were “racist or culturally offensive.”

column1: “There’s no place for racism in our game
column2: nor anywhere else
column3: ” the company said in a statement announcing its action.

column1: AD
With the country roiled by tensions and protests over African Americans’ deaths at the hands of police
column2: the issues entangling Magic and its creators are unlikely to subside soon. The fantasy game of goblins
column3: elves
column4: spells and more boasts some 20 million players
column5: and in pre-pandemic times
column6: thousands flocked to elite international tournaments with hefty prizes. Players of color say they have long felt excluded in the white- and male-dominated community from the game’s top echelons
column7: as well as employment at the company.

column1: AD
Wizards has “a long unbroken pattern of insidious racist behavior wrapped in self-congratulatory praise
column2: ” wrote Zaiem Beg
column3: a prominent Pakistani-American commentator who analyzes the game’s strategy and tournaments. His is one of numerous letters now circulating on social media.

column1: “Both Wizards and the community at large are guilty of making black people feel unwelcome in Magic
column2: ” wrote Lawrence Harmon
column3: a black player who hosts a podcast about the game. “It’s time that changed.”

column1: AD
An endorsement from the company
column2: which also produces Dungeons & Dragons
column3: can boost the livelihoods of players
column4: artists and commentators. A lack of support can have the opposite effect. Critics say individuals who speak out risk being shut out of certain high-profile competitions or opportunities to create content for the company.

column1: AD
The Wizards announcement did not address those issues
column2: and a spokesman declined to comment. Yet its statement this month identified a clear impetus.

column1: “The events of the past weeks and the ongoing conversation about how we can better support people of color have caused us to examine ourselves
column2: our actions
column3: and our inactions
column4: ” it said. “We appreciate everyone helping us to recognize when we fall short. We should have been better
column5: we can be better
column6: and we will be better.”

column1: AD
Wizards subsequently pledged to review every Magic card printed — a considerable undertaking given that 20
column2: 000 unique cards are in circulation. “This first pass isn't meant to be an exhaustive catalogue of every problematic card in Magic’s history
column3: ” the company tweeted
column4: “and we will continue to take actions on similar cards in the future.""

column1: AD
The game's lead designer — an icon in the Magic community — offered a mea culpa of sorts on his personal blog.
“I’m a white man that grew up in America in the ’70s and ’80s
column2: ” Mark Rosewater explained. “I need to recognize that a lot of things I’ve internalized as normal and ‘just part of life’ have ugly aspects tied to them. I need to self-educate to understand these biases so that I can remove them.”

column1: AD
The company did not provide an explanation of the thought process behind the banned cards. The former art director who approved the image for “Invoke Prejudice
column2: ” Jesper Myrfors
column3: commented on the controversy in a defensive Facebook post. Pulling that card “was the right call
column4: ” he said
column5: even though its characters
column6: while looking “like KKK members
column7: ” had actually been inspired by the Spanish Inquisition.

column1: AD
In a separate Facebook post
column2: the card’s artist also linked the scene to the Inquisition. “The later rather insulting assumptions and accompanying venom were a bit sad to me
column3: ” Harold McNeill added.

column1: McNeill
column2: once a regular contributor to Magic
column3: has a personal website filled with drawings of swastikas
column4: Adolf Hitler
column5: crusader knights and highly sexualized depictions of women. For years
column6: Magic players have raised questions about his use of fascist imagery and why “Invoke Prejudice” was ever released.

column1: AD
Neither Myrfors nor McNeill could be reached for comment.
Ebony Elizabeth Thomas
column2: an associate professor at the University of Pennsylvania who studies race in fantasy worlds and young adult literature
column3: says racism in popular media can play a pernicious role in reinforcing negative attitudes about minority groups.

column1: AD
“If all your life you’ve been fed a steady diet of black people not mattering in your fantasy world
column2: in your playtime
column3: then why in the real world would you think that black people’s lives matter?” she said in an interview last week.

column1: Thomas noted that the KKK itself drew on historical imagery such as the Inquisition to evoke an imagined ideal past. There’s a similar danger even when the imagining is for something as innocuous as a game
column2: she said.

column1: AD
“I feel like these things inter-animate one another
column2: ” she noted. “Every time we encounter some racist backlash
column3: we tend to want to go back to some imaginary past that was somehow purer.”

column1: For the moment
column2: players of color say they would appreciate at least being recognized for their accomplishments.

column1: Greg Orange
column2: a professional player from Minneapolis who is biracial
column3: won a high-profile tournament in 2018 — a victory that made him the fifth-ranked player in the world. Still
column4: he and critics say
column5: Wizards officials repeatedly overlooked him in favor of white players when selecting participants for their top invitational tournaments.

column1: AD
Orange lives in the same city where a police officer in late May knelt on George Floyd’s neck for more than eight ultimately fatal minutes. He has mostly stayed home of late
column2: “freaked out” by the confrontations that erupted there between police and protesters reacting to Floyd’s death.

column1: AD
Early this month
column2: in response to the turmoil nationwide
column3: Wizards sent out tweets highlighting Magic players of color and expressing support for the Black Lives Matter movement. Orange was one of those featured."/['Rob Wolfe']/2020-06-22 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/357Z2UFRUYI6VGFVE6NGI6NB4Q.jpg&w=1440"

column1: Cookies. Cookies are small files that are placed on your computer when you visit a website. Cookies may be used to store a unique identification number tied to your computer or device so that you can be recognized as the same user across one or more browsing sessions
column2: and across one or more sites. Cookies serve many useful purposes. For example:

column1: Cookies can remember your sign-in credentials so you do not have to enter those credentials each time you visit a Service.

Cookies can help us and third parties understand which parts of our Services are the most popular because the• Cookies can help us and third parties understand which parts of our Services are the most popular because they help us see which pages and features visitors access and how much time they spend on the pages. By studying this kind of information
column2: we are better able to adapt our Services and provide you with a better experience.

column1: Cookies help us and third parties understand which ads you have seen so that you don’t receive the same ad each time you access a Service.
Most browsers accept cookies automatically
column2: but can be configured not to do so or to notify the user when a cookie is being sent. If you wish to disable cookies
column3: refer to your browser help menu to learn how to disable cookies. If you disable browser cookies or flash cookies
column4: it may interfere with the proper functioning of the Services.

column1: Beacons. We
column2: along with third parties
column3: also may use technologies called beacons (or “pixels”) that communicate information from your device to a server. Beacons can be embedded in online content
column4: videos
column5: and emails

column7: know when you have viewed particular content or a particular email message

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/in-south-jersey-its-a-kennedy-against-a-power-broker-favorite-to-challenge-turncoat-rep-van-drew/2020/06/27/6fc7d532-b7c7-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/In South Jersey
column2: it’s a Kennedy against a power broker favorite to challenge turncoat Rep. Van Drew/"Now
column3: the mother of five is running in a key congressional battleground that has the backdrop of President Trump and a Democratic vendetta to take out a once trusted ally who betrayed them.

column1: And
column2: in perhaps the most unusual fashion
column3: she is running as an outsider
column4: trying to establish a new beachhead for one of the most famous families in Democratic politics.

column1: AD
“It’s not the name
column2: it’s more people just associate that legacy with kind of the unfinished work of social justice. And that’s what I think people are really hungry for right now
column3: ” Kennedy said Wednesday in an hour-long interview at her house on the bay.

column1: AD
The irony is not lost on Kennedy’s main opponent
column2: who has spent 20 years as a political commentator in New Jersey
column3: a tenure that helped to quickly win the backing of six of the eight Democratic county chairmen in this district.

column1: “The Kennedys as outsiders
column2: ” Brigid Callahan Harrison said Wednesday
column3: in an hour-long telephone interview
column4: amazed at how much the race is pivoting on personality. “That is how they’re marketing this.”

column1: AD
So
column2: as voters check off their mail ballots in this pandemic-era July 7 election
column3: the battle is coming down to two powerful
column4: yet very different political machines: the Kennedys versus South Jersey power brokers.

column1: Neither Kennedy nor Harrison is really supposed to be running for this seat.
For Kennedy
column2: her destiny flipped after a chance meeting in 2010 at an Atlantic City conference on mental health
column3: with then-Rep. Patrick J. Kennedy (D-R.I.) headlining. He was winding down the last months of a 16-year career in Congress
column4: one that had seen plenty of public battles with substance abuse. His family’s history with mental illness had made that the central cause of his public service.

column1: AD
AD
A few months before his father
column2: Edward M. Kennedy (D-Mass.)
column3: a legendary senator of almost 47 years
column4: lost his fight with brain cancer.

column1: By July 2011 he and Amy married at Hyannisport
column2: the family compound on Cape Cod where so many Kennedy campaigns had been mapped out. But instead of settling in New England
column3: he moved about 400 miles down the coast to Brigantine
column4: leaving behind the family business.

column1: Harrison
column2: after losing a local municipal race in the late 1990s
column3: was hired as a political science professor at Montclair State University. She did commentary on local TV and wrote a regular column in some New Jersey papers
column4: always engaged in policy without ever fully entering the arena herself.

column1: AD

column2: Democratic women
column3: many running for the first time
column4: racked up wins and handed the gavel back to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.)
column5: while South Jersey Democrats supported a socially conservative white man: Jeff Van Drew
column6: who had climbed his way up the ladder of state politics in Trenton.

column1: AD
“I held my nose and voted for him
column2: ” Harrison
column4: said.

column1: Then came Van Drew’s vote on Halloween to oppose Pelosi’s move toward impeaching the president over the Ukraine scandal.
“I was sick to my stomach
column2: ” Harrison recalled.

column1: So she began floating her name as a potential primary opponent. She talked to party operatives and
column2: having never really raised campaign funds
column3: asked Patrick Kennedy if he would join her finance team if she went through with it.

column1: AD
Van Drew did not just oppose impeachment — he switched parties and
column2: in the Oval Office
column3: shook Trump’s hand and pledged his loyalty. Amy Kennedy felt sick to her stomach.

column1: “How is that possible? And kind of knowing the significance there
column2: and what that meant for this upcoming election
column3: how it would then become a race about Trump really — that felt like the moment
column4: ” she said.

column1: AD
By the time she entered the race
column2: Harrison had already locked down much of the establishment support.

column1: So Harrison
column2: who began as an insurgent challenging a favorite Democratic son
column3: has become the establishment pick
column4: including an unusual alignment with Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.) so that their names are bracketed together on the primary ballots.

column1: AD
Kennedy
column2: with a last name that is synonymous with Democratic power
column3: is now running as the outsider in a district that she has lived and worked in her entire life.

column1: What has ensued is an increasingly bitter
column2: personal campaign that is befitting of this state’s bare-knuckle traditions.

column1: Moreover
column2: with Gov. Phil Murphy (D) endorsing Kennedy
column3: New Jersey’s intensely myopic insider class has lost focus on defeating Van Drew and instead see this primary as a proxy fight in a long-running civil war.

column1: AD
Murphy has clashed with Democratic power broker George Norcross and his protege
column2: state Senate President John Sweeney (D)
column3: from almost his first day in office in January 2018. Norcross
column4: a private businessman
column5: does not technically hold an official party position but his influence resembles a character from the HBO show “Boardwalk Empire
column6: ” about Atlantic City during Prohibition.

column1: Kennedy is trying to overcome that influence with a mix of hometown tied to an incredible legacy. Her Brigantine home is filled with family memorabilia
column2: including a framed box of all the airline tickets that Patrick Kennedy collected as he traveled across the country in 2000 as chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

column1: AD
She is viewed fondly by her extended family
column2: someone who helped anchor Patrick Kennedy’s life. They have four children together
column3: and he is a doting stepfather to her eldest daughter.

column1: AD
“She’s fantastic
column2: ” Rep. Joe Kennedy (D-Mass.) said.

column1: Joe Kennedy laughed at the idea of his cousin by marriage running as an outsider
column2: as he is in the midst of a challenge to Sen. Edward J. Markey (D-Mass.).

column1: The covid pandemic has limited how much in-person campaigning the Kennedys can do
column2: but the family is helping where it can. Joe Kennedy did a Facebook Live chat with Amy Kennedy.

column1: A piece of mail includes images of John F. Kennedy as president and his son saluting his casket at his funeral after the 1963 assassination
column2: among other iconic pictures.

column1: AD
“Ask not what your country can do for you
column2: ” it says
column3: “ask what Amy Kennedy can do for your country.”

column1: All of this has pushed Harrison to complain that her opponent is running “exclusively on the fact that she married someone with a famous last name.”
The two largely agree on policy
column2: but Harrison stresses
column3: “I know policy
column4: so there’s a big difference. I’m a candidate of substance.”

column1: AD
Kennedy dismisses those attacks as academic elitism
column2: incapable of connecting with typical voters. “To really connect with people
column3: that’s more about the personal stories that they have
column4: ” she said.

column1: A victory here
column2: in the primary and over Van Drew
column3: would demonstrate the Kennedy name still resonates."/['Paul Kane'
column4: 'Senior Congressional Correspondent']/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/5AC3EFFYTQI6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-administrations-move-to-end-obamacare-amid-pandemic-reignites-political-fight/2020/06/26/9c1ddb98-b7bf-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html/Trump administration’s move to end Obamacare amid pandemic reignites political fight/"Trump vowed as recently as last weekend
column2: at a campaign rally in Tulsa
column3: that he would “always protect patients with preexisting conditions
column4: always
column5: always.” But his own administration’s position in court is that the 2010 Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate is unconstitutional
column6: and therefore so is the entire law — even its most popular provisions
column7: such as coverage for those with preexisting conditions.

column1: AD
AD

“Nothing the 2017 Congress did demonstrates it would have intended the rest of the ACA to continue to operate in the absence of these three integral provisions. The entire ACA thus must fall with the individual mandate
column2: ” the brief said.

column1: On Saturday
column2: Trump tweeted that his administration is “asking the Supreme Court that Obamacare itself be terminated so that it can be replaced with a FAR BETTER AND MUCH LESS EXPENSIVE ALTERNATIVE.”

column1: Republican officials and strategists working on competitive campaigns were privately aghast Friday at the administration’s decision to reignite the issue
column2: particularly as health care is at the forefront of voters’ minds because of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

column1: AD
The ties between the pandemic and access to Obamacare were underscored this week with a new report from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
column2: which found that 487
column3: 000 Americans used a special enrollment period for the health care law after losing their own coverage
column4: probably due to job losses.

column1: AD
“To take that issue to the Supreme Court
column2: in the middle of a pandemic
column3: shows that there’s a lack of understanding about the fear out there in this country
column4: ” said Rep. Debbie Dingell (D-Mich.)
column5: who hails from one of the most closely watched presidential battleground states. “I think that we need to talk about it so that people understand what’s going on.”

column1: The potency of health care as an issue was evident in advance of the filing
column2: with Democrats — anticipating the Thursday deadline for the Justice Department to respond in the case — eagerly holding media calls promoting the Affordable Care Act and attacking incumbent Republican senators for their attempts to repeal it or insufficiently defend it.

column1: AD
In Maine
column2: Democrat Sara Gideon
column3: who is running against Sen. Susan Collins (R)
column4: criticized the four-term senator for casting a “key vote” that prompted the legal challenge from the Republican attorneys general. Collins has voted against repealing the health care law
column5: but supported a separate law enacted in 2017 that effectively eliminated Obamacare’s requirement that everyone hold insurance.

column1: AD
Collins
column2: in a statement Friday
column3: said the Justice Department arrived at the “wrong conclusion” in its argument in court
column4: saying it was never the intent of lawmakers to repeal the entire health care law when the Republican-controlled Congress got rid of its individual mandate through the 2017 tax cut bill.

column1: “The administration’s decision to submit this new brief is the wrong policy at the worst possible time as our nation is in the midst of a pandemic
column2: ” Collins said in a statement to The Washington Post. “The Affordable Care Act remains the law of the land
column3: and it is the Department of Justice’s duty to defend it.”

column1: AD
But with its legal filing
column2: the Trump administration directly contradicted that position
column3: arguing that even provisions regarding preexisting conditions or high-risk medical histories could not be severed from the mandate.

column1: AD

The administration’s aggressive argument against Obamacare comes amid heightened concerns from Republicans about their overall electoral fortunes this fall due to the president’s handling of the cratering economy
column2: a national uprising over racism and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

column1: Democrats have largely credited their winning back the House majority in 2018 to health care
column2: and they’ve seized on Trump and congressional Republicans’ repeated efforts to repeal it in campaigns. The GOP mantra for a decade has been “repeal and replace
column3: ” but the party has never been able to coalesce around an alternative.

column1: AD
Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden also jumped on the issue this week
column2: saying during a campaign swing in Pennsylvania on Thursday that Trump’s “twin legacies” are “his failure to protect the American people from the coronavirus
column3: and his heartless crusade to take health-care protections away from American families.”

column1: AD
At a virtual fundraiser Friday
column2: Biden said
column3: “Millions have contracted coronavirus
column4: people need a lifeline. And they don’t need a president suing to deny them health care.”

column1: The Biden campaign put an emphasis on the Trump administration’s move against the Affordable Care Act on Friday
column2: hosting events with surrogates designed to draw a sharp contrast with the president.

column1: AD
Former second lady Jill Biden and Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.) held a virtual event with supporters in Wisconsin
column2: a key battleground. “This administration is trying to take health care away from million of Americans. That’s it
column3: ” said Harris
column4: who is under consideration to be Biden’s running mate.

column1: Jill Biden promoted the steps Biden would take to add to the ACA
column2: rather than tear it down. She mentioned his support for an optional public insurance program
column3: among other things.

column1: AD
“This matters to Joe
column2: ” she said. “And you matter to him.”

column1: A Kaiser Family Foundation poll this month found that 53 percent of voters trust Biden more on health care issues
column2: compared with 38 percent for Trump. And according to internal Democratic polling of key Senate battleground states conducted in May
column3: GOP support for the legal challenge against Obamacare was the top negative against Senate Republicans
column4: particularly among swing and independent voters
column5: according to a party official familiar with the numbers who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the findings.

column1: AD
“Americans should look at what the Trump administration and Republicans do — not what they say — on health care
column2: ” said Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-N.Y.). “Republicans remain unflinching in their cruel and callous campaign to eliminate Americans’ health-care coverage
column3: even as the country faces down the biggest global health crisis in recent history.”

column1: AD

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Democrats will force Republicans to cast a tough vote on the issue next week. She introduced a bill Wednesday that would broaden the reach of the law and make it available to more Americans.

The bill would penalize states that do not expand Medicaid and expand subsidies for people who buy private health plans in the insurance marketplaces created under the law for individuals and families who do not have access to affordable health-care benefits through a job.
AD
Responding to the court filing late Thursday
column2: Pelosi said Trump and Republicans’ “campaign to rip away the protections and benefits of the Affordable Care Act in the middle of the coronavirus crisis is an act of unfathomable cruelty.”

column1: Health care has also been a dominant theme in televisions spots run this week by Democratic Senate candidates and groups working to elect them
column2: popping up as an issue in ads in Arizona
column3: Montana
column4: North Carolina and Colorado.

column1: AD
In private
column2: Republican officials working on down-ballot races vented their frustration with the administration’s decision to revive the health care fight
column3: while acknowledging that repealing Obamacare remains a core issue for their base. The timing of the filing
column4: amid the pandemic
column5: was also particularly unhelpful
column6: according to Republicans.

column1: “In a sea of stupid decisions this administration makes on a daily basis
column2: this one stands out
column3: ” complained one Senate GOP aide Friday
column4: granted anonymity to candidly assess the White House’s moves.

column1: Some in the Trump administration
column2: including Attorney General William P. Barr
column3: have privately argued parts of the law should be preserved amid a pandemic. In a meeting last month
column4: Barr made that argument with senior officials
column5: but days later
column6: Trump told reporters
column7: “We want to terminate health care under Obamacare.”

column1: Judd Deere
column2: a White House spokesman
column3: said after the brief was submitted that “a global pandemic does not change what Americans know: Obamacare has been an unlawful failure and further illustrates the need to focus on patient care.”

column1: “The American people deserve for Congress to work on a bipartisan basis with the President to provide quality
column2: affordable care
column3: ” Deere said.

column1: Oral arguments in the case aren’t scheduled until the next Supreme Court term
column2: which begins in October. It’s unclear whether they will occur before the Nov. 3 election.

column1: Some conservative lawmakers largely shrugged
column2: noting that the Republican Party has tried to overturn the health care law ever since it was enacted in 2010.

column1: “We’ve been trying to overcome the detrimental effects of the ACA for a long time
column2: ” said Rep. Douglas A. Collins (R-Ga.)
column3: who is running for one of two Senate seats in Georgia. “That was one of the biggest things that I think that the Republican majority
column4: looking back on
column5: I wish that we could have passed and got done.”

column1: Sean Sullivan contributed to this report."/['Seung Min Kim'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/congressional-black-caucus-seizes-on-push-for-racial-justice-to-wield-greater-influence/2020/06/27/08074206-b7e6-11ea-9b0f-c797548c1154_story.html/Congressional Black Caucus seizes on push for racial justice to wield greater influence/"Three caucus members — Sen. Kamala D. Harris (D-Calif.) and Reps. Val Demings (D-Fla.) and Karen Bass (D-Calif.) — are on the shortlist of potential running mates for presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden.
And with black candidates around the nation channeling the public clamor for equality into likely primary upsets last Tuesday
column2: the group is poised to expand its ranks next year — when it marks its 50th anniversary.

column1: AD
AD
“I’ve seen the CBC since its inception
column2: and this is quite a moment where everything has come together
column3: ” said Rep. Barbara Lee (D-Calif.). “It’s sort of something that I know the founders of the CBC dreamed of
column4: worked for . . . envisioned. . . . People are beginning to recognize this.”

column1: Lee reminisced about one of the original 13 members of the caucus
column2: Rep. Shirley Chisholm (D-N.Y.)
column3: the first black woman elected to Congress. Lee worked on Chisholm’s 1972 presidential campaign
column4: called her a friend and her mentor
column5: and recalled that Chisholm had to “fight just to get a seat at the table.”

column1: Members of the caucus are already making plans to capitalize on the moment
column2: eyeing two possible vacancies in chairmanships to increase their clout. Although mail ballots are still being counted
column3: House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot L. Engel (D-N.Y.) trails rival Jamaal Bowman
column4: an African American former middle school principal.

column1: AD
AD
Caucus members are uniting behind one of their own to replace Engel and lead the committee: Rep. Gregory W. Meeks (D-N.Y.). The panel has never had a black chairman.
Members are also discussing the possibility of Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton (D-D.C.) taking the gavel as chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Reform. The current chairman
column2: Rep. Carolyn B. Maloney (D-N.Y.)
column3: is locked in a close race that is also contingent on tens of thousands of mail ballots.

column1: Looking beyond Congress to the November election
column2: caucus members are upbeat about the potential for legacy-defining change — 12 years after one of their own
column3: then-Sen. Barack Obama (D-Ill.)
column4: was elected president.

column1: AD
“It’s a moment of leadership for our members of the Congressional Black Caucus
column2: ” said Rep. Shelia Jackson Lee (D-Tex.)
column3: who is not only hoping for an African American vice presidential nominee but black Cabinet members and Supreme Court nominees in a future Biden administration. “It’s time for us to lead on a national level. . . . It shouldn’t be just one
column4: it has to be many.”

column1: To be sure
column2: the CBC has always been a force to be reckoned with in Congress since its founding in 1971. The organization’s purpose is to use constitutional power and the federal government “to ensure that African Americans and other marginalized communities in the United States have the opportunity to achieve the American Dream.”

column1: AD
Now
column2: as the largest minority caucus in the House
column3: it boasts a record membership that is approaching 60 next year.

column1: AD
Its members hold four of the 21 permanent committee gavels. And the group’s highest-ranking member
column2: House Majority Whip James E. Clyburn (D-S.C.)
column3: can arguably claim the title of kingmaker after his endorsement in the South Carolina primary propelled former vice president Joe Biden to a statewide victory and the presumptive Democratic presidential nomination.

column1: But the nationwide conversation about race is giving the group even more power and stirring talk about the next leaders. Jackson Lee expressed hope that the policing bill could be one of several pieces of legislation addressing the needs of black Americans. And House Democratic Caucus Chairman Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.) has often been mentioned as a possible first black speaker.
AD
Members took pride Thursday night in securing passage of the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act
column2: even though the effort to overhaul law enforcement tactics has stalled in Congress with the Republican-led Senate favoring a narrower measure.

column1: AD
The Democratic bill would ban chokeholds and some no-knock warrants and establish a national database to track police misconduct. In the aftermath of Floyd’s death and nationwide protests
column2: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) deferred to the caucus to craft the legislation
column3: leaning on Bass
column4: its chairwoman
column5: to guide the process.

column1: On Thursday
column2: Jeffries gave an impassioned closing argument for the policing bill
column3: speaking directly to protesters around the nation: “We hear you
column4: we see you
column5: we are you.” He also recounted a story about how his son challenged him after news of Floyd’s death
column6: asking him: “What are you going to do about it?”

column1: AD
“I say to him
column2: and I say to all those other black children throughout America: We are here today as House Democrats to do something about it
column3: ” Jeffries said.

column1: AD
When three Republicans — Will Hurd (R-Tex.)
column2: Brian Fitzpatrick (R-Pa.) and Fred Upton (R-Mich.) — suddenly defected from their leadership instructions to vote “no” and backed the bill
column3: Bass cheered
column4: but bullishly vowed to get more of them to sign on soon.

column1: “I am ecstatic that we have a bipartisan historic passage of a bill to transform policing in the United States
column2: ” she said. “And now I look forward to getting my other Republican colleagues on board. Many
column3: many of them came over and approached me. And so
column4: I'm going to celebrate tonight
column5: and I'll be back at work tomorrow.”

column1: On the campaign trail
column2: black politicians have tapped into the energy from the growing demands for racial justice. In primaries this past week
column3: voters spoke when they picked black candidates over their white counterparts
column4: sending a signal of change to Washington.

column1: AD
AD
Beyond Bowman’s probable win in New York
column2: Cameron Webb — an African American physician
column3: former White House fellow and health policy researcher — captured the Democratic nomination in Virginia.

column1: In the New York City suburbs
column2: Mondaire Jones
column3: an attorney and former official in the Obama Justice Department
column4: held a primary lead in a crowded field vying to replace retiring Rep. Nita M. Lowey (D-N.Y.). If he wins
column5: Jones would be the first openly gay black member of Congress.

column1: And in Kentucky’s Democratic Senate primary Charles Booker
column2: once a long-shot candidate
column3: is running close with Amy McGrath
column4: the retired Marine fighter pilot backed by national Democrats. Either one would face a tough challenge in trying to unseat Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.)

column1: In Congress
column2: the mood has also made CBC members reassess their demands over gavels. Traditionally
column3: the group has been among the most adamant in insisting that House Democrats follow seniority rules
column4: designating the longest serving member as next in line of succession.

column1: AD
AD
Now
column2: caucus members are suggesting diversity should trump seniority
column3: coalescing around Meeks even though Rep. Brad Sherman (D-Calif.) is the next likely successor to Engel on Foreign Affairs.

column1: “I don’t want to start measuring drapes
column2: but I think in terms of foreign policy depth
column3: in terms of acumen
column4: in terms of passion
column5: in terms of someone who’s a patriot
column6: in terms of someone who wants to foster greater relationships with the global community
column7: you can’t find a better person than my mentor
column8: big brother and friend Greg Meeks — that’s for sure

column1: An African American heading the committee
column2: Carson said
column3: would be “monumental” and “historical.” “It’s necessary.”

column1: The committee has passed over Sherman once for the panel’s top Democratic slot in favor of the third-ranking Democrat. In 2012
column2: members objected to how a PAC supporting him sent out a mailer to voters warning that House members Maxine Waters
column3: Barney Frank and Barbara Boxer supported his opponent Howard Berman
column4: who happened to be the panel’s top Democrat. Sherman disavowed the mailing
column5: but Engel got the top post.

column1: AD
Meeks
column2: for his part
column3: isn’t ruling it out."/['Rachael Bade'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/video/politics/mississippi-house-takes-step-toward-removing-confederate-symbol-from-state-flag/2020/06/27/551b0fdb-1176-4ea0-b86a-04b39802f670_video.html/Mississippi House takes step toward removing Confederate symbol from state flag/"Mississippi House takes step toward removing Confederate symbol from state flag
On June 27
column2: the Mississippi House passed a resolution on its state flag
column3: which in part represents the Confederate flag. The resolution would allow the legislature to suspend rules and introduce a bill to remove the flag."/[]/2020-06-27 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/pbox.php?url=https://d1i4t8bqe7zgj6.cloudfront.net/06-27-2020/t_118b1ad37a5f4e309755f6c7c2db1eac_name_mississippi.jpg&w=1484&op=resize&opt=1&filter=antialias&t=20170517"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/kamala-harris-once-went-after-joe-biden-but-now-theres-only-bonhomie-as-the-vice-presidential-tryouts-continue/2020/06/26/9b525566-b6f9-11ea-a8da-693df3d7674a_story.html/Kamala Harris once went after Joe Biden
column2: but now there’s only bonhomie as the vice presidential tryouts continue/"On Friday
column3: a far different dynamic was on display. Harris (D-Calif.) smiled broadly as she introduced Jill Biden as “our next first lady.” Jill Biden closed her eyes and put her hands over her heart as she recalled how Harris’s op-ed on black maternal health touched her.

column1: The striking show of bonhomie came during a virtual discussion on the Affordable Care Act
column2: which had all the trappings of a typical Biden campaign event. Except this one was freighted with a tense history and effectively doubled as a high-stakes public tryout — the latest in a series featuring a Democrat under consideration to be Biden’s running mate.

column1: AD
AD
To some Biden allies
column2: it also served as a visible turning-of-the-page on an uncomfortable chapter that has loomed over the vice presidential search. Seeking to quell rumblings from some Democrats who have said they detected signs of frustration with Harris from Jill Biden and Valerie Biden Owens
column3: Biden’s sister and longtime political adviser
column4: the Biden campaign on Friday looked to publicly dispel the notion that their views of Harris are anything less than positive.

column1: “Both Dr. Biden and Valerie have nothing but the utmost respect
column2: admiration and affection for Senator Harris
column3: ” Biden campaign spokeswoman Elizabeth Alexander said in a statement. “Any rumors or conjecture to the contrary are not true and have zero basis in reality or fact.”

column1: On the debate stage in Miami one year ago Saturday
column2: Harris looked at Biden and told him it was “hurtful to hear you talk about the reputations of two United States senators who built their reputations and career on the segregation of race
column3: ” referring to friendly comments he once made about former Senate colleagues.

column1: AD
AD
She accused him of opposing school busing
column2: saying
column3: “There was a little girl in California who was part of the second class to integrate her public schools
column4: and she was bused to school every day. And that little girl was me.” (Within hours
column5: Harris’s campaign was selling a T-shirt emblazoned with those words.)

column1: Biden shot back that Harris had mischaracterized him. “I did not oppose busing in America
column2: ” he said. “What I opposed is busing ordered by the Department of Education.”

column1: For Harris
column2: who has emerged as a top contender to join the Democratic ticket and is the most prominent African American woman under consideration
column3: last summer’s exchange has complicated her prospects in the eyes of some Biden allies. Although some have moved on from it
column4: others said it was not so easy to forget
column5: particularly since Harris was a friend of Biden’s late son
column6: Beau.

column1: AD
AD
“I’m Irish and we Irish hold grudges
column2: ” said John Morgan
column3: a Florida trial lawyer and major Biden donor. “It was vicious. It was meant to kill him. And she was probably the one he never would have expected it from
column4: which to me made it more treacherous.”

column1: Other Biden allies said they saw Friday’s joint appearance as a sign of the strides Harris has made.
“It’s etched in my mind
column2: ” said Steve Westly
column3: a California investor and top Biden fundraiser
column4: referring to last year’s debate. But he added
column5: “Everybody knows that Jill is in Joe’s inner circle
column6: ” and so “the fact that Jill has chosen Kamala to do an event with her double underscores that Kamala is on the very shortlist of people Joe is considering.”

column1: South Carolina state Sen. Dick Harpootlian
column2: a longtime Biden friend
column3: said the impact of the 2019 dispute will be determined by Biden alone. “I know that there are people that were not happy with what she tried to do in the debate
column4: ” he said
column5: but Biden will decide if it “makes her unacceptable.”

column1: Some aides and associates of Biden and Harris said the tension between the two camps started to recede with the passage of time. As early as one month after the confrontation
column2: Biden greeted Harris on the second debate stage by joking
column3: “Go easy on me
column4: kid.”

column1: AD
AD
In October
column2: Harris
column3: Biden and their aides ran into each other at a private airport terminal after a campaign event in Iowa
column4: according to two people with knowledge of the situation. It was Harris’s birthday
column5: and her husband
column6: Doug Emhoff
column7: gave the Biden team some leftover cupcakes. Harris and Biden had a brief private discussion while their aides talked
column8: said the people
column9: who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe a private encounter.

column1: Ian Sams
column2: who served as national press secretary on the Harris campaign
column3: remembered Biden and Harris on other occasions “giving each other hugs backstage or talking about their families or random experiences on the trail.” Sams said his sense of Biden is “you can’t be successful at the highest levels of national politics for 40 years like he has without the rapid ability to turn yesterday’s rivals into today’s allies.”

column1: In recent weeks
column2: Biden frequently has enlisted the help of Harris and other candidates under consideration to be his running mate. Rep. Karen Bass (D-Calif.)
column3: who is being vetted
column4: participated in a call with reporters Friday about the Affordable Care Act. She referred a question about the vetting to the Biden campaign.

column1: AD
AD

Harris has been one of the most active Biden surrogates. The Friday event featured Harris and Jill Biden hearing from supporters in Wisconsin about health care. Together they spoke of the importance of the Affordable Care Act and safeguarding it from GOP efforts to dismantle it. Jill Biden frequently invited Harris to weigh in and offer her perspective.
The discussion got personal
column2: with the participants sharing stories about their health-care experiences. Harris shared the story of her late mother’s battle with cancer. Jill Biden told an emotional story of her sister’s stem-cell transplant
column3: her six-week isolation in a hospital room and the lifesaving help she got from the ACA.

column1: Harris hosted a virtual fundraiser with Biden this month that brought in $3.5 million. Biden offered a word of personal praise for Harris at the event
column2: mentioning her friendship with Beau Biden
column3: who died of brain cancer in 2015.

column1: AD
AD
He recalled running into Harris years ago. “You said
column2: ‘I love you and I loved Beau
column3: ’ ” Biden said. “I won’t forget that.” Harris said Emhoff had enjoyed spending time with Jill Biden
column4: and they stayed in touch beyond the primaries. On Friday
column5: Jill Biden reflected warmly on her relationship with Emhoff.

column1: In December
column2: on the day Harris ended her campaign
column3: Biden called her
column4: according to two people with knowledge of the situation. Harris endorsed Biden on March 8
column5: saying in a video that “he is a man who has lived his life with great dignity.”

column1: But only days earlier
column2: Jill Biden indicated the June 2019 debate had not faded from her mind. On March 6
column3: she was asked at a fundraiser about a potential vice presidential choice. When the discussion turned to Harris
column4: Jill Biden said Harris had a very close “bond” with Beau Biden
column5: and when Biden looked surprised onstage when Harris attacked
column6: it was because “our son Beau spoke so highly of her and
column7: you know
column8: and how great she was.”

column1: AD
AD
She added that she was not saying Harris wasn’t great
column2: but her debate comments were like a “punch to the gut; it was a little unexpected.”

column1: Former Iowa first lady Christie Vilsack
column2: a friend of Jill Biden’s
column3: said she does not have any sense of how Jill Biden and Owens feel about Harris.

column1: “I’ve never had that conversation
column2: ” she said. Speaking generally of Jill Biden
column3: Vilsack said
column4: “She
column5: like her husband
column6: is a very warm person and she values relationships.”

column1: Questioned on the topic
column2: Rep. Marcia L. Fudge (D-Ohio)
column3: an ally of both Biden and Harris
column4: said that “politics is not a business for people with thin skin.” She added
column5: “I just don’t believe that in our business you carry hard feelings about something like a debate.”

column1: AD
Some Biden allies pointed to Biden’s relationship with Barack Obama
column2: which Biden has said he is seeking to re-create with his eventual running mate. It
column3: too
column4: had some difficult chapters.

column1: AD
The Rev. Al Sharpton recalled Biden calling him to apologize after playing into black stereotypes when he said of Obama in 2007
column2: “I mean
column3: you got the first mainstream African American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy.”

column1: “That didn’t stop him from being selected
column2: ” Sharpton said."/['Sean Sullivan'
