column5: 'National Political Reporter Focused On The Presidential Campaign']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/JOITUPFX7EI6VKG2NE67HV3HJI.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/pence-puts-positive-spin-on-surging-coronavirus-cases-in-south-west/2020/06/26/70a1dfa2-b7c7-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/Pence tries to put positive spin on pandemic despite surging cases in South and West/"Vice President Pence held the first public briefing of the coronavirus task force in nearly two months and sought to deliver an upbeat message that was at odds with warnings from public health experts. The vice president dodged the question of whether people should wear masks in public
column2: as his own administration recommends
column3: and said campaign rallies that pack people together
column4: in violation of public health guidance
column5: will continue.

column1: Pence offered no new strategies to combat the rapidly spreading virus and minimized record daily case counts in several states as “outbreaks in specific counties.”
AD
AD
“As we stand here today
column2: all 50 states and territories across the country are opening up
column3: and safely and responsibly
column4: ” Pence said
column5: a point that was undermined as Florida and Texas on Friday began to scale back or reverse their reopening plans because of growing outbreaks.

column1: Pence’s remarks came as the virus has emerged as an urgent political crisis for Trump. With less than five months until Election Day
column2: a slate of recent public opinion polls show Trump trailing former vice president Joe Biden
column3: the presumptive Democratic nominee
column4: both nationally and in several key battleground states
column5: with voters taking a negative view of how the administration has handled the pandemic. Some of those states — including Arizona
column6: Florida and Texas — are putting their reopening plans on hold.

column1: The briefing was the latest effort by Pence and Trump to cherry-pick data as they attempt to gloss over the fact that on their watch
column2: the United States has failed to stop the spread of a virus that the White House has often said will soon go away or have less and less impact on daily life.

column1: AD
AD
While Pence acknowledged the rising numbers of cases in the South and the West
column2: he sought to play down the threat while heaping praise on Trump for how he has handled the pandemic. The vice president argued that many of the new cases are being found in younger Americans
column3: who are at less risk of developing deadly complications from the virus than older Americans are. He also argued that states have told him they have enough medical equipment to deal with the surge in infections and repeated the misleading claim that more testing is the main reason for the rising numbers of cases.

column1: Pence rejected the idea that campaign rallies should be curtailed during the pandemic
column2: arguing that the events are constitutionally protected free speech
column3: and he defended two events Trump held in the past week over objections from local officials or the advice of his own public health advisers.

column1: “Well
column2: the freedom of speech
column3: the right to peaceably assemble
column4: is enshrined in the Constitution of the United States
column5: and we have an election coming up this fall
column6: ” Pence said
column7: adding that people who attend such events are offered screenings and health advice.

column1: AD
AD
In a further sign of worry about the spread of the virus in the United States
column2: Europe is poised to stop allowing American travelers into the European Union as it tries to permit more flights into E.U. member countries.

column1: Trump has pushed for a swift reopening of shuttered businesses and an end to restrictions that have kept most people at home. In recent days he has reiterated that the economy will not be shut down again to contain the virus and has called outbreaks “embers” that can be put out.
Trump did not attend the briefing
column2: which
column3: unlike similar presentations early in the pandemic
column4: was not held at the White House. Those sessions were discontinued as Trump sought to reduce the focus on the pandemic and move on
column5: arguing that the economic toll of restrictions was too high.

column1: AD
The vice president and top federal public health officials spoke on the same day that Florida reported nearly 9
column2: 000 new coronavirus cases and announced that bars must close immediately
column3: a move echoed in Texas
column4: which is also dealing with a surge in cases and nearing its capacity to care for the infected.

column1: AD
Pence acknowledged that cases have been rising “precipitously” in some states
column2: largely in the South
column3: and announced that he and other task force officials would travel to Texas
column4: Arizona and Florida in the coming days for on-the-ground reports.

column1: He and federal health officials said the onus is on Americans to act responsibly and heed the advice of their local and state leaders
column2: since conditions and risks differ across the nation.

column1: AD
Anthony S. Fauci
column2: who leads the government’s infectious-disease effort
column3: pleaded with Americans to take the virus seriously and continue exercising precautions some four months into a national state of partial paralysis.

column1: “We are all in it together
column2: and the only way we’re going to end it is by ending it together
column3: ” Fauci said.

column1: He and other officials wore masks as they flanked Pence
column2: who did not wear one. Fauci and the others removed their masks when speaking at the lectern.

column1: Congressional Republicans have begun to express worries about the rising case numbers even as the White House has sought to downplay them.
AD

House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) suggested that nationwide protests against racial injustice were largely responsible for the spike that has led to record-setting numbers of new cases in recent days
column2: despite a lack of evidence supporting such a connection.

column1: AD
Florida’s new-case report blew past the state’s previous single-day record of 5
column3: set on Wednesday. It was the 19th day in a row that the state has hit a new average high. Average cases are now up about 77 percent from a week ago and 526 percent since Memorial Day.

column1: The sharp increases are fueling concerns that Florida — where Gov. Ron DeSantis (R) has pushed an aggressive reopening strategy — is fast emerging as a new epicenter for the virus.
DeSantis has sought to blame the surging infections on farmworkers
column2: anti-police-brutality protests and an increase in testing
column3: while cheering on the relocation of the Republican National Convention to Florida.

column1: AD
AD
The GOP announced in mid-June that it would relocate the celebratory public portions of its presidential nominating convention to Jacksonville
column2: Fla.
column3: from Charlotte after Trump balked at North Carolina’s social distancing requirements.

column1: The move has prompted growing concerns that a convention will only exacerbate the virus’s spread. According to data tracked by The Washington Post
column2: cases in Duval County
column3: which includes Jacksonville
column4: have nearly doubled in the past two weeks.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: less than a day after announcing that Texas would pause reopening plans but not revert to stricter measures
column3: Gov. Greg Abbott (R) issued an executive order that revives restrictions on bars
column4: restaurants and certain types of outdoor recreation.

column1: AD
“The trajectory that we’re on right now has our hospitals being overwhelmed
column2: probably about mid-July
column3: ” Austin Mayor Steve Adler (D) said during an appearance on CNN.

column1: AD
Nationwide
column2: infections surpassed 40
column3: 000 for the first time Friday
column4: the third national record this week.

column1: Pence said the increases were being driven by people under age 35
column2: which he called “very encouraging news” because they are generally less susceptible to severe illness from the virus.

column1: Other countries are seeing total positive cases going down
column2: regardless of age.

column1: Pence dismissed the idea that premature reopenings by states had contributed to the recent outbreaks. He stressed that while cases have increased
column2: the death rate has declined.

column1: “This moment in the coronavirus pandemic is different than what we saw two months ago
column2: ” he said. “It’s almost inarguable that more testing is generating more cases. The volume of new cases is a reflection of the great success in expanding testing across the country.”

column1: AD
Health authorities
column2: however
column3: project that those younger people
column4: many of whom show no symptoms
column5: will probably spread infections to the more vulnerable. They warn of a lag time of about three weeks between when people are diagnosed and subsequent hospitalizations and deaths. They also note that while the death count has declined since the first wave of cases
column6: it is slowly inching up as cases increase again.

column1: Trump told rallygoers in Oklahoma on Saturday that he had asked officials to “slow the testing down
column2: please” so the country would record fewer cases. White House officials have insisted that Trump made the comment in jest
column3: but the president said this week that he wasn’t kidding.

column1: Fauci
column2: director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and a member of the White House coronavirus task force
column3: and other public health experts have said increased testing alone does not explain the recent increases.

column1: Pence
column2: when pressed by a reporter
column3: declined to recommend that all Americans wear masks as public health officials advise
column4: instead urging people to listen to their local health officials and pray. Deborah Birx
column5: White House coronavirus response coordinator
column6: urged everyone to wear a mask.

column1: Trump refuses to wear a mask in public
column2: calling it unpresidential
column3: and the question has become increasingly partisan. Biden said this week that he would like mask-wearing to be mandatory.

column1: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) criticized Trump for continuing to seek to kill the Affordable Care Act
column2: even as coronavirus cases rise again
column3: and for failing to model good practices by wearing a mask.

column1: “So when the president of the United States says he doesn’t want to wear a mask and understands the bad example
column2: well
column3: I don’t know if he understands anything
column4: but somebody over there must understand the bad example that is to the country
column5: ” she said."/['Anne Gearan'
column6: 'White House Reporter'
column7: 'Yasmeen Abutaleb'
column8: 'National Reporter Focusing On Health Policy']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/DUFZZWVX3II6VJIQKW7SMSC4SM.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/as-support-for-mask-wearing-grows-so-do-political-risks-for-forgoing-them/2020/06/26/73707528-b7b7-11ea-a8da-693df3d7674a_story.html/As support for mask-wearing grows
column2: so do political risks for forgoing them/"This divergent accessorizing once highlighted yet another partisan divide. For Trump allies
column3: going barefaced is all about individual liberty. For Biden supporters
column4: the mask is a symbol of science and sound policy.

column1: But as infections spike in red states such as Texas
column2: Florida and Arizona
column3: support for masks has grown. In recent days
column4: even some Republicans have urged the public to cover their faces in public
column5: arguing that it’s the best way to slow the virus. This shift in rhetoric highlights the potential risks for the president as he continues to ignore the advice of public health experts
column6: who agree that masks are crucial to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus.

column1: AD
AD
“It does go to character and values
column2: ” Democratic pollster Joel Benenson said. “Biden is known for being decent
column3: for caring about the country
column4: a middle-class guy
column5: working with people on the other side. Trump is the antithesis of that. So the more Trump tries to attack Biden over petty smaller things
column6: the smaller it makes Trump look.”

column1: Polling suggests that the majority of Americans favor facial coverings.
More than 70 percent of Americans believe that people should wear masks most or all of the time in public places
column2: according to a Pew Research survey from mid-June.

column1: A Fox News poll from last week found that 80 percent hold a favorable view of those who wear masks
column2: including 68 percent of Republicans and 61 percent of respondents who strongly approve of Trump.

column1: AD
Some Republican leaders have echoed those favorable views.
AD
“Until we find a vaccine
column2: [masks] are really important
column3: ” Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters in his home state of Kentucky on Friday. “This is not as complicated as a ventilator. This is a way to indicate that you want to protect others. We all need during this period
column4: until we find a vaccine
column5: to think of us as protecting not only ourselves but others.”

column1: Rep. Liz Cheney (R-Wyo.)
column2: the third-highest-ranking House Republican
column3: endorsed facial coverings Friday with a photo of her father in a cowboy hat and blue disposable mask.

column1: The caption read: “Dick Cheney says WEAR A MASK. #realmenwearmasks.”
AD
Also Friday
column2: former Trump defense secretary Jim Mattis
column3: who has been publicly critical of the president since leaving the job in 2018
column4: starred in a public service announcement in his hometown of Richland
column5: Wash.
column6: urging people to wear masks.

column1: AD
“Hello
column2: neighbors. I’m Jim Mattis
column3: ” he says in a video posted to the town’s YouTube page. “I’m here to talk about that nasty little virus
column4: covid. . . . It’s clear this little bugger isn’t going away on its own.”

column1: “Wear those face coverings
column2: ” Mattis said
column3: “and let’s work together on this to beat covid.”

column1: Many local Republican leaders have echoed that message as infections spike in red states. “Protect yourself. Protect others. Help contain the spread of Covid-19. Wear a mask
column2: ” Arizona Gov. Doug Ducey (R) wrote in a social media post.

column1: AD
“Everyone should just wear a . . . mask
column2: ” Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) said. The Sunshine State had nearly 9
column3: 000 new infections Thursday
column4: a record.

column1: Even so
column2: Trump and his allies have steadfastly refused to wear face coverings
column3: even as the president has ramped up his travel schedule in the past few weeks.

column1: AD
At the Friday press briefing of the White House coronavirus task force
column2: the first in two months
column3: Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar
column4: White House coronavirus response coordinator Deborah Birx
column5: and Anthony S. Fauci
column6: the nation’s leading infectious-disease doctor
column7: all wore masks.

column1: Pence did not.
When asked whether he had a message to the nation about “the importance of wearing masks
column2: ” Pence said only that people should listen to the guidance from their state or local officials.

column1: AD
Analysts say Trump’s position is designed to appeal to his core voters. “Trump’s gut instinct is to play to his base
column2: ” Republican pollster Ed Goeas said.

column1: But Goeas said the strategy is misguided. Trump’s resistance to mask-wearing focuses the conversation on his polarizing persona
column2: Goeas said
column3: rather than on policy issues where the president can find broader support.

column1: AD
But Trump has suggested that he sees wearing one as a critique of his leadership
column2: telling the Wall Street Journal that “it could be” that people put them on to make a political statement against him.

column1: In the same interview
column2: Trump said that wearing a mask can have negative effects. “They drop it on the desk and then they touch their eye and they touch their nose
column3: ” Trump said. “I think a mask is a — it’s a double-edged sword.”

column1: AD
A spokesman for Trump’s campaign didn’t respond to a request for comment.
Trump and his allies have turned to social media to mock Biden for covering his face
column2: retweeting a message from Fox News’s Brit Hume
column3: who posted a photo with Biden wearing a mask and adding the caption: “This might explain why Trump doesn’t wear a mask. Biden today.”

column1: But Democrats see Biden’s face covering as an advantage.
AD
“Biden wants to lead by example
column2: ” said Donna Brazile
column3: a longtime Democratic strategist who briefly led the Democratic National Committee.

column1: “He is sending the right signal to the public
column2: ” said Rep. Jamie B. Raskin (D-Md.)
column3: who participated in a raucous hearing Friday where some Republicans refused to cover their faces.

column1: AD
“This is all we’ve got” to contain the virus
column2: he added.

column1: The partisan fight over mask-wearing spilled over onto Capitol Hill on Friday
column2: during a hearing of the Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus Crisis
column3: because Democrats wore masks and some Republicans did not.

column1: At one point
column2: Raskin accused Republican members who were maskless of provoking “terror and fear in your colleagues and perhaps your staff.”

column1: Raskin criticized Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio) in particular
column2: who is known for going jacketless
column3: saying that going without a jacket is “a fashion statement
column4: ” but not wearing a mask is a “public health menace.”

column1: AD
Republicans
column2: several of whom had worn masks into the hearing room before taking them off
column3: contended that they could practice social distancing safely while seated maskless at the dais.

column1: AD
“We are six feet apart. We don’t need a mask
column2: ” said Rep. Mark Green (R-Tenn.)
column3: a physician.

column1: House Majority Whip James E. Clyburn (D-S.C.) threatened to end the practice of holding in-person hearings — something Republicans have demanded — if they don’t wear masks.
“I will stay in the safety of my home as I would ask all you to do
column2: ” Clyburn said."/['Annie Linskey'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/after-announcing-modest-police-reforms-trump-pivots-quickly-to-a-law-and-order-message-in-appeal-to-his-base/2020/06/26/622c6688-b7b6-11ea-a8da-693df3d7674a_story.html/After announcing modest police reforms
column2: Trump pivots quickly to a law-and-order message in appeal to his base/"Since signing an executive action on police changes on June 16 in the Rose Garden
column3: Trump has shifted almost exclusively to “law-and-order” rhetoric — while dropping almost any pretense of personally addressing the widespread public anger over police brutality that has sparked nationwide demonstrations.

column1: The president’s posture comes as he has sought to energize his conservative political base in response to polls that show diminishing public approval over his handling of both the racial justice protests and the coronavirus pandemic. After framing his police executive action as an effort to balance the interests of victims’ families and police officers
column2: Trump has sided squarely with the law enforcement community
column3: reinforcing widespread skepticism about his commitment to addressing complaints of racial bias and systemic abuses in police departments that have harmed African Americans.

column1: AD
AD
“There are certain things I’ve accepted about Donald Trump
column2: ” said Lee Merritt
column3: the attorney for more than half a dozen black families that met with the president at the White House ahead of his Rose Garden announcement. “Part of it is that he is always going to favor his base
column4: which is law enforcement and law enforcement-aligned individuals.”

column1: Amid the nationwide debate that erupted after George Floyd’s death in police custody in Minneapolis last month
column2: Merritt added
column3: Trump “needed to be involved in that conversation
column4: but it goes contrary to everything he’s said before with regard to policing.”

column1: White House aides insisted that Trump has not given up on the executive actions he outlined to establish federal certification standards on police training
column2: create a national database to track police abuse cases and pair law enforcement agencies with social workers when responding in communities.

column1: AD
AD
The administration has been coordinating with Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.)
column2: who is leading the Senate GOP’s legislative proposals
column3: although that effort has clashed with a competing package from House Democrats that includes more expansive police changes.

column1: Ja’Ron Smith
column2: a White House domestic policy aide
column3: said on Fox Business this week that Trump was right to threaten protesters who have torn down monuments because “we’ve got to have a civil conversation and a civil society and a nation of laws. . . . This right here is lawlessness and anarchy
column4: and it doesn’t represent the people in the community.”

column1: Smith
column2: who helped develop Trump’s executive actions along with senior adviser Jared Kushner
column3: the president’s son-in-law
column4: said that the administration “will do all we can do administratively
column5: ” including using convening power to “bring both sides together.”

column1: AD
AD
Trump aides said the president has expressed support for peaceful protesters and empathy for Floyd on multiple occasions
column2: but the most recent example in a list provided by the White House was June 5.

column1: Over the past 11 days
column2: Trump has lashed out against demonstrators repeatedly
column3: and he changed a photo on his Twitter profile to one of him posing with 33 uniformed police officers in front of Air Force One.

column1: Ahead of a campaign rally in Tulsa last weekend
column2: he suggested in a tweet that “Any protesters
column3: anarchists
column4: agitators
column5: looters or lowlifes” would be treated more strictly in the Republican-led city than in New York
column6: Seattle or Minneapolis
column7: jurisdictions run by Democrats.

column1: AD
He slammed New York Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to have artists paint “Black Lives Matter” in front of Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan
column2: saying New York police “are furious.”

column1: AD
And after police thwarted an attempt to topple the statue of Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Square next to the White House last Monday
column2: Trump declared that “numerous people are in jail and going to jail today.” He also said he had authorized 10-year prison terms for “these vandals and these hoodlums and these anarchists and these agitators.”

column1: Yet in his eagerness to project toughness
column2: Trump exaggerated the state of affairs. In fact
column3: authorities made a combined four arrests that day — none in direct connection with damaging the Jackson statue.

column1: AD

D.C. police arrested two men accused of spraying officers with a fire extinguisher. And U.S. Park Police arrested two others who allegedly punched officers during skirmishes as the federal officers sought to clear the area of protesters. But the U.S. attorney’s office in the District
column2: led by a Trump appointee
column3: did not pursue criminal charges against the latter two men.

column1: AD
“The last time I checked
column2: the executive branch doesn’t make law
column3: ” said attorney Paul L. Goldstone
column4: who represents them. “President Trump can tweet all he wants about ‘lock them up
column5: ’ but the reality is he doesn’t make the criminal code. Someone needs to teach him a constitutional lesson.”

column1: In a town hall-style event with Fox News host Sean Hannity on Thursday
column2: Trump asserted that federal authorities had made hundreds of arrests since the protests began. In fact
column3: authorities have charged about 125 people with federal crimes
column4: according to a Justice Department tally released Friday afternoon.

column1: AD
Trump cited a recent spate of community violence in Chicago and told Hannity that city is more dangerous than Afghanistan. He said living in Baltimore; Oakland
column2: Calif.; and Detroit is “like living in hell.”

column1: And he touted the “stop-and-frisk” policing policies established two decades ago in New York City by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani
column2: now Trump’s personal lawyer. Liberals denounced those policies
column3: which were ended in 2014
column4: as unfairly targeting black residents
column5: and Mike Bloomberg
column6: who succeeded Giuliani
column7: apologized during his unsuccessful bid for the Democratic presidential nomination this year for having expanded the program.

column1: AD
“President Trump will always stand for law and order — which is the only way to ensure peace on our streets
column2: ” White House spokeswoman Sarah Matthews said in a statement. She accused Democrats of “calling for defunding our brave police officers
column3: caving to mob rule
column4: and promoting cancel culture which seeks to erase our history. The president speaks for Americans who want safety and security to prevail.”

column1: AD
Larry Cosme
column2: president of the Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association
column3: said he believes Trump has tried to strike a balance on police reform. Cosme was among a handful of law enforcement officials who stood next to Trump in the Rose Garden when he signed the executive order in mid-June. The officials also attended the private meeting that day between the president and the black families represented by Merritt.

column1: “I was like
column2: ‘Wow
column3: I saw a different side of the president
column4: ’” Cosme said. “He was sympathetic to these folks. He listened.”

column1: AD
Cosme said his organization
column2: which is nonpolitical
column3: supports peaceful protests
column4: “but you have to follow the law.” However
column5: the scenes of violence have frightened law-abiding demonstrators
column6: he added.

column1: AD
“Overall
column2: the message that all politicians should be putting out is the safety for the American public number one
column3: along with being sympathetic to folks who feel victimized
column4: ” Cosme said.

column1: Merritt confirmed Trump appeared sympathetic in private
column2: and he said the president instructed Attorney General William P. Barr to determine if federal intervention was necessary in their cases. Merritt said he maintains hope that Trump will ultimately support broader legislative reforms
column3: citing his efforts to help push a criminal justice reform bill through Congress in 2018.

column1: “That’s a possibility
column2: although it’s unlikely
column3: ” Merritt said. If not
column4: Trump and his aides “would then be exposed for being hypocritical and being liars and taking advantage of those most affected by police brutality by taking a meeting just to say he met with them. That would be more politically dangerous than he knows.”

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/arab-governments-denounce-israels-plans-to-annex-the-west-bank-warning-it-will-imperil-regional-security-and-peace-building-but-will-israel-listen/2020/06/26/35500c32-b71b-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Arab governments denounce Israel’s plans to annex the West Bank
column2: warning it will imperil regional security and peace building. But will Israel listen?/"The United Arab Emirates said annexation would imperil Israel’s chances of building stronger ties to Persian Gulf nations. The headline of an opinion piece published in an Israeli newspaper by Yousef al-Otaiba
column3: the UAE’s ambassador to the United States
column4: read: “It’s Either Annexation or Normalization.”

column1: AD
AD
To many Palestinians
column2: the pushback coming from Arab countries is welcome
column3: especially to those who have detected a degree of fatigue and silence from their neighbors in recent years as countries have focused less on the conflict and more on quietly improving ties with Israel.

column1: “I’m definitely pleased they are saying something
column2: because there have been years when they said nothing
column3: ” said Diana Buttu
column4: an activist and former negotiator for the Palestine Liberation Organization now living in Haifa.

column1: But it remains to be seen whether Arab leaders will go beyond mere statements of solidarity for Palestinians and take concrete measures in the event of annexation
column2: Palestinians and regional analysts say. Pressure from the streets to do so could be limited
column3: as Arabs across the region are distracted by the coronavirus pandemic
column4: economic instability
column5: civil wars and other woes.

column1: AD
AD
Additionally
column2: the gradual warming of relations between the Jewish state and its neighbors is based on common goals — containing Iranian expansionism
column3: countering extremist movements — that will probably remain priorities regardless of Israel’s actions in the West Bank.

column1: “I have no faith in the statements they are making
column2: ” added Buttu
column3: referring to Arab leaders. “The rapprochement is on the level of governments where their interests are the same.”

column1: The West Bank
column2: which the Jewish state has occupied since the 1967 Middle East war
column3: is home to as many as 3 million Palestinians and roughly 430
column4: 000 Israeli Jews living in scores of settlements. The United Nations and most European countries consider the settlements illegal
column5: but Israel and the Trump administration dispute this.

column1: AD
AD
It’s unclear how much land would be annexed
column2: should it happen. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed last year to annex the Jordan Valley
column3: a swath along the West Bank’s boundary with Jordan
column4: as well as areas containing Israeli settlements. This year
column5: Netanyahu said as much as 30 percent could be annexed.

column1: But Israeli media reports have suggested that any takeover could be 5 percent or less of the land
column2: depending on what’s approved by the United States. Annexation is linked to a plan by the Trump administration for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict — and the Arab condemnations have raised concerns about alienating key U.S. allies in the region.

column1: Such denunciations didn’t occur after other steps recently taken to benefit Israel to Arabs’ detriment. When the United States last year recognized Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights
column2: territory seized from Syria in 1967
column3: Arab leaders were critical but took no concrete measures. That was also the case when the Trump Administration relocated the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem
column4: after recognizing it as Israel’s capital.

column1: AD
AD
“Israel enjoys a less hostile Arab world
column2: a friendlier Arab world and an Arab world that seeks Israel’s help with broader geostrategic interests in the region
column3: ” said Amaney Jamal
column4: a Princeton professor and co-founder of the Arab Barometer
column5: which gauges public opinion in the Middle East. “So why is Israel not saying
column6: ‘Let us maintain this new era of ties
column7: friendships and alliances and resolve the Palestinian issue’? It’s in Israel’s strategic interest
column8: but Israel is calculating that it doesn’t need to.”

column1: So far
column2: Jordan has been the most outspoken in its opposition to the annexation plans. With its close ties to the United States and Israel
column3: it’s also the most influential Arab country in changing Israel’s mind
column4: analysts say.

column1: AD
AD
Netanyahu and his loyalists have argued that the response by Arab governments to annexation is likely to be muted because of the interests they share with Israel in security
column2: trade
column3: technology and opposition to Iran.

column1: But Otaiba
column2: the ambassador
column3: said in his opinion piece that “annexation will certainly and immediately upend Israeli aspirations for improved security
column4: economic and cultural ties with the Arab world and with [the United Arab Emirates].”

column1: He added that annexation would “harden Arab views of Israel.” That
column2: analysts said
column3: could trigger populist anger at Arab leaders’ growing rapprochement with Israel.

column1: “If the Palestinians themselves eventually begin to organize
column2: they are likely to draw lots of support from younger Arabs in other countries
column3: who might well challenge their governments’ ties with Israel
column4: ” said Michelle Dunne
column5: head of the Middle East program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace
column6: in an email.

column1: AD
AD
Arab leaders
column2: she added
column3: are aware that with Israel’s occupation
column4: “a de facto Israeli annexation of the West Bank” has been ongoing for decades. But hopes for a two-state solution — an independent Palestinian state coexisting with Israel — were always there. Annexation would undermine the legitimacy of the Palestinian leadership and spell the end of a two-state solution
column5: Arab leaders
column6: the U.N. and Western officials say.

column1: “Once it is clear that there is no longer any realistic chance of a viable
column2: sovereign state of Palestine being created
column3: it becomes more difficult for Arab leaders to justify publicly their plans to further develop strategic cooperation with Israel
column4: ” Dunne said.

column1: AD
Many Palestinians
column2: though
column3: remain skeptical about neighboring governments and their intentions.

column1: AD
“I don’t think Israel gives a damn for the Arab position
column2: except Jordan because of the sensitivity of its relations with Israel and the United States
column3: ” said Ghassan Khatib
column4: a former spokesperson for the Palestinian Authority. “So whether the Arabs are divided or united
column5: whether they oppose or not oppose
column6: I don’t believe this is one of the major factors Israel will take into consideration when deciding to annex or not.”

column1: Buttu blames Arab diplomats for framing the steady encroachment of Israel into the West Bank as a threat to improving ties and regional stability rather than a violation of basic human rights.
AD
“That’s misguided
column2: ” Buttu said. “You don’t oppose it just because it could lead to instability and violence. You oppose it because it’s illegal and it’s wrong for the Palestinian people.”

column1: AD
Buttu said Israel’s de facto annexation will continue even if Israel pulls back from formally extending its control over the settlements."/['Sudarsan Raghavan'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/india-china-border-clash-trade-imports/2020/06/26/4eca1f76-b4e2-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/After deadly border clash
column2: India faces uncomfortable truths about its reliance on China/"Now India is facing an uncomfortable truth familiar to governments around the world: It’s difficult to disentangle from China.

column1: In wide-ranging goods such as cars
column2: cellphones and medicine
column3: Chinese components are a crucial part of Indian supply chains. Even bulletproof vests used by Indian soldiers are made with material imported from China.

column1: India’s economic relationship with China was in the spotlight even before the June 15 clash high in the Himalayas. The pandemic had already prompted Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to launch a high-profile campaign for “self-reliance” — aatmanirbharta in Hindi — in which he urged Indians to buy local.
AD
AD
Reducing India’s reliance on China won’t be easy. The economic relationship between the two countries
column2: like the military one
column3: is asymmetrical. China is India’s second-largest overall trading partner and its biggest source of imports. India
column4: by contrast
column5: does not figure in China’s top 15 trading partners and is even lower on the list of sources of imports.

column1: An economic boycott by India of Chinese products would not even “amount to a decent slap
column2: ” said Manoj Joshi
column3: a fellow at the Observer Research Foundation in Delhi who has researched China’s global trade ties.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the situation at the disputed border between the two countries remains precarious
column3: with troop buildups on both sides. Talks to ease the tensions are underway at the military and diplomatic levels; earlier this week
column4: the Indian army said there was a “mutual consensus to disengage” from “all friction areas.” China said the two sides had agreed to “lower the temperature.”

column1: But neither country provided any details and they continued to condemn each other for instigating the violence. Some analysis of satellite imagery suggests that China has not retreated from its positions near where the deadly clash took place in the Galwan valley
column2: but rather fortified them. (China has said that there were “casualties” in the conflict but has not confirmed how many of its soldiers were injured or killed.)

column1: Experts say the clash — the most serious between the two countries in more than 50 years — marks a turning point. “There’s no trust right now
column2: ” said Tanvi Madan
column3: the director of the India Project at the Brookings Institution. “Nobody is going to buy this idea anymore that greater economic engagement is going to alleviate political strains” between the two countries.

column1: AD
AD
Even as India faces a grim economic outlook
column2: Modi has elaborated on his goal of self-reliance. “India will reduce its dependence on imports
column3: ” he said three days after the clash with China. Self-reliance also means that “we become [the] biggest exporters of the commodities that we now import
column4: ” Modi said.

column1: Now there are signals that India is preparing to make it harder for Chinese firms to do business in the country. In recent days
column2: e-commerce platforms have been told to label their products with the country of origin
column3: Bloomberg News reported this week; a government procurement site has told sellers to do the same thing. Both steps are viewed as attempts to reduce imports of Chinese goods.

column1: In April
column2: the Indian government announced that it would review all foreign direct investments by Chinese companies rather than allow them to proceed through an automatic route.

column1: AD
AD
One important test of India’s shifting stance will come in the telecom industry. Nearly 40 percent of India’s electronic-equipment imports come from China
column2: while Chinese brands dominate the smartphone arena
column3: capturing 72 percent of the market last year. India is among those countries mulling whether to allow China’s Huawei Technologies to build its next-generation 5G mobile networks
column4: something that now looks highly unlikely.

column1: Another striking example of China’s role in Indian supply chains came in the days after the Galwan clash. S.C. Kansal
column2: managing director of SMPP
column3: a firm that was awarded a major contract to make more than 100
column4: 000 bulletproof jackets for the Indian army in 2018
column5: told the Indian Express newspaper that the company was reliant on imports of materials from China to make its products.

column1: The company “will move with the mood of the country
column2: ” Kansal added. “If required
column3: we will look at alternative routes.” Kansal declined to respond to further questions.

column1: Mohinder Kumar Gupta is the managing director of Star Wire
column2: an Indian firm that makes bulletproof vests for Indian paramilitary and police forces. His company
column3: too
column4: sources a raw material for its products — high performance polyethylene — from China. A similar input is available from Europe or the United States
column5: albeit at a higher price.

column1: AD
AD
His company uses Chinese suppliers “only for economic reasons
column2: ” Gupta said. If the government tells the firm to do otherwise
column3: it will shift its approach. “We’re all very keen” to do so
column4: he said.

column1: India’s pharmaceutical sector
column2: a major player in the global generic drug industry
column3: is also deeply dependent on China. About 70 percent of the active ingredients used by drugmakers comes from China
column4: according to Ashok Kumar Madan
column5: executive director of the Indian Drug Manufacturers’ Association. Long before the conflict
column6: India was looking to decrease that reliance
column7: but there is no easy or quick route to achieve that goal.

column1: To make the active ingredients
column2: you need the starting materials
column3: Madan said. And “that is an arena where
column4: again
column5: you have to look to China.”

column1: AD
For some trade experts
column2: India’s heightened attention to its dependence on China is overdue. Biswajit Dhar
column3: a former Indian trade negotiator
column4: said that even as the economic relationship between the two countries has expanded over the past decade
column5: he sees a troubling trend.

column1: AD
The economic exchanges between India and China remind him of colonial-era patterns of trade
column2: Dhar said
column3: where India largely exported raw materials while importing higher-value intermediate and final products. “If you consider the division of labor
column4: then China is certainly on the winning side
column5: ” he said.

column1: Especially in two key areas — telecoms and pharmaceuticals — the government “must put in place a medium-term strategy to get out of this kind of dependence” on China
column2: Dhar said. It is “absolutely imperative.”

column1: AD"/['Joanna Slater'
column2: 'Foreign Correspondent Covering South Asia']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/UOUN6SVXXAI6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/06/27/how-worlds-beaches-are-readying-summer-social-distancing//How the world’s beaches are readying for a summer of social distancing/"But while the novel coronavirus may dislike direct sun and open air
column2: it loves a crowd and shared spaces. That’s why officials in southern England were so shocked last week by what they classed as a “major incident” amid a heat wave: thousands of people packing beaches
column3: all in violation of social distancing measures. In Brazil
column4: beachgoers have similarly flocked to sandy shores while flouting face mask recommendations.

column1: From “beach bubbles” to drones to sensors and cellphone tracking
column2: here’s how some countries are readying their beaches for a summer of social distancing.

column1: Greece
Greece’s picturesque sandy seasides have long been an alluring summer destination. But this year
column2: the Mediterranean country has a new attraction: a low coronavirus count and
column3: as a of mid-June
column4: borders open to some foreign tourists.

column1: AD
AD
Greece also wants to keep it that way
column2: despite the risk of a resurgence posed by letting in travelers. So the government has devised a plan for mandating disinfectants and maintaining physical distances since it began to reopen beaches in mid-May
column3: with updates since. Under current regulations
column4: only up to 40 people will be permitted per every 1
column5: 000 square meters of beach
column6: or about a quarter acre. A maximum of two chairs can be under each umbrella
column7: which must be placed at least 13 feet from another. (An exemption is made for families
column8: who are allowed to be in proximity to one other as a group.)

column1: Beachgoers are supposed to place a towel on their chair
column2: which staff are required to sanitize after every use. To further discourage crowds
column3: beach-based restaurants were initially allowed to serve only takeaway meals
column4: and no alcohol
column5: to people waiting at least five feet apart while in line.

column1: Beachgoers who violate these rules can face a fine from the police of up to $1
column3: according to the BBC.

column1: Belgium
Cellphone tracking and sensors will be deployed to keep Belgium’s seaside resorts and beaches less crowded this summer
column2: Reuters reported.

column1: AD
AD
Beaches are allowed to open as of Saturday
column2: and the government has devised a tracking system aimed at rerouting residents and tourists to less-populated areas. Using cellphone data and 130 sensors stationed around towns
column3: authorities will be updating a public website sharing in real-time that areas are more or less crowded. Dark green will indicate an area is calm
column4: while orange will denote high density
column5: according to the Reuters news agency.

column1: Some local governments have devised their own designs. In the town of Knokke-Heist
column2: tourism council member Anthony Wittesaele came up with “beach bubbles” — or markings in the sand to indicate 32-square-foot boxes
column3: or about the size of a medium-size carpet.

column1: “We have implemented what we call ‘beach bubbles
column2: ’ where one family or friends can be together in a safe way and to visualize the distance that they should be from one another
column3: ” he told Reuters.

column1: Dubai
The financial center of the United Arab Emirates is beginning to reopen
column2: months after its upscale malls and lavish hotels shut down. During scorching summer days
column3: much of life in the Emirates happens in the air-conditioned indoors
column4: which now poses a problem for coronavirus infection-control.

column1: AD
AD
But in public
column2: the politically restrictive city-state is trying to enforce its new beach protocol. Dubai has made mask-wearing at the beach mandatory and banned groups of more than five. Masks while in the water
column3: though
column4: are not required. (Masks in general are required in public
column5: except in some instances like strenuous exercise.)

column1: Between May 29
column2: when beaches reopened
column3: and June 7 the government reported that 316 people were penalized for violating the rules
column4: according to the Abu Dhabi-based the National newspaper. On just one Friday in early June
column5: police cited 221 offenders. The fine for violating face mask-wearing and social-distancing rules is more than $800.

column1: Police told the National they have also made use of drones to zone in on rule breakers.
Thailand
Thailand still remains closed to international travelers
column2: so its beloved beaches have fewer crowds and possible pitfalls to worry about.

column1: AD
AD
In the meantime
column2: mask-clad workers at the entrance of beachside venues screen and count everyone entering to keep a low capacity. In the coastal city of Pattaya
column3: beachgoers are required to stay around three feet apart. Residents told the South China Morning Post that they had never seen the water so clean or sand so empty.

column1: Like many Southeast Asian countries
column2: Thailand’s confirmed coronavirus count remains comparatively low to other European or Latin American countries. But it has still taken the virus seriously. Some beaches reopened only on June 1. And after kick-starting local tourism
column3: the government is considering travel corridors with China and Japan
column4: among others
column5: Bloomberg News reported.

column1: Spain
Drones are also buzzing above the carefully monitored beaches of Lloret de Mar
column2: a resort town in northeastern Spain.

column1: AD
AD
Spain is readying for the return of foreign travelers after curbing its initial coronavirus outbreak
column2: which killed more than 28
column3: 300 people. “The way we go to the beach this year has changed but that doesn’t mean we can’t enjoy it
column4: ” urged a promotional video for one resort very popular with British tourists
column5: AFP reported.

column1: At Lloret de Mar
column2: sensors are also in place to alert the municipality when an area’s capacity has been reached. Visitors can then access this information via a designated app
column3: according to AFP.

column1: So far
column2: crowding hasn’t been an issue. But Lloret de Mar is prepared for all kinds of beach conditions. The local government has additionally devised plans for cordoning off sections based on age
column3: such as designating special areas for the elderly
column4: families with children
column5: and groups without kids.

column1: France
In May
column2: France initially reopened its beaches to short-term exercising but banned most other activities. That prompted one resort to experiment with social-distancing compliant sunbathing
column3: The Washington Post reported. The resort town of La Grande Motte near Montpelier roped off 75 squares to keep people separated. The municipality’s website then offered beachgoers the chance to reserve a three-hour spot up to two days in advance. Openings quickly filled up.

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/06/27/this-italian-hilltown-is-covid-free-it-reopens-visitors-will-it-lose-that-status//This Italian hilltown is covid-free. But as it reopens to visitors
column2: will it lose that status?/"SAN FELE
column3: Italy — The mountaintop town is four hours south of Rome
column4: reachable by switchback roads — appropriately remote for an alternate reality. Here
column5: far away from the coronavirus pandemic
column6: in a place where nobody has tested positive or gotten sick
column7: it was lunchtime
column8: and a restaurant in town was filling up: tables of four
column11: and then the biggest table of all
column12: reserved for teachers and middle schoolers celebrating graduation.

column1: The teenagers had taken their final exams online — per national rules — but this was San Fele
column2: so they were able to push through the restaurant doors
column3: laughing
column4: eating in a hurry
column5: trading seats
column6: no masks in sight. The teachers weren’t wearing masks either. Nor the mayor
column7: sitting at another table. Nor the live musicians
column8: who started belting out tunes in the kind of celebration that could only happen in a place where nobody was deemed a threat.

column1: “It’s almost normal
column2: ” said Elisabetta Chieca
column4: a city councilor
column5: sitting at a nearby table where the mayor was fighting to speak over the din.

column1: “All locals here
column2: ” said Donato Sperduto
column3: the mayor. “Everybody knows everybody.”

column1: With some combination of geographic isolation
column2: initial precautions and good fortune
column3: the town of San Fele never even had a coronavirus curve to flatten — and it now has the enviable chance to ride out the pandemic as a New Zealand-like oasis
column4: free from the virus’s dangers and disruptions.

column1: But like other places around the world that have managed to control or prevent outbreaks
column2: from island nations to nursing homes
column3: there is recognition here that coronavirus-free status is a precarious state. At any moment
column4: somebody with the virus could come up the switchback roads.

column1: “Our fear
column2: ” Sperduto said
column3: “is those who come from the outside.”

column1: The first tour bus arrived in San Fele this past week. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)
Emilia Caputi
column3: Maria Crecca
column5: Giovanna Di Gregorio
column7: and Michelina Tronolone
column9: sit in front of their homes. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)

column1: San Fele survives economically by pitching itself as a weekend tourism destination. Before the pandemic
column2: on many summer Sundays
column3: dozens of tour buses from other parts of Italy would pull up
column4: in what amounted to a momentary doubling of the town’s population. Visitors would stroll through the city center. They’d buy ricotta at a local farm. After hikes to see the nearby forest and waterfalls
column5: they’d stop at the very restaurant where the mayor was now talking about how to navigate Italy’s reopening.

column1: “We can’t rest easy
column2: ” he said
column3: as the server brought out pasta topped with truffles
column4: then roast lamb.

column1: So after lunch
column2: the mayor took the three newest arrivals in town — two reporters and a photographer — back into the city center
column3: where the stone streets were too narrow for cars. He led the way around the corner and walked up the steps to the office of one of San Fele’s two doctors.

column1: “Ciao
column2: Michele
column3: ” Sperduto said.

column1: The door opened
column2: and a nurse spread out three coronavirus antibody tests
column3: a batch of which the mayor had ordered for the town at the beginning of Italy’s outbreak.

column1: “As soon as somebody arrives
column2: we’ll try to test them
column3: ” Sperduto said. “Of course
column4: it’s all based on being aware of who visits.”

column1: A nurse
column2: with a prick
column3: drew blood samples from three fingertips. A couple of minutes later
column4: the results were back.

column1: The town was still coronavirus-free.
San Fele's remote hilltop location has been an advantage during the pandemic. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)
With no curve to flatten
column2: locals have been able to return more quickly to a semblance of normal life. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)

column1: From the highest point in San Fele
column2: one can see the signs of decay common in so many Italian hilltop towns — places built for medieval defense
column3: but less practical for the modern world.

column1: The town
column2: over the past century and a half
column3: saw its population get halved and then halved again
column4: to 2
column5: 800. Most of the youth left for college or jobs
column6: returning only as visitors to see their elderly parents.

column1: The town center has become a hollowed husk
column2: 30 percent occupied
column3: beautiful but crumbling. Weeds twist through some of the sidewalks and walls. A couple of front doors are padlocked. Some of the windows are knocked out. One resident
column4: leading a short tour down the street where she lived
column5: pointed to the houses all around her.

column1: “That one is empty
column2: ” Angela Verducci
column4: said. “That one is empty. They’ll be tearing that one down because the roof collapsed.”

column1: Because those who remain in San Fele are largely older — it has an estimated 15 centenarians
column2: and many more in their 90s — officials had worried at the outset of the pandemic that the town might be in for a disaster. While outbreaks raged in Italy’s north
column3: experts warned about what could lie ahead for Italy’s poorer south
column4: given its dearth of hospital intensive care beds and medical resources.

column1: So San Fele took precautions in every way it could. It barred people from entering the pharmacy and instituted home deliveries for prescriptions. It administered coronavirus tests to volunteers
column2: police officers
column3: trash collectors — anybody having contact with others. Meanwhile
column4: a nationwide lockdown halted most movement
column5: and saved the south from a calamity of the scale experienced in the north.

column1: San Fele’s region — Basilicata
column2: the obscure instep of Italy’s boot — has had only 401 coronavirus cases
column3: and only two in the last month.

column1: At least one was a person who entered the region from the outside.
In retrospect
column2: the mayor said
column3: San Fele felt most secure during the lockdown. People were anxious
column4: but almost nobody was arriving in town.

column1: Italy loosened restrictions on inter-regional travel June 3. Now it is opening up to travelers from across Europe. Many of the people who grew up in San Fele and moved away now have the chance
column2: at last
column3: to come back.

column1: And gradually
column2: that is what is happening.

column1: The mayor’s eldest daughter
column3: who lives in the northern city of Turin
column4: recently made plans for a return visit. A man from Milan showed up in town on a recent weekend
column5: wearing an N95 mask
column6: to check in on his mother.

column1: Locals leave afternoon mass at Santa Maria della Quercia. Vincenzo Tauriello
column3: and his brother Vito Tauriello
column5: are among the town's many older residents. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)

column1: LEFT: Locals leave afternoon mass at Santa Maria della Quercia. RIGHT: Vincenzo Tauriello
column3: and his brother Vito Tauriello
column5: are among the town's many older residents. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)

column1: “Most of my family — grandfather
column2: brothers
column3: cousins — all left
column4: ” said Vito Ricigliano
column6: who then mentioned that a cousin who lives in Rome was also returning to San Fele later that day.

column1: “We grew up together
column2: ” he said. “We trust one another. But anything is possible. When I go visit him
column3: I’ll wear a mask.”

column1: Several hours later
column2: Ricigliano was knocking on the door of his cousin
column3: who was still unpacking and cleaning up. The cousin
column4: Michele Maselli
column6: moved away from San Fele at age 14 and said the place was “dying
column7: ” but he came back every summer — for the “tranquility
column8: ” and because it was home.

column1: Maselli mentioned that
column2: when he arrived in town
column3: somebody stopped him and asked why he was wearing a mask.

column1: He was taken aback.
“Out of respect
column2: ” he replied. He didn’t consider himself high-risk — there weren’t many new daily cases in Rome and he and his wife had driven directly to town. Still
column3: it seemed the right thing to do.

column1: “Here
column2: ” Ricigliano said with a laugh
column3: “you are the threat.”

column1: Red Cross volunteers help maintain social distancing within the Santa Maria della Quercia church. Michele Maselli drove back to San Fele from Rome once travel was permitted again. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)

LEFT: Red Cross volunteers help maintain social distancing within the Santa Maria della Quercia church. RIGHT: Michele Maselli drove back to San Fele from Rome once travel was permitted again. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)
The new arrivals had no duty to inform the town they were coming
column2: and so they hadn’t yet been tested. Meanwhile
column3: the town had no chance to test people who were just passing through.

column1: The following day
column2: around 10 a.m.
column3: the first tour bus of the season pulled up to a parking lot at the base of the town. It brought a group of 23 people from across Italy’s south. They had started the morning in Matera
column4: one hour away. They got off the bus here wearing backpacks and sneakers
column5: holding walking sticks. Most had masks.

column1: For the next three hours
column2: they trekked through the town center and into the surrounding forest
column3: on trails crowded with day-trippers. They took photos at the waterfalls. At lunchtime
column4: they made their way to the restaurant.

column1: It was even more packed than it had been a few days earlier. Big families
column2: with children and grandparents
column3: were there for their Sunday meals. One teenager
column4: with balloons at his table
column5: was celebrating a birthday.

column1: A server pushed several tables together. The group of 23 out-of-towners sat down.
San Fele's hiking trails are becoming crowded once more. (Federica Valabrega for The Washington Post)
