column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/europe-prepares-to-reopen-to-foreign-travelers-but-americans-dont-even-figure-into-the-discussion/2020/06/26/6232dff8-b7b2-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Europe prepares to reopen to foreign travelers
column2: but Americans don’t even figure into the discussion/"Europe’s draft in-and-out list reflects its assessment of how well other countries have managed to control their outbreaks. E.U. countries were among the world’s hardest-hit by the pandemic this spring
column3: but most now have the virus under control and have been willing to consider opening their borders to other countries where the novel coronavirus is similarly in check.

column1: China is among the 15 countries set to make the cut
column2: despite E.U. skepticism about how transparent it has been about its outbreak. Visitors from China would be allowed to enter Europe only if Beijing drops measures against E.U. travelers.

column1: AD
AD
Also expected to be approved: Algeria
column2: Australia
column3: Canada
column4: Georgia
column5: Japan
column6: Montenegro
column7: Morocco
column8: New Zealand
column11: South Korea
column13: Tunisia and Uruguay. The list is subject to final approval Saturday
column14: but diplomats said it was unlikely to change. The rest of the world would continue to be kept out for nonessential travel.

column1: The decision underscores the perception here that the United States has failed in its coronavirus response. European leaders and health experts have watched with unease as many American states insist on reopening
column2: even as infections spike in many parts of the country.

column1: E.U. members have seen clusters of infections since they began relaxing their own restrictions. Germany
column2: Spain and Portugal are among those that have reimposed localized lockdowns. But for the bloc as a whole
column3: diagnoses have slowed to 16 cases per 100
column4: 000 people over the past two weeks
column5: the main measure Europe is using to determine whether countries make the cut.

column1: AD
AD
The United States
column2: by contrast
column3: stands at 122 cases per 100
column4: 000 people
column5: and numbers are getting worse. Florida has set records for the past 19 days in a row.

column1: Wary of being pulled into a diplomatic brawl with each country they continue to exclude
column2: European leaders have strained to keep their internal discussions focused narrowly on issues of science and epidemiology.

column1: “The European Union has an internal process to determine from which countries it would be safe to accept travelers
column2: ” Eric Mamer
column3: a spokesman for the European Commission
column4: told reporters Thursday as the discussions were underway. “Our internal process is related
column5: obviously
column6: to considerations based on health criteria.”

column1: AD
But there are clear political pressures.

Continuing the ban on travel from Russia will exacerbate diplomatic tensions with an already volatile neighbor. Extending restrictions on travel from the United States will strain Europe’s most important geopolitical relationship
column2: even if it was President Trump who moved first to block European travelers in March.

column1: AD
Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday acknowledged the desire in Washington to open up the world for travel again.
“We’re all taking seriously the need to figure out how to get this open. We need to get our global economy back going again
column2: ” he said in an online discussion hosted by the German Marshall Fund of the United States. “We’ll work closely with our European friends
column3: broadly
column4: because I know there’s different views
column5: again
column6: inside the European Union.” He cited “a dozen or more” countries that were interested in opening up to Americans
column7: without naming any of them.

column1: AD
The E.U. list is a recommendation
column2: not a requirement
column3: because each E.U. nation retains sovereign control over its borders. But E.U. members have strong incentives to go along with the decision
column4: since
column5: if they do not
column6: the gradual process of restoring border-free travel within Europe could be placed on hold or reversed
column7: diplomats said. The E.U. plans to review its list of acceptable countries every two weeks.

column1: AD
European diplomats
column2: gathering in person in a Brussels conference room
column3: negotiated for hours in multiple meetings in recent days. The blandly technocratic discussions masked the human drama caused by the travel disruptions. Couples have been stuck on opposite sides of the Atlantic for months. Business negotiations are on hold. Long-dreamed-of vacations have been delayed. Europe’s airports
column4: once bustling connectors for the world
column5: have been eerily quiet. In Brussels
column6: the airport usually has 300 flights a day. It expected 435 for all of next week
column7: according to a spokeswoman.

column1: People fell into two camps during the discussions
column2: according to diplomats who spoke on the condition of anonymity to talk about the closed-door negotiations. Those from poorer
column3: tourist-dependent southern European nations — led by Greece and Portugal — favored approving more countries
column4: hoping to salvage at least a scrap of their fast-dwindling summer season. Other E.U. nations
column5: especially in the richer north
column6: wanted to proceed more cautiously.

column1: AD
The talks were further complicated by the fact that European caseloads vary widely. Sweden
column2: the worst-off in Europe
column3: reported 155 cases per 100
column4: 000 residents over the past two weeks. Portugal
column5: the second-worst
column6: stood at 44. Britain
column7: which is no longer a member of the E.U. but until the end of the year is subject to many E.U. decisions
column8: was third at 24.

column1: AD
The diplomats debated which outside countries’ public health numbers they could trust. There was extensive back-and-forth about China
column2: which has been reporting lower infection rates than the E.U. and which has imposed travel restrictions on some E.U. countries but not others.

column1: The E.U. plans to consult with its delegations on the ground to decide how much stock to put in each country’s official figures.
AD
Negotiators also had to make judgment calls about countries that are trending worse
column2: even though their overall infection levels remain relatively decent.

column1: Much of the talks focused on where
column2: precisely
column3: to draw the line for the list. Turkey
column4: Canada and Egypt all had backers and detractors
column5: the diplomats said
column6: since they have slightly worse infection rates than the E.U. Ukraine was on the list
column7: then dropped off. Tiny Georgia
column8: a country of 3.7 million people

column1: AD"/['Michael Birnbaum'
column2: 'Brussels Bureau Chief Covering Europe'
column3: 'Quentin Ariès']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/3PRMNBFX3YI6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/omar-garcia-harfuch-mexico-city-attack/2020/06/26/de2e8900-b7bb-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Mexico City’s top security official injured in apparent assassination attempt/"Violence has continued to rise across Mexico
column2: even during the coronavirus pandemic. Mexico City’s wealthier enclaves have typically been spared
column3: though
column4: making Friday’s attack particularly startling for residents here. Photos of García Harfuch’s Chevrolet Suburban show the vehicle ripped apart by bullets.

column1: AD
AD
Several hours after the attack
column2: García Harfuch wrote on Twitter that one of Mexico’s largest drug cartels
column3: the Jalisco New Generation Cartel
column4: known by its Spanish acronym
column5: CJNG
column6: was responsible for the attack.

column1: “This morning we were cowardly attacked by the CJNG
column2: two colleagues and friends of mine lost their life
column3: I have three bullet wounds and several shards
column4: ” he wrote. “Our Nation must continue to confront the cowardly organized crime. We will continue working.”

column1: The Jalisco cartel has risen to prominence since splitting off from the Sinaloa Cartel around 2010. It has gained territorial control over much of Mexico and has violently clashed with other cartels during that expansion. But it has seldom attempted to assassinate high-level Mexican officials.
AD
The United States has actively targeted members of the cartel
column2: arresting hundreds of people associated with the group and extraditing others.

column1: AD
At 38
column2: García Harfuch is among the youngest people ever to ascend to the top of Mexico City’s security apparatus. Many see him as a promising leader
column3: willing to take on the country’s growing problem of narco-violence.

column1: On Friday afternoon
column2: the Mexico City attorney general’s office interrogated suspects. In a statement
column3: Attorney General Ernestina Godoy Ramos said detainees admitted that a total of 28 gunmen were recruited about three weeks ago and were promised cash in exchange for their participation.

column1: After the attack
column2: Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador suggested that it was García Harfuch’s willingness to take on organized crime that made him a target.

column1: AD
“It has to do
column2: without a doubt
column3: with the work that is being carried out to guarantee peace and tranquility both in Mexico City and in the country
column4: ” López Obrador said at a morning news conference.

column1: Earlier this week
column2: six police officers were ambushed and killed in the state of Guerrero. Last weekend
column3: 12 people were killed in the state of Sonora during what officials described as a clash between two rival criminal groups.

column1: AD"/['Kevin Sieff'
column2: 'Latin America Correspondent']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/OMCLOPFXXYI6VLFF5O3D2J7B74.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/coronavirus-germany-meatpacking-tonnies/2020/06/26/9287e336-b58e-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Coronavirus outbreak at a meatpacking plant exposes weakness in Germany’s covid-19 response/"“Once they arrive
column2: ” he continued
column3: “they have a job through the subcontractor and then work for Tönnies or another company.”

column1: Tönnies
column2: whose hulking factory sits just a few miles down the road
column3: is Europe’s largest slaughterhouse — and the site of a coronavirus outbreak that triggered Germany’s first snapback in restrictions. More than 1
column4: 500 workers have tested positive
column5: contributing to a sharp rise in the country’s overall virus reproduction rate and forcing more than half a million people into a semi-lockdown.

column1: AD
AD
The meat-processing industry has emerged as the Achilles’ heel of Germany’s otherwise widely praised coronavirus response.
Processing plants are thought to be especially conducive to viral spread
column2: with their cold temperatures
column3: limited ventilation and people close together shouting to one another over all the noise. Abattoirs from the United States to the Netherlands have been forced to close their doors because of coronavirus outbreaks.

column1: In Germany
column2: the eight outbreaks linked to the meat industry have also focused scrutiny on murky hiring practices and substandard living conditions for laborers — largely from Romania
column3: Bulgaria and Poland — who do the grueling work of slaughtering pigs for minimum wage. Even during the peak of the epidemic on the continent
column4: when travel between countries was banned
column5: exceptions were made so that workers could cross borders and ensure that Western Europe could continue to eat.

column1: Now
column2: for many Gütersloh residents who have seen their schools
column3: gyms
column4: pools and bars closed once again
column5: ire is directed both at Tönnies and government officials
column6: who they complain have long failed to act on calls to clean up working practices.

column1: AD
AD
“There is a lot of anger and disappointment
column2: ” said Daniela Brey
column4: who was waiting in a snaking four-hour line for a voluntary coronavirus test
column5: with her 6-year-old son and 4-year-old daughter in tow.

column1: “Tönnies is just a symptom of the problem
column2: ” she said. “The government has to do something.”

column1: Even before the Tönnies outbreak
column2: Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government had hastily drafted new regulations to stop the use of subcontractors at Germany’s meat firms. The practice hampers the simplest question for coronavirus contact tracing: Who works there?

column1: Legislation must still be approved by parliament
column2: and the meat lobby is pushing back
column3: calling the move “arbitrary discrimination” and saying it is not a means for guaranteeing worker protection.

column1: If the legislation does come into force
column2: it wouldn’t be until next year at the earliest — meaning that Germany will continue to face a threat of outbreaks that are difficult to trace.

column1: AD
AD
Inge Bultschnieder
column2: a local bakery owner
column3: said she’d been warning about the coronavirus risk at Tönnies for months
column4: as workers were ferried around with little regard for social distancing. “The town was worried
column5: ” she said.

column1: Bultschnieder organized her first demonstration against Tönnies in 2013
column2: after a hospital stay when she befriended a Bulgarian Tönnies worker in the next bed.

column1: But in this part of Germany
column2: meat is money. Atop the slaughterhouse
column3: a towering Tönnies sign — featuring a smiling pig
column4: cow and steer
column5: tails intertwined to form a heart — is a sky-high reminder of the source of much of the wealth here.

column1: The slaughterhouse sits on the outskirts of Rheda-Wiedenbrück
column2: a postcard-perfect town a few miles from Gütersloh
column3: the district’s main hub. At the site of the plant is Tönnies Arena: a 4
column4: 000-seat stadium used for local soccer matches. Clemens Tönnies
column5: a self-made billionaire who runs the meatpacking firm
column6: also owns Schalke
column7: a Bundesliga soccer team.

column1: AD
AD
His company is a giant in the European meat industry
column2: with an annual turnover of more than 7 billion euros (about $8 billion). It slaughters more than 20.8 million pigs a year
column3: according to industry publications.

column1: Now
column2: with the factory closed and more than 7
column3: 000 workers in quarantine
column4: scores of distribution trucks sit idle
column5: and European farmers are scrambling to find other places to slaughter their fattened livestock.

column1: Clemens Tönnies has called it an “existential crisis” for the firm he co-founded with his brother nearly 50 years ago. Initially
column2: the company suggested the outbreak might be attributed to cross-border travel by workers. But Clemens Tönnies apologized and said he was “fully responsible.” He has resisted calls to resign.

column1: AD
Last year
column2: he was forced to temporarily step down from his position as president of the Schalke soccer club after comments roundly condemned as racist. Rather than fighting climate change with tax increases
column3: he said
column4: governments should fund power plants in Africa. “Then the Africans would stop cutting down trees
column5: and they would stop making babies when it gets dark
column6: ” he said.

column1: AD
German authorities have said his company might be liable for damages related to the coronavirus outbreak.
Experts say the system of subcontracts is designed to avoid accountability
column2: with subcompanies that continuously change their names responsible for worker safety
column3: rather than the firms themselves.

column1: AD
While Tönnies the company is highly visible
column2: its workers are less so.

column1: “They are in their own microcosm
column2: ” said Claus Freitag
column4: who runs an electronics store in ­Rheda-Wiedenbrück
column5: not far from the town’s moated castle. “They stick together. They live in the more remote places. They jump in these minibuses in the morning.”

column1: The Tönnies company is footing the bill for mass testing. But Clemens Tönnies cited data protection as the reason he could not share a worker list with health authorities.
Mobile coronavirus testing teams
column2: wearing white protective overalls
column3: have been left to largely rely on official but inaccurate city lists as they try to figure out who works at the plant and where they live.

column1: AD
AD
“Most of the time
column2: there’s more people or also other people than we have on the lists
column3: ” said Martin Bieker
column4: a volunteer medic with the teams that fan out each morning.

column1: Some of the Tönnies workers live in dilapidated low-rise apartment blocks
column2: in cramped
column3: unsanitary conditions that experts say probably helped the virus spread.

column1: To enforce the quarantine
column2: wire fences have been erected around those apartment buildings and police cars line the streets.

column1: “If I don’t work
column2: who will pay me if I stay two weeks at home?” said a young man at the fence
column3: who spoke on the condition of anonymity out of fear of affecting his employment.

column1: Employers are required to continue to cover wages during quarantine
column2: but the man said he was between jobs.

column1: AD
Tönnies workers are paid minimum wage
column2: about $10 an hour
column3: but they must each pay about $350 a month for a mattress
column4: according to activists and experts.

column1: AD
The pay in Denmark is more than twice as high
column2: said Karin Vladimirov
column3: spokesperson for the meat-processing labor union representing German workers. “Nowhere is slaughtering as cheap as in Germany
column4: ” she said
column5: adding that people often work more hours than they are paid for and lack knowledge of their rights.

column1: So far
column2: health officials say the outbreak in Gütersloh looks to be contained. Only 32 positive cases have been found outside the meat industry. But another outbreak has emerged at a plant in Lower Saxony. And foreign diplomats are concerned that Tönnies workers may have spread their infections farther afield
column3: returning to their home countries in the chaotic period when a quarantine for the plant was being established.

column1: Jakub Wawrzyniak
column2: the Polish consul general in Cologne
column3: spent a day out with mobile testing teams in the hopes of establishing contact with some of the Polish Tönnies workers. At some doors
column4: neighbors said residents had “gone on holiday.”

column1: AD
“I think that means they are at home” back in Central and Eastern Europe
column2: he said. “If we had the data
column3: Polish police or Bulgarian police could go and ask them to quarantine. I’m afraid it’s going to spread out.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Süzan continues to ferry workers to local firms. Each worker he brings across is charged $135 for transportation and $30 for a health certificate. The money is docked from their wages by subcontractors when they arrive
column3: he said. He says that his workers live in good conditions and that companies responsible for the squalid conditions for workers are “black sheep.”

column1: Even though reforms afoot in the industry could cut out subcontractors

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/lebanon-currency-economy-crisis/2020/06/26/9e2c62ea-b712-11ea-9a1d-d3db1cbe07ce_story.html/Lebanon’s currency takes a new dive
column2: and there is no end in sight/"The currency has now lost 78 percent of its value since October
column3: when banks began restricting withdrawals of dollars — the main foreign currency used in Lebanon — then closed their doors for weeks. It was the first sign that they were running out of foreign currency and that the country’s economy was in deep trouble.

column1: AD

Widespread street protests against the corruption and cronyism at the root of the country’s problems compounded the decline and paralyzed the economy for weeks. Then came the seven week-lockdown to contain the coronavirus earlier this year
column2: which added to the pain.

column1: AD
The reopening
column2: now in full swing
column3: has done little to stem what is fast turning into a major economic implosion that risks destabilizing the already volatile region. Intermittent protests against the government for failing to halt the financial free fall have served as a reminder of the potential for greater social unrest.

column1: “The country is not doing well
column2: ” Prime Minister Hassan Diab told a meeting of Lebanon’s top politicians called by President Michel Aoun on Thursday to address the ballooning crisis. But only those who support the government showed up
column3: leaving little hope of a consensus to address the troubles anytime soon.

column1: Bailout talks stalled
The government is seeking a $10 billion bailout from the International Monetary Fund
column2: but talks that began in February have not yet progressed beyond the preliminary stages
column3: according to officials familiar with the proceedings who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue.

column1: Reforms promised by the government
column2: ranging from its unwieldy structures and costly subsidies of essentials such as fuel and wheat
column3: have not materialized because of the lack of political agreement.

column1: AD
AD
Lebanon has pegged the value of its currency to the dollar at the rate of 1
column2: 507 for the past three decades
column3: and the government still officially maintains the level even as the pound collapses and banks halt all dollar withdrawals
column4: except for what are called “fresh” transfers of dollars from overseas.

column1: The banks have set other rates for certain transactions
column2: meaning that Lebanese people now must navigate five different exchange rates
column3: including the black market one
column4: which is considered the most reliable indicator of the currency’s true worth.

column1: In the absence of a clear policy path ahead
column2: there is no bottom to the value of the Lebanese pound
column3: said Nasser Saidi
column4: a former Lebanese finance minister who is now a financial consultant based in Dubai.

column1: AD
Citizens have lost trust in the banking system and the country is shifting to a cash-only economy.
AD
Some retail outlets have started accepting only dollars
column2: which are hard to find. U.S. and European sanctions against neighboring Syria have deprived that country of dollars
column3: too
column4: making Lebanon the chief destination for Syrians seeking to fund imports there
column5: increasing the demand for dollars
column6: Saidi said.

column1: 'Going into the unknown'
Government revenue
column2: meanwhile
column3: has skidded to a halt because of the shutdowns and economic retraction
column4: forcing the Central Bank to print Lebanese pounds to fund government expenditures
column5: including salaries for the bloated civil service.

column1: “Those go into the market and they are chasing fewer and fewer dollars
column2: ” Saidi said. “There is no longer any anchor for the value of the Lebanese pound and we are going into the unknown.”

column1: The impact is palpable on the once-vibrant country.
AD
AD
Businesses are closing by the day
column2: unemployment is rising and prices are soaring. Lebanon depends on imports for more than 80 percent of its consumption
column3: notably food
column4: the cost of which has nearly doubled so far this year
column5: according to government figures
column6: raising the risk of widespread hunger.

column1: People who once lived comfortably are struggling to get by on incomes that have lost as much as 80 percent of their real value
column2: pushing the price of most products
column3: and especially food
column4: beyond their means.

column1: “We are surviving day-to-day because we no longer have enough to cover our needs
column2: ” said Hanan Hani
column4: as she lined up earlier this week to receive food handouts from a local charity.

column1: AD
Her husband’s monthly pension is now worth only a little more than $200 a month
column2: well below the World Bank’s poverty line and not enough to provide for their family of four.

column1: AD
Hani and her husband spent $70
column2: 000 to put their two children through university
column3: but they can’t find work and are living at home."/['Liz Sly'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/renowned-russian-director-convicted-of-embezzlement-in-what-critics-call-a-show-trial/2020/06/26/ee8031d6-b776-11ea-a510-55bf26485c93_story.html/Renowned Russian director convicted of embezzlement in what critics call a show trial/"Supporters who had waited for hours in the heat for the verdict cheered and hugged. “Freedom!” some shouted.
Serebrennikov’s suspended sentence came amid Kremlin sensitivities about an ongoing nationwide vote on constitutional changes that would allow Putin to potentially stay in power until 2036.
AD
A hefty jail term for Serebrennikov could have triggered protests
column2: alienated young voters and distracted from the Kremlin’s efforts to ensure a high voter turnout as part of an effort to lend legitimacy to an extension to Putin’s power. Voting ends Wednesday.

column1: AD
Serebrennikov has often voiced criticism of conservative politicians
column2: the increasingly harsh censorship under Putin and rising authoritarianism. He spoke out for anti-government protests in 2018
column3: has supported LGBTQ rights and criticized the rising influence of the conservative Russian Orthodox Church in political affairs.

column1: Prosecutors at Meshchansky District Court in Moscow had demanded six years in prison for Serebrennikov
column2: five years for producer Alexey Malobrodsky and four years for producer Yuri Itin — all convicted of embezzlement.

column1: AD
Prosecutors also asked for a four-year sentence for art historian and former Culture Ministry employee Sofia Apfelbaum
column2: who was convicted of negligence in handling state funds.

column1: Serebrennikov
column3: is director of Moscow’s Gogol Center and the Seventh Studio theater. Appearing in court
column4: he wore a black mask
column5: dark glasses
column6: a black cap and a gray T-shirt.

column1: AD
He and three other defendants stood trial for the embezzlement of about 133 million rubles (more than $1.8 million) in state funds through the Platforma arts project
column2: which he founded. The four defendants pleaded not guilty
column3: testifying that the funds from the Culture Ministry were used only to stage theatrical productions.

column1: AD
Judge Olesya Mendeleyeva said the Culture Ministry demanded the return of the allegedly embezzled funds.
The judge also fined Serebennikov 800
column2: 000 rubles
column3: or about $11
column4: 5000. Malobrodsky and Itin were ordered to pay smaller fines. The three were barred from administrative positions in state cultural institutions: Serebrennikov and Itin for three years
column5: and Malobrodsky for two.

column1: “The court believes that the defendants can be reformed without being isolated from society
column2: ” the judge said.

column1: AD
Serebrennikov’s lawyer
column2: Dmitry Kharitonov
column3: said he would appeal against the verdict.

column1: Among those who have spoken in Serebrennikov’s defense was one of ballet’s geniuses
column2: Mikhail Baryshnikov
column3: who stated that the director was being persecuted for political reasons.

column1: AD
“An artist of whom Russia should be proud is being debased and humiliated
column2: ” he said in a statement when Serebrennikov was called in for questioning in 2017. He said that because Serebrennikov “is a person who is known for his independence and love of freedom
column3: a person who has more than once made brave political declarations
column4: these sudden repressions look particularly foul.”

column1: Baryshnikov defected to Canada in 1974 and holds dual U.S. and Latvian citizenship.
Many Russian actors
column2: directors and cultural figures have spoken out for Serebrennikov since his arrest. More than 3
column3: 700 Russian cultural figures signed an open letter Monday to Culture Minister Olga Lyubimova
column4: requesting that the ministry withdraw its charges against the defendants in what is known here as the “Seventh Studio case.”

column1: AD
AD
Russian rapper Miron Fyodorov
column2: who goes by Oxxxymiron
column3: posted Thursday to his 2.1 million Instagram followers
column4: apparently in Serebrennikov’s support
column5: a condemnation of “custom-made lawsuits
column6: the purpose of which is to intimidate freethinking and creative people.”

column1: Hundreds of people gathered outside the court behind police barriers before the verdict was handed down Friday morning.
“I came here to demonstrate my support
column2: ” said a protester
column3: Alexander Kuznetsov
column4: 56. “Kirill is not a thief. He is a decent and very talented person. Lots of thieves are in power. Look at the Duma deputies
column5: ” he said
column6: referring to lawmakers. “And yet they go after an innocent person.”

column1: AD
Platforma
column2: which staged modern theatrical
column3: dance and musical productions
column4: was an outlet for innovative young artists and directors and was popular among Moscow’s young crowd. It was also a platform for political satire lampooning Russian politicians. But the theater soon became a threat to authorities increasingly intolerant of dissent
column5: activism and liberalism.

column1: AD
“Youth always chooses freedom
column2: ” Serebrennikov told the court in his final remarks Monday. He said Platforma “gave artists and audiences a feeling that the ideals of freedom would sooner or later become the foundation of our lives in this country
column3: too.”

column1: Platforma accountants testified that they were ordered to embezzle the funds by the Platforma management. The prosecution said Monday the case against all defendants was proved.
AD
But one key prosecution claim — that a production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream
column2: ” one of the performances for which the grant money was provided
column3: never took place — was false
column4: the defense stated. The production won awards and toured abroad.

column1: Human Rights Watch
column2: PEN America’s Artists At Risk Connection and many international cultural and film organizations Thursday called on prosecutors to drop the charges and free the defendants. They argued that even if there were financial irregularities
column3: these could have been resolved without resort to criminal charges.

column1: AD
Serebrennikov admitted that Platforma’s accounts were sloppy but said he never involved himself in bookkeeping.
AD

“The state’s leap to criminal embezzlement charges seems to be a thinly veiled way to retaliate against Serebrennikov for his political criticism and to send a chilling message to other artists — who have no choice but to accept state funding to survive as artists — to refrain from political criticism
column2: ” the Human Rights Watch statement said. “The case is widely considered a specious attempt to punish him for his political candor and artistic nonconformism.”

column1: Under Putin
column2: Russian authorities have mounted increasing attacks on opposition figures
column3: activists
column4: journalists
column5: bloggers and artists
column6: arresting and jailing them
column7: leveling fraud charges and freezing their assets and those of family members.

column1: AD
Putin has made clear his disdain for liberal democracy
column2: telling the Financial Times in an interview last year that liberalism was “obsolete” and was being rejected by millions of people.

column2: when he was released on bail."/['Robyn Dixon'

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/magazine/2020/06/24/some-zoo-animals-are-doing-fine-without-visitors-many-are-lonely-without-us//How zoo animals are surviving the coronavirus pandemic/"Maybe this time will be different.
The blue crowned pigeon approaches his mate and begins davening
column2: twerking his tail toward the skylight of the Cape May County Zoo aviary as his beak dips toward earth. His intensity and focus during the mating ritual
column3: coupled with the wild tuile topping his head
column4: give him the look of an 18th-century composer banging away at what just might be a masterpiece. The recipient of this overture is completely still
column5: her eyes projecting a glazed endurance.

column1: When the dance is over — or perhaps in a move that ends the dance — the female pigeon turns and begins picking at the ground.
“We’d like them to breed
column2: but they just can’t get it right
column3: ” sighs Janeen Moore
column4: a zookeeper charged with caring for these birds
column5: as well as every other winged creature at this zoo. Like the other 20 full-time keepers
column6: she is wearing one of her many monogrammed Cape May County Zoo shirts
column7: unisex work pants and a face mask. Moore explains that the female pigeon had been at the zoo for nearly three years before her “genetically suitable” mate arrived for this arranged marriage. Though the male has been trying to impress her since 2016
column8: the female pigeon is simply
column10: “not feeling it.” The male’s efforts to woo also include repeated attempts to build a nest
column11: but when he summons his mate to inspect his efforts
column13: “She comes up and goes
column14: ‘That’s not good enough
column16: ” knocking the insufficiently arranged sticks out of the tree and onto the ground. Every egg the dysfunctional coupling has managed to produce was either unfertilized or cracked.

column1: After so many years
column2: it would seem childishly optimistic to think the pigeon couple might get it right during this particular mating season. But without the peeping eyes of the usual spectators
column3: now could be the perfect time.

column1: Like so much of the rest of the country
column2: the Cape May County Zoo closed in March to ensure the safety of the human public. But the closure keeps its animal inhabitants safe
column3: too: In April
column4: New York City’s Bronx Zoo found that eight of its big cats had contracted the coronavirus from an asymptomatic keeper
column5: and it’s assumed primates can also be infected because of their biological similarity to humans. The sudden absence of civilians puts into focus who is really served by zoos. The institutions ostensibly exist for the preservation of animals. But if we’re honest with ourselves
column6: conservation is often for and funded by human enjoyment of animal life; zoos
column7: after all
column8: are categorized by New Jersey law as “amusements.” During the pandemic
column10: zoos continue to run for the benefit of the amusers even as we forgo our own good time.

column1: Which means no annoying people crowding around enclosures. No kids yelling or cameras flashing or cellphones accidentally dropping into their homes. There have been news stories about penguins that got to take a hike in the woods near their exhibit in Oregon and cheetahs in Providence
column2: R.I.
column3: that were visited by a keeper in a tantalizing rabbit costume. In Hong Kong
column4: a pair of pandas that had been haplessly failing to mate for a decade managed to consummate their union after their zoo shut to the public in January. Nature is healing
column5: as the coronavirus-era meme says. Humans are the disease.

column1: If that’s true
column2: then a human-free environment is a respite for the animals of the Cape May Zoo — a blessed break from watching us watch them. Away from the strains and scrutiny of public life
column3: without people making everything worse
column4: maybe the blue crowned pigeons will get the chance to follow the lead of the pandas: It’s time to relax
column5: make a baby and finally finish that home improvement project.

column1: Peacocks and other birds are allowed to wander freely while the Cape May County Zoo is closed.
When I visited the 52-acre Cape May County Zoo in mid-May
column2: it had been locked to the public since March 16 at the order of New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy. The length of this shutdown bests the previous record-holding break by several months. Since then
column3: keepers who normally rotate between groups of the more than 600 animals there have been staying in one section to avoid cross-contamination and are working in isolation from other employees. While the zoo is a public facility that gets a budget from the county government to pay zookeeper salaries
column4: parks director Ed Runyon says the organization runs “almost entirely” on donations from visitors
column5: who pay no entrance fees. In spring
column6: the zoo typically takes in about a quarter of its annual donations
column7: which cover costs like the staggering $50
column8: 000 a month food bill. A month from now
column10: zoo director and head veterinarian Hubert “Doc” Paluch will enact his plan to reopen with limited visitors
column11: one-way foot traffic and
column13: masks. If the zoo didn’t resume visitation this summer
column14: it would lose the remaining 75 percent of its annual donations.

column1: Animal keeper Robin Kirwin with Azur
column2: a hyacinth macaw
column3: in May.

column1: For now
column2: the sudden disappearance of the humans who pay for meals is the biggest change for the animals. Which is just fine by the reptiles
column3: says general curator and supervising animal keeper Kevin Wilson: “They certainly don’t seem to be fazed by the quiet time. I think they like it.” Wilson says during “the very bad months” of summer
column4: “you’ve got a thousand people in this building
column5: ” gesturing around the now-quiet indoor reptile house
column6: covered in swamp-approximating murals and lit with the sallow flicker of heat lamps. “They’re all banging on the glass
column7: because the kids want the animals to react
column8: ” Wilson says. “And the more people bang on the glass
column9: the more the animals just hide in the back. And some of them do stress out. They don’t eat.”

column1: Unlike mammals
column2: who are temporarily raised by their parents
column3: reptiles are heuristic. “Out of the egg and on their own
column4: ” says Wilson. It’s not built into them to socialize with each other
column5: much less people. “Alligators
column6: crocodiles
column7: snakes
column8: everything like that
column11: an eight-foot American alligator whose eyes and nostrils are the only body parts that break the meniscus of his pond. Paddling runty claws tipped with white
column13: Ike silently drifts toward the voice of the man who feeds him but whom he feels nothing toward. “It’s not so much they want to be with you
column14: ” Wilson says. “You’re fulfilling a need.”

column1: “They certainly don’t seem to be fazed by the quiet time. I think they like it
column2: ” says general curator and supervising animal keeper Kevin Wilson.

column1: This exchange — you give me what I require to survive
column2: I let your buddies look at me — is what I assumed to be the basis of most human-zoo animal relationships. That if animals were the aristocracy of the zoo
column3: keepers were the staff that knew its place and the public was merely tolerated as the subjects funding the venture.

column1: But for some animals
column2: the attachment is more than transactional. Bird keeper Moore introduces me to Gil
column3: a gray cockatoo who became so distressed at his newfound solitude that he began self-harming
column4: plucking his chest feathers until he gnawed a hole in his skin that had to be covered with a vest the bird immediately ripped apart. (He was subsequently outfitted with a fetching pink polka-dot ruff that matched the peachy feathers at the back of his head.) “They love getting talked to all day
column5: ” Moore says
column6: turning her head upside down at a blue parrot named Brat. He is used to Moore’s face
column7: and
column8: like everyone else
column9: hates the masks protecting us; he repeatedly tries to remove Moore’s. “He just doesn’t think it belongs there
column10: ” she says. “You think you’re coming to the zoo to watch the animals. Well
column11: the animals are watching you
column12: too.” When I laugh at Moore’s words
column13: Brat’s mate
column14: Azur
column15: mimics my peal back at me.

column1: Like the parrots
column2: the zoo’s primates socialize with humans. So do otters and camels and
column3: unlike their reptile brethren
column4: tortoises
column5: which come over to keepers and excitedly play at their feet even when they know no food is forthcoming. They thrill at human contact.

column1: Keepers are filling in the new social gap: “[The animals] look forward to their company
column2: ” says Doc. But
column3: he tells me
column4: “They do miss the crowds and the variety of people coming through.” Watch the news or go on Twitter or attend a peaceful protest met with tear gas and rubber-coated bullets
column5: and you know the meme is true: Humans are almost always the disease. It feels like a miracle to find a place where our presence is a cure.

column1: After two months of the rapture-like scene at the zoo
column2: even animals generally apathetic to people seem to feel the loss. “I might have been a little surprised by certain species that may have missed the public more than I thought they would
column3: ” says Doc. (He clarifies that even after 31 years at the Cape May Zoo
column4: he is not an animal psychic: “I just look at what I can observe. I certainly can’t interpret what they’re thinking.”) “I was walking by the bison
column5: ” parks director Runyon says. “Usually they don’t care about anything. But they were all coming right over and just staring at us as we were walking by.” When I cross the bridge by the massive bison enclosure
column6: several steers
column7: mid-spring molt
column8: walk underneath and gaze up at me.

column1: Later
column2: the female half of a pair of lions comes up to the fence and pushes her haunch against the chain link for a scratch no one is allowed to give her. Based on what we saw from the cats at the Bronx Zoo
column3: if the lioness’s keeper had the coronavirus and the lioness got near enough to her keeper to catch it
column4: the most severe symptom she’d experience is a cough. Who is being served by these rules? “It’s the people that [the virus] is affecting
column5: ” says Doc. “It’s not affecting animals to any extent.”

column1: Gil
column2: a gray cockatoo
column3: at the zoo. He became so distressed at his newfound solitude that he began self-harming.

column1: When Michael Jackson lived at Neverland Ranch
column2: he owned a flamboyance of Chilean flamingos. (Yes
column3: “flamboyance” is the actual collective noun.) Though Doc insists the birds’ home at Neverland was much like the one at this zoo
column4: they shared the property with a Ferris wheel and a full-size amusement park chair swing ride. After Jackson moved out of Neverland following his 2005 child molestation trial and acquittal
column5: the flamingos went from being living lawn ornaments to residents of the Cape May County Zoo.

column1: Merlin
column2: a siamang gibbon
column3: hangs from his enclosure.

column1: When animals’ well-being is prioritized over their availability to be admired
column2: an object becomes the subject; a prop transforms into the protagonist. Though this shift in values has never been starker than during this pandemic — the lives of the animals at the Cape May County Zoo are given vastly more consideration than
column3: say
column4: workers at a meat plant — it’s part of a broader movement in the industry. Zoos like Cape May are increasingly oriented toward welfare
column5: which Doc says has become a “buzzword” in the past decade. Enclosures have become larger and more naturalistic
column6: and animals have more places to secret themselves away from our gaze. They are no longer trained to perform for our enjoyment
column7: but to sit for necessary medical treatment they used to be sedated or restrained to endure. Even if an animal is owned by Cape May County
column8: accrediting organization the Association of Zoos & Aquariums might recommend it be sent to another facility for breeding to promote genetic diversity among an endangered species. “It’s a good thing everybody’s going more towards conservation and protect[ion]
column10: ” event and program coordinator Jean Whalen says. “But it’s getting out of the entertainment business. That’s making it harder.”

column1: A zoo’s mission is to use the human draw toward charismatic megafauna to protect those creatures. Without that trade
column2: zoos don’t exist. Which means they have to figure out how close we can safely get
column3: whether it’s to prevent tigers from getting the coronavirus or to allow them to live as organic and fulfilling a life as one can behind a fence. (Doc admits: “There’s nothing like seeing animals in the wild. You can see them in the zoo
column4: which brings in the educational part of it and the conservation part of it. But just to be able to see them in the wild is extremely exciting. You know that they’re still out there.”)

column1: “You think you’re coming to the zoo to watch the animals. Well
column2: the animals are watching you
column3: too
column4: ” says zookeeper Janeen Moore.

column1: Distance protects humans
column2: too — definitely from getting mauled
column3: but also from the pain of attachment to what never really belonged to us. When I ask why the name of Mr. Bojangles the bobcat is not printed on the information card about his species in front of his enclosure
column4: Whalen says
column5: “The [keepers] don’t really like the public to know their names
column6: because it just gets messy if something happens to that animal
column7: and the [public] keeps expecting it to be that [same] animal. We have to explain how it went back to Kansas because it didn’t belong to us. And we had two [snow leopard] babies that passed. They were healthy
column8: and then a parasite from being outside went to their brain. It was so sad. So it’s tricky: How much do you share with the public? Because they hurt

column1: One of the last enclosures before the zoo’s exit is the primate habitat. A bonded pair of siamang gibbons come outside to inspect the unfamiliar person standing next to their keeper Megan Draper. It’s been a long time since they’ve seen a stranger
column2: and the muscular duo swing across branches
column3: patrolling their territory. After a few minutes
column4: Merlin
column5: the male
column6: stills and begins the ritual he shares with his mate
column7: Leela
column8: every morning around 10:30. The flaccid pouch at his neck tumesces with song
column9: sharp little honks that sound like didgeridoo notes. At first the performance is a solo. Then Leela starts to harmonize
column10: and the second voice throbs against the first. The music is loud enough to make my chest vibrate
column11: letting everyone in earshot know that Merlin and Leela are together and we are in their space.

column1: The gibbons hang on the net
column2: their bodies overlapping. Against the brightness of the sky
column3: it’s impossible to tell where her dark body stops and his starts. They are one in silhouette
column4: extra limbs fanning out like Shiva as they bellow their duet to their audience. And what’s the point of a song if there’s no one to hear it?

column1: Anna Peele is a writer in New York.

Designed by Twila Waddy. Photo editing by Dudley M. Brooks"/['Anna Peele']/2020-06-24 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/resizer/RMXmoGkU1ndU6JM-MnXgkNnvPhA=/1484x0/arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/NKAX44BCNBD73I77KFNLJW5734.jpg"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/food/order-from-these-three-restaurants-and-watch-vegetables-steal-the-show/2020/06/25/ff1c6d28-b3cc-11ea-a8da-693df3d7674a_story.html/Vegetables steal the show at these three D.C.-area restaurants/"Diners looking to restaurants for self-care would be wise to find time for takeout from the following trio
column2: all of which promise a garden of good eating.

column1: Good thing Amber Spice in Laurel has two chefs. When one of them
column2: Saravan “Sam” Krishnan
column3: couldn’t make it home from a trip to his native south India in March
column4: his brother
column5: Venkatesan
column6: or “John
column7: ” devoted himself to the kitchen full time. It further helps that the two got their start together
column8: as waiters at the vegetarian Udupi Palace in Takoma Park
column9: and previously cooked side by side at the departed Curry Leaf

column1: Their time at Udupi Palace taught them you could fill a place without the aid of meat. Much as I like the Goan shrimp curry and sizzling lamb kebabs at Amber Spice
column2: I’m perfectly content feasting solely on vegetables.

column1: Arranging the takeout for a group portrait on my kitchen counter not long ago
column2: I was struck by the beauty of the spread. The forest-green spinach kofta next to the dusky gold aloo gobi alongside the shocking red paneer chili begged for a frame. Better still
column3: the vibrant buffet delivered on the palate. Finely chopped carrots
column4: peas
column5: potatoes and beans lend their charms to the kofta
column6: balls cloaked in a spinach-cream puree. Cauliflower
column7: potatoes and onions are gently steamed so that the aloo gobi
column8: colored with turmeric
column9: holds its shape and texture. The cubed paneer and sauteed bell peppers
column11: come with a one-two punch from vinegar and roasted chiles.

column1: AD
AD
You may think you don’t like okra. But naysayers become converts when they taste okra as it’s coddled here: cubed
column2: seasoned with mustard seeds
column3: cumin seeds and half a dozen other jazz notes
column4: and fried to a tender crunch. “Like we cook in our house
column5: ” says Venkatesan Krishnan of his light touch with oil.

column1: Then there’s egg curry
column2: saucy with coconut milk
column3: tomatoes and onions and served with flaky paratha. The bread gets more delicious as it soaks up the broth
column4: lit with ginger
column5: chile powder and curry leaves and as close as I see myself getting to Kerala for the foreseeable future.

column1: Krishnan says the brothers
column2: who co-own Amber Spice with longtime friend Moses Krishnarajan
column3: decided against naming their restaurant after a person or a village. They opted to sum up the place with a well-used ingredient. Manjal might have confused someone who wasn’t south Indian. Turmeric
column4: its English translation
column5: was already taken. Amber
column6: the trio ultimately concluded
column7: was a color diners would catch in most every bite of their radiant food.

column1: 13524 Baltimore Ave.
column2: Laurel
column3: Md. 301-477-4828. amberspicemd.com. Open for takeout 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. and 5 to 9:30 p.m. Wednesday through Sunday. Delivery via DoorDash and Uber Eats. Entrees

column1: AD
AD
Since the pandemic disrupted their business model
column2: the owners at Aracosia in McLean have discovered that
column3: much like for UPS
column4: people love their packages. As in family dinners
column5: a three-course menu including a bottle of wine
column6: and vegetarian/vegan samplers. “You get to taste a bunch of things
column7: ” says Omar Masroor of the Afghan restaurant’s sampler packs. Hopefully
column8: he says
column10: into the dining room” for a favorite dish.

column1: I’m smitten with the vegetarian deal: a choice of appetizer
column2: entree
column3: side dish and dessert for $24 a person. While the online menu calls for a four-person minimum
column4: that’s a request rather than a demand; without revealing my identity
column5: I was able to order the deal for two. And had I been able to pick up the meal before 4 p.m.
column6: the cost would have been $5 less. That includes the aushak: floppy dumplings green with leeks and scallions inside and decked out with a blanket of carrots and peas
column7: a drizzle of garlic yogurt and dustings of cayenne and dried mint. It’s my preferred starter
column8: although the crisp turnovers with diced portobellos come close.

column1: As for main courses
column2: a bevy of greens — spinach
column3: collards and kale simply seasoned with fenugreek and turmeric — go into the rib-sticking sabzi lawaan
column4: spooned over fragrant basmati rice. And seemingly a bushel of beans — chickpeas
column5: black beans
column6: kidney beans — top a carton of dumplings sweetened with pumpkin. (Ask for kadu tosh peyra.) When I request a side of eggplant
column7: the voice on the other end of the line responds with a verbal high five. My tongue has the same reaction when the vegetable
column8: soft from roasting and set in a light tomato stew

column1: AD
AD
Flavor is achieved without a speck of butter. “No cream
column2: no milk
column3: no cheese
column4: ” either
column5: says Masroor
column6: whose business partner is his wife
column7: chef Sofia. Yogurt
column8: on the other hand
column9: is as everywhere as athleisure. “I don’t think we can live without yogurt
column10: ” the restaurateur says of his compatriots. As in the dining room
column11: the accompanying flatbread comes with four dips. I’m partial to the sting of vinegar and herbs in one
column12: the cool of avocado and yogurt in another. Firni
column13: a custard infused with cardamom and garnished with pistachios
column14: is Afghan bliss

column1: News flash: The owners are conducting an experiment in Washington at their Afghan restaurant in the Palisades. They are in the process of turning their back dining room into Aracosia Market
column2: a mini-bazaar showcasing spices
column3: sweets
column4: tea and more from Central Asia
column5: North Africa
column6: India and elsewhere. Look for the door to open in (knock on wood) September.

column1: 1381 Beverly Rd.
column2: McLean
column3: Va. 703-269-3820. aracosiamclean.com. Open for takeout noon to 9 p.m. daily. Delivery via Door Dash
column4: GrubHub
column5: Seamless
column6: Uber Eats and the restaurant (free within a three-mile radius with a minimum order of $50). A la carte entrees

column1: The signature draw at Shouk may be the most labor-intensive burger in the city.
AD
AD
“Every single ingredient is prepared separately
column2: ” says Dennis Friedman
column3: chef and co-founder of the Middle Eastern fast-casual restaurant. No fewer than 15 vegetables and legumes — cauliflower
column4: black beans
column5: beets
column6: mushrooms
column7: etc. — go into the Shouk burger
column8: which is held together with pureed flaxseed and slipped into tender whole-wheat pita the size of an oven mitt. Far from being a kitchen sink
column9: the mouthful would be less without the support of each element. And the accessories are as considered as the centerpiece. Charred onions add welcome smokiness. Pickled turnips lend tang. A downy layer of peppery arugula gives the sandwich height and hue. The construction is thoughtful
column10: beautiful and as rewarding as any of the beefy alternatives around town.

column1: I’m not surprised when Friedman tells me the K Street original sometimes sells more than 200 Shouk burgers a day. Or that the vast majority of the eatery’s customers aren’t vegetarian. Good taste is the driving force behind the plant-based menu. The kitchen also makes an eggplant burger
column2: based on the Israeli dish sabich
column3: and I like it almost as much as the bestseller. Like the Shouk burger
column4: the sliced eggplant is soft in parts
column5: crusty in others. Unlike the burger
column6: the fried eggplant comes with bun mates of magenta cabbage and sheer potato slices.

column1: As detailed as the Shouk burger sounds
column2: Friedman says he put more time into his chickpea fritters. “Everybody knows falafel
column3: ” says the chef
column4: who launched the kosher business four years ago with Ran Nussbacher
column5: a native of Israel with a background in technology. The brown spheres are green with parsley and cilantro in their centers
column6: fluffy thanks to sparkling water in the mix. My preferred way to enjoy the wonderful falafel is atop a bowl of hummus
column7: whipped up fresh daily with chickpeas imported from the Middle East.

column1: AD
AD
Shouk is Hebrew for “market
column2: ” an image the owners hoped to capture in their restaurant
column3: designed with a walk-in cooler that gets replenished every two days and an open kitchen for transparency. Before the pandemic
column4: orders were called out
column5: to create a little buzz in the place. A larger sibling is located at 395 Morse St. NE
column6: near Union Market.

column1: You don’t have to live close to either branch to enjoy Shouk
column2: which rolled out its own delivery service
column3: Hood Drop
column4: to neighborhoods across the region in mid-March
column5: partly to feed fans whose jobs used to put them downtown. More vegetables for everyone!

column1: 655 K St. NW. 202-945-4747. shouk.com. Open for takeout 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily. Delivery via Caviar
column2: DoorDash
column3: Postmates
column4: Uber Eats and the restaurant’s Hood Drop (weekly schedule published online). Salads and sandwiches

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/date-labdaters-say-they-dont-tolerate-racial-bias-their-actions-say-they-do-have-racial-preferences/2020/06/18/0d1eace4-a039-11ea-9590-1858a893bd59_story.html/Date Lab: Daters say they don’t tolerate racial bias. Their actions say they do have racial preferences./"Like so many prior actions that Americans are now reevaluating about race
column2: dating preference has to be put under the microscope. Racial bias is insidious
column3: only surfacing when someone challenges a societal norm or a personal choice. My industry has allowed daters who claim to be friendly advocates of black people to hide racial bias under the guise of dating preferences for far too long.

column1: In my very first session with clients
column2: as they begin the process of identifying their ideal mate
column3: we always discuss racial preferences. It’s usually easy to convince them that inner qualities matter more for long-term compatibility than physical attributes such as height and weight
column4: yet if a racial preference comes up
column5: we have to dig in deeper.

column1: AD
AD
That’s when I bring out the Five Whys
column2: a business technique used to explore the cause-and-effect relationships underlying a particular problem. I begin with a question like “Why didn’t you check the box for black in your dating preferences?” The initial response is usually a surface-level reaction like
column3: “I’ve just never dated anyone black before
column4: ” to which I reply
column5: “Why?” Each answer leads to a deeper question that drives my clients into a challenging self-reflection. As we peel back the layers of the onion
column6: we often find unconscious bias at the core
column7: which has been shaped over time by family
column8: media imagery and personal experiences.

column1: In his 2014 book “Dataclysm
column2: ” Christian Rudder
column3: co-founder of the OkCupid dating app
column4: published data about its users’ hypocritical statements about racial bias. OkCupid bases users’ compatibility on their answers to wide-ranging questions on subjects such as lifestyle and current events. In the book Rudder says 84 percent of OkCupid users responded that they would not date someone who exhibited a strong racial bias
column5: yet based on OkCupid’s user data
column6: most of the people at the time were not responding to messages from users of a different race.

column1: As a writer for Date Lab
column2: I’ve seen instances of coded racial bias. The application does not ask for racial preferences
column3: but daters might say they have a thing for blondes or list celebrity crushes of only one race. The subtext is crystal clear.

column1: AD
AD
Francesca Hogi
column2: love coach and host of the “Dear Franny” podcast
column3: interprets code words like “all-American” to mean white and “exotic” to mean a person of color to Caucasian daters.

column1: Francesca
column2: who is black but coaches daters of all races
column3: has found that about 10 percent of her white clients state a racial preference
column4: compared with about 50 percent of her black clients. She told me: “For my black clients
column5: usually their preference is based on who they think will like them. They often don’t have the experience of being asked out by white men
column6: so they assume these men aren’t interested.”

column1: AD
Black women aren’t wrong about this perceived rejection. “Dataclysm” also revealed that black women received the fewest responses of any racial group.
AD

Francesca continued: “Some worry they’ll be fetishized by any nonblack men who are interested in them. Other times they feel strongly that it’s important to have a partner who knows what it’s like to be black
column2: and they don’t want to educate anyone about their experiences.”

column1: While I can understand the feeling of being burdened by having to explain our culture to a partner
column2: I believe learning from someone you love is the fastest way to bridge the divide between us.

column1: But what if you’re just not attracted to someone outside of your race? That’s hard to defend when you understand why we have attraction to certain races and aversion to others. Did you only have a model of a successful white couple in your household? Have you
column2: like most of us
column3: been limited to European standards of beauty in media and advertising? Are you simply terrified of saying the wrong thing at Thanksgiving dinner?

column1: AD
AD
Carmelia speaks for many love professionals like Francesca and me when she says
column2: “Eliminating an entire race of people truly limits one’s potential to date and find a life partner.” Furthermore
column3: I tell my clients that no choice in life is more important than who you choose to spend it with
column4: so if you really believe that black lives matter
column5: it’s time to put your dating choices in alignment with your values."/['Damona Hoffman']/2020-06-18 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/GE76KUVRPUI6VBLNKBKCSZZV4U.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/gene-weingarten-operation-warp-speed-trump-plan-for-a-coronavirus-vaccine-is-well-warped/2020/06/05/f4137468-9b84-11ea-a2b3-5c3f2d1586df_story.html/Gene Weingarten: ‘Operation Warp Speed’? Trump plan for a coronavirus vaccine is
column2: well
column3: warped./"Because I am sensitive to charges that the media nitpicks every utterance from this particular president — looking for “gotcha” mistakes — I decided to do precisely the opposite by lining up scientific support for his plan
column4: starting with its very name. So I got on the phone with Sean Carroll
column5: a renowned theoretical physicist at Cal Tech. Sean specializes in quantum mechanics
column6: gravity and cosmology. He is an internationally recognized expert on the Higgs boson
column7: an extremely important tiny thing that apparently only he understands. I don’t want to overstate Sean’s credentials for the purpose of inflating the gravitas of this column
column8: but he is basically Isaac Newton

column1: Me: So
column2: this warp speed thing! Going at warp speed — literally at
column3: or faster than
column4: the speed of light — how fast can the president bring this project in? Might it be done already?

column1: AD
AD
Sean: Warp speed is physically impossible. It is unfeasible based on absolutely everything we know about the laws of physics. I am 99.99 percent confident of that.
Me: Surely
column2: that can’t be true! The president said it! Also it was on “Star Trek”!

column1: Sean: As you accelerate incrementally to speeds closer to the speed of light
column2: it takes more and more energy until you would have to expend more than an infinite amount of energy. So.

column1: Me: So ...
Sean: That was just a rephrasing of the fact that you literally can’t do it.
To understand warp speed
column2: it’s helpful to understand the famed Karate Neck Chop
column3: a device used in early “Mission: Impossible” episodes and other low-budget 1960s-era TV shows. It is employed when the hero is being held at gunpoint by the bad guy. This is resolved when the hero delivers a karate chop to the back of the bad guy’s neck
column4: briefly knocking him out and thus facilitating an escape
column5: thereby resolving a plot problem without turning the hero into a murderer. For a book
column6: I once consulted a neurologist who assured me that this maneuver is impossible
column7: but if it were possible
column8: it would also cause death.

column1: AD
AD
Same background to warp speed. Though it has been twisted over the years to refer to the fastest possible speed
column2: the only valid way to define it is by its original meaning. It was a baseless theoretical contrivance used to solve plot problems in science fiction
column3: because if you couldn’t fly faster than the speed of light
column4: you could never get to another star system — the distances are too great
column5: meaning there would be no strange new worlds to visit
column6: aliens to see
column7: etc. “To boldly go where no man has gone before” is a better tag line than “You can’t get there from here.”

column1: Actually
column2: Sean told me there is one possibility for interplanetary travel by humans
column3: but he warned me it would sound far-fetched: “However
column4: ” he said
column5: “it is easier to imagine extending the human life span to thousands of years
column6: than that we might travel at the speed of light.”

column1: I had one last idea to save the president’s terminology
column2: and broached it: Wormholes!

column1: AD
AD
Sean: Ah
column2: wormholes. Well
column3: here’s the thing. As my colleague Kip Thorne once said
column4: if there were such a shortcut through space and time
column5: you’d be able to go back in time and kill your grandparents.

column1: Me: So?
Sean: So
column2: no.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/lifestyle/magazine/the-endless-call-for-racial-equity-and-justice-in-photos-and-quotes//Angela Davis
column2: James Baldwin and more put their faith in the future. The protesters following George Floyd’s death insist that the future is now./"Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: June 2. (Photo by André Chung) The Endless Call Demands for racial equity and justice have always been part of the American story. While the images here span the past two weeks
column5: the words paired with them span the past 100 years. Demands for racial equity and justice have always been part of the American story. While the images here span the past two weeks
column6: the words paired with them span the past 100 years. Turn music on Washington

column8: June 2. (Photo by André Chung) Warning: This graphic requires JavaScript. Please enable JavaScript for the best experience.

column1: Your browser does not support the audio element.
Ninety-nine years ago in Tulsa
column2: white mobs torched the black side of town and killed as many as 300 residents
column3: with the tacit support of some in law enforcement
column4: in one of the worst spasms of racial violence in American history. Last month in Minneapolis
column5: George Floyd died with a white police officer’s knee pressed to his neck
column6: just days ahead of the May 31-June 1 anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Those two episodes bookend nearly a century in which civil rights progress has been fitful
column7: hard-fought and unfinished. Across 10 decades
column8: from Tulsa to today — against a backdrop of lynching and cross burning
column9: more recently replaced by police chokeholds and vigilante gunshots
column10: amid the subtler violence of systemic racism — voices have been raised in protest and defiance.

column1: Words spoken in times of uplift or assault
column2: hope or despair
column3: can crystallize a moment or a movement: I have a dream. ... Black Power. ... I can’t breathe. ... Black Lives Matter. The voices collected here elaborate and extend the mantras
column4: such as Langston Hughes versifying his insistence that America live up to its myth
column5: and James Baldwin defining protest as a duty.

column1: But how many other voices have been lost? For a long time the Tulsa massacre was barely mentioned in history books. The account of eyewitness B.C. Franklin quoted here surfaced only in 2015. Today it’s harder for people and events to be ignored because another phrase from protests past — The whole world is watching — has literally come true
column2: thanks to the cameras in every potential witness’s pocket. The recent demonstrations were sparked by a bystander’s video of George Floyd’s death — and they have ended up generating more evidence of excessive force used by police against demonstrators in Washington
column3: Buffalo
column4: Philadelphia
column5: New York and Atlanta.

column1: The images presented here
column2: photographed in late May and early June
column3: capture the passion
column4: anger and hope of new voices demanding to be heard. The raised fists communicate as directly as the cardboard signs — hand-lettered with yet more indelible words — while the fleeting tears of a young demonstrator and the warm embrace of comrade marchers speak of the vulnerability and pain at the root of any protest.

column1: Washington
column2: D.C.
column3: June 2. (Photo by Kian Kelley-Chung
column4: son of André Chung
column5: who took the photo at top) Paris
column6: June 6. (Photo by Peter Turnley) Houston
column7: June 2. (Photo by Greg Noire)

column1: The juxtaposition of the historic voices and contemporary images underscores how much work is left to be done. Read in the context of today’s clamors for justice
column2: the decades-old diagnoses and laments sound remarkably — and wrenchingly — fresh and relevant. That those dreams remain unfulfilled speaks to an American futility and systemic failure. Seen in that light
column3: the images of today become part of the canon of timeless illustrations documenting the unfinished struggle.

column1: The killing of George Floyd offers yet another tragic opportunity to continue an erratic process of change begun long ago. No one can say if this time will be different. All we can know is that these voices echoing from the past put their faith in the future — and that these demonstrators insist that the future is now.

column2: May 28. (Photo by Joshua Lott for The Washington Post)

column1: For fully forty eight hours

column3: rich

column1: No
column2: I’m not an American. I’m one of the 22 million black people who are the victims of Americanism. One of the 22 million black people who are the victims of democracy
column3: nothing but disguised hypocrisy. So
column4: I’m not standing here speaking to you as an American
column5: or a patriot
column6: or a flag saluter
column7: or a flag waver — no
column8: not I. I’m speaking as a victim of this American system. And I see America through the eyes of the victim. I don’t see any American Dream; I see an American nightmare.

column1: Malcolm X
column2: from a speech in Cleveland

column1: Portland
column2: Ore.
column3: June 2. (Photo by Andrew Wallner)

column1: See
column2: it’s time for America to wake up and know that we’re not going to tolerate — we’re not begging anymore. And I’m not going to say it’s not any more of us going to die
column3: because I’m never sure when I leave home whether I’ll get back home or not. But if I fall while I’m in Kentucky
column4: I’ll fall five feet and four inches forward for freedom
column5: and I’m not backing off it. And nobody will have to cover the ground that I walk on as far as freedom is concerned because I know as well as you should know that no man is an island to himself
column6: and until I’m free in Mississippi
column7: you’re not free in no other place.

column1: Fannie Lou Hamer
column2: from a speech in Kentucky

column1: New York
column2: June 5. (Photo by Celeste Sloman)

column1: New York
column2: June 5. (Photos by Celeste Sloman)

column1: Let me speak of a recent
column2: a very recent black dream: The waiting for the Messiah
column3: some leader. Now nobody — Martin Luther King did not tell Rosa Parks to stay in her seat. That came first. Then he came. She just didn’t move. We didn’t used to have to wait for the word. And the history of black people in this country is those people who got up and moved
column4: all over this country.

column1: Toni Morrison
column2: from a speech in Portland
column3: Ore.

column1: Atlanta
column2: June 2. (Photo by Lynsey Weatherspoon)

column1: We imagined a more humane future
column2: but we also risked our very lives to defeat racism and U.S. military aggression against Southeast Asia. Now
column3: it is your turn to imagine a more humane future — a future of justice
column4: equality and peace. And if you wish to fulfill your dreams
column5: which remain the dreams of my generation as well
column6: you must also stand up and speak out against war
column7: against joblessness and against racism.

column1: Angela Davis
column2: from a commencement address to the Berkeley High School graduating class

column1: Brooklyn
column2: June 2. (Photo by Yunghi Kim/Contact Press Images)

column1: What happened in Los Angeles in April of 1992 was neither a race riot nor a class rebellion. Rather
column2: this monumental upheaval was a multiracial
column3: trans-class
column4: and largely male display of justified social rage. For all its ugly
column5: xenophobic resentment
column6: its air of adolescent carnival
column7: and its downright barbaric behavior
column8: it signified the sense of powerlessness in American society.

column1: Cornel West
column2: from “Race Matters
column3: ” on the reaction to the acquittal of white police officers in the beating of Rodney King

column1: New York
column2: June 1. (Photo by Jelani Rice)

column1: This is where we are right now. It’s a racial stalemate we’ve been stuck in for years. ... But I have asserted a firm conviction
column2: a conviction rooted in my faith in God and my faith in the American people
column3: that working together we can move beyond some of our old racial wounds and that
column4: in fact
column5: we have no choice — we have no choice if we are to continue on the path of a more perfect union.

column1: Barack Obama
column2: from a speech on race during the 2008 presidential campaign

column1: Washington

column3: June 3. (Photo by Evelyn Hockstein for The Washington Post)

column1: We know how to be racist. We know how to pretend to be not racist. Now let’s know how to be antiracist.
Ibram X. Kendi
column2: from “How to Be an Antiracist

column1: Minneapolis

column1: I came to this city in 1955
column2: which was the year that the body of Emmett Till was found in a body of water in Mississippi
column3: same year that Rosa Parks refused to give up the back seat on the bus. ... Since that time
column4: I have seen any number of struggles against racism
column5: and they have all ended up with relatively little outcome. So the question is valid
column6: it’s a reasonable question: Is this going to be just like so many other movements
column7: a moment of anger and rage and then back to business as usual? ... [But] his death did not simply start a bunch of good speeches
column8: a bunch of tributes. Out of his death has come a movement
column9: a worldwide movement. And that movement is not going to stop after two weeks
column11: a month. That movement is going to change the world.
