column5: June 9
column6: 2020"/['David Montgomery']//"https://www.washingtonpost.com/resizer/cPJsAPTd0uJ9xXVS-ppmvgqPgzE=/arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost/L6LP6XM37VC4FII43XLGVISFDI.jpg"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/the-stars-and-stripes-newspaper-has-long-supported-the-troops-now-it-needs-congresss-support/2020/06/18/10046b92-8982-11ea-8ac1-bfb250876b7a_story.html/The Stars and Stripes newspaper has long supported the troops. Now it needs Congress’s support./"Stars and Stripes has been chronicling the military angle of the covid-19 crisis for months now: sailors infected on Navy ships
column2: face masks purchased for the Department of Defense workforce
column3: stimulus checks cut for veterans. But in the midst of the pandemic
column4: the newspaper faces an unprecedented threat all its own: In February
column5: the Trump administration proposed eliminating all of the publication’s federal support in 2021. That’s more than $15 million a year
column6: about half its budget. “I can’t think of a graver threat to its independence
column7: ” the paper’s ombudsman
column8: Ernie Gates
column9: told me recently. “That’s a fatal cut.”

column1: AD
AD
Defense Secretary Mark Esper justifies the cut by saying the publication’s money should be spent on “higher-priority issues
column2: ” including space and nuclear programs. But considering that Stars and Stripes represents a minuscule fraction of the department’s $705 billion budget — “decimal dust
column3: ” as editorial director Terry Leonard puts it — critics see the proposal as consistent with the president’s broader war on journalism. “It’s another obnoxious assault by the Trump administration on freedom of the press
column4: ” says Rep. Seth Moulton (D-Mass.)
column5: a Marine veteran and member of the House Armed Services Committee
column6: who blasts the defunding plan as “un-American.”

column1: Now Moulton’s committee — and ultimately the rest of Congress — must decide whether to support the appropriation by the fall
column2: preserving a news organization with a unique civic role. This deliberation comes as the coronavirus economic crisis exacerbates the news industry’s financial woes
column3: adding to what The Washington Post recently described as a “tsunami of layoffs
column4: cutbacks
column5: furloughs and closures” washing over American newsrooms.

column1: Stars and Stripes
column2: which dates back to the Civil War
column3: has published continuously since World War II. In 2010
column4: the paper won a prestigious George Polk Award for revealing the Defense Department’s use of a public relations firm that profiled reporters and steered them toward favorable coverage of the war in Afghanistan. In 2015
column5: the publication broke the news that NBC anchor Brian Williams had exaggerated a story about his reporting in Iraq. Much of the day-to-day coverage is news of direct concern to service members and their families: pay and benefits
column6: life on base and in the field
column7: the real people behind the global geopolitics.

column1: AD
AD
The paper is a modern multimedia operation with a website
column2: a social media presence and a couple of podcasts
column3: and the print edition reaches troops in parts of the world where Internet access is absent. “I remember being in al-Anbar and Haditha and picking up Stars and Stripes in the middle of a war zone
column4: ” says Rep. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.)
column5: one of Moulton’s committee colleagues and a fellow Marine veteran. “I didn’t have a cellphone. Access to the Internet was very limited. But with every mail delivery there came a Stars and Stripes
column6: and I was able to keep connected to the world.”

column1: “Stars and Stripes kept our spirits up and kept us informed at some of the most difficult times
column2: ” says Moulton
column3: who served four tours of duty in Iraq. “Just knowing they were out there doing their job — looking out for us by doggedly pursuing the truth — gave us more faith in our work and reinforced the values we were literally putting our lives on the line for.” The paper’s publisher
column4: Max Lederer
column5: told me
column6: “You can give a service member the best gun in the world
column7: but if his mind is elsewhere — if he’s worried about things at home — then he’s not going to be as good a soldier
column8: and part of our role is to provide that information to give him a sense of comfort.”

column1: Though the Trump administration is the first to propose defunding the paper
column2: there has always been a natural tension between Stars and Stripes and the Pentagon. The paper’s editorial staffers are Department of Defense employees
column3: but their charge is different from — and sometimes at odds with — that of the military’s public affairs team. Elaine McCusker
column4: the Pentagon’s acting comptroller
column5: told reporters in February
column6: “that newspaper is probably not the best way that we communicate any longer.” But that misrepresents what the paper is meant to communicate. “We’re not there to provide the command message
column7: ” Lederer told me. “We’re there to analyze the command message and to provide information necessary for the military community.”

column1: AD
AD
Another impediment to providing that information
column2: Lederer said
column3: is a Pentagon that restricts journalistic access more than under previous administrations. Fewer reporters are allowed to travel with military officials. Asking questions in informal “gaggles” is no longer routine
column4: and formal briefings were discontinued until Esper revived them. In general
column5: information is harder to come by
column6: inhibiting reporters from playing their watchdog role.

column1: But Stars and Stripes has always garnered strong bipartisan support from another Pentagon watchdog: Congress. And that looks likely to continue this year. “We have the numbers
column2: ” Gallego told me. “I think we have the votes.” Rep. Mac Thornberry of Texas
column3: the top Republican on the Armed Services Committee
column4: likewise opposes cutting the funding
column5: despite asserting that “Secretary Esper is right to look for efficiencies.”

column1: “This service cannot be duplicated in the private sector and should be maintained
column2: ” Thornberry said in a statement to The Post. “Ultimately
column3: ‘Stripes’ should be preserved
column4: but the business model will have to change so that the program can be maintained without taxing DOD resources.” But Thornberry concedes the fundamental point: “Stars and Stripes performs a useful function for men and women in uniform
column5: particularly those who are forward deployed with limited access to news.” As Gates puts it
column6: “Nobody else covers the Defense Department schools in Japan.”

column1: AD

AD"/['Graham Vyse']/2020-06-18 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/7LMND2FPGAI6VBLNKBKCSZZV4U.jpg&w=1440"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/you-cant-be-a-historian-of-black-america-without-being-hopeful-says-smithsonian-secretary-lonnie-bunch/2020/06/18/54f96ebe-a039-11ea-b5c9-570a91917d8d_story.html/‘You can’t be a historian of black America without being hopeful
column2: ’ says Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie Bunch/"There’s no doubt that this is a partisan time. But you can’t be a historian of black America without being hopeful. Because this is a group of people who
column3: in many ways
column4: believed in a country that didn’t believe in them. So for me
column5: there is always hope. There is always resilience. That also is what inspires me to always tell the unvarnished truth. And I would argue that in a partisan time what you need more than anything else is clarity based on scholarship
column6: understanding and trying to find reconciliation and truth.

column1: AD
AD
How are you thinking about ways the Smithsonian can be that glue in this time of isolation?
What I’ve realized is that the wonders of the Smithsonian need to get outside of the Smithsonian
column2: so sort of really taking advantage of our digital commitment. We’ve always had a digital commitment
column3: but it was always sort of secondary. So now everything is digital.

column1: The second piece that’s really crucial for us to recognize is that life will never return to exactly the way it once was. So we begin to think: What’s the new normal? What does it mean for cultural institutions if people aren’t going to come back in the same numbers? What does it mean if people are now more comfortable with the digital world? What does it mean for staff who are now more comfortable teleworking? There are fundamental issues about what the new normal means. And I think you don’t try to re-create the museum digitally. It’s a very different experience. I love the social interaction that people have when they stand in front of Harriet Tubman’s hymnal or when they’re standing in front of a dinosaur trying to explain that to a 10-year-old; I want to always make sure that’s there. But we have to now think about: Okay
column2: how do you create a different kind of interaction digitally?

column1: AD
AD
Do you think museums ever will cease to be physical entities?
No. It’s interesting
column2: when we started building the African American Museum
column3: that was a conversation we had
column4: right? Should this be all virtual? And we felt that at the Smithsonian
column5: most people come for the authentic. They want to see the ruby slippers or the Hope Diamond or the Greensboro lunch counter. So we felt that our job was to find the tension between technology and traditional. We want to find the balance between releasing things and saying
column6: Go at it
column7: versus giving people more guidance: Here’s how to look at this; here’s how to think about that. I think this is a horrible time. But it’s also a time that encourages us to think about things differently because the country will never be exactly the same.

column1: When you left the Chicago Historical Society to create the African American Museum
column2: you said you thought of it as a move from doing something for yourself versus for your ancestors. How then did you think about your move to head the Smithsonian system?

column1: AD
AD
Good question. [Laughs.] Building the African American Museum was something I did for my ancestors
column2: for my dad
column3: for my mother
column4: even for myself. But being able to help the whole Smithsonian was really my way to give back to the place I love the most. To the place that has shaped my career. It's where I met my wife. So it was more about: How can I give back to the place that transformed my life and gave me not just a career
column5: but a calling?

column1: Can you talk about a moment in your career when it felt like it was all coming together: You’re in the place you’re meant to be
column2: doing the work you’re meant to do?

column1: Well
column2: sure. There was a point when we were building the African American Museum
column3: still conceptualizing
column4: when I was able to hire other curators. And suddenly it was no longer just my idea. I remember being in a meeting where we were talking about what this museum could be
column5: what some of the stories were. There were scholars from around the country
column6: there were staff there. And suddenly I realized that this is going to work. It was going to work because all these people bought in and were now taking this hope of mine and making it real in ways I could never have imagined. I’ve never forgotten that moment of feeling that we could pull this off. The other one is when I was part of a small group that opened the California African American Museum in Los Angeles in time for the Olympic Games. I was doing the big exhibit on the history of blacks in the Olympics. I didn’t know a lot of what I was doing; I was making it up as I went along. And I was in a meeting where I called together Olympic athletes who participated from the ’60s into the ’80s. So there I am
column7: in front of all these amazing athletes — you know
column8: John Carlos
column10: all these people — and I’m trying to convince them to support this idea and that it was going to be great. They were kind of
column11: like
column12: “I don’t know. We’ve heard this before. Are we going to get paid for this?” And I was getting frustrated. And as I was getting frustrated
column13: apparently my New Jersey accent kept coming out. So John Carlos
column14: you know
column17: “Wait a minute. You sound like you’re from Jersey. Are you from Jersey?”

column1: AD
AD
Because he’s from Harlem
column2: right?

column1: That’s right. And he stood up
column2: and he said
column3: “This guy is from Jersey. You can trust him.” And they all came around after that. And so
column4: for me
column5: it was one of those moments of serendipity and luck. What if I hadn’t gotten tired? What if I didn’t have a Jersey accent? Those moments where things came together beyond my wildest dreams.

column1: What’s the most important advice you’ve gotten?
That the work you do shouldn't be about you. It should be about the greater good. It should help people understand themselves better. Also
column2: I'll never forget
column3: I was working on an exhibition and really wanted to understand slavery through the lens of a plantation. So I was in Georgetown
column4: South Carolina
column5: and [met] Princy Jenkins
column6: this quiet man in his 90s who had been the caretaker for a long time. He began to tell me what it was like for his ancestors. He gave me advice that was so important. He said
column7: ""If you're a historian
column8: your job is to help people understand not just what they want to remember
column9: but what they need to remember.""

column1: AD

AD"/['Kk Ottesen']/2020-06-18 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/I5W3LHVJZII6VFGS266EHMTL7E.jpg&w=1440"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/gene-weingarten-capturing-the-pandemic-and-protests-in-poetry/2020/06/18/b2f3eafe-a65f-11ea-b473-04905b1af82b_story.html/Gene Weingarten: Capturing the pandemic and protests in poetry/"I last looked at reader-submitted poems after 9/11 and wrote about them — their technical awfulness
column2: their cliched
column3: saccharine sentimentality — but ultimately about my lump-in-the-throat reaction to them. There is something deeply reassuring that when many people are moved or scared or grieving
column4: their intuitive impulse is not to shout or rant
column5: but to harness their feelings of compassion and hope in a form of expression older than Homer
column6: a form originally designed for timelessness
column7: to last through generations
column8: even among the illiterate. Poetry — which prompts you with rhymes — is far easier to memorize than prose
column9: so even illiterates could hear it and pass it along.

column1: I dipped into the Post mail again earlier this month.
AD
AD
Those readers who attempted rhyme were stymied by their own tin ears (no
column2: “coughing” does not rhyme with “sobbing”) as well as the peculiar rhyme-defying lexicon of the day: pandemic
column3: hydroxychloroquine
column4: misery
column5: dictator
column6: social distancing
column7: etc. Those who went for blank verse seemed to think that anything
column8: however banal

column1: is automatically
a poem if it’s in lowercase and
the lines
have random
spacing and raggedy
ends.
And again
column2: every single one of these poems moved me. All were rejected
column3: but you can have this instead.

column1: We’re all wearing masks
column2: again and again

column1: We look just like a nation of holdup men.
The White House harbors a would-be dictator
He’s half ignoramus (the other half hater).
AD
Too many people have died or are dying
Words from our leader are bloated and lying.
Not even a president (nor a king nor a queen)
AD
Should ever be pimping hydroxychloroquine.
Where compassion is called for
column2: cruelties rule.

column1: We’re out of work
column2: our kids out of school.

column1: And then
column2: in the thrall of a heartless pandemic?

column1: More confirmation of a breakdown systemic.
Black people perishing — killed by police
Under the guise of protecting the peace.
One victim dies while taking a knee
An irony lost on no one but he
Who has found it convenient to further divide us
To rant and to sputter and not stand beside us.
And so in the midst of this countrywide misery
He just fans the flame on the Devil’s rotisserie.
AD
Which leads to mass rallies to show our disgust
Ignoring our safety
column2: to protest the unjust —

column1: We know in our hearts that the plague is still there.
And we say with our presence we no longer care.
We’re out in the thousands
column2: defying the brass.

column1: Defying the truncheons
column2: the bullets
column3: the gas.

column1: AD
Masks have come off
column2: and in our resistance-ing

column1: We shout in close quarters
column2: ignore social distancing.

column1: It’s reckless
column2: incautious
column3: unwise and un-smart

column1: And wonderful
column2: bracing and noble of heart.

column1: And maybe
column2: just maybe
column3: that’s at the core of this.

column1: Telling the bastards we won’t take any more of this.
Email Gene Weingarten at weingarten@washpost.com. Find chats and updates at washingtonpost.com/magazine.
AD

https://www.washingtonpost.com/transportation/2020/06/26/complaints-about-airline-service-have-skyrocketed-during-covid-19-pandemic//Complaints about airline service have skyrocketed during the covid-19 pandemic/"Or in many cases
column2: the inability of consumers to get refunds for trips they canceled because of the novel coronavirus.

column1: Of the nearly 20
column2: 000 complaints filed in April
column3: nearly 90 percent concerned refunds. By comparison
column4: consumers filed just over 1
column5: 200 complaints in April of last year. The vast majority of those were about flight problems
column6: including cancellations and delays. Only 98 concerned refunds.

column1: AD
AD
United recorded the highest number of complaints. American Airlines ranked second.
Airlines for America
column2: the airline trade group
column3: said: “U.S. airlines comply with all federal laws and regulations. Accordingly
column4: refunds are issued to passengers when flights are canceled by the airline. Throughout the pandemic
column5: U.S. airlines have updated travel policies to offer increased flexibility for customers
column6: and the Department of Transportation’s website offers clarity for consumers with questions.”

column1: The carriers’ reluctance to provide refunds has drawn particular outrage because airlines received more than $50 billion in bailout funds as part of the $2 trillion coronavirus relief package known as the Cares Act.
AD
Southwest
column2: United and Spirit airlines have all been sued by consumers outraged that carriers offered them vouchers or credits for future trips rather than cash.

column1: AD
The dramatic increase in complaints has also prompted warnings from the Transportation Department. In May
column2: the department issued a second enforcement notice reminding carriers of their obligations under consumer protection laws. Although the notice does not guarantee that travelers will receive refunds
column3: it offers them additional information about their rights — and reminds airlines that they could face consequences if they refuse to comply.

column1: In a statement that accompanied the notice
column2: officials said the department will be monitoring airlines’ refund practices and would issue letters or fines “as necessary.” Until then
column3: it would give airlines “an opportunity to come into compliance.”

column1: AD
In March
column2: as the issue was heating up
column3: a group of nine senators
column4: including Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.)
column5: wrote to airlines saying that the pandemic was putting an “enormous financial strain on millions of Americans
column6: ” and that carriers had “a moral responsibility to provide real refunds
column7: not travel vouchers” to consumers.

column1: AD
Based on information received from airlines
column2: the lawmakers estimated that carriers were potentially holding on to as much as $10 billion in consumer cash.

column1: Airlines have shifted some policies in response to consumer complaints
column2: but some travelers still report running into problems when they have asked for their money back. Airline executives said they are trying to accommodate consumers
column3: but are struggling to stay afloat in the midst of the worst downturn in industry history.

column1: AD

Friday’s report also showed how dramatically airlines have cut their operations. Airlines scheduled fewer than half the number of flights they did in March and ultimately ended up canceling 41 percent of the ones that were scheduled within a week of their scheduled departure. It was the highest number of cancellations on record
column2: exceeding the number canceled in September 2001
column3: the month of the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

column1: AD"/"['Lori Aratani'
column2: 'Reporter Focusing On Transportation Issues'
column3: 'Including Airports'
column4: 'Airlines'
column5: ""The Nation'S Railroad""
column6: 'Subway Systems']"/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/XQNBTRVXKUI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/milton-glaser-graphic-designer-who-put-the--in-new-york-dies-at-91/2020/06/27/1e609dbc-b828-11ea-aca5-ebb63d27e1ff_story.html/Milton Glaser
column2: graphic designer who put the ❤ in New York
column3: dies at 91/"In a career spanning six decades
column4: Mr. Glaser lent his talents to books
column5: periodicals and posters — the usual province of graphic designers — as well as to films
column6: restaurant interiors and public artworks.

column1: With editor Clay Felker
column2: he co-founded New York magazine in 1968 and went on to design hundreds of issues that “established the format for the now-ubiquitous city magazine
column3: ” said Michael Bierut
column4: a prominent New York graphic designer.

column1: AD
However
column2: Mr. Glaser’s renown rested foremost on the I ❤ NY motif
column3: which was adapted
column4: with slight modifications
column5: around the world. “People everywhere were anxious to say
column6: ‘I love something
column7: ” Mr. Glaser said in a 2019 interview for this obituary.

column1: AD
So popular was the formulation that it became a kind of logo for the Bronx-born Mr. Glaser himself. With a deep voice
column2: precise elocution and extraordinary powers of description
column3: he served as a de facto spokesman for his profession. He was the only graphic designer ever to receive the National Medal of Arts
column4: bestowed on him by President Barack Obama in 2010.

column1: “At a time when European designers
column2: especially in Switzerland
column3: were defining the terms of vanguard design
column4: Milton Glaser helped launch an alternative ethos rooted in American pop culture and counterculture
column5: ” said Ellen Lupton
column6: senior curator of contemporary design at the Cooper Hewitt
column7: Smithsonian Design Museum. “His more personal
column8: narrative and permissive design philosophy itself became a worldwide phenomenon.”

column1: AD
One of Mr. Glaser’s most important early commissions came in 1966
column2: when Columbia Records hired him to design a poster to be packaged with the “Bob Dylan’s Greatest Hits” LP. He created a silhouette of Dylan with a mane of twisted
column3: brightly colored locks. More than 6 million copies were printed
column4: making the poster a signature artifact of the “psychedelic era.” (Mr. Glaser later designed posters for such entertainers as Mick Jagger
column5: Aretha Franklin and Jerry Garcia.)

column1: AD
Mr. Glaser traced the origins of the Dylan design to a Marcel Duchamp self-portrait from the 1950s and the jewel-like colors of Islamic art.
He often drew on the past to create images that seemed to capture the present. For the 1993 Broadway run of Tony Kushner’s Pulitzer- and Tony-winning drama “Angels in America
column2: ” Mr. Glaser designed a poster inspired by Albrecht Dürer’s 16th-century watercolor “Wing of a European Roller.”

column1: AD

column2: the New York State Department of Commerce launched an ad campaign to attract tourists and
column3: not incidentally
column4: improve the morale of New Yorkers amid a crime wave and financial crisis that had New York City teetering on bankruptcy. Mr. Glaser was tasked with creating a logo to accompany the state’s new slogan: “I love New York.”

column1: He drew the original logo

column3: ” in the back of a taxi. That drawing
column4: in red crayon on a scrap of paper

“There was a sense of desperation
column2: despair

column1: AD

“It is one of those peculiarities of your own life where you don’t know the consequences of your own actions. Who in the world would have thought that this silly little bit of ephemera would become one of the most pervasive images of the 20th century?”
Mr. Glaser’s other seminal contribution to New York iconography was the magazine he founded with Felker
column2: who once called Mr. Glaser “a gigantic creative force.”

column1: His “densely packed layouts and illustrated ‘best-of’ listicles

column1: Among his other contributions to the magazine

column3: ” a column about affordable restaurants. The column and guidebook by the same name helped shift attention from haute cuisine to varied ethnic fare.

AD
Mr. Glaser designed restaurant logos and menus and even interiors
column2: including that of the Windows on the World restaurant atop the World Trade Center. He also reimagined the struggling Grand Union supermarket chain at the behest of its owner
column3: tycoon James Goldsmith. Mr. Glaser began by giving the chain a new logo: a bright red circle nestled in the letter A. He then tackled labels
column4: signs and the designs of the stores themselves
column5: placing giant pears in front of some. Mr. Glaser said the grocery-store makeover appealed to him because it was anti-elitist.

column1: The son of Jewish immigrants from Hungary who ran a dry cleaning business
column2: Milton Glaser was born June 26
column4: and was raised in a Bronx housing complex dubbed Little Moscow for its population of leftists. Some residents were labor and civil rights activists who championed racially integrated housing.

column1: He later told the Times that growing up amid that ferment was “like heaven” during the Great Depression. “You had this enormous commitment to the idea of human possibility
column2: that you didn’t have to just accept existing conditions
column3: you could change yourself and change society.”

AD
At 8

column3: ” he told Believer magazine
column4: “because I was never bored for a minute that whole year.”

column1: As the years passed
column2: young Milton became known for his ability to draw almost anything
column3: as well as for his entrepreneurial instincts; he sketched naked women for older boys for a nickel apiece.

column1: He studied at the High School of Music & Art in Manhattan
column2: for which he later designed a logo
column3: pro bono. With letters arranged on a musical staff
column4: it was
column5: he said

At the time
column2: graphic designers learned a modernist style that eschewed colorful flourishes. But a Fulbright scholarship
column3: after Mr. Glaser graduated in 1951
column4: took him to Italy

column3: he said

From 1954 to 1974

column4: he said

column3: ” he said

“Play ‘Scotland the Brave!’” shouted one dog walker.
Proper gigs are rare these days. In March
column2: the busiest month on the bagpiper’s calendar

column4: Saffron United
column5: stepped off at only one St. Patrick’s Day parade. Then

column2: Scotland
column3: where he planned to compete in August
column4: were called off
column5: too. And then the funerals. Because of New York’s social-distancing restrictions

column1: AD
Henderson
column2: who has played everywhere from Radio City Music Hall to Woodlawn Cemetery
column3: was left to idle
column4: tuning his pipes and timing his steps.

column1: “I thought I had a line on a gig to stand across the street from someone’s house
column2: ” he said

column1: Henderson first heard a call for bagpipers almost 20 years ago. In October 2001
column2: he listened to a radio newscaster assert there weren’t enough pipers in the city to play all of the police officer and firefighter funerals following the 9/11 attacks. Later that week

column1: AD
AD
“I heard children laughing rather than people weeping
column2: ” he said. “I could still hear them as I looked up the number to call to take lessons.”

column1: Henderson knew a few notes. His mother
column2: Dorothy
column3: a schoolteacher
column4: insisted he learn the piano as a boy in Iowa City. He read music on a white upright piano in their house and picked up the baritone horn in fifth grade.

column1: He played football as a high school freshman before transitioning to the marching band. While a student at the University of Illinois he played the baritone horn in the Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena
column2: Calif.
column3: when the Illini reached the Rose Bowl. He earned two engineering degrees but put down the horn upon graduating.

column1: “There aren’t a whole lot of marching band opportunities available outside of college
column2: ” he says. “It’s just a muscle that atrophies

column1: The pipes were his first musical endeavor since college. Practicing proved therapeutic as the city started its recovery.
AD
AD
At the end of each workday

column4: where he practiced in Friends Cemetery

column2: the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and Yankee Stadium

“I then dropped them like a hockey fight

column1: The first funeral he ever played was for a 13-month-old who died from leukemia. The most recent was his mother’s

column3: a decade after his father
column4: Bob

column1: Bob always joked about his wife’s tardiness

They discussed efforts to reopen the city in the wake of being ravaged by the coronavirus and roiled by unrest related to police brutality protests.

column2: postponed due to covid-19/"All three high-level runners
column3: like people across the country
column4: are now facing a much different scenario. Because of the covid-19 pandemic
column5: races across the country and world have been canceled or postponed. For elite athletes who often spend nearly a year with their eyes on one big prize
column6: this is a serious blow.

column1: In this new reality
column2: Kirkpatrick
column3: Serafini
column4: D’Amato and other elite runners must figure out a new path forward — with the mental-emotional part as significant as anything. Step one
column5: says Denver-based sports psychologist Justin Ross
column6: is allowing themselves to process the emotions that surround the loss of their “A” races.

column1: AD
AD
“You have to give yourself permission to be sad
column2: ” he says. “Any major loss connected to a personal goal will have a big emotional impact.”

column1: Justin Bosley
column2: a board-certified sports medicine physician in the San Francisco Bay area
column3: concurs. “Whenever I work with high-level athletes
column4: I remind them that when an unforeseen circumstance arises that forces a change in plans
column5: it’s okay to mourn
column6: ” he says. “You can’t move on until you process your emotions first.”

column1: D’Amato
column3: a real estate agent from Midlothian
column4: Va.
column5: is hoping she will have a chance to compete at her race at its new rescheduled date in October. Still
column6: she says that her knee-jerk reaction was to find another race near the original for which she could use her hard-earned fitness.

column1: AD
“I was excited for the opportunity and I was bummed when the situation changed
column2: ” she admits. “As I tried to find a replacement race
column3: all those were canceling as well.”

column1: AD
In 38-year-old Kirkpatrick’s case
column2: the vaunted Boston race had become a big goal after she ran a disappointing Olympic marathon trials race in February.

column1: “The trials were my ‘A’ race for a long time
column2: but then I headed into them rundown and anemic
column3: ” she says. “I missed key workouts and took awhile to bounce back. I handled myself surprisingly well during the trials and felt strong
column4: so I had confidence heading into Boston.”

column1: A path forward
Bosley recommends that once runners have a chance to process the loss of all racing prospects
column2: they choose the next best target. It “doesn’t have to be another race to be motivating
column3: ” he says. “It can be measuring progress on a favorite route
column4: for instance.”

column1: AD
This is something D’Amato has put into place. Recently she set a personal best in a solo effort 5K on the track. “I’m focusing on the daily and the weekly instead of a race
column2: ” she says.

column1: AD
Serafini
column3: the community manager at clothing brand Tracksmith who had been leading a training group preparing for Boston
column4: has already changed his outlook. “The message I’m trying to convey to my group is that right now
column5: running is one of the only constants in our lives
column6: ” he says. “We can use it as meditation. I’ve come to enjoy the fact that I don’t have to have the foot on the gas right now.”

column1: This approach is an emotionally healthy one
column2: Ross says. “This is an opportunity to recognize that running provides so many other benefits beyond achieving race goals
column3: ” he says. “It gives us freedom to explore the outdoors and connect back to the reasons it matters to us.”

column1: AD
Kirkpatrick
column2: who lives in Colorado with plenty of outdoor space around her
column3: is doing just that. “I have no foreseeable races
column4: so I’m just enjoying the beauty of Colorado and taking a break from structured training
column5: ” she says. “I love running
column6: so I don’t necessarily need a race to get me out the door. Racing is icing on the cake.”

column1: AD
Now is a good time to get more sleep
column2: focus on nutrition and foster a recovery mind-set
column3: too. “Athletes are very good at using the fight-or-flight mechanism for training and competition
column4: ” Bosley says. “But it’s important to cultivate a . . . rest and recovery cycle
column5: too.”

column1: This might look like a string of easy runs
column2: or one hard workout per week
column3: for the time being. “Go slow
column4: go fast
column5: do whatever feels good right now
column6: as long as it’s off a regimen
column7: ” Ross recommends. “It’s an opportunity to find that ‘flow state’ with running that’s not found when running for metrics.”

column1: AD
The danger comes when athletes ignore that right now is a stressful time for all
column2: and try to push through it with hard training. Stress is stress to the body — adding in hard training on top of that can lead to a drop in immunity.

column1: AD
Serafini
column2: for his part
column3: is going easier right now. “I want to maintain fitness but not go over the top
column4: ” he says.

column1: As summer progresses
column2: along with the possibility of races getting rescheduled sometime in the future
column3: Ross encourages athletes to take their temperature on enthusiasm.

column1: “Don’t race because you feel you must
column2: ” he says. “Race because you are excited and have renewed purpose after this break.”

column1: For now
column2: Kirkpatrick is considering signing up for December’s California International Marathon
column3: but she says she won’t get her hopes up as she had for Boston. Instead
column4: she’ll focus on a sure bet: The local “Firecracker 5k
column5: ” which will be an invitation-only
column6: 20-person elite field (10 men/10 women).

column1: AD
“They’re doing an individual time trials for each runner and film[ing] each person running the course
column2: ” she says. “On July 4
column3: they’ll release the video and announce the winners
column4: paying out prize money. It will be really fun.”"/['Amanda Loudin']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/7O7WF5DFQ4I6VLGKQDBCXPXJN4.jpg&w=1440"

column1: https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/risks-for-some-medications-rise-as-temperatures-climb/2020/06/25/0ba887e4-ae90-11ea-856d-5054296735e5_story.html/Risks for some medications rise as temperatures climb/"These include drugs widely used for many common conditions
column2: including blood pressure
column3: asthma
column4: depression and allergies
column5: among others. When the temperature rises
column6: they can impair the body’s ability to cope with heat.

column1: “Everyone who takes medications
column2: whether they are over-the-counter or prescription
column3: needs to consider that their medication can put them at risk once summer arrives
column4: ” says Aaron Bernstein
column5: a pediatrician and interim director of the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health’s Center for Climate
column6: Health and the Global Environment.

column1: AD
AD
“Heat waves are getting worse with climate change
column2: ” Bernstein says. “We need to be mindful when medications mix with heat. Too much heat can make an otherwise safe and effective drug dangerous.”

column1: Some medicines
column2: such as diuretics
column3: make our bodies lose water
column4: which can result in dehydration when it’s hot outside. Others — such as beta blockers or ACE inhibitors — lower blood pressure
column5: which makes fainting more likely in the heat. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors — commonly prescribed antidepressants like Prozac — can make us sweat more
column6: also causing dehydration.

column1: Still others — the OTC allergy drug Benadryl
column2: for example
column3: Cogentin
column4: a medication for Parkinson’s disease
column5: and Spiriva
column6: an asthma treatment — can reduce sweating
column7: the body’s natural cooling mechanism
column8: which can lead to overheating and heat stroke. Finally
column10: for example — can hamper the brain’s ability to regulate body temperature.

column1: AD
AD

Consumers can protect themselves by taking the same precautions as those recommended generally to prevent heat sickness. These include monitoring weather forecasts and — if you exercise outside — go out early in the morning or evening.
“If you have to be outside in the middle of the day
column2: try to stay in shade and drink fluids
column3: ” Bernstein says
column4: and seek medical help if you stop sweating or you begin to feel tired or sleepy
column5: signs of heat exhaustion or heat stroke.

column1: “For many people on medications
column2: working outside may not be a choice
column3: ” Bernstein says. “If you know you have to be outside
column4: make sure your doctor knows your job requires you to be outside. The dose may be adjusted based on that exposure
column5: either in terms of how much or when you take it.”

column1: AD
Be especially vigilant if you start a new medication in the summertime
column2: as the risk of heat reactions is higher and as the body is unaccustomed to a new drug and needs time to adjust
column3: Bernstein says. And — most important — don’t consider halting any of your medications when it turns hot. “If you are prescribed a medication
column4: it’s for good reason and don’t stop
column5: ” Bernstein says.

column1: AD
Normal body temperature is about 97.9 degrees Fahrenheit
column2: although there is a range. Some people consistently measure lower
column3: others a bit higher. But “when your body’s ability to get rid of heat fails
column4: your body temperature can go up very quickly
column5: often to 103 or higher
column6: ” which is dangerous
column7: Bernstein says.

column1: We keep our body temperatures constant by producing and losing heat
column2: an important balance.

column1: AD
“When the outdoor temperature is higher than the skin temperature
column2: the only heat loss mechanism available is evaporation
column3: or sweating
column4: ” says Ying Zhang
column5: senior lecturer at the University of Sydney’s School of Public Health. “Therefore
column6: any factors that hamper evaporation
column7: such as high humidity
column8: reduced cardiac output
column9: reduced air flow — or some drugs — can cause body temperature to rise
column10: which can culminate in life-threatening heatstroke.”

column1: AD
Few studies have examined the dangerous interaction between drugs and heat
column2: and experts say more are needed.

column1: “Due to the lack of research in the field
column2: it is impossible to estimate the scale of the problem
column3: ” Zhang says. “However
column4: it is for sure that climate change will bring more health problems due to medications. Older people will be especially vulnerable because they usually take more than one drug.”

column1: AD
Bernstein agrees on the need for more research.
“We would be able to do much more in terms of adjusting and advice if we spent a little more time and money figuring this out
column2: ” he says.

column1: Patients also should take care in storing their drugs because heat exposure could affect their efficacy
column2: Bernstein says. Many drug labels contain storage instructions
column3: although this won’t help those who need their drugs — asthma inhalers
column4: for example — with them at all times.

column1: AD
“I’d be surprised to learn of any medication that was completely stable when exposed to extreme heat
column2: but
column3: at the same time
column4: it’s not always clear how much of an effect heat has
column5: ” Bernstein says. “We don’t know nearly enough about how keeping a medication in a purse outside on a hot day may degrade the medication inside.”

column1: AD
As the world experiences more frequent and prolonged heat waves
column2: it’s also important for physicians and other health professionals to become more aware of the problem
column3: experts say.

column1: “Medical schools don’t teach doctors about these risks
column2: in part because the risks are new
column3: ” Bernstein says. “This is because climate change has brought unprecedented heat. People are experiencing heat unlike any in our history. In the past
column4: we didn’t have to worry about medications and heat in the summer. But now
column5: we do.”"/['Marlene Cimons']/2020-06-25 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/EJHCR3FXAQI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

The particle gives others their mass
column2: and when it was finally observed in the LHC in 2012
column3: it confirmed a prediction of the Standard Model of particle physics. The model helps physicists understand how matter works
column4: but until the Higgs boson was observed
column5: it hadn’t yet been verified.

column1: AD
AD
But though the Standard Model is the closest physics has come to explaining the nature of matter
column2: physicists still have unanswered questions — and want to generate more Higgs boson particles and study how they work. A massive electron-positron collider could be used to pump out many Higgs particles
column3: then study them to see whether they do what physicists predict.

column1: Eventually
column2: the tunnel would be repurposed to house an even more powerful proton collider than the LHC — a collider that generates so much energy it might produce new kinds of particles for physicists to study.

column1: Mid-century may seem far off
column2: but not if you consider how long it took to build the LHC. It took decades to plan the particle accelerator and 14 years of construction and testing before the machine was ready to run. It’s still being upgraded. The accelerator’s next run is scheduled for May 2021
column3: and when it goes back online it will generate many more particle collisions than the LHC.

AD"/['Erin Blakemore']/2020-06-26 00:00:00/"https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-apps/imrs.php?src=https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/EISYGSFW7YI6VGQ52PNRZPQHZY.jpg&w=1440"

https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/06/26/stimulus-dead-people//Why the IRS should not claw back $1.4 billion in stimulus checks sent to dead people/"“We hope this payment provides meaningful support for you at this time
column2: ” said the letter signed by President Trump.

column1: The Coronavirus Aid
column2: Relief
column3: and Economic Security (Cares) Act provides up to a $1
column4: 200 economic impact payment for individuals and up to $2
column5: 400 for taxpayers filing a joint return. But the distribution has been beset by glitches — including checks sent to dead people.

column1: AD
AD
The optics of sending stimulus payments to dead people didn’t look good for the administration. So
column2: in an offhand comment on April 17
column3: Trump said the payments should be returned. “Sometimes you send a check to somebody wrong
column4: ” Trump said in a coronavirus task force press briefing. “Sometimes people are listed
column5: they die
column6: and they get a check. That can happen. … We’ll get that back.”

column1: But nobody from the IRS communicated this directly to Moore.
(The Florida widower hasn’t received a stimulus payment anyway
column2: not for himself
column3: nor his wife — but that’s because of a whole other series of unrelated IRS glitches
column4: too numerous to recount here).

column1: For many surviving spouses
column2: adult children and estate administrators
column3: the confusing signals have created anxiety over what to do with the payments — and the prospect that the IRS could go after people who have already spent the stimulus money.

column1: AD
AD
Moore learned his wife wasn’t entitled to the payment only after he made half a dozen calls to the number listed in the letter bearing Trump’s signature
column2: a document the IRS is required to send under the Cares Act. Eventually
column3: Moore was able to reach a live IRS representative who told him he was only entitled to $1

column1: “It’s frustrating
column2: ” Moore said. “Unfortunately there is enough stress with the death of a spouse without the IRS adding more.”

column1: To make matters worse
column2: this misstep was entirely avoidable.
the GAO identified weaknesses in IRS processes that allowed payments to be made to deceased individuals. The watchdog agency recommended corrective actions
column3: which the IRS put in place. The agency is supposed to use death records to update taxpayers’ accounts to prevent improper payments.

column1: AD
AD
But in the rush to get out the stimulus payments
column2: this process was sidestepped.

column1: “Bypassing this control for the economic impact payments
column2: which has been in place for the past seven years
column3: substantially increased the risk of potentially making improper payments to decedents
column4: ” the GAO said in its report.

column1: In response
column2: the IRS said on its website Friday that it has taken action to prevent future payments to dead people.

column1: Gayle Griffith is administering the estate of a friend
column2: who died last November.

column1: Under the Cares Act
column2: estates aren’t eligible for a stimulus payment. Yet
column3: Griffith received a letter from the IRS dated May 15 indicating her friend
column4: Joan Duprey
column5: who had lived in Honolulu
column6: would receive a $1
column7: 200 stimulus payment by check or a debit card. But next to Duprey’s name were the letters “DECD
column8: ” indicating the IRS knew she was deceased. The promised funds haven’t arrived yet.

column1: AD
AD
Even with the federal deficit at an all-time high
column2: trying to chase down $1.4 billion — a tiny percentage of the $2.2 trillion stimulus package — is futile
column3: and unfair to the recipients
column4: given that the IRS has a system in place that should have largely avoided sending stimulus payments to dead people in the first place.

column1: On May 6
column2: the IRS issued guidance about ineligible payments. To find the information
column3: recipients had to know to go to the agency’s Economic Impact Payment Information Center page at irs.gov and navigate through the frequently asked questions. “Ineligible payment recipients who do not visit IRS’s website or do not have Internet access may not be aware of the process to return payments
column4: ” the GAO report said.

column1: The IRS doesn’t even have a plan to directly notify ineligible recipients on how to return payments
column2: the GAO said.

column1: AD
AD
“If they don’t provide a timely
column2: clear way for people to send the money back
column3: I don’t think that’s right to approach people to get it back
column4: ” said Griffith
column5: who says she’ll return the money if it ever appears. “Ethically
column6: I believe it should be given back. No question in my mind. But practically
column7: I don’t think they’ve created a situation where people can easily do that.”

column1: With the IRS still fielding a reduced staff because of the coronavirus pandemic
column2: their attempts to snatch back the stimulus money aren’t cost-effective. The IRS is already overwhelmed
column3: with the tax deadline delayed until July 15. Millions of paper returns with refunds due must be processed. Tax fraudsters trying to steal a lot more than $1
column4: 200 have to be pursued.

column1: The agency is still trying to send legitimate stimulus payments to eligible Americans.
AD
AD
“As of today
column2: I still haven’t received a relief check
column3: and I’m a non-filing Social Security recipient
column4: ” said Guy Walker from Hillsdale
column5: N.Y.

column1: Is the IRS really going to allocate resources to track down surviving spouses or heirs to recover stimulus money the recipients honestly didn’t know they couldn’t spend? After all
column2: the intent of the economic impact payments was to stimulate the economy."/['Michelle Singletary'

column1: CONCORD

Police are saying they cannot confirm that the incident on Saturday evening has any connection to the missing persons reported.

column1: “What happened on Saturday evening in California has nothing to do with the amount of people that have gone missing since then
column2: ” said Detective Ron Alvarez of the New Hampshire Missing Persons Bureau. “It was a missile that everyone saw on Saturday and that is that. It has been confirmed by the Federal Aviation Administration as a missile
column3: and people need to leave it just as that. In the meantime
column4: we are doing everything we can to find the people that are missing.”

column2: unknown creatures found dead in fields Western Maine. These theorists say that as quickly as these photos appear on Facebook

column1: BOSTON
column2: Massachusetts –

column1: New Englanders
column2: get ready. Although the snow and extremely cold temperatures have come quick this year

column3: with all of them expected to hit most of New England by the middle of next week. The storms
column4: dubbed “nor’easters” because of the direction they travel
column5: will bring over ten feet of wet
column6: packed snow between Tuesday and Thursday.

column1: “I don’t want to go on record and say this is unprecedented
column2: but it’s pretty close
column3: ” said NOAA weather researcher Mark Henry. “To get that much snow in such a small window of time is going to be hell for many people. Plus
column4: because of the type of snow
column5: we can expect massive and long-lasting power outages. It will be heavy and wet and packed
column6: and downed trees and power lines will be almost a guarantee. This is absolutely the worst storm I’ve ever seen brewing in over 35 years as a weather researcher.”

column1: Maine
column2: New Hampshire
column3: and Massachusetts are already calling for a state of emergency
column4: and plow crews from nearby states and Canada are already being prepared to help with the storm.

column1: “This is going to be the Big One
column2: ” said Henry. “Everyone get that bread and milk from the store – you’re going to need it.”

column4: and have their mom be your new mom! There are plenty of people out there who will accept you for who you are. It will probably be hard at first to tell your mother
column5: but if she can’t handle it
column6: then how is she going to handle when you find a mate? Get married? Adopt children? In my opinion
column7: your mother needs to grow the hell up and deal. It’s 2014 for crying out loud. How much longer are we going to have to deal with these conservative bigots? Listen
column8: you tell your mom that she’s going to have to accept you
column9: or you smack that bitch in the face. No two ways about it. Good luck!

column2: let me congratulate you on coming up with the worst damn pseudonym that I’ve ever seen. “Ugh?” Oh God

column5: but you could
column6: you know

column10: I think you’re going to have much

Who cares if your families can’t get along? Do they really have to have anything to do with each other? My husband hasn’t spoken to my side of the family since the wedding four years ago
column2: and he’s never been happier. In case you didn’t know this
column3: in-laws have never gotten along with their son or daughter’s significant other. Or you could play it the complete opposite way and try and get your parents divorced so you can hook up your father and mother-in-law. It could be one big
column4: happy family. It’s really your call. Either way
column5: people do stupid things when drunk. If your mother doesn’t know that
column6: she must be a complete and total stick in the ass…or mud. Whatever floats your boat.

NEW YORK CITY
column2: NY –

column1: President Trump was arrested by the NYC Police Department while exiting his former residence at Trump Tower on Sunday morning
column2: according to reports from the Associated Press.

column1: Police Chief Mario Brann said that his officers were acting on an open warrant from 1998
column2: when Trump allegedly struck a pedestrian while driving through the city
column3: and left the scene. The pedestrian
column4: whose name was not released
column5: later died of their injuries.

column1: “It is with great pleasure that I announce that we have taken President Donald Trump into custody for his role in the death of a young man in 1998
column2: ” said Chief Brann. “Mr. Trump is alleged to have killed the victim in a hit-and-run accident
column3: for which he had never been charged. That changes today.”

column1: Lawyers for President Trump say that the charges are “absolutely ridiculous” and “totally absurd.”
“There is no way that he was driving through the streets of New York and killed someone
column2: ” said Richard Moorehouse
column3: a private attorney retained by the president. “President Trump cannot drive. The guy can barely navigate a golf course in a golf cart
column4: you think he has ever learned to drive an actual car? He’s a total moron. Nobody would let him behind the wheel. If this accident occurred as they say
column5: then we attest that Mr. Trump had a driver at the time
column6: and he is not guilty of anything.”

column1: “I’ve heard of people pleading insanity
column2: but I’ve never heard of anyone pleading total idiocy to get out of a crime before
column3: ” said Chief Brann. “I am intrigued to see how this plays out. Either way
column4: this gives everyone a break from Trump’s stupid goddamn tweets for a few hours.”

column1: https://newspunch.com/police-face-backlash-for-installing-watch-towers-in-london-to-enforce-social-distancing//Police Face Backlash For Installing ‘Watch Towers’ In London To Enforce Social Distancing/"The police have reportedly installed “watch towers” on London’s Oxford Street to make sure people are adhering to social distancing rules.
Social media users have blasted the move comparing the ‘Orwellian’ police watch towers to something out of a ‘dystopian’ novel.
RT reports: Luke Johnson
column2: a British entrepreneur
column3: shared a picture of the new installations on Friday
column4: raising eyebrows among Brits who questioned whether it was an appropriate way to spend taxpayer money. Many denounced the new street features as a “stupid waste” of resources.

column1: This is the latest lockdown lunacy from govt: police patrol towers on Oxford St pavement – enforcing 2m distancing. Dystopian overreach and waste of taxpayer money. No wonder citizens have no respect for authorities. pic.twitter.com/yMNrsiYABw — Luke Johnson (@LukeJohnsonRCP) June 26
Many also pointed out that the “two-meter rule” is guidance
column2: not an actual law
column3: making the decision to have police monitor citizens’ behavior especially debatable.

column1: Others complained that the watchtowers were something more likely to be seen in an authoritarian state like North Korea.
The towers were also branded as “dystopian” and “Orwellian
column2: ” with one user dubbing them “Covid-1984” towers.

column1: The decision to install the watchpoints comes as London Mayor Sadiq Khan announced £110mn in police cuts
column2: which left one Twitter user wondering how authorities still had “enough money to turn London into a concentration camp.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2020-06-27 14:59:26+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Covid-1984-watch-police-towers-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/muellers-star-witness-george-nader-sentenced-prison-child-sex-crimes//Mueller’s Star Witness George Nader Sentenced to Prison for Child Sex Crimes/"George Nader
column2: a Lebanese American businessman who was a key witness in special counsel Robert Mueller’s report
column3: was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison on sickening child sex charges.

column1: George Nader pleaded guilty in January to bringing a 14-year-old boy from the Czech Republic to the U.S. 20 years ago to engage in sexual activity. He also acknowledged possessing child pornography.
On Friday
column2: a federal judge in Virginia sentenced Nader
column4: to 10 years in prison — the absolute minimum he could receive for his charges!

column1: Time report: Nader’s name appears more than 100 times in the Mueller report. It details Nader’s efforts to serve as liaison between Russians and members of President Donald Trump’s transition team.
In the 1990s
column2: Nader served as a broker to facilitate the release of American hostages held in the Middle East.

column1: The convictions carried a 10-year mandatory minimum. The judge could have imposed a longer term
column2: though prosecutors also recommended a 10-year sentence.

column1: Nader also agreed to pay $150
column2: 000 in restitution to the Czech boy he abused
column3: who is now an adult and testified at Friday’s sentencing hearing in U.S. District Court in Alexandria by phone.

column1: “George destroyed practically my entire life
column2: and I am trying to put it back together piece by piece
column3: ” he said through a translator.

column1: Nader’s interest in children and his status as a behind-the-scenes power player both extend back decades. And there’s at least some indication that the latter shielded him from the consequences of the former.
Almost 30 years ago
column2: Nader was caught by customs officials transporting two films
column3: hidden in candy tins
column4: of minor boys into the U.S. He received a six-month sentence
column5: a term that prosecutors in the current case acknowledge is “far below what would be expected of such a crime today.”

column1: Later
column3: Nader sentenced to a 1-year prison term in the Czech Republic after being convicted there on 10 counts of sexually abusing minors and sentenced to a one-year prison term in 2003.

column1: https://newspunch.com/bill-gates-lashes-out-america-rejecting-globalism-amid-coronavirus-pandemic//Bill Gates Lashes Out at America for Rejecting Globalism Amid Coronavirus Pandemic/"Bill Gates has lashed out at America for rejecting globalism amid the coronavirus crisis
column2: accusing the US government of “turning inward” by refusing to cooperate with the World Health Organization (WHO)
column3: the European Union and China during the pandemic.

column1: During a Forbes philanthropy summit
column2: Microsoft founder Gates bitterly attacked the Trump administration’s decisions in recent months
column3: claiming that by putting the American people first
column4: the US has created a “vacuum” in world leadership.

column1: Gates accused the administration of being more concerned with “trying to cast blame” for the spread of the virus.
The Microsoft co-founder added that he believes “rationality will reappear from someone” and the US will rejoin the globalist efforts of the WHO.
President Donald Trump recently withdrew US funding from the WHO over concerns about the UN health organization’s relationship with the ruling Communist Party of China.
Melinda Gates also spoke out in support of Bill’s global health work
column2: later adding that when a vaccine is available
column3: black Americans should be among the first to receive it.

column1: “One of the reasons we are so involved in this is that you don’t want the first vaccines to go to the highest-bidding countries
column2: ” Melinda explained.

column1: “There are 60 million healthcare workers [around the world].
“They deserve to get the vaccine first
column2: they’re the ones dealing with this on the front lines
column3: trying to keep us all safe.

column1: “And then you have to start to tier from there
column2: based on the countries and the populations.

column1: “Here in the United States
column2: it’s going to be black people who really should get it first and many indigenous people
column3: as well as people with underlying symptoms
column4: and then elderly people.”

column1: The couple was speaking on June 19 at the Forbes 400 Summit on Philanthropy that was held virtually for the first time because of the pandemic.
“Usually
column2: the United States plays a role in global problem-solving
column3: so rather than withdrawing from WHO
column4: they’d be involved
column5: collaborating with other countries
column6: not just trying to cast blame
column7: ” Bill told the summit.

column1: “It’s a tricky situation
column2: where the U.S. sort of turned inward on this one.

column1: ‘We’re trying to stitch different country efforts together."/['Baxter Dmitry']/2020-06-27 13:51:12+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Bill-Gates-2.jpg.optimal.jpg"

https://newspunch.com/biden-says-he-would-use-federal-power-to-force-americans-into-wearing-masks-in-public//Biden Says He Would Use Federal Power To Force Americans Into Wearing Masks In Public/"Joe Biden has said that he would use federal power to make Americans wear face masks in public.
The Presumptive Democratic nominee said on Thursday
column2: if elected president
column3: he would make the wearing of masks mandatory.

column1: “I would insist that everybody out in public be wearing that mask.” he said
The move would mark a significant intervention by the federal government and would also see considerable pushback from states.
Several sheriffs have said that making face masks compulsory is unconstitutional and unenforceable
column2: with one going as far as actually urging residents to defy a statewide mandate by Gov. Jay Inslee.

column1: Fox News reports: Biden made the comments in an interview with CBS affiliate KDKA
column2: in which he spoke about what he thinks should be done to reopen the country from the coronavirus shutdown. He said that he wants to see greater use of masks.

column1: “The one thing we do know
column2: these masks make a gigantic difference. I would insist that everybody in public be wearing that mask
column3: ” he said. “Anyone to reopen
column4: it would have to make sure that they walked into a business that had masks.”

column1: The interviewer asked if he would use “federal leverage” to mandate mask-wearing
“Yes
column2: I would from an executive standpoint
column3: yes I would
column4: ” he said
column5: to which the interviewer asked if he would then be mandating mask-wearing.

column1: “I would do everything possible to make it required the people had to wear masks in public
column2: ” Biden said.

column1: A number of states require mask-wearing in public when social-distancing is not possible
column2: while a number of others merely recommend Americans in their states wear masks.

column1: The Centers for Disease Control
column2: meanwhile
column3: recommends wearing “cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain
column4: such as grocery stores
column5: pharmacies
column6: and gas stations.”

column1: But mask-wearing has been hotly debated in many parts of the country and among lawmakers. Sen. Marco Rubio
column2: R-Fla.
column3: recently said that “everyone should just wear a damn mask.”

column1: But President Trump has not been seen in public wearing a mask
column2: and has dismissed suggestions he should wear one. He has also suggested they could be counterproductive.

column1: “They put their finger on the mask
column2: and they take them off
column3: and then they start touching their eyes and touching their nose and their mouth
column4: ” Trump told the Wall Street Journal last week. “And then they don’t know how they caught it?”

column1: Any federal mandate that people wear masks would likely stir significant opposition
column2: considering that state mandates have proved controversial."/['Niamh Harris']/2020-06-27 13:30:53+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Joe-Biden-4.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/pelosi-supports-bidens-push-for-federal-mask-mandate-calls-trump-cowardly-for-not-wearing-one/#comments/Pelosi Supports Biden’s Push For Federal Mask Mandate
column2: Calls Trump ‘Cowardly’ For Not Wearing One/"House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she agrees with presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden that wearing face masks in public should be mandated at federal level throughout the pandemic.

column1: During NPR’s “All Things Considered” on Friday
column2: Pelosi also called President Donald Trump “cowardly” for chosing not to wear a mask.

column1: Breitbart reports: When asked if she agrees with about Biden making masks mandatory
column2: Pelosi said
column3: “Absolutely. In fact
column4: the reason the CDC hasn’t made it mandatory is because they don’t want to embarrass the president
column5: or insult the president
column6: whatever it is
column7: offend the president. They said they recommend it they didn’t require it.”

column1: She continued
column2: “The president saying this is a hoax
column3: that it magically disappears and not wearing a mask himself as an example to the country
column4: how cowardly is that?”

column1: She added
column2: “I totally agree with Joe Biden. As long as we’re faced with this crisis
column3: masks should be mandatory. It’s not about protecting yourself it’s about protecting others.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2020-06-27 17:47:40+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Pelosi-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/muellers-star-witness-george-nader-sentenced-prison-child-sex-crimes/#comments/Mueller’s Star Witness George Nader Sentenced to Prison for Child Sex Crimes/"George Nader
column2: a Lebanese American businessman who was a key witness in special counsel Robert Mueller’s report
column3: was sentenced Friday to 10 years in prison on sickening child sex charges.

column1: George Nader pleaded guilty in January to bringing a 14-year-old boy from the Czech Republic to the U.S. 20 years ago to engage in sexual activity. He also acknowledged possessing child pornography.
On Friday
column2: a federal judge in Virginia sentenced Nader
column4: to 10 years in prison — the absolute minimum he could receive for his charges!

column1: Time report: Nader’s name appears more than 100 times in the Mueller report. It details Nader’s efforts to serve as liaison between Russians and members of President Donald Trump’s transition team.
In the 1990s
column2: Nader served as a broker to facilitate the release of American hostages held in the Middle East.

column1: The convictions carried a 10-year mandatory minimum. The judge could have imposed a longer term
column2: though prosecutors also recommended a 10-year sentence.

column1: Nader also agreed to pay $150
column2: 000 in restitution to the Czech boy he abused
column3: who is now an adult and testified at Friday’s sentencing hearing in U.S. District Court in Alexandria by phone.

column1: “George destroyed practically my entire life
column2: and I am trying to put it back together piece by piece
column3: ” he said through a translator.

column1: Nader’s interest in children and his status as a behind-the-scenes power player both extend back decades. And there’s at least some indication that the latter shielded him from the consequences of the former.
Almost 30 years ago
column2: Nader was caught by customs officials transporting two films
column3: hidden in candy tins
column4: of minor boys into the U.S. He received a six-month sentence
column5: a term that prosecutors in the current case acknowledge is “far below what would be expected of such a crime today.”

column1: Later
column3: Nader sentenced to a 1-year prison term in the Czech Republic after being convicted there on 10 counts of sexually abusing minors and sentenced to a one-year prison term in 2003.

column1: Prosecutors say the abused boys were largely child prostitutes. The 14-year-old boy brought to the U.S. also alleged he was victimized by Nader int he Czech case
column2: though Nader’s lawyers say he wasn’t convicted there. The two sides dispute the extent of abuse inflicted on the boy in the U.S. but Nader has admitted to one sex act.

column1: Nader “used his contacts and his wealth to accomplish” bringing the Czech boy into the U.S.
column2: prosecutor Jay Prabhu wrote."/['Baxter Dmitry']/2020-06-27 13:52:19+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Nader.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/bill-gates-warns-coronavirus-will-be-back-in-big-numbers-in-october-november//Bill Gates Warns Coronavirus Will ‘Be Back In Big Numbers’ In October & November/"Bill Gates is warning that the US is still very much at risk from the coronavirus.
He believes that due to many people refusing to wear face masks and not practicing social distancing
column2: that the country ise heading for another big round of infections in the fall when the temperatures start to cool.

column1: The Billionaire philanthropist added that he was disappointed that the US
column2: under President Trump
column3: had not taken a leadership role in preventing and ending the pandemic.

column1: Money Control reports: In an interview with CNN
column2: Bill Gates said the virus may be back in October and November in greater numbers in the US “if we don’t restrain our behavior more than it looks like we are right at the moment”

column1: Bill Gates predicts coronavirus will ""be back in big numbers"" in October and November ""if we don't restrain our behavior more than it looks like we are right at the moment."" #CNNTownHall https://t.co/GMAoOhJ5TO pic.twitter.com/CQqWtsi4pU — CNN International (@cnni) June 26

Though he was speaking specifically about the US but considering how countries globally have more or less followed a similar timeline to open the economies it may translate into the virus getting stronger and spreading further around October and November across the world.
In the interview
column2: Gates stresses on restraining behaviour or using masks and following social distancing better to arrest the spread further. He adds that quarantining COVID-19 positive cases and contact tracing is helping many countries control the virus.

column1: Gates has been working in the field of health and sanitation as part of his philanthropic efforts through the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
Notably
column2: a TED talk by Bill Gates in 2015 was much talked about after Coronavirus outbreak took shape after it first surfaced in China in December 2019.In the talk
column3: Bill Gates had said
column4: “If anything kills over 10 million people in the next few decades
column5: it’s most likely to be a highly infectious virus rather than a war. Not missiles
column6: but microbes. Now
column7: part of the reason for this is that we’ve invested a huge amount in nuclear deterrents. But we’ve actually invested very little in a system to stop an epidemic. We’re not ready for the next epidemic.”"/['Niamh Harris']/2020-06-27 09:05:26+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Bill-Gates-1-1200x630-cropped.jpg.optimal.jpg"

column1: https://newspunch.com/washington-state-sheriff-says-dont-be-sheep-urges-residents-to-defy-face-mask-order//Washington State Sheriff Says ‘Don’t Be Sheep’ Urges Residents To Defy Face Mask Order/"A Washington state sheriff has urged residents to defy a statewide mandate by Gov. Jay Inslee which requires people to wear face masks in public.
“Don’t be a sheep
column2: ” Lewis County Sheriff Rob Snaza told a cheering
column3: unmasked crowd adding that his deputies would NOT be enforcing the rder. it

column1: The New York Post reports: He said people should break the coronavirus safety order during a speech in a church parking lot Tuesday
column2: according to footage posted by a Daily Chronicle photographer.

column1: “In case you guys didn’t hear

column1: This week
column2: Palm Beach County in South Florida issued a countywide mask mandate. Facial coverings are now required in all businesses and government buildings
column3: while using public transportation
column4: and in public when social distancing is not possible. The emergency order noted that the county saw a “sharp increase” in positive COVID-19 cases in late May and June. The county has the highest number of COVID-19 cases in Florida after Broward and Miami-Dade.

column1: Palm Beach County commissioners unanimously passed the mandate on Tuesday
column2: with one commissioner saying the majority of calls and emails she received were in favor of it
column3: according to the Palm Beach Post. Still

column5: ” and dozens of local residents heatedly testified against mask-wearing during a more than three-hour public comment session.

column1: https://newspunch.com/president-trump-adam-schiff-arrested-treason//President Trump Says Adam Schiff Should Be Arrested For Treason/"President Trump has suggested Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) should face “arrest for treason” after he “illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement” that he read out in Congress in an attempt to frame the president.
For the second time in days
column2: President Trump has accused a Democratic member of Congress of treason
column3: escalating his attacks on those leading an impeachment inquiry against him based on a complaint lodged by a “whistleblower” with no first-hand knowledge of events.

column1: On Sunday
column2: Trump tweeted that Schiff should be “questioned at the highest level” for “treason.”

column1: Trump suggested in a tweet Monday that House Intelligence Committee Chair Adam Schiff (D-CA) should face “arrest for treason
column2: ” claiming Schiff “illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement.”

column1: Rep. Adam Schiff illegally made up a FAKE & terrible statement
column2: pretended it to be mine as the most important part of my call to the Ukrainian President
column3: and read it aloud to Congress and the American people. It bore NO relationship to what I said on the call. Arrest for Treason? — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 30

column1: President Trump was referring to Schiff’s “analysis” of Trump’s July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Schiff misrepresented the call as a gangster-like shakedown
column2: with Trump blatantly threatening the Ukrainian president.

column1: The U.S. Constitution defines treason as waging war on the U.S. or giving “aid and comfort” to American enemies. Punishment for the crime may include the death penalty.
During a House hearing Thursday
column2: Schiff tried to ramp up criticism of President Trump portraying him as a mob boss.

column1: “It reads like a classic organized crime shakedown
column2: ” Schiff said of Trump’s call. “Shorn of its rambling character and in not so many words
column3: this is the essence of what the president communicates.”

column1: He then parodied Trump’s call in wildly inaccurate terms.
“We’ve been very good to your country
column2: very good. No other country has done as much as we have
column3: but you know what? I don’t see much reciprocity here
column4: ” Schiff said
column5: supposedly “parodying” Trump’s demands to the Ukrainian leader. “I have a favor I want from you
column6: though
column7: and I’m gonna say this only seven times
column8: so you better listen good. I want you to make up dirt on my political opponent

column1: Schiff explained he was trying to make clear what the president “was trying to communicate with the president of Ukraine.”
“This is
column2: in some character
column3: what the president was trying to communicate with the president of Ukraine
column4: ” Schiff said. “It would be funny if it wasn’t such a graphic betrayal of the president’s oath of office.”

column1: Schiff’s remarks received coverage from Fox News."/['Baxter Dmitry']/2019-09-30 19:17:54+00:00/"https://cdn.newspunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Trump-arrest-schiff-for-treason.jpg.optimal.jpg"
